_Schools that permit extracurricular clubs to meet on school property cannot bar student prayer and worship groups from having the same access. _States may outlaw the religious use of peyote, an illegal drug, by members of the Native American Church. The ruling said state laws neutrally applied to all citizens are not invalid even if they adversely affect one group's religious beliefs. _The sale of religious items may be taxed by states just like any other merchandise sales.

_People charged with child abuse do not have an absolute right to at least one face-to-face confrontation in the courtroom with their young accusers. The ruling lets states use various means to protect some children from courtroom trauma. _Police making a lawful arrest at someone's home do not need a court warrant to search the entire home if they have a reasonable suspicion of danger. _Overnight guests have the same constitutional protection as their hosts against unwarranted police arrests. _Prosecutors may not introduce evidence that was unlawfully obtained by police to rebut the trial testimony of any defense witness other than the defendant. _Statements obtained in violation of a defendant's Sixth Amendment right to legal help may be used to rebut his trial testimony. The ruling extended decisions that allow such use of statements obtained in violation of the defendant's Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination. _Police videotapes of routine booking questions asked of suspected drunken drivers may be used as trial evidence even if the suspects were not given so-called Miranda warnings. _The requirement that police warn suspects of their right to remain silent and have a lawyer's help do not apply when jailhouse undercover agents try to trick suspects into making incriminating statements. _The justices, ruling in several cases, dramatically curtailed the right of defendants convicted in state courts to appeal in federal court.

_States may make the death penalty the only punishment possible for some convicted murderers by mandating it if at least one aggravating factor and no mitigating factor is found. The ruling upheld Pennsylvania's capital punishment law. _Judges may decide whether those convicted of capital murder are sentenced to death or life imprisonment. The ruling upheld Arizona's law. _Sentencing juries cannot ignore asserted mitigating factors even if they fail to agree unanimously that such factors are present. The ruling invalidated a key provision in North Carolina's law.

_The federal agency protecting the pensions of more than 30 million American workers has the authority to order employers to restore terminated pension plans. _States and private citizens may sue under federal antitrust law in efforts to break up business mergers. _Employers cannot assume that workers who cross a union picket line during a strike oppose the union as their collective bargaining representative. _Hospitals and nursing homes may sue state officials over reimbursement rates for providing Medicare services.

DOC.HEAD: Orthodox Patriarch Makes First-Ever Visit to US
DOC.TEXT: Dimitrios I, spiritual leader of 250 million Orthodox Christians, arrives today for the first visit to the United States of a Greek patriarch since his office was established more than 1,400 years ago. Before returning to his headquarters in Istanbul, Turkey, on July 29, he plans to visit seven cities and see representatives of 6 million Orthodox Christians in the United States and Canada. There also are Orthodox churches in Russia, Romania, Serbia, Bulgaria, Soviet Georgia, Cyprus, Czechoslovakia, Poland, Finland, Albania and Sinai as well as Greece. Archbishop Iakovos, head of the church in North and South America, told reporters last week that the patriarch will conduct a ``Liturgy for Peace'' at the Lincoln Memorial. ``His Holiness will address the importance the family in society,'' the archbishop said. ``He will challenge all of us to meet our obligations to the victims of today's times _ victims of drugs and alcoholism and of AIDS.'' Members of the church also emphasized his interest in environmental questions. Dimitrios, 75, is considered the 269th successor to St. Andrew the Apostle, believed to have founded the church in what was then called Byzantium in the year 36 A.D. In 1453 the city, by then called Constantinople, was conquered by Moslem Turks. They permitted te headquarters of the church to remain in the city, now Istanbul. Dimitrios is a Turkish citizen and he will be a luncheon guest of Turkey's ambassador in Washington on Tuesday. Traditionally, orthodox churchmen speak less about social and political issues than those of many other denominations. In 1973, a year after his enthronement, Dimitrios sent a message to the World Council of Churches recommending that it become more theological and less sociological. Archbishop Iakovos said the patriarch wants to cultivate the religious changes brought by political change in eastern Europe. He added that the patriarch seeks a meeting of orthodox leaders to discuss the transition from oppression to religious freedom. Dimitrios visited the Soviet Union in 1987 and had long talks with Patriarch Pimin, leader of the Russian church. Pimin died earlier this year. Archbishop Iakovos said he believed that representatives of the new Russian patriarch, Alexei, will come to a meeting. ``They will come because today we have a rekindled faith throughout the world and together with democracy comes religious freedom, one of the most important freedoms,'' he added. During his 10 days in Washington, Dimitrios will visit President Bush at the White House and meet leaders of Congress. On Wednesday he will deliver an Independence Day doxology at St. Sophia, the Orthodox Cathedral in Washington. The following week he will open the 30th Biennial Greek Orthodox Clergy-Laity Congress. After leaving Washington July 13 he visits New York, Chicago, San Francisco, Buffalo, N.Y., Boston, Mass., and Allentown and Johnstown in Pennsylvania, a state with a large Orthodox population.

DOC.HEAD: Deal on Ozone Reveals Old Tensions
DOC.TEXT: An agreement signed by 56 nations aimed at saving the earth's ozone layer was heralded as a landmark in international relations and a historic step in protecting the global environment. Countries set aside self-interest and reached across traditional divides to tackle a common threat. They agreed to ban a range of chemicals that are depleting the ozone layer and set up a $240 million international fund through which industrialized nations can help developing countries adopt environmentally safer technology. Friday's agreement substantially toughened the 1987 Montreal Protocol, a treaty signed by the 56 countries to protect the ozone layer. But the two-week conference, attended by 100 nations, also revealed traditional conflicts between rich and poor countries and environmentalists and business executives that have far-reaching implications. The conference was widely viewed as a prelude to talks on the far more complex and expensive issue of global warming. The conference ``set the tone not only for how we are to go about a climate change convention but also how difficult it is going to be,'' said Dr. Mostafa Tolba, the Egyptian who heads the U.N. Environment Program. ``We tried to strike a balance between what scientists say is going to happen if we don't save the ozone and what is politically and financially feasible,'' he said. At the conference at least a dozen countries, including most of the European Community, the Nordic countries, Australia, New Zealand and Canada, thought swifter action was feasible and necessary. These nations advocated a ban effective in 1997 on chemicals called chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) that erode the ozone layer, which shields the planet from harmful ultraviolet rays. The United States, Japan and the Soviet Union insisted on setting the target date for the year 2000. The United States argued that industry needs the additional time to test alternative chemicals before introducing them as replacements for chlorofluorocarbons. Environmentalists said the extra three years would mean 11 billion tons of additional CFCs pumped into the stratosphere. ``Industry defeated science, the environment and common sense,'' said Paul Hohnen, a Greenpeace spokesman. CFCs, used in refrigeration, insulation, cleaning solvents and as aerosol propellents, rise into the stratosphere where they break down in constituent chemical parts. One of these, chlorine, destroys the thin shield of ozone, which helps preserve the Earth's flora and protects humans from developing skin cancer. Another compromise was reached at the conference between developing nations and underdeveloped countries on the transfer of technology. Chemical company officials met with Indian Environment Minister Maneka Gandhi and agreed to make available technologies to produce CFC substitutes. Gandhi, speaking for developing nations, had demanded assurances that Third World countries would have access to advanced technologies. ``Very often in the Third World we have come across this problem,'' Ms. Gandhi said. ``They tell us we have no access to the technology, only the finished product. We become clients on a very large scale.'' India and China have flourishing chlorofluorocarbon plants, burgeoning populations and a growing demand for the chemical. The conference thus set up an ozone fund to coax such countries into signing the treaty by helping them build industries that do not rely on ozone-depleting chemicals. China and India will receive $40 million from the fund over the next three years after signing the protocol, which they have said they will do.

DOC.HEAD: Farmland Prices May be Leveling Out
DOC.TEXT: Farmland prices may be settling down after more than a decade of climbing to record levels and falling even faster, an Agriculture Department analyst says. The department's Economic Research Service announced in April that farmland prices rose nationally in 1989 for the third straight year. As of Jan. 1, the average was $693 per acre, up about 4 percent from $667 a year earlier. Another increase of 3 percent to 4 percent is expected in 1990, the agency forecast in June. Economist Roger Hexem noted that the high point for U.S. farmland prices _ which includes buildings as well as land _ was $823 per acre in 1982. That was followed by a 27 percent decline over the next five years to $599 per acre in 1987. The plummet in land values was a key part of the overall farm recession of the mid-1980s, which turned out to be the worst in 50 years. Many analysts believe farmers and investors learned a lot in the 1980s about the land market and how it can be affected by so many factors not tied directly to agriculture. But the general economic health of farming is still hugely important to the land market. And USDA estimates of annual farm income, interest rates and credit availability are part of the overall investment picture. ``In 1989, farmland values did not increase as much as some factors seem to indicate they might have,'' Hexem said in the July issue of Farmline magazine. ``The modest increase (of 4 percent), in a time of positive income and debt indicators, suggests that investors may have anticipated the 1989 conditions'' in 1988 and 1987 as land prices began climbing again, he said. As it turned out, last year's net farm income was at a record level, and farm real estate debt edged lower, continuing a six-year decline from its 1983 peak. ``Other factors that may have held farmland values down (in 1989) include uncertainties about changes in the capital gains tax, possible changes in income and price support programs in the new farm bill, movements in interest rates, and the outcome of the trade liberalization negotiations,'' Hexem said. Estimates of farmland values come from an annual survey of farmers and ranchers by the department's National Agricultural Statistics Service.

Cooperatives providing fuel to the nation's farmers have reduced production of leaded gasoline but not as rapidly as U.S. refineries in general, according to an Agriculture Department report. In 1988, according to the department's Agricultural Cooperative Service, co-ops produced 16.5 million barrels of leaded gasoline, down 30 percent from 1982, when the previous study by the agency was made. ``That decline was much smaller than the estimated 60 percent figure representing all U.S. refiners and reflects cooperatives' response to the continuing demand by farmer members for leaded gasoline to power older equipment,'' the report said. The use of leaded gasoline has been banned in new automobiles for some years as part of the nation's anti-pollution campaign. But farmers with older tractors say the unleaded fuel means more wear and tear on their machines. Overall, co-ops provided nearly 40 percent of the gasoline, diesel fuel and liquefied petroleum used by farmers in 1988, the report said. The fuel came from 2,300 regional and local farmer-owned cooperatives and had a total value of $4.4 billion. Cooperatives owned and operated five refineries with a total capacity of more than 197,000 barrels per calendar day. Most of their crude petroleum came from domestic sources, although the refineries received only 12 percent of their raw materials from co-op sources.

A four-day national conference about federal and state regulation of biotechnology will be held July 10-13 in Sacramento, Calif. The Agriculture Department said the meeting will include a workshop to help state regulators during the final two days of the conference, the second sponsored by the government. Last year's was held in Triangle Park, N.C. James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said this year's conference also will include speakers from Canada, Europe, Japan and Mexico. Representatives from USDA, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Food and Drug Administration will talk about the federal regulatory process for biotechnology, which include genetic modification of plants and animals so they can resist disease or be more productive. No registration fee will be required. Further details are available from Shirley Ingebritsen, UISDA, APHIS, BBEP, Room 847, Federal Building, 6505 Belcrest Road, Hyattsville, Md. 20782. Telephone 301 436-5874.

DOC.HEAD: Census Reaches 99 Percent of Homes
DOC.TEXT: The Census Bureau is closing in on the last 1 percent of American households that haven't yet been tallied. The 1990 count has reached 99 percent of all homes, officials proclaimed Sunday, despite a disappointing start in April. The door-to-door counting will continue at least through autumn in areas where the work is not complete, officials have said. In many regions a ``were you counted'' campaign is starting in an effort to reach people who have been overlooked so far. ``Without the willingness of hundreds of thousands of Americans who volunteered and stuck with a tough job, we would not be where we are now,'' Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said in a statement. With more than 100 million households across the nation, the 99 percent mark means that 1 million homes remain to be counted. Officials hope the new campaign will reach many of them through posters in stores and community centers, newspaper advertising and similar efforts. People will be encouraged to call or write the census bureau so they can be counted. The results of the census, taken every 10 years, are used to reapportion seats in the House of Representatives and to distribute billions of dollars in federal money over the next decade. With such high political and financial stakes, the effort has attracted close attention. Minority groups are concerned about being undercounted and cities have claimed that many of their people are missed, especially in hard to count inner-city areas. A group of large cities led by New York has sued in an effort to get the final totals adjusted to account for this assumed undercount. Census forms were mailed out to most Americans in March, but only 63 percent were returned because of delivery problems and apparent public confusion. Thus the door-to-door effort starting in April had to be increased, likely adding several million dollars to the $2.5 billion-plus cost. Officials said more than 80 million of the completed census forms have been processed at census offices. In the 1980 census that processing didn't begin until August. The bureau is required to report the population of each state to President Bush by Dec. 31, and Census Director Barbara Everitt Bryant said she is confident that deadline will be met. Nationwide, the Census Bureau said 100 percent of households have been counted in 27 states, while work remains to be done in 23 states and the District of Columbia. Those with the count still incomplete are: Arizona, 97.5 percent; California, 94.4 percent; Colorado, 99.7 percent; Connecticut, 96.3 percent; District of Columbia, 88.7 percent; Delaware, 94.3 percent; Georgia, 99.1 percent; Maryland, 94.4 percent. Also, Massachusetts, 97.4 percent; Michigan, 99.4 percent; New Jersey, 98.9 percent; New Mexico, 98.9 percent; New York, 89 percent; North Carolina, 98.3 percent; North Dakota, 99.5 percent. And Ohio, 99.8 percent; Pennsylvania, 98.1 percent; Rhode Island, 99.2 percent; South Carolina, 95.1 percent; South Dakota, 99.5 percent; Tennessee, 99 percent; Utah, 99.7 percent; Virginia, 99.6 percent; Wyoming, 99.7 percent. Major cities where the bureau says it has counted all the households are Austin, Texas; Chicago; Cleveland; Columbus, Ohio; Dallas; El Paso; Fort Worth; Houston; Indianapolis; Jacksonville, Fla.; Kansas City; Milwaukee; Minneapolis-St. Paul; New Orleans; Oklahoma City; San Antonio, Texas, and Seattle. Cities where the bureau said the count is still incomplete include Atlanta, 97.3 percent; Baltimore, 97 percent; Boston, 90.9 percent; Denver, 99.2 percent; Detroit, 98 percent; Los Angeles, 95.6 percent; Memphis, 96.4 percent; Nashville, 99.9 percent; New York, 83 percent; Philadelphia, 95.1 percent; Phoenix, 95 percent; San Diego, 99.9 percent; San Francisco, 90.7 percent; San Jose, Calif., 84.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Tax Issue Gives Gingrich His Ultimate Challenge
DOC.TEXT: For many Americans, President Bush's abandonment of his anti-tax pledge was a betrayal. For House Minority Whip Newt Gingrich, it's the ultimate challenge of his closely watched career. Gingrich, R-Ga., is the ideological leader of the Conservative Opportunity Society. He spent most of the 1980s engaged in rhetorical and parliamentary warfare against the Democrats. Last year he hit paydirt with his ethics committee charges that forced Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas, to resign from Congress. As Wright went down, Gingrich rocketed into the No. 2 position among the House Republicans. While maintaining his wonderfully hyperbolic rhetoric, he joined the establishment. He talks with Democrats about vacation schedules and even supported the controversial House pay raise passed last fall. Now, he's a Republican negotiator in the big budget talks. But Bush's tax flip might be too much for him to take. The Neutron, as his friends call him, is fighting a political meltdown. The tax issue is at the core of Gingrich's political being. His rhetorical package is anchored by attacks on the ``bureaucratic liberal welfare state'' fed by undeserved tax dollars. And George Bush is saying he needs a tax increase to get the budget talks moving and prevent cuts in needed government services? Gingrich wasn't invited to the meeting last Tuesday when Bush told the top congressional leaders he'd go along with a statement calling for ``tax revenue increases.'' Apparently, when Gingrich first heard about it he couldn't believe it. A heated argument over the telephone with White House Chief of Staff John Sununu ensued. Gingrich afterward tried feeding reporters the Sununu ruse that nothing had changed since Bush had started the budget talks with a pledge that ``everything was on the table.'' But his anger made it obvious that he didn't believe it himself. ``I'm just frankly enraged,'' he said. By day's end, he was telling reporters that Bush had ``thrown an interception.'' And by week's end, he was distancing himself from the White House. The president ``made a mistake on Tuesday and I think it has been a severe blow to the president's credibility and a significant blow to the Republican party,'' Gingrich said. ``I do not think he has to raise taxes. I'm willing to stay in the summit but I'll just say flatly that I think it is an error to give in to the Democratic party,'' he said. Gingrich says the Democrats forced Bush into reversing his pledge by refusing to negotiate, and says the president should have gone to the American people and told them that. But Gingrich also states the obvious truth, that the Democrats weren't going to pull out of the talks. They didn't even threaten it, and neither can he. There's too much at stake, and he's a part of the Republican leadership now, part of the establishment. What Gingrich can do is maneuver to make sure he and his supporters retain some influence in the budget talks. Gingrich's deputy, Rep. Robert Walker, R-Pa., reacted to Bush's statement last week by gathering the signatures of more than half of the House Republicans on a statement opposing any tax rate increase. Gingrich, wearing his negotiator's hat, didn't sign it. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., has stated repeatedly that Democrats won't vote for any tax increase unless most Republicans support it also. If Foley sticks to that pledge, it could give Gingrich the equivalent of a veto. If Foley doesn't, it might give Gingrich back the tax issue which Bush's statement has so badly blunted.
Steven Komarow covers Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats All But Certain of New York 1992 Convention
With PM-Democrats, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Democratic Party will choose New York over New Orleans for its 1992 presidential convention barring a last-minute collapse in negotiations, party officials say. New York has been party Chairman Ronald H. Brown's favorite from the outset of the search, and passage of a tough anti-abortion law by the Louisiana Legislature has all but quashed any hopes New Orleans had to change Brown's mind, two party officials said Sunday night. Brown plans to make his choice public within a week and only an unexpected snag in negotiations would deny New York the convention, said the officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ``A formal decision has not been made but he's closing in on New York very quickly,'' one of the officials said. ``Unless there's a snag it's New York,'' said the other. Brown, during a weekend meeting of the party's state chairmen in Oregon, refused to discuss his choice but acknowledged the anti-abortion law was affecting his deliberations. ``I'd be less than frank if I didn't acknowledge I have trouble with that,'' he said in an interview Saturday. ``This is a tough decision, with two first-class cities that have made very serious proposals and worked hard.'' Later, in a speech to the party chairs, Brown said the decision had him ``in a pressure cooker and I want to get out of the pressure cooker as soon as possible.'' Those in the party who favor New Orleans believe choosing the city would be a needed gesture to the South, where Democrats have done poorly in national elections. But the 1988 convention was in Atlanta and nominee Michael Dukakis did poorly in the South and even worse in Georgia. New York's Madison Square Garden is a tight hall for the gathering and the media center would be blocks away, but prominent party fund-raisers in the city have been promising to fill the party's coffers for the campaign. And New York has expressed no trouble with fronting the $20 million Brown wants in advance from the convention city to pay for the event, while New Orleans has expressed reservations about that amount. The party officials said dozens of party leaders and activists have said going to New Orleans would send a bad signal at a time when Democrats are trying to capitalize on the Republican Party's internal debate on the abortion issue. While in Oregon, Brown made repeated references to the Democratic Party's pro-choice stance.

DOC.HEAD: Bushes Send Champagne for White House Reporter's Wedding
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, sent a bottle of champagne and their best wishes to a White House reporter who got married at a seaside ceremony here. Associated Press reporter Rita Beamish and Paul Costello, a public relations executive, were wed Sunday on the grounds of the Shawmut Inn by Kennebunkport Town Clerk Janet Winters. About 15 people, most of them reporters here with the vacationing president, witnessed the ceremony. It was the first marriage for both. Ms. Beamish, 38, covered the campaigns of Bush and Jessie Jackson in 1988 and has covered the White House since Bush's inauguration. Costello, 37, was a press aide to Rosalynn Carter during the Carter administration. He also was press secretary to Kitty Dukakis, wife of Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis, during his 1988 campaign for the presidency. Costello, now a vice president of Ogilvy & Mather in Washington, also once was the spokesman for Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste. The couple plan a honeymoon in Greece later in July.

DOC.HEAD: NOW Considers Third Political Party
DOC.TEXT: The National Organization for Women is considering forming a third political party, complaining the Democrats and Republicans are dominated by white men. ``It's high time we questioned the status quo and challenged a system that just isn't working, that is leaving too many citizens out,'' said NOW President Molly Yard. The organization, which concluded its annual convention here on Sunday, launched a commission to consider a new party that would represent feminists and others who say they are ignored or used and abused by the two main parties. The 40-member commission formed Saturday will hold its first meeting this summer in Philadelphia. It will make its recommendations at the NOW convention next summer in New York City. NOW delegates on Sunday also re-elected Yard and endorsed 15 resolutions, including a campaign to elect women to office, including former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein, Democratic candidate for governor of California. Patricia Ireland, NOW executive vice president, noted that the organization's allies called NOW ``suicidal'' and ``naive'' when the idea of a third-party surfaced at the last convention. ``But are we naive? ... Isn't it time, with a Congress that's 95 percent male, 95 percent white _ with only two `out' gay males, and no `out' gay females? Isn't it time for a representative democracy?'' Ireland asked. Members on Saturday said the GOP abandoned all claim to women's support when the party came out against the Equal Rights Amendment and legal abortion. While they rated Democrats as somewhat better, they complained that too many party members resist abortion rights or take other repugnant stands. NOW leaders said Republican and Democratic candidates who support women on issues of concern to them would not be hurt by their third party, which could endorse a major party candidate instead of running its own. West German Parliament member Petra Kelly, who helped form the anti-nuclear, alternative Green Party in her country in 1979, urged 2,400 delegates to think about becoming an ``alternative political force.'' ``If not now, when are you going to do it? The time has come,'' Kelly said.

DOC.HEAD: Scramble for Western Currency At Economic Union
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East Germans ushered in the East-West currency union with cheers, rock music, fireworks _ and a huge shoving match outside the first bank where they could collect their new West German cash. West Germany's Deutsche Bank opened a branch on East Berlin's main square, the Alexanderplatz, the moment the currency union took effect at midnight Saturday. It was believed to be the only bank in the country to open before 8 a.m. Sunday. As it turned out, it was a publicity stunt that backfired. Thousands of people stood in line, thousands of others crowded around them and a writhing mass of people packed the bank's door, which was eventually broken. Ambulances took two people away when they became faint. In the same square, mass demonstrations last fall had helped bring down the former Communist government, heralding the drive to unification of the two German states. Anke Kirchner, 24, a teacher, thought the rush for West German money was ``rather depressing'' compared to the exuberant, idealistic demonstrations that brought down the Berlin Wall. Still, to many East Germans, Sunday was the day the two nations became one. The first man in line at the bank _ and the first person in East Germany to withdraw his new West German marks _ was Hans-Joachim Corsalle, 41, a coal delivery man from East Berlin. Corsalle showed up about four hours before the doors opened. ``Before I came here I told my wife this is going to enter the history books,'' he said. ``And it will.'' He took out 2,000 marks (about $1,200) and planned to use it to take his family on vacation. He got a gift basket and a 100-mark bonus for being the first East German in line. ``Never saw a line this long, except for the line at Elvis Presley's funeral,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Victims Seek Solace in Church
DOC.TEXT: Firefighting helicopters droned overhead as churchgoers from fire-ravaged neighborhoods gave thanks and sought solace. ``Let us remember that through death and death situations, we enter into new life,'' the Rev. Vincent McMurray of Saint Raphael's Catholic Church said Sunday. In the hall, about 250 boxes of donated clothing awaited parishioners. None had yet come to collect the clothes. ``I guess they might not have any place to keep clothing,'' said parishioner Rosemary Varesio. The 4,900-acre blaze that leveled about 430 homes and 28 apartment buildings on the edge of Santa Barbara was contained late Saturday. Ten businesses and four public buildings also were burned. People whose homes were spared trimmed trees and cleared shrubs in preparation for the rest of fire season. Experts said wildfires could strike at any time; the region is tinder-dry from four years of drought. Services were also held at the Coast Community Church of the Nazarene, which is past a checkpoint beyond which police threatened to fine gawkers $500. The church is blocks from the devastated Park Highlands neighborhood. ``I told the highway patrolman, `I'm here to preach,''' the Rev. Ira True told the congregation. ``He said, `That sounds like a good idea to me,' and let me in.'' ``It's good to be here,'' said Jim Hopper, who helped his in-laws out of their hillside home, which was spared. ``In some ways it's an act of God we were spared.'' True read to the congregation from Isaiah: ``When you pass through the waters I will be with you.'' He did not read the next verse, perhaps just too much for this Sunday: ``When you walk through the fire you will not be burned. The flames will not set you ablaze.'' Few families at Emanuel Lutheran Church were affected by the blaze, but the fire scene nearby was on everyone's mind. ``Our hearts and emotions are full,'' said the Rev. James A. Schmidt. ``There is worry, there is stress, there is bewilderment and there is also thankfulness.'' In special prayers before the start of regular services at Emanuel Lutheran, Betty Friske saw a message for the upper middle-class parish. ``Forgive us, oh Lord, for thinking we are in control of our well-ordered lives _ for the events of the past few days have shown us how small, fragile and powerless we really are,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,160.23, up 219.99 points, or 0.69 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Opens with Demand For Gorbachev's Resignation
DOC.TEXT: A delegate rose shortly after Mikhail S. Gorbachev opened the 28th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party on Monday and demanded that he and the top leadership resign their party posts immediately. Just nine minutes after the start, the session turned stormy. At 10:09 a.m., a delegate who identified himself as Brudov from the northeastern Siberian region of Magadan stepped up to a microphone on the floor of the Kremlin Congress of Palaces and offered a resolution that the Politburo and the Central Committee resign. It was voted down overwhelmingly by more than 4,000 of the 4,683 delegates to the congress. The congress continued as other delegates offered proposals on procedural matters.

DOC.HEAD: Dole: Bush Won't Try To Boost Income Tax Rate
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 3rd graf, 1st item, ``Moynihan said xxx to restore dropped words ``prepared to''
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republican leader Bob Dole says he does not expect President Bush to propose an increase in income tax rates, but rather to back higher oil import fees and taxes on alcohol and tobacco. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., countered Sunday on ABC's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' that such an approach would not raise enough money to reduce huge budget deficits. Moynihan said Democrats are prepared to force a $100 billion spending cut Oct. 1, as required by the Gramm-Rudman deficit spending law, if Bush does not increase income taxes and reduce the Social Security payroll deduction. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, meanwhile, said on NBC's ``Meet the Press'' that the top tax rate should be raised from its present level of 28 percent to reduce the budget deficit, mentioning 33 percent and 35 percent as possibilities.
DOC.HEAD: Two Colombians Extradited to U.S. on Drug Charges
DOC.TEXT: Two more Colombians wanted on U.S. drug-trafficking charges have been extradited to the United States to stand trial, says the U.S. Marshals Service. The two were identified as Luis Carbacas, 60, charged with leading a drug ring in North Carolina, and Rafael Juliao, 42, charged with cocaine distribution in New York City. They are among 17 people extradited from Colombia since the government of Colombian President Virgilio Barco began its drive against the narcotics cartel last August. Carbacas and Juliao were turned over to the marshals service in Bogota on Saturday evening and were flown to the United States early Sunday morning.
DOC.HEAD: West Germany Regains Export Leadership Over U.S.
DOC.TEXT: West Germany was the world's biggest exporter for the first three months of 1990, regaining its leadership over the United States, according to the International Monetary Fund. West Germany increased its exports to $99.8 billion, up more than 18 percent over the first quarter of last year, the IMF said Sunday. The U.S. increase of nearly 10 percent brought its total to $97.2 billion. In 1989, the United States regained first place with $364 billion worth of exports compared to West Germany's $341 billion. West Germany first forged ahead in 1986. Experts say the economic unification of West Germany and East Germany, which officially began Sunday, could put the united Germany ahead of the U.S. as the world's biggest exporter for years to come. The fund gave no figures for East Germany, which is not among its 151 member countries. Japan was a distant third place with $274 billion worth of exports for 1989 and $68 billion for the first quarter of this year. The United States remained by far the world's biggest importer, with $125 billion in foreign-made goods coming into the country in the first quarter of the year. That compared with $118 billion a year earlier. West Germany's imports also increased, to $78 billion from $65 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Two Planes Collide; At Least Four Dead
DOC.TEXT: Two small planes collided and plummeted to the ground, killing at least four people aboard, authorities said. Witnesses said the private planes were flying side by side Sunday evening when their wings touched. The planes went down about 70 miles west of Huntsville, one in a field and the other in a wooded area 1{ miles away. Sheriff Billy Townsend said that four people were confirmed dead and that authorities were searching for a fifth person who may have been aboard. Michael Meyer said he saw the planes flying at 1,000 to 1,500 feet when their wings touched and ``they both just went down.'' Another witness, John Connolly, said one plane lost a wing. Sheriff's deputies said the planes were owned by Bolivar Aviation School, in Bolivar, Tenn. Spokesman Bob Cantrell said he could not could not immediately confirm that. Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Roger Myers said the FAA and National Transportation Safety Board would investigate.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Remains Lower Against Yen, Index Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with closing. Picks up 7th pvs, `In currency ...'
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange erased morning losses and rebounded Monday, while the dollar closed sharply lower against the yen. The dollar closed at 151.40 yen, down 1.45 yen from Friday's 152.85-yen finish. It opened at 151.85 yen and ranged between 151.40 yen and 152.25 yen. On the stock market, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average recouped 219.99 points, or 0.69 percent, ending the day at 32,160.23. The index, which lost 165.95 points on Friday, shed another 96.62 points at the end of the morning session before rebounding in the afternoon. Traders attributed the index's afternoon recovery to index-linked, large-scale buying from foreign securities houses as well as position adjustments following its drops earlier. The index fell in early trading as market players stepped off to the sidelines worrying about a possible discount rate increase resulting from the government's earlier pledge to spend 430 trillion yen ($2.83 trillion) on public works over the next 10 years, which investors think could lead to inflation. In currency dealings, the dollar remained weak as the market waited to see whether Japan's interest rates would remain high and whether U.S. monetary authorities would act this week to lower U.S. interest rates, dealers said. Speculation over U.S. interest rates has grown in the market since Tuesday, when President Bush said tax revenues might be raised to help reduce the budget deficit. The U.S. Federal Reserve Board's policy-making committee is scheduled to meet on Tuesday. The Bank of Tokyo dealer Norio Takeda attributed the dollar's decline to the strength in the German mark, which became the only accepted currency in West Germany and East Germany on Sunday. ``The German monetary union is being welcomed by the market'' in Tokyo, he said. Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu told reporters Monday that the currency unification of the two German nations seemed to be moving smoothly and that he welcomed the move toward one Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Battle Troops Just Outside Monrovia
DOC.TEXT: Frightened refugees are pouring into Liberia's besieged capital as fighting between government troops and rebels rages just a few miles outside the city. Monrovia was in its fifth day without water today, and its fourth without electricity. Both were cut off when rebels captured the West African nation's main water treatment plant and hydro-electric power station, which are within 12 miles of Monrovia. Rebels battled retreating government troops two miles from the capital on Sunday, according to refugees fleeing the fighting. Health officials feared a cholera epidemic as refugees flooded the overcrowded port city. Refugees from a village near Sheiffelin, a major army base 12 miles east of Monrovia, said they heard sounds of heavy artillery and submachine gunfire before soldiers ordered them to evacuate. The fighting was near Caldwell, a small settlement two miles from the Atlantic coast port of Monrovia. The rebels, who launched their insurgency six months ago and now hold most of the country of 2.5 million people, also apparently seized a ship carrying rice to the capital, where residents face a food shortage. Guerrillas were advancing from Robertsfield International Airport, which they seized over the weekend after destroying the terminal with shell and mortar fire. Sunday's battle took place three miles from a U.S. radio transmission station used to relay diplomatic messages for sub-Saharan Africa. Also near the rebel lines is the Omega navigational station, a major U.S. navigation facility. The rebels so far have kept a promise not to damage U.S. government installations. A Voice of America relay station for Africa that fell behind rebel lines last week has not been threatened by the guerrillas. In the capital, residents spent Saturday night crouched on floors as soldiers fired wildly into the air in hopes of scaring away rebels. Western health workers in Monrovia said they had reports from rebel-held Buchanan, Liberia's second-largest city and a port, that young children and old people were beginning to die from starvation. President Samuel Doe, meanwhile, remained in his fortified executive mansion, protected by about 500 elite Presidential Guards. The rebels demand the resignation of Doe, who seized power in a bloody 1980 coup. They accuse him of 10 years of nepotism, brutal suppression of opposition and corruption. Rebel leader Charles Taylor was accused last week of ordering the execution of one of the founding members of his National Patriotic Front. Taylor has made it clear that elections will not be an immediate priority if he takes power. Both sides have been accused of killing hundreds of civilians. The U.S. State Department suggested Saturday that Doe step down. The call came in a statement supporting proposals by the Economic Community of West African States to end the rebellion, which has degenerated into a tribal war. Washington supported Doe with $500 million in aid from 1980-85, but the aid dropped to $7.5 million in rice this year because of reported human rights abuses and Doe's failure to repay debts. The 1980 coup ousted elitist descendants of freed U.S. slaves, who founded Liberia in 1847.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Official Says Quake Aid Won't Generate Goodwill Toward West
DOC.TEXT: Any Western government seeking to improve its relations with Tehran by sending earthquake aid will be disappointed, Iran's interior minister says. ``Bilateral issues between nations and governments, whether general or fundamental, are not settled with such things,'' the official, Abdollah Nouri, told reporters on Sunday. Iran is believed to have influence with the kidnappers who hold 16 Western hostages, including six Americans, in Lebanon. Asked whether Iran wanted better relations with the United States, one of the countries that sent aid after the devastating June 21 earthquake, Nouri said: ``No.'' Nouri spoke after a London newspaper quoted another Iranian official, Sayed Hossein Mosavian of the Foreign Ministry, as saying it was possible a Western hostage would soon be freed. ``It is very optimistic news for you,'' the Sunday Correspondent quoted him as saying without elaboration. Two American hostages _ Frank Reed and Robert Polhill _ were freed in April. Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held hostage. He was abducted March 16, 1985. Iran called off observations of a three-day Moslem holiday beginning today to commemorate the earthquake's dead, Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said Sunday. The agency said Iran's Cabinet canceled all official ceremonies and celebrations for the Eid al-Adha, or Feast of Sacrifice, out of respect for the bereaved. The three-day feast commemorates prophet Abraham's offering of his son to God. Abraham is revered by Moslems as well as by Jews and Christians. IRNA also reported that two aftershocks shook the northwestern Gilan province Sunday afternoon. It said the first measured 5.1 on the Richter scale, but did not give a reading for the second. The agency said no casualties or damage were reported. Nouri, the interior minister, said that despite generous foreign aid for Iran's earthquake victims, it would be overwhelmingly difficult to rebuild the devastated region 125 miles northwest of Tehran. He said Iran had two months to build shelter before the rainy season begins in September and that it would welcome donations of prefabricated housing from other countries. ``The best form of assistance is cash,'' Nouri told reporters. He said Iran would not seek international loans for reconstruction. He said 90,000 residences had been damaged in the quake. Most of them were made of mud brick or kiln-dried brick with little reinforcement in the walls. Nouri did not have final figures on casualties. The Iranian Red Crescent society has put the toll at 40,000 dead and the injured at 60,000. Estimates of the homeless range up to 500,000. The interior minister said Iran needed to repair roads, water systems and electrical service, as well as replace commercial buildings destroyed in the quake. He said experts were working on the best form of permanent housing and implementing codes that will make the structures earthquake resistant. The cost just to repair residences and the water and electrical systems will be $1 billion, he said. Nouri said virtually all of the dead and injured had been recovered from the rubble in the first 72 hours after the earthquake, but there might still be a few isolated cases of unrecovered bodies. The quake measured between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter scale, a guage of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake of the magnitude 7 is capable of widespread, heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: Carbon Monoxide Sickens Dozens
DOC.TEXT: Paramedics revived motel guests who had passed out in their rooms from carbon monoxide that apparently leaked from a hot tub furnace. Up to 30 people were sickened, but none was seriously hurt, authorities said. ``There were people passed out all over,'' said Betty Elliot, a guest at the Cazador Inn. ``Then they started carrying kids out, it was unbelievable. It was the scariest thing I have ever been through.'' More than 120 people at the two-story, 33-room motel were taken to a hospital Sunday morning, even those with no symptoms. All were later released. As many as 30 people experienced symptoms associated with carbon monoxide poisoning, which include nausea, headaches and grogginess, authorities said. Some motel guests were found passed out; dozens were treated on the front lawn of the motel, officials said. ``They were quickly brought around with oxygen,'' said Dana Miller, a paramedic. Ms. Elliot said some of her friends were found sick in their room. ``They looked terrible,'' she said. ``I thought they were dying. They thought they were both having heart attacks.'' Officials said they believe a flue on a furnace for the building's hot tub caused the leak. Carbon monoxide may have begun seeping into the motel as early as Thursday, authorities said. Spicer is a town of about 600 people, about 90 miles west of Minneapolis. It is holding its 87th annual Spicer Independence Day Celebration this week. Authorities had gone to the motel because of a call that a woman was sick, emergency technician Bryan Reichel said. ``When we got there, the other people in the room were sick, too, and others were complaining of nausea and headaches,'' Reichel said. Firefighters went from room to room. ``People were just waking up and realizing they were sick,'' he said. ``I was walking down the hall and kept saying, `More ambulances. More ambulances''' into his walkie-talkie.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Activist Found Dismembered
DOC.TEXT: An environmental activist last seen going to door to door to enlist support has been found dead, his torso and other body parts dumped in two plastic trash bags along a country road, authorities said. James Michael Madden, 24, of Whitefish Bay, had disappeared Wednesday while canvassing for Citizens for a Better Environment. His remains, minus the head and arms, were found Friday and identified Sunday. Authorities said they had no motive. Asked about the circumstances of Madden's death, Rosemary Oliveira, the environmental group's state administrative director, said investigators told her the death is not believed to be related to the organization. ``My own feeling is this is some psychopath out there,'' she said. Officials said that there were several stab wounds in Madden's back and chest but that the exact cause of death had not been determined. Ms. Oliveira said Madden had been with the group for about two months and worked at the Milwaukee headquarters. She said canvassing has been suspended. ``He was extremely well-liked. He was an avid environmentalist. He was very devoted to the cause,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls; Stocks Up
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar plunged against the Japanese yen for the second consecutive trading day today, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index rebounded moderately. The dollar closed at 151.40 yen, down 1.45 yen from Friday's 152.85-yen finish. It opened at 151.85 yen and ranged between 151.40 yen and 152.25 yen. The dollar fell 1.57 yen Friday. The dollar's low opening followed a downswing on overseas markets. It fell further as securities and life insurance companies actively sold it, dealers said. ``Market players bought the yen mainly because short-term interest rates have been rising,'' said a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, speaking on condition of anonymity. Also pushing the dollar lower was speculation over lower U.S. interest rates. Such speculation has grown in the market since last Tuesday, when President Bush said tax revenues might be raised to help reduce the budget deficit. ``Participants were trying to test how far the U.S. currency would slide, but 149 yen would probably be the bottom because the incentive is not strong enough to sell it further,'' the dealer said. About $11.24 billion changed hands in spot trading. On the stock market, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average climbed 219.99 points, or 0.69 percent, closing at 32,160.23. The index, which lost 165.95 points on Friday, was down another 96.62 points at the end of the morning session but rebounded in the afternoon. ``The index started to recover in the afternoon when many investors picked up underpriced issues to make position adjustments and foreign securities companies, especially Salomon Brothers, actively conducted index-linked buying,'' said Tomoyuki Morimoto, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. He said stability in the bond market also helped boost Monday's afternoon purchases. The Nikkei fell in early trading amid caution over the possibility of Japan's central bank pushing up interest rates to deal with potential inflation. Some investors see inflation as a risk of a large public works spending increase promised to the United States in efforts to trim Japan's trade surplus. Trading was thin, with first section volume estimated at 380 million shares, down from last Friday's 500 million. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds edged up to 86.53 points as of 5 p.m. (4:00 a.m. EDT) from last Friday's close of 86.29. The yield stood at 7.290 percent, down from 7.340 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Former AP Newsman Ronald Wei Dies at 67
DOC.TEXT: Veteran Associated Press newsman Ronald J. Wei died in his sleep at his home today, his wife reported. He was 67. Wei, born in Shanghai, left China shortly before the 1949 Communist takeover. He joined the AP in Hong Kong in 1960 and reported on political developments in China in the years before U.S. news agencies established bureaus in the Communist country in the mid-1970s. He retired in 1986. Before joining the AP, Wei worked for the Hong Kong Standard newspaper, the U.S. government and a Hong Kong motion picture company. He was a graduate of the prestigious St. John's University in Shanghai where he earned a degree in political science. His wife, Ann, said Wei died after a long illness. In addition to his wife, he is survived by a son, Christopher, and two daughters, Teresa and Patricia. Funeral arrangements were pending.

DOC.HEAD: Party Newspaper Calls for U.N. Control of Disputed Islands
DOC.TEXT: The disputed Kuril Islands should be turned into a special economic zone owned by the Soviet Union and Japan under the auspices of the United Nations, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda says. The Soviet Union occupied the mineral-rich islands north of Hokkaido after the end of World War II in 1945 and has rejected all Japanese demands since then to give them back. Writing in the Sunday edition of Pravda, political commentator Vsevolod Ovchinnikov said the fate of Iturup, Kunashir, Shikotan and Habomai, known as the Northern Territories, should be settled when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev visits Japan early next year. Ovchinnikov said the dispute could be solved by agreeing during the summit to place the islands under U.N. trusteeship as a special economic zone jointly owned by the Soviet Union and Japan. ``The two sides could also discuss other variants that would be mutually acceptable,'' Ovchinnikov said. He said that until recently, Japanese officials have refused to budge on the issue of the Kuril Islands. The meeting between South Korean President Roh Tae-Woo and Gorbachev during the Soviet leader's visit to the United States in June and their agreement to work on regional problems should be noted by Japan, Ovochinnikov said. ``Now that Seoul has expressed its readiness to provide its capital, techology and equipment for Siberian projects, Tokyo's tough stand is losing its meaning,'' the Pravda commentary said. It said only a mutually acceptable compromise on the Kuril Islands will end the 45-year-old dispute, and that Gorbachev's visit will be the best time to achieve that goal. The islands' economic value lies in its deposits of iron, copper and gold. The main occupation is fishing.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Develop Mini-Mice by Gene Engineering
DOC.TEXT: Scientists today said they employed genetic engineering to create a strain of midget mice, a development that could be applied to other animals and lead to a treatment for gigantism in humans. In a report in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, John J. Kopchick and Wen Y. Chen, molecular biologists at Ohio University, said they developed a gene that suppressed the growth hormone in mice. The mice were half the normal size, the scientists said. The discovery could lead to the development of smaller farm animals that would use food more efficiently and perhaps even to the development of new drug treatments for gigantism, in which the body grows abnormally large because of excessive production of growth hormone by the pituitary gland, the researchers said. The gene was developed during experiments in which the biologists were attempting to grow ``super mice,'' Kopchick said. ``As often in science, you get what you don't expect. This is the most exciting thing I've ever done,'' Kopchick said. The researchers were building on earlier genetic engineering experiments in which mice twice as big as normal were produced by inserting a growth hormone from cows into the genes of embryonic mice. The biologists intended to make the mice grow even bigger by making three changes in the hormone before inserting it. The changes instead produced large amounts of a protein that retards growth. The researchers said they will try to determine how genes can be created to control growth in specific ways. ``The idea would be to design a drug that would mimic the activity of this hormone,'' Kopchick said.

DOC.HEAD: Militants Stop Water Supply to Besieged Fort, 16 Rebels Killed
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels have intensified their siege of a government-held fort in Jaffna and cut off water to the troops, who have been trapped inside for three weeks, the military said today. Elsewhere in the north and the east, 16 rebels and two soldiers were killed in fighting Sunday, the military officials said. More than 250 soldiers and policemen have been trapped inside the 200-year-old Dutch fort in the center of Jaffna since June 11, when the latest fighting erupted between the government and separatist Tamil rebels. If the fort falls, it would be a major blow to the government, which controls only three other military installations on the Jaffna Peninsula, the main stronghold of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam militia. An airfield and two naval bases in the peninsula, 185 miles north of Colombo, are also facing continued attacks by the Tigers. Rebels cut the water supply to the Jaffna fort on Sunday, said military officials speaking on condition of anonymity. Damage and casualties from Sunday's offensive against the fort were not known, they said. On Sunday, eight rebels and two soldiers were killed in northwestern Puttalam district, military officials said. They did not elaborate. Also Sunday, six rebels were killed by police commandos in two encounters in the eastern coastal town of Pottuvil and two guerrillas were killed in Ampara district during clearing operations, they said. The latest deaths bring to 1,838 the number of combatants slain. The fighting erupted after a Tamil man complained to the rebels he was manhandled by Sinhalese police. Sinhalese comprise 75 percent of the Sri Lanka's 16 million people and dominate the police and the military. Tamils, who make up 18 percent of the population, complain of discrimination in jobs and education by the predominantly Sinhalese government. Several Tamil militant groups had been fighting since 1983 for a separate homeland in the north and the east where most of Sri Lanka's Tamils live. The Tamil Tigers continued the campaign after the other groups surrendered their arms. The separatist war has claimed nearly 13,000 lives in seven years.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Barry's Wife: I Told You So
With PM-Barry Trial
DOC.TEXT: Washington Mayor Marion Barry's wife says she warned him another woman would be his downfall. ``I told him all along: `You're going to be set up with a woman,''' Effie Barry was quoted as saying in today's New York Post. ``My gut was that this would be his downfall.'' The FBI used former model Rasheeda Moore on Jan. 18 to lure Barry to a Washington hotel, where he was videotaped smoking crack. She was scheduled to take the stand again today at his drug and perjury trial. ``I know that this kind of thing _ where you're set up by the FBI with a woman _ has happened,'' Mrs. Barry said. She said ``one never knows'' if her marriage will last, and she blamed her husband's troubles on alcoholism. ``My husband denied his problem until he was arrested,'' she said. Mrs. Barry said she had no knowledge of any cocaine use by her husband. ``The times I've seen him incapacitated were due to drink,'' she said. ``Those other alleged activities were when I wasn't present, so at this trial I, too, may learn things.'' Moore testified that she and the mayor used cocaine, marijuana and opium more than 100 times from 1986 to 1989. But she was unable in most cases to recall the dates or even the month that specific incidents supposedly occurred. Asked whether she knew of the relationship between her husband and Moore, Mrs. Barry said: `Not in particular. I only knew her name when I read it in the paper.'' The mayor's wife also blamed her husband's problems on his appetite for power and his up-from-the-streets background. ``Power was his mistress. When you're in power, people feed into your weakness,'' she said. ``And Marion was indiscreet because he's a street dude.''

DOC.HEAD: East Germany's Prime Minister Not Worried About Loss of Sovreignty
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere says he has no qualms about seeing East Germany's sovereignty disappear as its moves toward merger with its powerful neighbor, West Germany. After all, de Maiziere led his Christian Democrats to power by promising quick unification in the wake of last autumn's anti-Communist revolt. The Germanys moved a giant step closer Sunday as a treaty took effect that joined the two states economically and eliminated internal border controls. ``We want unity,'' de Maziere told The Associated Press. ``We want that one sovereign state developed and you have to commit to that goal.'' The prime minister criticized the widespread predictions that East Germany will face heavy unemployment in the coming weeks as its enterprises are forced to compete with the West. ``In recent weeks there has been too much talk about possible risks and not enough about the opportunities,'' he said. The West German mark became the official currency of East Germany on Sunday and West Germany's central bank took control of East Germany's money supply. But the prime minister said he does not expect an inflation-fueling buying spree by East Germans, who now have convertible currency to spend and Western products filling their stores. ``People are not plunging into vulgar materialism,'' he said. He also indicated that East Germany will not accept unification completely on West German terms. Asked if East Germany would seek to retain some of its own laws and institutions in a united Germany, he said, ``We're not coming with empty hands. We're bringing five states. We're bringing 16 million people.'' The prime minister, a 50-year-old lawyer, is a close ally of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, and it is anticipated he would join the united German government if Kohl is elected as its leader. All-German elections are expected in December, when the unification process is expected to be complete. But de Maiziere sidestepped questions about his future. ``Those questions have been asked a lot of times and I don't like the wording,'' he said. De Maiziere said he spent his first Western currency _ 4.6 marks ($2.80) _ on lunch in the cafeteria of the government ministerial building. ``Potato soup with sausage. Including the drink,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in New England, Intense Heat in Plains
DOC.TEXT: Rain dampened southern New England today and searing heat gripped the Plains and eastern Rockies. Temperatures were expected to approach 110 degrees in Nebraska and Kansas. Unseasonably warm weather also was expected in Minnesota, Iowa and Missouri. Today's forecast also called for rain in Idaho, Montana and southern New England and storms in southern Texas, Georgia and Alabama and from Minnesota to Missouri. Strong thunderstorms were scattered across the eastern half of the nation from Pennsylvania to Alabama on Sunday. Storms produced baseball-size hail at Driver and Chesapeake, Va., and at Middlesboro, Ky., where winds downed trees and power lines and destroyed a home. Temperatures rose above 90 in most areas between the southern Atlantic Coast and the high Plains, with readings above 100 in Kansas, Nebraska, Oklahoma, Colorado and Montana. Two dozen cities reported record highs for the date. Charleston, S.C., equalld its July record of 103 degrees. The high for the nation Sunday was 125 at Death Valley, Calif. DOC.HEAD: N.Y. Enacts `Right-to-Die' Legislation
DOC.TEXT: Adopting the nation's first right-to-die legislation since the Supreme Court ruling on the issue last week, the Legislature voted to let the terminally ill designate someone to decide whether to pull the plug. The bill was adopted by both chambers Sunday after a three-year struggle. It goes next to Gov. Mario Cuomo, who supports it. It allows the sick to appoint a proxy to make health care decisions for them when they are no longer able to do so. ``This legislation provides New Yorkers with a vehicle to ensure that treatment is provided according to their own personal, religious and moral convictions, as conveyed by someone they have selected and trust,'' Cuomo said. Advocates for AIDS patients hailed the legislation, which also was supported by the American Association of Retired Persons and the state Medical Society. ``We have seen many of our friends and lovers go through long and difficult deaths,'' said Tim Sweeney, deputy director for policy for the Gay Men's Health Crisis. ``AIDS robs people of so much control in their lives and this bill restores a measure of control for people with AIDS and their families.'' It was the first such legislative action in the country since the Supreme Court decision recognizing a right to die, said a spokesman for Senate Health Committee Chairman Michael Tully. The court, ruling June 25 in the case of Nancy Cruzan, a Missouri woman injured in a traffic accident, that the state could prevent her family from withdrawing medical care in the absence of clear evidence of the patient's desires. Tully said the Supreme Court decision gave his bill the final push toward adoption. ``More people talked about it and it opened the door to the fact that so many people and organizations supported the legislation,'' he said. The bill passed the Senate 51-6 and the House 116-28. A person would have to state in the agreement whether artificial feeding can be cut off for the proxy to be able to make that determination. Private hospitals or clinics could refuse, for moral or religious reasons, to let a proxy order a cutoff of life support. But the hospital would have to inform the patient upon admission that it won't honor a proxy's decision. That provision was among a handful of last-minute concessions made by lawmakers to avoid the active opposition of the state's Roman Catholic bishops.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Soldier Acquitted of Murder; Guilty of Lesser Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf before last graf with more information about shooting.
DOC.TEXT: An Army sergeant was acquitted of murdering a civilian during the closing days of the U.S. invasion of Panama but was convicted of other offenses and sentenced to 20 months in prison. Paul Finsel Jr., 25, of Arkoma, Okla., was found guilty Saturday of offenses including obstruction, conspiracy and loss of a military weapon. He was one of three soldiers charged in the slaying of Leila Diaz de Panay, 50, who was shot to death Jan. 25 while taking a bath outside her Panama City home. Investigators said she was slain during a gunfight staged by U.S. soldiers to conceal Finsel's loss of his pistol at a brothel. Col. Kenneth Mitchell, the military judge who decided the case, also busted Finsel down to private and gave him a bad-conduct discharge. Last week, Pfc. Mark McMonagle, 20, of Philadelphia, was convicted of unpremeditated murder and drew seven years in prison and a dishonorable discharge. Pfc. Marc Gussen, 19, of Teaneck, N.J., pleaded guilty to disobeying orders and obstruction April 23 and received two years in prison and dishonorable discharge. McMonagle admitted to an investigator that he went to a bar and brothel with Finsel, who lost his handgun when the two went into a back room to evade military police. Finsel convinced him that they should fake a firefight and say the gun was lost in the melee, McMonagle told the investigator. The two fired their rifles in the air, and soldiers nearby took up the fake firefight. At one point, McMonagle said, he had seen a shadow in the woman's courtyard and fired six times. The shooting took place during the last days of the invasion that overthrew Gen. Manuel Noriega.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Blacks Strike to Protest Faction Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with heavy strike participation reported in Johannesburg and other cities, police helicopter dropping leaflets, three killed in Natal over weekend. Picks up 9th pvs, `More than...'
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of blacks stayed away from work and schools today after the African National Congress called a general strike to protest factional strife that has claimed thousands of lives. Up to 90 percent of blacks in many areas did not go to work in response to the ANC's call for a 24-hour ``stayaway,'' according to police and local journalists. Johannesburg, Pretoria, Durban and East London on the east coast were all hard hit, they said. The ANC called the strike to protest black factional fighting in the eastern province of Natal, where it has demanded the white government end a state of emergency and disband local Zulu police. Police reported today that three blacks had been killed in factional fights in Natal over the weekend. Troops were on nationwide alert today and heavily armed police in armored cars and trucks patrolled some areas, but there were no immediate reports of violence. Bands of protesters erected barricades in black townships in Durban, but did not clash with police who demolished the barriers. Police patrols in some black townships offered transport to black workers trying to get to work. Police trucks took black hospital workers to their jobs in Durban. In Pretoria, a helicopter dropped police leaflets urging blacks to ``ignore imtimidation and go to work.'' More than 4,000 people have been killed in Natal since 1986 in fighting between the ANC and its allies and Inkatha, a Zulu party. The ANC contends Inkatha is responsible for the fighting. The ANC and Inkatha both oppose apartheid, but differ in their plans for a future South Africa with Inkatha favoring a more conservative philosophy that espouses Zulu nationalism. Last month, the government lifted a nationwide state of emergency everywhere except in Natal. Government officials say the state of emergency must be maintained in Natal to try and halt the bloodshed. Business groups warned that workers taking part in today's strike would not be paid and would face disciplinary action. The white government and some black groups opposed the action, saying it would only increase tension. The National Congress of Trade Unions, the second largest-labor federation with some 500,000 black members, told its members to go to work today. ``We are concerned this call will aggravate the violence not only in Natal but (throughout) the country,'' said Strini Moodley, spokesman for the Azanian People's Organization, a black group. The strike is supported by several ANC allies, including the Congress of South African Trade Unions, the country's largest black labor federation with about 1 million members. At least one senior ANC leader has expressed reservations about the stayaway. Archie Gumede, a top ANC figure in Natal, said he could understand the strike ``in terms of (black) anger, but I can't explain it in terms of logic.'' Black groups have become increasingly hostile to one another in recent months as they compete for supporters and influence. Hundreds of blacks have died in factional fighting since President F.W. de Klerk legalized dozens of anti-apartheid organizations in February.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.-dated third item in rdp to add name of sport.
DOC.TEXT: Cleveland Cavaliers center Brad Daugherty proclaimed his love from the skies when he tied the knot with his 19-year-old bride. The couple rode to the reception Sunday in a white, horse-drawn carriage as a banner plane overhead announced, ``I love you Heidi! Love Brad.'' Daugherty, drafted by the pro basketball team in 1986, met his future wife, Heidi Rost, when she served him lunch at a local restaurant a year ago. He liked her so much he moved to her hometown. ``I love the area, the beach,'' said the beaming groom, 24, after the wedding at the First Presbyterian Church. ``It's so warm and pretty here.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Show Up At Statehouse To Vent Anger Against Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of unhappy taxpayers, some tossing rolls of toilet paper, rallied at the statehouse to protest $2.8 billion in new taxes. Chanting ``Recall, Recall!'' and ``Florio Must Go!,'' the crowd Sunday repeatedly castigated Gov. Jim Florio and Democratic lawmakers who passed the package of sales and income tax increases. Most of the increases went into effect Sunday. Hundreds wore T-shirts and held placards with anti-Florio slogans. State police said the crowd numbered about 4,500 at its peak, and that as many as 4,000 others attended portions of the 2{-hour rally. Thousands of others never arrived in Trenton because of traffic jams caused by an automobile accident, police said. Before the rally, cars streamed across Route 195 in a 40-mile caravan from Belmar to Trenton and crowds cheered from highway overpasses. Most of the rally's wrath was directed toward Florio, who proposed a higher and expanded sales tax, a higher income tax, and increased taxes on items such as cigarettes and liquor. The package is expected to raise $2.8 billion in the first year. Among the items being taxed for the first time are soap and toilet paper. The state sales tax, which increased from 6 percent to 7 percent, became the second highest in the country behind Connecticut, which charges 8 percent. The $2.8 billion tax package will be used to close a budget gap of more than $1 billion, provide $1.1 billion in added state aid to public schools and ease some property taxes. The rally's organizers emphasized that their anger toward a Democratic governor did not mean they supported Republicans. ``They make promises and they don't keep them,'' said John Budzash, 39, a postal worker from Howell whose idea led to the rally. ``We can't take these tax increases. But the Republicans are as much to blame as the Democrats.'' Budzash said the group, which called itself ``Hands Across New Jersey,'' wants the tax hikes repealed, the ability to initiate legislation and a ``complete audit of state government to see where our money goes.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Steady
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with later rates, comment on impact of German monetary union; pickup graf 12 `The dollar's...'
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was significantly lower in European trading this morning after falling sharply against the yen in Asian markets. Gold steadied after opening higher. The dollar was under pressure because of President Bush's statement last week confirming his support for a tax increase, and the smooth start of German monetary union, dealers said. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 151.40 yen, down 1.45 yen from the finish Friday, when the dollar fell 1.57 yen. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 151.20 yen. Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with Friday: _1.6535 West German marks, down from 1.6653 _1.4010 Swiss francs, down from 1.4155 _5.5570 French francs, down from 5.5945 _1.8605 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8737 _1,214.60 Italian lire, down from 1,222.50 _1.1623 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1657 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.7570, up from $1.7450 late Friday. The mark was boosted by the early success of monetary union with East Germany. Moderate cash withdrawals by East Germans dampened fears of excessive consumption and subsequent inflation, dealers said. The dollar's low opening in Tokyo followed a decline on overseas markets. It fell further as securities and life insurance companies actively sold it, dealers said. ``Market players bought the yen mainly because short-term interest rates have been rising,'' said a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, speaking on condition of anonymity. Also pushing the dollar lower was speculation over lower U.S. interest rates. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $357.10 per troy ounce this morning, up from $353.25 bid late Friday. In Zurich, the metal traded at $356.90 per troy ounce, up from $352.00 bid late Friday. Silver bullion rose in London to a bid price of $4.91 a troy ounce, from $4.84 bid late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Celebrates with 42-Member Wedding Party
DOC.TEXT: It took 2{ pews to seat the 21 groomsmen and 21 bridesmaids when Yvonne Garcia and Raymond Mora tied the knot. ``We just didn't want to leave anyone out,'' said Mora, 29. ``The bigger the better, with more people happy.'' Mrs. Mora, also 29, said the relatives and friends in the wedding party Saturday ``have been waiting for us to get married a long time.'' She and Mora had been seeing each other for 11 years, she said. Best man Daniel Mora, the groom's brother, said it took 20 minutes to march into the sanctuary at St. Mary's Cathedral. The couple started planning the wedding a year ago, Mora said. The biggest obstacle was providing formal clothing for the grooms. ``It's the biggest wedding party I've outfitted, and I've been here 10 years,'' said Carol Heinen, assistant manager of Varsity Formal Wear in Grand Island. Heinen said Varsity fitted 28 tuxedos. The couple said that after all that work and worry, they were ready for their honeymoon, a seven-day Caribbean cruise.

DOC.HEAD: Mark Stronger Against Dollar After Becoming East Germany's Currency
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The West German mark was strong today on international markets during the smooth start of the historic merger of the East and West German economies. Currency dealers said the mark also was strengthened by the possibility of U.S. tax increases to combat the American deficit. The mark was fixed at 1.6538 to the dollar in Frankfurt, up from 1.6715 marks on Friday. In London, the mark was pegged at 1.6535 to the dollar, up from 1.6635 marks on Friday. The dollar had already begun easing down following Friday's fixing after President Bush said he was reconsidering his stance against raising taxes. Bush's announcement that tax increases may be needed to cut the budget deficit could have the effect of dropping U.S. interest rates and brake foreign investments, dealers said. In addition, dealers said moderate withdrawals of West German marks by East Germans in Sunday's first official day of economic unification was a clear indication that a consumer's buying spree would not occur, keeping inflation in check. The drop of the dollar led to only light trading on European markets. One dealer said the U.S. currency could settle to about 1.65 marks, pending economic figures clarifying the trend in East Germany's economy. But another dealer said that warning strikes at two East German factories today demanding a shorter work week and more pay could spread to other businesses and hurt the mark's strength.

DOC.HEAD: Stunt Pilots Killed in Air Show Crashes in New York, Connecticut
DOC.TEXT: Two U.S. stunt pilots were killed in air show crashes during the weekend, including one in which a World War II vintage plane plunging into the Niagara River before thousands of spectators. Four other U.S. stunt pilots have died since May 23 in air show crashes or while practicing for air shows across the United States. In addition, a Canadian pilot was killed Sunday when his plane crashed during a Canada Day air show in Ottawa. Despite the deaths, Federal Aviation Administration spokeswoman Kathleen Berger said stunt flying is generally a safe form of aviation. While the complicated acrobatics are designed to look dangerous, Berger said, ``they are safe. We have somebody at every air show checking things out before the show.'' On Sunday, thousands of spectators watched as an AT-6 training plane failed to come out of an aerial maneuver and crashed into the Niagara River along the United States-Canada border off Buffalo Harbor. The crash killed Gifford T. Foley, 43, of South Salem, N.Y. Mason Dunn, a technician for a stunt jet team, said Foley's plane ``started on a nose dive and was rotating. He never pulled out and went straight in.'' On Saturday, a stunt pilot was killed in Groton, Conn., while attempting a stunt takeoff in his 1942 Stearman biplane during an air show, according to state police there.
