Other recent fatal accidents included: _a June 23 crash of a P-51 Mustang plane during an air show in Abilene, Texas. _a June 17 crash in Oklahoma City of a Soviet-made Sukhoi-26M, which failed to come out of an intentional stall. _a June 14 crash of a single-engine plane during practice for an air show in Zeeland, Mich. _a May 26 crash in maneuver during an air show in Tuskegee, Ala.

DOC.HEAD: Euphoria Of Economic Merger Tempered By Warning Strikes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with coal protest; pickup graf 9 pvs, `East German....' ADDS new last graf with background on last year's revolution.
DOC.TEXT: East Germany plunged headfirst into the capitalist world today after its weekend economic merger with West Germany, but new worries and warning strikes blunted the euphoria of holding a new hard currency. Many East Germans were snatching up long desired goods with their new West German marks, but some were shocked by higher prices. Workers at two East German factories staged warning strikes today. They were the first of what is expected to be a wave of work stoppages. In another protest, coal dealers used their trucks to block loading points in four places in East Berlin. The city's 66 coal dealers were protesting the end of state subsidies that were a hallmark of the nation's Communist-run economy. State subsidies have been halted as the country adopts capitalism. On the first business day since economic union, long lines formed at most grocery stores and other shops. The official ADN news agency, reporting from Potsdam just southwest of Berlin, said prices for East German-produced butter and cheese were about the same as before, but the price of milk had more than doubled. It said consumers were comparing prices and shopping carefully. One shopper, 70-year-old Werner Ludwig of East Berlin, said he saw Western electronic goods of lower prices and better quality than those available before. ``But on the other hand, things that you need daily, like bread and flour, are much more expensive,'' he said. ``How often do you buy a color TV? You need bread every day.'' Today's warning strikes _ at the Ludwigsfelde automobile parts plant just south of Berlin and the Brandenburg steel works west of Berlin _ were for better pay and working conditions, ADN said. East German workers are demanding to be brought up to parity with their rich neighbors in West Germany. Others were expected to strike in a bid to keep their factories from closing. Both East and West German officials predict the next few months will be difficult, mostly because many of East Germany's 8,000 state-owned companies are expected to close. Burdened by heavy debt and unable to generate enough sales to pay their employees in West German marks, many East German factories and businesses are expected to fold even before they can convert to private ownership. There has been speculation some would file for bankruptcy as early as today. One company, Elektrowerk Electronicon of Gera, was quick to announce that a quarter of its 5,000 workers would have reduced shifts beginning today. The sobering reality contrasted with the outburst of euphoria that greeted the economic merger. At the stroke of midnight Saturday, the West German mark became the official East German currency and the West German central bank took control of East Germany's money supply. Border controls were eliminated. East Germans cheered, honked horns and set off fireworks to welcome the currency they had long coveted. West German businessmen _ everyone from furniture salesmen to travel agents offering tours to Rio de Janeiro _ rushed in to tempt them. At border crossings that were impenetrable before the Communists fell from power in last fall's democratic upheaval, smiling families walked, drove and bicycled back and forth without a policeman in sight. Although full political union with West Germany remains months away, for most East Germans Sunday was the long awaited day of unification, ending a failed 40-year experiment with socialism. Under the economic merger, most East Germans were able to exchange up to 4,000 East German marks in private savings at a 1-1 rate, receiving the equivalent of about $2,400. Additional ``Ost'' marks could be converted at 2-1. There is fear of mass unemployment as East Germany, a country of 16 million people, tries to quickly shift to a free market. There have been predictions that up to 4 million could be thrown out of work as the country struggles to rebuild an economy ravaged by decades of Communist mismanagement and inefficiency. The Credit Reform Economics Institute of West Germany predicts that more than half of East Germany's businesses will fold. Still, East Germany is likely to achieve prosperity much quicker than other East European countries making the transition to capitalism, including Poland and Hungary. An average East German now earns about 1,200 West German marks ($720) a month, less than half the average West German salary. However, East German rents and other basic items will be kept low for a while to help compensate. ``It will take hard work, until we have reached unity and freedom, prosperity and social balance for all Germans,'' West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said in a televised address Sunday evening. Many West Germans have been grumbling about the high cost of bringing East Germany up to full Western standards. They fear tax increases, further housing shortages and reduced old-age pensions. Officials of both Germanys are working on a political unification treaty to prepare for full union and all-German elections in December. This is contingent upon the two Germanys reaching agreement with the four victorious World War II allies on the international ramifications of unification, including the military alignment of a united Germany. The changes were launched with last year's democratic revolution in East Germany and other East European countries, where Communist regimes that had ruled during the postwar era were ousted during popular protests.

DOC.HEAD: Zambians Find Calm for First Time in Week
DOC.TEXT: Life appeared to return to normal today for the first time in a week following an aborted military coup and the deaths of 23 protesters in the country's worst urban violence in history. President Kenneth Kaunda played golf, and long lines formed before dawn outside state stores, private supermarkets and gasoline stations. Such services were closed after student-led rioting over higher food prices broke out one week ago. No unrest was reported, but the government kept a nighttime curfew in effect. State television Sunday night reported that more than 1,000 people had been arrested, mainly for curfew violations, during the violence. But witnesses said many people were arrested in daylight during the anti-government protests. Today, paramilitary police and troops patrolled the streets of Lusaka, the capital, and other cities and towns of this southern African country of 7.5 million. Officials said no one was killed during the coup attempt Saturday. But witnesses and diplomats said three civilians celebrating Kaunda's reported death were shot dead. Kaunda, 67, was in the central city of Ndola early Saturday when a signal corps lieutenant announced on state radio that the army had seized power. But loyalist troops detained the soldier and at least four other officers involved in the coup plot, diplomats said on condition of anonymity. The government has acknowledged the arrests of only two people. The broadcasts prompted thousands of Zambians to take to the streets to hail the reported coup and denounce Kaunda. In an apparent move to consolidate control, Kaunda on Sunday transferred army commander Lt.-Gen. Gary Kalenge. Former air force chief Lt.-Gen. Hanniah Lungu was appointed defense minister, a post that had been vacant. Kaunda gave no explanations for the moves. The anti-government protests began last Monday and were led by students who denounced a state-ordered price increase for corn meal, the nation's staple, and demanded Kaunda resign and multiparty democracy be restored. At least 23 protesters were killed in clashes with security forces. Over the weekend, the president vowed to crack down on enemies and refused to budge on the 120 percent price increase for cornmeal. Kaunda is under pressure from a faltering economy and foreign creditors who are owed $7.5 billion. In similar rioting in December 1986, security forces shot to death at least 15 civilians. Kaunda rescinded the price increases at that time.

DOC.HEAD: 24 Injured When Lightning Hits Pavilion; 11 Still Hospitalized Today
DOC.TEXT: Lightning hit a tin-roofed pavilion and injured 24 people huddled under it to escape a storm which was part of a system that brought heavy rains, high wind and hail. Eleven members of the Kingwood Pike Coon Hunters Club were still hospitalized this morning following the storm Sunday at a Preston County archery range. All were in stable, fair or good codition. ``It just happened _ no crack, no thunder, no nothing, then it hit and there were people over there yelling,'' said James Seaman, who was under the shelter when the lightning hit. The club was holding target practice when a thunderstorm hit shortly before 1 p.m., and the members sought refuge under the open-air structure in this northern West Virginia city. ``It was kind of a state of confusion. People were scattered everywhere,'' said Ed Turnley of the Reedsville Volunteer Fire Department. All but one of the injured were conscious when rescue workers arrived, he said. The victims complained of chest pains, burns and other sensations associated with electrical shock, officials said. On Sunday, heavy thunderstorms rolled across northern West Virginia, and rain, hail and high winds raked portions of Preston, Wetzel, Harrison, Upshur and Lewis counties, knocking down trees and power lines. Nearly 1,000 Marion County homes and businesses lost power, Monongahela Power Co. said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sees Changes in NATO's Nuclear Policy
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today NATO leaders will make changes in the alliance's nuclear weapons policy but, ``I don't happen to believe it's bombshell dimension.'' Bush, preparing for this week's NATO meeting in London, said he wanted to talk with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Colin Powell, chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, about the current NATO policy on nuclear weapons. The Washington Post and The New York Times reported today that Bush is proposing a NATO policy of using nuclear weapons only as a last resort. Current policy is that such warheads could be used first if an enemy was gaining the upper hand in conventional warfare. Bush talked with reporters as he stood outside his seaside vacation home with a coterie of advisers who flew up from Washington. Asked if he expected changes in NATO policy coming from the meeting of the 16-member alliance, he said: ``What I expect is a ... document that is unanimously agreed to that will set the course for the future. As conditions have changed, NATO will change... some will call it dramatic policy changes and others won't.'' ``There will be some changes, but I don't happen to believe it's bombshell dimension,'' Bush said. Bush said that his administration had been in close contact with the allies in advance of the London summit. He said ``we've got broad general agreement'' on the issues, but indicated differences remain in some areas. ``There's still some work to be done,'' he said. Joining Bush on a blustery Maine morning at his family compound were Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Vice President Dan Quayle, Cheney, Powell, Chief of Staff John Sununu, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, and others. U.S. officials said earlier the administration is ready to look toward eventual withdrawal of some 1,400 nuclear-tipped artillery shells from Western Europe. Bush will attend the NATO meeting on Thursday and Friday. The officials said the Bush administration will consider eliminating U.S. nuclear stockpiles, including the artillery shells now deployed in West Germany, only if the Soviets withdraw their troops completely from foreign soil in Europe. The shells have a range of about 18 miles. Addressing another matter on Sunday, Bush said he was worried about the fate of a kidnapped Peace Corps worker in the Philippines. He noted that the United States is pulling its Peace Corps workers out of the Pacific nation because of danger from communist guerrillas. ``They're coming out of there anyway,'' he told reporters when asked about the matter on the golf course Sunday. ``The age of the terrorist. It's not good.'' He said the news was contributing to an overall downbeat day of his vacation. ``No fish,'' he said of a midday fishing trip. ``It's been that kind of a day. Lost in tennis. No fish. No particularly good news from around the world.'' But Bush later made a birdie on the 13th hole of a local golf course. ``It's the second happiest day of my life, from a bad day starting off,'' he told reporters who pressed him on what the happiest day was. He thrust his right thumb upward and said, ``Barbara.'' On Tuesday, Bush will host Brady and other officials at his home on Walker's Point to plan for a second summit meeting, this one an economic summit to be held July 9-11 in Houston with other major industrialized nations. Bush leaves for the NATO summit in London on Wednesday evening, and then flies back to Houston on Friday. Final language has not been completed for the communique that will conclude the NATO summit. But the officials said Sunday that it will focus more on other issues than on nuclear weapons. It is expected to emphasize the need for NATO to shift more to a political rather than a military body and also urge the strengthening of the 35-nation European Security Conference. There also is expected to be discussion of a European suggestion to provide economic aid to the Soviet Union to help its ailing economy. The Bush administration has been somewhat cool to the idea from the U.S. point of view, but has said that other nations may want to provide aid.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Opens with Demand For Gorbachev's Resignation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to ADD further Gorbachev comment, details of proposals; EDITS to trim. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev moved to take firm control of a watershed Communist Party congress today, fending off a call for his resignation and aggressively defending his reform efforts. The president and party leader seemed to have succeeded in averting a possible challenge to his leadership by hard-liners and the threat of a walkout by radical reformers. ``Voices are being heard that all of our present problems should be blamed on perestroika,'' Gorbachev told the delegates to the 28th Soviet Communist Party Congress in a keynote speech. He acknowledged that the party's top leaders had made mistakes, especially in ethnic relations where ``we did not see the dangers.'' Hundreds of people have been killed in recent waves of ethnic violence in Armenia and Azerbaijan, central Asian cities, and other places. Also, the three Baltic republics are trying to secede. In today's speech, though, Gorbachev laid much blame for the nation's pressing problems _ including the economic crisis _ on the ``heavy legacy'' of previous leaders dating to Josef Stalin. Gorbachev also attacked the Soviet Union's vast bureaucracy, saying many functionaries only cared about protecting their own power and privileges. Radical reform is vital, he insisted, because ``the U.S.S.R. is rapidly becoming a second-rate power.'' He offered few specifics but said Communists must: _``Stop the brain and talent drain abroad.'' _Pass legislation ending the government monopoly on the manufacture of farm machinery ``to provide for an influx of foreign capital in this area.'' _Quickly make the Soviet currency convertible on the world market. _Negotiate a new treaty uniting the 15 Soviet republics on a looser basis while preserving the nation. In the days leading up the party congress, it appeared the Soviet leader might face a challenge from hard-liners for the top party leadership post, and that radical reformers might walk out and split the party. But today, Gorbachev seemed successful in his exhortations for unity among party reformers and moderates. Members of the radical Democratic Platform said they had dropped plans to walk out of the congress to form their own party. Also, hard-liners who last month demanded that Gorbachev give up his post as Communist Party general secretary said they planned to support him, although they might use the new policy of openness to criticize some policies. ``Gorbachev must be the party leader,'' Soviet Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov told reporters at the congress. Public opinion polls indicate the people's trust in the party _ until Gorbachev's tenure the country's sole political force _ has waned significantly as it fails to cope with mounting discontent. Coal miners have threatened a one-day strike for July 11, a day before the scheduled end of the congress, to protest the failure of the Communist leadership to improve living conditions. The nationally televised opening session was tempestuous, in contrast to previous congresses, which were carefully orchestrated by the party leadership. This time, speaker after speaker rose from the floor to offer resolutions and proposals clearly not on Gorbachev's agenda, including a call for the party leadership to resign. Gorbachev, who heads the party as general secretary, did not comment on the demand and the 4,683 delegates approved his proposal to return to the issue later. Conservatives had been threatening for two weeks to try to oust Gorbachev as party chief, but it appeared that threat had diminished. Hard-liner Ivan Polozkov said he would not run against Gorbachev for the top party post. However, Polozkov _ elected last month as leader of the largely conservative Communist Party of the Russian republic _ said he expected Politburo members to explain ``what they see as the way out of the situation that has been created, the loss of direction for which they must answer.'' For the first time, the 12 members of the Politburo are scheduled to report to the congress on their work since the last party congress, in 1986. The progressive Democratic Platform demands that the party give up its cells in the police, military, the KGB and in nearly every workplace. It had authorized its estimated 100 delegates to walk out and form a new party if they are not happy with the session. Such a split would have been the first in the party since 1921. But Sergei Stankevich, a leading reformer from Moscow, said the Democratic Platform leaders had decided against the walkout. Gorbachev, who heads the government as president, wants to use the congress to transform what have traditionally been the most powerful Soviet institutions, rewriting party rules that affect all 19 million party members. The proposed changes include replacing the general secretary with a party chairman and first secretary and renaming and expanding the Politburo, thus diluting the power of each member. Other proposals include nominating multiple candidates for party jobs and restricting elected party officials to two terms. Gorbachev wants to strip the party of involvement in day-to-day administration of the government and economy. He seeks to end the party's domination of government. His most important proposed rule changes would affect the Central Committee, the party's policy-making body and a bastion of conservative holdovers. Politburo member Lev Zaikov has said 90 percent of the 249 Central Committee members should be replaced by younger people. The congress will elect a new Central Committee. Gorbachev had one previous chance to win control of the committee _ at the 1986 congress _ but had been in office just 11 months and lacked the power.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Debt Burden Surged 25 Percent in 1989
DOC.TEXT: America's foreign debt burden surged 25 percent in 1989 to $663.7 billion as foreigners' holdings in the United States grew at a faster pace than Americans' assets abroad. The new assessment, based on data supplied today by the Commerce Department, showed that the United States increased its lead as the world's largest debtor country. Unlike past years, the department did not publish the actual net debtor position of the United States although it did supply enough information on the component parts that simple math allowed the number to be derived. The department defended its change by saying that the debtor figures as presently compilied were unreliable. Critics charged that the move was prompted by a desire to avoid publishing a report that has become a political embarrassment. The Commerce Department report showed that U.S. holdings of overseas assets rose by $146.9 billion last year to $1.412 trillion, a gain of 11.6 percent. But foreign holdings in the United States climbed at an even faster pace of 15.6 percent, rising by $279.6 billion to $2.076 trillion. The net debtor position is the difference between America's assets abroad and foreign assets in the United States. That difference grew to $663.75 billion last year, up from $531.08 billion in 1988. Some economists believe that debt total could surpass $1 trillion sometime in the next few years, a stunning reversal for a country that began the 1980s as the world's largest creditor nation. As recently as 1983, the United States held the title of largest creditor, when it had an investment surplus of $89 billion. That surplus fell to $3.3 billion in 1984 and disappeared altogether in 1985, the year the country became a net debtor for the first time in 71 years. The surplus was erased by the huge merchandise trade deficits the United States piled up during the 1980s as Americans transferred billions of dollars into the hands of foreigners to pay for imported cars and television sets. Those dollars, now in foreign hands, have been reinvested in the United States in everything from U.S. Treasury bills to Los Angeles office buildings, setting off cries that America was transferring control of its economic destiny to foreigners. Allan Young, head of the BEA, said there was no pressure from the Bush administration to halt publication of the net debtor figure. He said he took the action because of concern that the report understated the value of U.S. assets overseas because the report measured those assets at their historical purchase price. That undervalued the worth of U.S. assets in foreign countries, many of which were purchased decades ago, in comparison to foreign holdings in the United States, many purchased in the 1980s. Young said the BEA is working to produce a report that will give an up-to-date current value on all assets, both foreign and U.S. holdings, and hopes to have that report ready in a year. If it is, the BEA will resume publishing a bottom-line figure, he said. But private economists said they believed the final results still will show the United States as a net debtor. C. Fred Bergsten, head of the Institute for International Economics, said that while the current report does understate the value of America's holdings overseas, it also understates foreign holdings in the United States because of errors in gathering data on foreign ownership. ``Our view is that both the asset and liability numbers are substantially understated and as a result the bottom-line figure is probably about right,'' said Bergsten, who is completing a book on America's debtor status.

DOC.HEAD: Missing Child Back at Home; Teen-Agern Held
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Ryann is cq in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: An infant abducted from a hospital nursery slept in her own bed today after police arrested an 18-year-old honor student who allegedly crafted an elaborate story to explain the baby's arrival. Teresa and Willie Morse flew to Butler, Mo., to retrieve their first-born, 2-week-old Whitney Ryann Morse, on Sunday. The infant was taken June 20 from Deaconess Hospital in Oklahoma City by a woman dressed in hospital scrubs. ``We had to travel a long way to get her,'' Mrs. Morse said at her home Sunday night, with Whitney in her arms. ``I remember when we were about halfway home, I felt `I don't feel any anger, I don't feel any pain, I don't feel anything, but just love for my child,''' Mrs. Morse said. An anonymous telephone tip helped officials find the baby, Max Geiman, FBI spokesman in Kansas City, said Sunday. The caller recognized a drawing of the abductor on a television news show, Geiman said. Former high school honor student Heather Brewster, 18, was arrested in Butler late Saturday, after questioning by Bates County sheriff's officers. Ralph Lindsey, chief deputy in the Bates County Sheriff's Department, said Ms. Brewster concocted a detailed plan to obtain a baby after she became pregnant by a boyfriend and then had a miscarriage in January or February. She told friends that she was carrying twins, and one baby was lost. The woman went to great lengths to fool friends and family into thinking she was pregnant, Lindsey said. She showed friends a document with an official-looking seal that said the baby was born at 3:32 a.m. at the Boone County Hospital, in Columbia, Mo. She also told family and friends that she had enrolled in a prenatal class in Columbia, and had made a trip there, Lindsey said. ``Both sides of this story can pull on the heartstrings,'' Lindsey said. ``It's just too bad that we had to go through such a horror story because of it.'' Authorities said Ms. Brewster was a student at Central Missouri State University in Warrensburg. She denied taking the baby during questioning Saturday night, but the child was positively identified as the Morse child, officials said. Federal authorities in Oklahoma City probably would handle any charges that may be filed against the woman, Geiman said. Federal prosecutors in Missouri and Oklahoma will work out that decision, he said. The baby had gained a pound in the time she was gone, Mrs. Morse said.

DOC.HEAD: Montana Man Loses Appeal In Maine Bride's Cliff-Falling Death
DOC.TEXT: A man lost his murder appeal today in the cliff-falling death of a woman he met, married and insured just weeks after running a newspaper personal advertisement. The Maine Supreme Judicial Court unanimously turned down each of the challenges raised by Dennis R. Larson, who is serving a 50-year prison sentence in the death of Kathy Frost Larson. Mrs. Larson plunged 80 feet to her death at Otter Cliffs in Acadia National Park on Oct. 11, 1987. Authorities centered their investigation on Larson after learning he had collected insurance money when his first wife allegedly washed away in a Montana stream. Larson, 40, was convicted of murdering the former Miss Frost in a plot to collect $400,000 in life insurance money, but he challenged his appeal by saying the state improperly took statements from him. The Great Falls, Mont., man also said that during his trial, Superior Court Justice Jack O. Smith improperly let the state reopen its case after the prosecutor failed to prove that the body found at the base of the cliff was that of his bride. Larson also challenged the use of testimony from an old friend who recounted a trip when Larson said he would like to marry a foreign woman, arrange an apparently accidental death, then collect insurance money. The state's highest court found no merit in any of Larson's arguments. ``The state presented more than adequate evidence to warrant the Superior Court's belief beyond a reasonable doubt that defendant did indeed intentionally or knowingly murder Kathy Frost Larson,'' wrote Chief Justice Vincent L. McKusick. The high court also said that Maine was able to bring the murder charge against Larson because the state and federal governments share jurisdiction in Acadia. Larson's first wife, Leslee Reynolds Larson, vanished in 1975 with Larson being the only witness. Larson claimed that the woman was washed away in Prickly Pear Creek, some 50 miles south of Great Falls. No traces of Leslee Larson were ever found, which authorities considered unusual under the circumstances, and she was pronounced dead seven years later. Larson collected a $20,000 payment from Allstate Insurance. After Larson was divorced from a second wife in Montana, he came to Maine in June 1987. Larson soon joined a computer dating service and ran several personal advertisements in area newspapers, including the one that Miss Frost responded to. Within two weeks of their first meeting, Larson proposed marriage. They married on Sept. 20, 1987. The next morning, the newlyweds met with an insurance agent. They purchased a policy that included $200,000 coverage for Mrs. Larson, with a double indemnity for accidental death. On Oct. 10, 1987, the couple went to Acadia National Park. The next day, Larson reported that his wife had fallen from the cliffs. Larson initially said his wife had wandered off alone looking for sea otters, but friends and family did not believe it because the woman had been terrified of heights.

DOC.HEAD: Exerpts From Gorbachev Speech at 28th Party Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf to change to ``second-rate power'' sted ``second-rate state'' to CONFORM with translation in PM-Soviet-Party.
DOC.TEXT: The following are excerpts from the first half of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech to the 28th Communist Party Congress. Some of the excerpts were translated from Russian by the official Soviet news agency Tass, which did not provide a full text. Other excerpts were translated by The Associated Press.

PERESTROIKA AND PARTY FAILURES The Soviet citizen of today no longer accepts what he meekly tolerated in the past. He reacts with understandable alarm and anger to the negative phenomena that, like foam on the surface, accompany the turbulent and basically healthy process of perestroika. A clear and well-founded answer to the question why this has happened is important for formulating conclusions as to what should be done next and how it should be done. It is also essential in order to fortify people's faith in perestroika. After all, voices can now be heard _ even more _ this is now something like an attitude _ claiming that perestroika is to blame for all our present troubles. In speaking of all this, comrades, I certainly do not want to mitigate assessments or conclusions concerning the activities of the Central Committee, the Politburo, the Communists working in the party, or government and economic bodies in the republics or locally. We have inherited a heavy legacy. The deplorable state of our lands and economy and the disastrous state of the energy sector ... are not the result of recent years. There are many things we could have foreseen and there are negative processes, above all, in the economic and social spheres, in inter-ethnic relations, in the sphere of culture and ideology, whose development we could have prevented. The Politburo does not deny its responsibility for these errors. We must analyze the situation, and we must see what revolutionary transformations will be made because the U.S.S.R. is rapidly becoming a second-rate power.

THE ECONOMY Improvement of the Soviet economy depends to no small extent on how it integrates in the system of the international division of labor. And the main thing is to work for the convertibility of the ruble. This matter should not be put off. At present, the government is drawing up proposals for the entire set of problems related to economic activity abroad. This applies to expanding ties with capitalist countries, and going over to world prices and settlements in hard currency within the framework of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance. This also concerns revision and introduction of certain correctives in our cooperation with Third World countries.

SELF-SERVING BUREAUCRACY We are being directly opposed by the bureaucratic sector of the population. If we do not overcome the resistance of such workers, and there are many in management structures, the situation will worsen.

CHRONIC SHORTAGES I would subscribe here to everything that is said on this subject and express solidarity with the most scathing criticism. But just fanning emotions won't increase the amount of goods. Yet at the same time, the situation on the consumer market, far from becoming less strained, has in many cases grown more acute and become intolerable. In any case _ and this should be admitted _ the consequences could have been less painful if the government had approached the economic reform comprehensively, and had managed to stand up to the pressure of various industries and the old managerial structures that sought to keep their position and maintain command of administration.

ETHNIC STRIFE At present, as we embark on a succession of deep-going changes in our multinational state, we need tranquility, peace and cooperation in the interests of all nations. I hope that this appeal of our congress will be heard in all parts of the country. What we lived through and reflected upon in recent times, has caused us to realize that the updating of the union cannot be confined to mere, even though highly considerable, extension of the rights of the republics and autonomies. What we need is a real union of sovereign states.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: This serves as a 2nd Ld-Writethru to the first item in PM-Washington in Brief, a0465, updating with White House comment.
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republican leader Bob Dole says he does not expect President Bush to propose an increase in income tax rates, but the White House said today that Bush has made no such assurances. ``He has not made any assurances on anything. Everything is up for discussion,'' White House press spokeswoman Alixe Glen told reporters accompanying Bush on a Fourth of July vacation in Kennebunkport, Maine. Dole said he expects Bush will not back tax rate increases, but to support higher oil import fees and taxes on alcohol and tobacco. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., countered Sunday on ABC's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' that such an approach would not raise enough money to reduce huge budget deficits. Glen refused to characterize any proposals that were under discussion by administration and congressional negotiators who are trying to reach an agreement on reducing the deficit. Moynihan said Democrats are prepared to force a $100 billion spending cut Oct. 1, as required by the Gramm-Rudman deficit spending law, if Bush does not increase income taxes and reduce the Social Security payroll deduction. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, meanwhile, said on NBC's ``Meet the Press'' that the top tax rate should be raised from its present level of 28 percent to reduce the budget deficit. He mentioned the figures of 33 percent and 35 percent as possibilities.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Appeals Ruling Barring Two From Courtroom
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry today appealed a federal judge's ruling that barred black leaders Louis Farrakhan and Bishop George Stallings from the mayor's drug and perjury trial. It is a violation of Barry's constitutional right to a public trial to keep Farrakhan and Stallings from attending, lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union, representing the three, said in papers filed in federal appeals court. The appeal came as Barry's trial was resuming with former model Rasheeda Moore back on the stand for a third day of cross-examination by Barry's attorneys. The rights of Farrakhan and Stallings right to attend the trial is guaranteed by the First Amendment, the court papers said. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ruled that the presence of Imani Temple Bishop Stallings and Nation of Islam Minister Farrakhan would be ``potentially disruptive and very likely intimidating.'' The judge's discretion ``does not include ... orders barring well-behaved members of the public from court without extraordinary and well-documented reasons,'' said the ACLU. ``If ... it is not inappropriate for the United States attorney, who is not trying this case, to appear in the courtroom ... it cannot be improper for a black leader to appear,'' said the court filing. Stallings was barred from the courtroom last Friday. Inside, the jury heard Barry attorney R. Kenneth Mundy elicit testimony from Moore that she doesn't remember using cocaine with Barry on a 1986 trip to the Virgin Islands. Convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis has testified that Barry and Moore repeatedly went into a bathroom on a sailboat with a bag of cocaine that was nearly empty by the end of the ride. Did she remember that? asked Mundy. ``Not to my recollection,'' said Moore. ``I have not been able to remember the use of cocaine on that trip'' in 1986. Mundy has gotten Moore to admit that she violated her instructions from the FBI during a videotaped sting operation. The ex-model was told by her FBI handlers not to persuade or invite Barry to take drugs, and she testified that she got carried away in her duties on behalf of the government. Barry was videotaped the night of Jan. 18 taking two long drags of crack cocaine. The riveting videotape, including his arrest by federal and local authorities, was shown in the courtroom and on local television on Thursday. The core of Moore's testimony was that she and Barry used cocaine, marijuana and opium more than 100 times from 1986 to 1989. Last week she provided details about her alleged drug use with Barry. But she was unable in most cases to recall the dates or even the month that specific incidents of alleged drug use occurred. She's not good with numbers, she testified. Mundy launched attacks on Moore's credibility and her motives. She was seeking revenge on Barry because he had abandoned her for a woman named Maria McCarthy, the mayor's lawyer suggested. Moore denied that. Mundy brought out that she lied to a federal grand jury in 1989 by denying she and Barry had used drugs. She used cocaine as recently as April and is a recovering alcoholic, she admitted. She lied again to a grand jury in January by denying her own recent drug use, she acknowledged. Meanwhile, Barry got a rousing ovation Sunday as he and his wife, Effi, attended the first anniversary service for Stallings' breakaway congregation. ``They figured that since Mayor Marion Barry couldn't get bought, he had to get caught,'' Stallings told his Imani Temple African-American Congregation. ``That's why Mayor Marion Barry is in trouble right now, he is too smart, too intelligent, too black.'' On Saturday, Barry was cheered at an anti-drug rally and told the crowd his legal situation is ``just a matter of good lawyers and good jurors.'' Stallings was excommunicated from the Roman Catholic Church earlier this year after forming his breakaway congregation for disenchanted black Catholics.

DOC.HEAD: Two Cargo Vessels Collide in Chesapeake; 35,000 Gallons of Fuel Spilled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to add detail on effort to protect waterfront, other detail, minor recasting. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `The Columbus...'. Adds one graf on end with routing drug tests given.
DOC.TEXT: Two cargo ships collided in the Chesapeake Bay during a thunderstorm, severely damaging one of the ships and spilling at least 35,000 gallons of fuel, authorities said. Cleanup crews remained on station today after working through the night to contain the spill from this ships' fuel tanks after the Sunday evening collision. Some oil washed up on city beaches. ``We consider this a major marine casualty because of the damage done and the amount of oil spilled,'' said U.S. Coast Guard Cmdr. George Naccara. Naccara said 35,000 gallons to 40,000 gallons of No. 4 heavy oil and diesel were spilled when the Columbus America, registered in West Germany, and the Neptune Jade, based in Singapore, collided shortly before 7 p.m. Sunday about five miles north of Norfolk near the Hampton Roads Bridge-Tunnel. The 635-foot Columbus America received extensive damage and the Neptune Jade was also damaged, Naccara said, but no injuries were reported on either ship. Capt. Eugene Johnson, commander of the Coast Guard Marine Safety Office in Portsmouth, said the 6-mile Norfolk shipping channel remained closed this morning while efforts were made to corral the oil. Some oil washed ashore on beaches from Willoughby Spit to Little Creek in Norfolk, a distance of several miles. Johnson said cleanup would take several days and ``a lot of manual labor.'' Coast Guard workers and a private contractor strung oil-containment booms along the harbor protecting marinas and the Waterside Festival Park, a major shopping and tourist attraction. The region's main resort area, Virginia Beach on the Atlantic Ocean, would probably be spared, Johnson said. The Columbus America was taken to the Norshipco yard on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River. The ship had a hole below the water line and 12 of its cargo containers were severely damaged, he said. Six containers went overboard but were recovered. Johnson said, however, that none of the cargo containers leaked. Both vessels were carrying hazardous material, including petroleum distillates, paint and lacquer products. The Columbus America held about 140,000 gallons of fuel. Naccara said Coast Guard and Navy personnel spent most of the night stringing containment booms around the ship and using oil skimmers to pick up as much of the spill as possible. Naccara said a Coast Guard helicopter was in the air at first light to survey the extent of the spill. The accident happened as severe thunderstorms and high winds battered the area. The National Weather Service had issued a marine warning and severe weather watches for the area before the crash. The cause of the accident was under investigation, according to Coast Guard spokesman Rick Woods. Both the Coast Guard and the National Transportation Safety Board will take part in the investigation. Johnson said the crew had been given drug tests as a routine matter, but the results will not be available for at least a couple of days.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Says Racism Reigns in South Africa, Despite Reform
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with Mandela comments on sanctions, IRA, speech to Parliament; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Back in Europe after a triumphant U.S. tour, Nelson Mandela made an uncompromising appeal today to keep up sanctions, saying the racist system in South Africa remains fundamentally intact. He also put himself at odds with the British and Irish governments by calling on Britain to negotiate peace with the Irish Republican Army. The deputy president of the African National Congress arrived in Ireland from California on Sunday to a rapturous welcome. He was made an honorary citizen of the city of Dublin. Mandela today became the first foreigner except for heads of state to address a joint meeting of the 166-member parliamentary Dail and 60-member Senate. He delivered a 25-minute speech laced with allusions to Ireland's own struggle against ``unrelenting tyranny'' to achieve independence from Britain. He also declared that ``all the fundamental features of the South African racist system remain unchanged.'' South African President F.W. de Klerk has argued vigorously that foreign countries should end sanctions against his white government because of social reforms he has launched. Heralding the wave of change, Mandela was freed earlier this year. He had been in prison since 1962 and was serving a life term for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. Mandela flew to Ireland after an exhausting eight-city U.S. tour. Although 71 years old and nursing a bad cold, he looked well today as he took a walking tour of Leinster House, the seat of Parliament, before entering the packed chamber. His wife, Winnie, sat in the gallery. Earlier, at a news conference, he was questioned about his attitude toward the IRA, which is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland. While giving no hint of approval for the IRA's violent methods, Mandela said: ``The only way of resolving this conflict and of stopping this mutual slaughter ... is to sit down and talk.'' The British and Irish governments both maintain that talks can only be held with the constitutional parties of Northern Ireland that eschew violence. They say the IRA, outlawed on both sides of the border, represents only a small minority. Mandela, however, implied the situation was analogous to that of South Africa, where the white government had long insisted the African National Congress lay down its arms before negotiations. De Klerk's government has now launched talks, though the ANC has made no such concession. ``It is not for anyone of the involved parties (to say) that I can't talk to so and so, because this is a minority,'' Mandela said. Mandela's remarks risked annoying some of his British hosts when he flies to London later today. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who herself has narrowly survived an IRA bomb, is firmly against any compromise with the militants. She also disagrees with Mandela on sanctions, saying they should be eased in recognition of de Klerk's reforms. But Mandela was adamant, saying, ``This matter as to what the international community should be doing must be left entirely to ourselves; that is, the ANC.'' Mandela said de Klerk had asked to meet him as soon as he returned from his tour of Europe and the United States, ``and the reason for that is because sanctions are biting.'' In his address to Parliament, Mandela said ``a good start'' has been made toward negotiations between the government and the ANC. But he added: ``We should not mistake the promise of change for change itself.'' De Klerk says he wants to negotiate a new constitution that will bring blacks into the national government but allow whites to maintain veto power over major policy decisions. De Klerk opposes the one-person, one-vote system that the ANC is demanding. Before his public appearances, Mandela met today with State President Patrick Hillery and held an hourlong talk with Prime Minister Charles Haughey.

DOC.HEAD: Western Leaders Review an Outdated War Machine
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 6 grafs on change in NATO doctrine; picks up 3rd graf pvs, Bush, asked...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will urge NATO allies this week to modify nuclear weapons strategy and set the stage for the eventual withdrawal of nearly 1,400 nuclear-tipped artillery shells, U.S. officials said today. The proposed change would still leave U.S. nuclear weapons in Europe and retain a threat to use them in order to deter a blitzkrieg attack by Soviet forces against Western Europe, the officials told The Associated Press. But the nuclear facet of the doctrine of ``flexible response'' that has guided NATO since the 1960s would be changed under Bush's initiative. There still would be a threat to use nuclear weapons but only after NATO tried other military measures and it was clear a massive invasion of the Red Army could not be stopped otherwise, the officials said. The threat now is ``early first-use,'' an official said. ``The idea is to go to late first-use, or what might better be called no early-first use.'' The two main factors behind the proposed shift in policy are the projected withdrawal of thousands of Soviet troops and tanks from Europe and a decline in the strength of the Soviet-led Warsaw pact, the officials said. Bush and his NATO partners will meet in London on Thursday and Friday to celebrate the end of the Cold War and consider how to bring the now-outdated military alliance into line with a changing world. Bush, asked today if he expected major changes in NATO policy, said, ``What I expect is a ... document that is unanimously agreed to that will set the course for the future. As conditions have changed, NATO will change... some will call it dramatic policy changes and others won't.'' ``There will be some changes, but I don't happen to believe it's bombshell dimension,'' Bush said in Kennebunkport, Maine, where he is preparing for the London conference. The allied leaders will examine the aging NATO war machine and make some preliminary judgments about bringing it up to date _ but with considerably less firepower. The Bush administration, in pre-summit planning, has urged the NATO allies to reaffirm the strategy of keeping nuclear weapons in Europe. The Washington Post and The New York Times reported today that Bush is proposing that the United States and its western European allies make nuclear arms ``weapons of last resort.'' That would be a switch from the current ``flexible response'' strategy, in which nuclear weapons could be used early in a battle if Warsaw Pact conventional forces appeared to be gaining the upper hand. The New York Times also said Bush has proposed accrediting Eastern European and Soviet diplomats to NATO, although they would not be permitted to become members. Hungary, whose parliament last week voted in a non-binding resolution to leave the Warsaw Pact, has quietly proposed to NATO being allowed to participate as ``observers'' in political, or non-military, committees, a U.S. official said today ``It was a trial balloon and we welcomed it,'' the official, who insisted on anonymity, told The Associated Press. Meanwhile, U.S. officials, who spoke Sunday on condition of anonymity, said the Bush administration will consider eliminating U.S. nuclear stockpiles, including the artillery shells now deployed in West Germany, only if the Soviets withdraw their troops completely from foreign soil in Europe. The shells have a range of about 18 miles. The proposal is designed to reflect the warming Cold War tensions and the weakening of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. The officials stressed, however, that a communique to be adopted at the end of the two-day summit will reaffirm the policy of using nuclear weapons for deterrence. Bush in May, responding to the changed situation in Eastern Europe, decided against shipping new short-range nuclear Lance missiles to western Europe, but plans are proceeding to develop a new tactical nuclear air-to-surface missile called TASM. The officials said the summit communique would give far more attention to issues other than nuclear weapons. Specifically, they said, it would stress the need for NATO to take on more of a political character and also urge the strengthening of the 35-nation European Security Conference. That alliance was established in 1975 to lower East-West tensions. The 16 NATO allies have been exchanging ideas for the windup communique since the NATO foreign ministers held a preliminary meeting last month in Turnberry, Scotland. The final language has not been drafted, the officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Flooding Kills 108 in Southwestern Province
DOC.TEXT: Floods last month killed 108 people in a southwestern province, the official China News Service reported. The report, seen Monday, said more than 80 counties in Yunnan were hit by thunderstorms from June 18-22, causing flooding and landslides. Two small reservoirs burst, it said, and 1,159 homes collapsed. Many parts of China have received unusually heavy rain this year. More than 250 people died in flooding in central China's Hunan province last month.

DOC.HEAD: Black Banned at Service for Muppets Creator
DOC.TEXT: Well-wishers were asked not to wear black at a memorial service Monday for Muppets creator Jim Henson at London's St. Paul's Cathedral. Henson's family requested the ban, saying the event would be as much a celebration and thanksgiving for Henson's life as a traditional memorial service. Henson died in New York on May 16 after a bout with pneumonia. He was 53. He came to Britain in 1976 to make The Muppet Show, which became one of the most widely seen television programs in the world with an estimated 235 million viewers in 100 countries.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 30 Injured in Qantas Flight Turbulence
DOC.TEXT: More than 30 people were injured Monday when severe turbulence hit a Qantas 747 jetliner over Thailand as it was about to begin its approach into Bangkok, airline officials said. A Qantas spokesman in Sydney said the incident happened about 9:30 a.m. (7:30 p.m. EDT Sunday) when flight QF2 from London hit turbulence at 37,000 feet. He said the aircraft was lifted about 200 feet, and more than 30 of the 368 passengers were injured as the plane stabilized in flight. Two doctors on the flight treated the injured before the plane landed in Bangkok, where six people were taken to a hospital, the spokesmam said. The plane, which also carried 22 crew members, flew on to Melbourne later Monday. The spokesman said there was some damage to the interior of the cabin of the aircraft and said the incident was being investigated by the airline and the Australian Bureau of Air Investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Wartime Orphanage To Be Educational Museum
DOC.TEXT: A house where Jewish orphans lived during World War II will be made into a museum to commemorate 44 children arrested by Gestapo agents and sent to their deaths at Auschwitz. The Izieu Memorial Museum Association bought the house Monday from Marie Thibaudier, 80, for $300,000. She had lived in the home in Izieu, a small village east of Lyon, since 1950. The association president, Pierre-Marcel Wiltzer, said the home will be transformed into a museum featuring photographs, letters and drawings by the 44 children who were arrested on April 6, 1944 by the Gestapo. All of the children, who ranged in age from 5 to 17, died in the gas chambers at the Auschwitz death camp in Nazi-held Poland, as did six of the seven adults deported with them. Klaus Barbie, the ``Butcher of Lyon'' convicted of crimes against humanity in 1987, ordered the Izieu raid. A telex in which Barbie recounted to his superiors the roundup of Jews at Izieu was a key element in his trial. The house was purchased with government funds.

DOC.HEAD: Centennial Wagon Train Experiences Old and New Along the Dusty Trail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with group on its way, details of breakfast. Picks up 3rd graf, `Who knows.. '. SUBS 12th graf, `The wagon ... ' with 5 grafs to conform and ADD quotes. Wagon train expected to arrive in Cody around 3 p.m. EDT.
DOC.DATELINE: ALONG THE JIM BRIDGER TRAIL, Wyo. (AP)
DOC.TEXT: Remnants of the wagon trains that crossed Wyoming in the mid-1800s _ deep ruts, tin cups, gravestones _ have been meticulously preserved as symbols of the Cowboy State's pioneer heritage. But the 1990 Wyoming Centennial Wagon Train, with as many as 200 wagons and 1,600 riders re-creating the trek west, is forbidden to leave traces of its own passing. The group started its day this morning with a hearty breakfast of eggs, bacon and pancakes to help them complete the last dusty miles of the Jim Bridger Trail in honor of Wyoming's 100th birthday. The wagons and riders on horseback broke camp for the final 16 miles into Cody. Along the way, the group made sure not to leave behind any trash. ``Who knows what a Pepsi can will be worth in another 100 years?'' said cowboy and outfitter Kevin Lauer. ``We even have to cart our ashes out of camp each night.'' But 100-year-old trash is a different story. Under an agreement with the U.S. Bureau of Land Management, participants on the 30-day, 260-mile trip must not disturb the bits of history they encounter along the trail. ``A couple times we've had to move our camp to avoid the artifacts,'' said B.J. Wertz, a stagecoach driver and the wagon train's spokeswoman. ``They say, `Whoops, another arrowhead. Move three feet to the right.''' In addition, the federal agency will not allow the wagon train to camp on riverbanks, as the pioneers did, for fear of environmental damage. Instead, the modern-day pioneers have been camping most of the last 29 nights on the rough, dry prairie _ all the while loosely following the Jim Bridger Trail, established in 1864 as an alternate route to the gold fields of western Montana when tensions with Indians along the Bozeman Trail were high. ``There was such a thing as shade trees along the rivers,'' Lauer lamented, sporting a scraggly beard and a beat-up cowboy hat that looked as though it had put out a few fires. ``All we have is cactus, cactus and dust.'' But the riders are not complaining. It's the cactus, cactus and dust that bring the experiences of the early trailblazers to life. ``The only time I ever questioned being on this trip was when I found scorpions in my bed,'' said Carleen Bennett, 47. The wagon train today began its final leg into Cody, where a grand reception from well-wishers and dignitaries was planned. The wagon train left Casper on June 2 to celebrate Wyoming's centennial. For those on the trail, the last day meant different things. ``There's always the feeling that you made good friends and it's hard to say goodbye,'' said Morris Carter, one of the head wranglers responsible for circling the wagons each night. Other riders had had enough and wanted nothing more than to tie up their horses to the nearest hitching post in town and abandon the beasts. ``I definitely am ready for this wagon train to end,'' said Nancy Breithaupt, wearing a prairie dress and hat in the shade of a makeshift tent. ``You caught me at a bad time. It's been a tough day sitting in the sun.'' Like the pioneers who preceded them, the 1990 cowpokes are encountering rattlesnakes and frying them up for dinner, taking apart wagons to get them through deep ravines, nursing the injured that get bucked off horses and singing songs and playing fiddles in the center of the circled wagons at night. ``The only difference is they used the old Montgomery Ward catalog and we use toilet paper,'' said outrider Ron Brault. The riders do have some modern-day conveniences _ cellular phones, two-way radios, trucked in water and hay, outhouses and daily newspaper delivery. Other contemporary conveniences are missed. ``It's been hot and it's been freezing. That rainstorm was unbearable, and how do you get four or five layers of grit off your face and mud out of your teeth?'' said Helen Boreczky. ``I was blistered from the nose over on the first week of the trip. To think, they didn't have Chapstick back then. The Avon lady would have had a ball.'' ``In today's day, we're all used to the soft life, hot showers, phones. Back then they didn't know what they were missing,'' Lauer said. ``I don't think we could have done what they did 100 years ago, but our hardships are just as hard on us as theirs were on them.'' Still, there are alternatives to such things as a hot shower. ``You can always take a pail to the horse trough,'' said Lois Artzis of Billings, Mont. ``Horse slobber's never hurt anything.''

DOC.HEAD: Grateful Nation Prepares Welcome For Triumphant Losers
DOC.TEXT: Pride overcame dejection Monday as Cameroon prepared a grateful homecoming salute to its Indomitable Lions soccer team, among the most triumphant losers in World Cup history. ``For a defeat, it was more like a victory,'' state radio said after the Lions' close 3-2 overtime loss t England Sunday night. ``Honor to those who know how to struggle, head high,'' the radio added. Across Africa, the reaction was similar. Never before had an African team reached the World Cup quarterfinals, and the Lions' strong showing assured the continent of three representatives, instead of two, when the tournament is held again in 1994. ``Thanks, Cameroon,'' said a headline in Fraternite Matin, the government-owned daily in the Ivory Coast. Hoping there would be a victory to celebrate, Cameroon President Paul Biya had declared Monday a holiday. Many fans who had stayed up late to watch the match slept late, then reunited with friends to relive the highs and lows of their team's last match. There was a lingering sense of disappointment, due to the fact that the underdog Lions _ missing four suspended starters _ led 2-1 with only seven minutes left in regulation time. Had the game ended that way, it would have immortalized Onomo Disma, one of Cameroon's best-known sorcerers. In a nationally circulated newspaper Saturday, he predicted a 2-1 Cameroon victory _ apparently not foreseeing the late-game penalty call that allowed England to draw even. Preparations were under way to give the team a hero's welcome when it returns after a few days' rest in Italy. Also awaiting the players are bonuses offered by businessmen in Cameroon and elsewhere in Africa, including cars and cash. A campaign has begun to raise funds for a monument to Roger Milla, 38, who came out of retirement to score four World Cup goals. Across Africa, it seemed that virtually everyone with access to a television watched Sunday's game. Abidjan, the Ivory Coast's capital, came to a virtual halt. Restaurants normally full on Sunday nights were empty, and viewers huddled around TV sets in unusual places, including garages. ``The World Cup continues tomorrow without Africa,'' said Fraternite Matin. ``But no one will forget that Africa left its mark.''

DOC.HEAD: Fears of United Germany Run Deep as Western Changes Speed Forward
With AM-US-NATO, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fears of a united Germany's potential economic and military strength are lingering among European leaders who are trying to keep pace with the continent's changing political face. The fears bred from two world wars this century and West Germany's industrial power are in the background as the leaders gather to discuss the Western alliance. They're meeting this week in London just days after the biggest step yet toward unification with a merger of East Germany's economy into West Germany. German officials and American observers say neither the West nor the Soviet Union need fear military aggression. And they say a single Germany will provide healthy economic competition for new East Bloc markets. But the concerns over a new Germany's possible strength are deeply ingrained by the painful history of Germany's military past. Twice in this century, the United States and European allies have fought long wars against a Germany barely larger than the nation expected to be born of unification. The new Germany will have a population of approximately 80 million, far larger than that of Britain or France, and a gross domestic product equal to that of Britain and France combined. According to the private, nonprofit Council on Competitiveness, West Germany already outstrips the United States in investment in plant and equipment and in non-defense research and development, although not in investment in education. ``The Germans clearly will be the moving force behind the European union,'' said George A. Carver Jr., a fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies and former U.S. official in Germany. However, he added, ``I do not think a united Germany is a threat to the Soviet Union or anyone else.'' The Soviets, devastated in World War II, see it far differently. Moscow has balked at removing some 380,000 Soviet troops who remain on East German soil and objects to NATO's plans to absorb a united Germany into the Western military alliance. ``Everyone has legitimate historical reasons to be concerned about German reunification, there is no question about that,'' said Jay Kosminsky, deputy director of defense policy studies for the conservative Heritage Foundation. ``The Soviet Union is no different in this respect, except perhaps in the respect that it is better equipped to deal with Germany.'' Last week, Rita Suessmuth, president of the West German parliament, and her East German counterpart, Sabine Bergmann-Pohl, went to Jerusalem to tell Israelis that concern over a united Germany are unfounded. But the fear runs as deep for many Israelis as their memory that 6 million Jews were slain by German Nazis in the Holocaust of World War II. ``We have the right and maybe the obligation to be afraid and alarmed,'' said Shevac Weiss, a deputy speaker of the Israeli parliament who spent two childhood years hiding from the Nazis in a basement in the Ukraine. Henry Siegman, executive director of the American Jewish Congress, interviewed by telephone in New York, said that although Jewish scars may make them more concerned than others, ``they probably have far less at stake than most people. There aren't many Jews left in that part of the world. That's not where Jews live any more.'' Noting West Germany's record of democratic government and support of Israel, Siegman said, ``I don't believe that the circumstances that combined to produce an Auschwitz are likely to reappear on the world scene again.'' Jan Surotchek, a consultant with the Institute for Foreign Policy Analysis, which held a recent conference on German armed forces in a changing Europe, said he sees little likelihood of Germany becoming a military threat. ``I don't know how you can read over the history of German opinion of the military since the war and feel there is enough support either among the public at large or in the financial community or in the industrial community to do the kind of things that they have done before,'' Surotchek said. In trade, he said, ``The Germans are going to play it hard, but we should expect that. That doesn't seem to me to be an unfair thing.'' Kosminsky and Kim Holmes, director of foreign policy and defense studies for the Heritage Foundation, argued that the most dangerous course would be to cut Germany off from its NATO allies. ``Now, most Germans talk as if military power is something in the past,'' Holmes said at a briefing for reporters. ``This is because of the new situation, the dependence on the U.S. nuclear guarantee. What happens when that is gone? My view is that the old military balance of power logic will reassert itself and one of things that could happen is that the Germans themselves may some day want to find nuclear weapons.''

DOC.HEAD: Nebraska Board Declares Attorney Nelson Winner in Gubernatorial Primary
DOC.TEXT: An elections board today declared Ben Nelson the winner of the Democratic gubernatorial primary, declaring he had beat the runner-up by 42 votes in the closest such election in state history. The State Board of Canvassers voted 4-0 this morning to certify Nelson's victory over fellow Democrat Bill Hoppner. The vote means Nelson, an Omaha attorney, will challenge Gov. Kay Orr in the November general election. Hoppner, a former aide to Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., had urged the certification of his rival, saying he was still not satisfied with the way the recount was conducted but believed Nelson had won. He said his party needed to get on with the effort to defeat Mrs. Orr. The final tally showed Nelson won the election with 44,721 votes to Hoppner's 44,679. The board's decision came 48 days after the May 15 primary in which seven candidates sought the nomination. It followed an initial recount that was mandated by state law because the election was so close and a second recount of so-called undervotes in 21 counties. Undervotes are ballots, read by machine, that initially showed no vote for the governor's race. Attorney General Robert Spire made the motion to certify Nelson's victory. Spire said he was convinced that Nelson had indeed won the nomination. The Washington-based consulting firm Election Data Services said it was the closest primary or general election contest for governor in modern American politics. Spire's decision meant he chose not to ask the state Supreme Court to order three counties _ Gage, Cass and Butler _ to re-open sealed ballot boxes and count their undervotes. The three counties have refused to count undervotes, contending that only a court can order them to re-open the ballot boxes. Spire noted that undervote recounts in the other counties made no material change in the outcome.

DOC.HEAD: The Beach Bounces Back, But Some Remain Wary
DOC.TEXT: Blue skies, blue seas, brown bodies, white sands. The vista from the Belmar boardwalk captures all the elements of a perfect summer's day. This is as it should be, but not the way it's always been. Few people here can forget the summer of 1988, when the tide ran brown and carried sewage and syringes onto abandoned shores. This year, the beach is back. The water is clear and the ocean breezes carry the scent of salt water and suntan lotion. And yet, there's an undercurrent of uneasiness among those who care for the beach, a sense that the days of innocence are over. ``All it would take is two days of that northwest wind for that stuff to come washing in again,'' said Jack Roberts, lifeguard supervisor. It hasn't been an entirely pristine summer here or elsewhere around the country. Just as the season was beginning, an oil spill in New York Harbor sent dribbles of tar onto beaches in New Jersey and on New York's Long Island. A sewage spill closed three New York beaches last week. Oil from the tanker Mega Borg threatened beaches along the Texas coast. And at Huntington Beach in Southern California, heavy surf recently churned up buried oil from a tanker spill in February. But there has been nothing comparable to the pollution that slimed large stretches of the East Coast two years ago, and tourism seems to be rebounding in areas that were hurt. ``It looks to me like it's going to be a very good season,'' said Ralph Savastano, the owner of Ralph's Snack Shop on the Belmar boardwalk. ``The ocean's been good. They've cleaned up the ocean really good.'' The ocean is cleaner, in fact; at least that miniscule portion of it that laps onto New Jersey's shores. The state of New Jersey has enacted some of the nation's most stringent standards to monitor its water quality, and pollutants haven't exceeded those standards yet this year. Last year, excessive pollution forced beaches to close 19 times; in 1988, there were 68 closures. In Monmouth County, which includes Belmar, Public Health Coordinator Lester Jargowsky overflows with enthusiasm when he talks about the improvements. ``Positively, unequivocally, we have at this point the cleanest water you could ever jump into,'' he said. ``And I don't mean maybe.'' One reason is that New Jersey has stopped dumping raw sewage into the ocean; sewage spills caused many of the problems two years ago. Also, New York City has taken steps to keep its garbage from spilling close to shore. But there also is some element of luck _ as Roberts said, freakish winds were partly responsible for the mess in 1988. Nationwide, the Natural Resources Defense Council warned last week that water quality standards vary so widely from state to state and town to town that water that's considered polluted in one place might be considered clean in another. The council, a scientifically oriented environmental group, urged the federal Environmental Protection Agency to establish stricter national standards. ``No one should have to swim in waters laced with human waste,'' said council scientist Allen Hershkowitz. Roberts, who heads a crew of about 40 lifeguards, has been working on the beach for 25 years, as his deep tan attests. Through long stretches of that time, the water was brown and smelled foul. But he's upbeat about this year. ``This year, there hasn't been one day when I've hesitated about going in the water,'' he said. ``Other years, there have been whole summers when I wouldn't go in unless I had to.'' As befits someone who's spent his entire adult life on the beach, Roberts is eloquent about its attractions. ``The ocean, for one thing _ it's like Niagara Falls or the Northern Lights or something. ... It does something to your mind. It makes you feel younger, it makes you feel more romantic, it unleashes something that's locked up the rest of the year and can't get out.''

DOC.HEAD: Poll Finds Americans' Confidence Waning in Drug War
With AM-Poll-Method
DOC.TEXT: Nearly half of all Americans say drug abuse is plaguing their neighborhoods, and increasing numbers are skeptical about President Bush's multi-billion dollar war on cocaine, a poll has found. In September, just after Bush declared war on drugs, 74 percent of Americans believed the administration was making a serious effort to combat illegal drug use. But that confidence has fallen to 59 percent. At the same time, nearly half the respondents to the Media General-Associated Press poll said drugs are a serious problem where they live. That was up from 40 percent when Bush announced the campaign. Many respondents _ more than four in 10 of those under age 45 _ continued to say they know a cocaine user. And while most believed the government can reduce drug abuse, 55 percent expected the problem to worsen. Despite that concern, the poll found a sharp drop in the number of Americans citing drug abuse as the nation's greatest problem, down from 61 percent after Bush's speech to 24 percent now. But that gauge is one of the most sensitive to publicity, and Bush's remarks capped a months-long media focus on the drug crisis. Even though it fell sharply in the new survey, drug abuse remained the most-cited problem facing the country. The federal deficit was nex, named by 15 percent. Eighteen percent in the new poll said the problem of drug abuse is ``very serious'' in their own neighborhoods _ up from 14 percent in September _ and 30 percent said it was ``somewhat serious,'' up from 26 percent. The results confirmed the severity of the drug plague in poor areas: Poorer respondents were far more likely than the wealthiest to say drugs were a ``very serious'' problem in their neighborhoods. Of those earning less than $15,000 a year, 27 percent called the problem ``very serious''; among those earning more than $50,000, 16 percent said so. Blacks were twice as likely as whites to call the drug problem ``very serious'' in their neighborhoods, 35 percent to 17 percent. And blacks were far more likely than whites to say they personally know someone who uses cocaine, 52 percent to 31 percent. The survey also found stark evidence of the addictive power of cocaine or its smokable derivative, crack: Of the respondents who knew a cocaine user, half said they believed the user was addicted. That means one in six American adults personally knows a suspected cocaine addict. The new poll was conducted by telephone May 11-20 among a random sample of 1,143 adults. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points. When it comes to combating drugs, majorities continued to support strict measures against occasional users. Six in 10 said users' cars should be confiscated if drugs are found inside, and eight in 10 favored suspending their licenses. But cracking down on domestic drug dealers was the preferred line of attack, favored by 34 percent. Roughly two in 10 preferred cracking down on drug users or on foreign drug producers, and the rest had no preference. Nearly eight in 10 also continued to support higher federal taxes on cigarettes and alcoholic beverages to finance the drug war. Sixty-three percent supported a 1 percent increase in corporate income taxes _ down from 70 percent last fall _ and 45 percent favored a 1 percent increase in the income tax to pay for the fight against drugs. Still, more than a third of the respondents _ 36 percent _ said they believe the federal government cannot significantly reduce drug abuse in this country. Despite the administration's efforts, that level of doubt was up from 29 percent in the fall. Media General Inc., a communications company based in Richmond, Va., publishes the Richmond Times-Dispatch, the Richmond News Leader, the Tampa (Fla.) Tribune and the Winston-Salem (N.C.) Journal, and operates TV stations WXFL in Tampa, WCBD in Charleston, S.C., and WJKS in Jacksonville, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: World Cup Euphoria Provides Insights into Irish Identity
DOC.TEXT: Can the Irish love the English? Are they wrapped in a Celtic shell or part of the European whole? And when is an Irishman an Irishman? These are some of the intriguing issues that arise in the euphoria sweeping Ireland over its team's performance at the World Cup soccer tournament. From the prime minister to the 300,000 welcoming Irish who filled the streets of Dublin on Sunday, from the editorials in the press to the banter in a thousand pubs, all Irish eyes have been on team manager Jack Charlton and his lads. As one huge banner across the airport highway put it, banally but truthfully, ``Irish Eyes Are Smiling.'' That the team's accents are more English than Irish matters little. Nor does the fact that to Irish purists, soccer is a foreign import. That manager Charlton is a pure-bred Englishman does not prevent some pundits proposing he be made president of Ireland. And that Ireland was knocked out in the quarterfinals does not stop the nation behaving as though it won the cup. Reaching the quarterfinals, in Ireland's first appearance in the tournament, has been reason enough to fill the streets with the largest crowds seen in Dublin since Pope John Paul II visited in 1979. People stood for six hours for a glimpse of their heroes, waving everything from Irish flags to inflatable rubber shamrocks, they hung from trees, lampposts and the statue of Oliver Goldsmith outside Trinity College. The two open-topped doubledecker buses bringing the team from the airport needed three hours to inch through the throng, and though the Irish came home beaten the multitudes were singing: ``Oh we'll really shake 'em up@ When we win the Wor-orld Cup@ Yes Ireland is the greatest football team.'' The event cast interesting light on the myriad cultural and linguistic strands that bind Ireland to England, its ancient foe. Many of the Irish players belong to English league teams and are descendants of Irish emigrants. A couple of them claim Irish citizenship on the strength of a single grandparent. The team, commented The Irish Times, ``is a mixture of full-Irish, part-British and a variety of other races thrown in. The manager is a full-blown Geordie'' _ from the Newcastle area of northern England. But the captain, Mick McCarthy, said of the crowd Sunday, in a broad north England accent: ``They've made us feel very, very proud to be Irish. And despite what many people may say, every member of this team is 110-percent Irish.'' Irish sport can make potent politics. The Gaelic Athletic Association, long a vehicle of Irish nationalism, has always regarded soccer as an alien sport and still won't lend its stadiums to soccer matches. But an association official, Pat Daley, acknowledged that ``a greater degree of ecumenism is inevitable.'' In an interview, he noted that the association's Limerick chapter had proposed lending its ground to an Ireland-Soviet Union soccer game. ``Permission wasn't forthcoming,'' he said. But the very notion ``would have been unheard of 10 years ago.'' During the World Cup games, the association ran TV ads extolling its sports, trying to show that the sports of hurling and Gaelic football are more exciting than soccer. But for as long as Ireland was in the World Cup, no sport but soccer mattered. ``It was the most liberating few weeks I've ever experienced in Ireland,'' wrote columnist Nuala O Faolain in The Irish Times. Her paper felt the team ``brought us closer to the wider world _ including our near neighbors. They have brought about a great boosting of national morale which is not limited by class or creed or politics. ``They have shown that there is a way to be proud of being Irish, without triumphalism or resentment toward those of other races and traditions. They have done well for Ireland.'' Ireland played tenacious defense in the opening matches to gain a 1-1 tie with England, a scoreless tie with Egypt and a 1-1 deadlock with a strong Dutch team. In the second round, Ireland defeated Romania on penalty kicks to advance to the quarterfinals, where Italy defeated the Irish team 1-0 on Saturday.
