The big-hearted Irish gave most of their adulation not to home-grown heroes but to Charlton, the blunt, 55-year-old former soccer star who turned a nondescript team into one of the World Cup's top eight. The aircraft bringing the team home was renamed St. Jack in his honor, and the crowds chanted over and over, ``We Want Jack!'' As the Irish Press commented: ``If ... as our history shows, we have had a pretty raw deal from England over the past 800 years, then she has made some amends by giving us Jack Charlton.''

DOC.HEAD: Ooops: Literacy Cup Misspells Mayor's Name
DOC.TEXT: There was just one thing wrong with a commemorative cup issued to benefit the city's literacy program. The mayor's name was spelled wrong. The cups were distributed by Coca-Cola to vendors at the 10th anniversary celebration of Baltimore's redeveloped waterfront, which began Monday. They declared that proceeds would benefit ``the literacy initiative of Baltimore City's Mayor, Kurt L. Schnoke.'' Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke took the error in stride. ``I've heard it was a problem with the Coca-Cola print shop,'' said Schmoke, laughing at the typographical error. ``I guess I'll just have to stay around for another 10 years and see that they get it right next time.''

DOC.HEAD: Officials To Negotiate For Peace Corps Volunteer's Release
DOC.TEXT: Authorities will negotiate with Communist rebels rather than use military force to try to gain the release of a U.S. Peace Corps volunteer, a provincial official said Monday. Timothy Swanson, 26, of Cheyenne, Wyo., was kidnapped June 13 from his home in the village of Patag on the central island of Negros. He was taken by four to eight New People's Army guerrillas, who told his Filipino wife they were just ``borrowing'' him. Daniel Lacson, governor of Negros Occidental province, said he met Monday with U.S. officials, who gave him authority to work for Swanson's release. ``No military operation unless we exhaust political means,'' Lacson said. He said he would form a committee to negotiate with the rebels. ``The bottom line is to get Swanson alive,'' Lacson said. Swanson was among seven Peace Corps volunteers assigned to Negros, where he worked in a nursery project. The U.S. Embassy said it learned of the abduction only Saturday because the rebels warned Swanson's wife, a rural school teacher, not to report the incident. She did so only after U.S. officials ordered the 261 Peace Corps volunteers to leave the Philippines because intelligence reports indicated rebels might try to kill or kidnap them. Negros, 300 miles southeast of Manila, is a stronghold of the rebels, whose 21-year-old insurgency is aimed at establishing a Marxist state in the Philippines. On Monday, 15 people were killed in two separate battles between Communist guerrillas and government forces on Negros. They included three rebels killed about 20 miles south of Swanson's village. Four militiamen, an agricultural official and seven civilians were killed when rebels fired at them after their vehicle struck a rebel mine in the southern part of the island. Swanson's kidnapping has revealed signs of strained U.S.-Philippine relations. Officials in President Corazon Aquino's government accused the United States of overreacting to the rebel threat and one even hinted that Swanson may have defected. After the abduction was reported Sunday, presidential press secretary Tomas Gomez said it might have been avoided if U.S. officials had consulted with Philippine officials on security. Gomez was asked Monday whether _ given reports that Swanson was friendly with the rebels _ the volunteer might have gone with them freely. He said that was ``speculative'' but added: ``Of course, the telltale marks are there.'' He did not elaborate. Swanson's father, Leonard, said his son knew rebels in the area, but that he never considered them a threat. ``He tried to be friendly with all the folks in the village and all who he encountered,'' Swanson's father said in an interview in Cheyenne. In Manila, military chief of staff Gen. Renato de Villa said the government would try to free Swanson peacefully but would use force if necessary. U.S. Embassy spokesman Stanley Schrager said American officials were in Negros to discuss ways to win Swanson's release. He said no payment would be made to the guerrillas. President Bush, vacationing in Kennebunkport, Me., said Sunday that U.S. officials were ``very much worried'' by Swanson's abduction.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers Union Boss Criticizes Administrators
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with detail from Shanker's `state-of-the-union' speech, quotes from Barbara Bush, Michael Dukakis, updated union membership total. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `In the interview...'.
DOC.TEXT: Teachers union leader Albert Shanker says the public is grasping at radical school reforms because the educational system is not taking the initiative, and he blames foot-dragging administrators. In an interview on the eve of the American Federation of Teachers' annual convention, the president of the 744,000-member union said administrators have responded to the national clamor for better schools with ``a lot of public relations and no action.'' ``The country is 100 percent full of verbal commitment for change. But that's where it ends: verbal,'' he said Sunday. As the convention got under way this morning, he gave a ``state-of-the-union'' address, telling the 3,200 delegates that the group's membership has grown by 70,000 in the past two years and outlining achievements during the group's 75-year history. Shanker will deliver a second speech on Wednesday dealing with educational issues. He said in the interview it will likely include sharp criticism of school boards and superintendents who he says have failed to respond zealously to school reform. Shanker has said he also blames the Bush administration for a ``very poor record of commitment'' on implementing the national education goals agreed upon in February by Bush and the 50 governors. Still, Shanker opened the convention by reading a brief message from first lady Barbara Bush congratulating the union on its 75th anniversary. She said her work in literacy had taught her ``that teachers cannot do the job alone.'' Teachers reserved their warmest greeting for Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis, who told cheering delegates: ``We should be holding this convention in the East Room of the White House. There are some folks in Washington who could use some education.'' Other scheduled speakers at the AFT gathering this week include Senator Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., and U.S. Secretary of Education Lauro Cavazos. In the interview, Shanker said a central theme of this year's gathering will be his belief that radical school reorganization in Chicago and the spreading popularity of choice plans that let parents decide where to send their children to school are among growing signs of public impatience with the pace of reform. A resolution to be voted on by AFT delegates later this week reiterates the union's openness to choice schemes but adds the union's opposition to any such plan that includes public funding of private schools. Shanker said his union has been open to such reform ideas as choice and merit pay. But administrators have too rarely responded with leadership, he said. The convention runs through Thursday. The rival 2-million-member National Education Association will gather in Kansas City on Thursday through Sunday. Later today, the AFT was to release findings of its annual teacher salary survey showing average U.S. pay topping $31,000. Other issues to be tackled this week by teacher delegates include a resolution calling for phasing out standardized, multiple-choice testing, a notion the AFT considered dangerously radical less than a decade ago. The convention will also play host to some 60 foreign delegates, many of them from emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. A resolution would commit the AFT to helping budding democratic teacher unions in those countries. Jan Urban, a former Czechoslovak teacher who was instrumental in helping elect Czechoslavak President Vaclav Havel, will address the convention later in the week.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Japan Agrees on Anti-Monopoly Measures
DOC.TEXT: The Japanese government, moving to improve trade relations with the United States, agreed to toughen enforcement of anti-monopoly laws on companies in Japan, the Justice Department's top anti-trust official said Monday. The changes in laws against price-fixing, bid-rigging, group boycotts, and other practices should improve the ability of American companies to sell products in Japan, said James Rill, assistant attorney general for anti-trust. Lax anti-trust enforcement in Japan has been a major sticking point in talks to reduce the huge U.S. trade deficit with Japan. ``We are very, very positive about these steps by the Japanese for they represent in a one-year period a very, very substantial departure from the practices that existed before,'' Rill said of the agreement reached last week in Tokyo. The Japanese government has promised to step up criminal enforcement of existing laws, propose higher fines for civil anti-trust violations and make private lawsuits easier to pursue in Japan's courts. Tougher anti-trust enforcement is expected to reduce group boycotts of products, which some have called ``a way of life in Japan,'' Rill said. The changes should `` erase the hurdle posed by those boycotts on U.S. importation and other countries' importation of products into Japan,'' he said. Japan's Free Trade Commission also agreed to make public its legal and factual findings in anti-trust cases so that private plaintiffs can pursue lawsuits. The two nations announced agreement last week on a wide-ranging package of economic reforms aimed at eliminating many trade barriers and reducing disputes over trade issues that have soured the U.S.-Japan relationship. The United States currently runs about a $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. Rill dismissed the notion that the Japanese have a history of not keeping commitments on trade matters. ``We don't believe they would make these public commitments after such arduous talks over such a long period of time without an intention to follow through on them,'' he said. The procurement and transport ministries have agreed to increase efforts to root out bid-rigging and to increase the time that companies guilty of such collusion would be barred from getting government contracts, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Precede NEW YORK
General Didn't Tell Superiors About Stealth's Failure
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with Pentagon comment; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The chief of the Tactical Air Command learned after the Panama invasion that stealth fighter-bombers missed their targets but did not tell his superiors because he believed others had done so, a spokesman said today. Col. Ron Sconyers, a spokesman for Gen. Robert D. Russ, said in a telephone interview from Tactical Air Command headquarters at Langley Air Force Base, Va., that it was at least 10 to 15 days after the operation before Russ learned of the missed targets. Sconyers said Russ assumed that officers who were in the operational chain of command for the invasion, as he was not, would have informed their superiors at the Pentagon and that it was not necessary for him to do so. The spokesman said Russ did take steps to improve training as a result of the information he had received. The New York Times, reporting on what it said was a classified Air Force report said in today's editions that the lack of information led Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to brag about how accurate the bombing had been when bombs actually missed by as much as 160 yards. The newspaper also said the report concluded there were defects in planning the Panama operation, confusion over the mission of the planes, poor coordination between the Army and the Air Force in picking targets and inadequate pilot training for the weather conditions over the targets. Russ gave the newspaper a statement saying he had left it up to Army commanders to tell the Pentagon how the invasion fared. Sconyers said neither he nor Russ had seen the classified report. ``General Russ eventually knew that the aircraft had missed its targets, but not early on,'' Sconyers said. In the Panama operation, the spokesman said, Russ, whose command controls the Air Force fighter planes, ``is basically just a supplier of aircraft; he is not part of the operational chain of command.'' ``Because he wasn't part of the operational chain of command and doesn't receive or generate operational reports, he made the assumption that that would be done through the operational chain of command,'' Sconyers said. ``In hindsight he would have done it a little differently,'' the spokesman said. ``There was never any intent on Gen. Russ' part at all to withhold information,'' he said. ``In fact, he acted on that information and made some training decisions based on that information.'' ``There is always some confusion in the reporting of any military operation, and I didn't want to add to it,'' Russ' statement said. He added: ``When I look back at what has transpired, it is evident that more detail should have been forwarded.'' The report on the performance of the F-117A, called stealth for its ability to avoid radar detection, was prepared by the Air Force inspector general, Lt. Gen. Bradley C. Hosmer. Cheney had demanded an explanation following reports that a bomb from one of the two planes had actually hit a hillside some distance from the intended target. After receiving the report, Cheney's spokesman said May 31 that Cheney was satisified that Air Force officials didn't try to mislead him.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Says Housing Slightly More Affordable in May
DOC.TEXT: Rising incomes and falling mortgage rates and prices boosted the typical American family's ability to buy an existing single-family home in May, a real estate trade group said Monday. The National Association of Realtors said its housing affordability index was 105.6 in May, up from 104.3 the previous month. That means a family earning the national median income of $34,142 had 105.6 percent of the income needed to qualify for conventional financing covering 80 percent of the median-priced home costing $94,800. The median income means of half the families earned more and half less. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less. Because the national median income in May exceeded the qualifying income, a family earning $34,142 could purchase a home priced at $100,300. The median price of a home declined $800 in May, while incomes rose $110. Mortgage rates edged downward from 10.15 percent to 10.14 percent. ``Home buying conditions were good in May and while they could have been better, 105.6 is an extremely healthy level,'' said Realtors President Norman D. Flynn. ``During the early 1980s, when interest rates were nearing the 20 percent mark, the index was in the low 70s.'' Flynn said the Realtors expect rates to hover just under 10 percent for the rest of the year. The mortgage rate used to calculate the index is a composite of closing rates offered for fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages for existing homes as reported by the Federal Housing Finance Board. Changes in the national median home price and the average mortgage rate from April to May resulted in a $7 decrease in the monthly mortgage payment to $673, the Realtors said. Under May's affordability conditions, the Realtors said, a family earning $20,000 would have sufficient income to qualify for a $58,800 home using a loan covering 80 percent of the cost. A family earning $30,000 would qualify for an $88,100 home, while a family earning $40,000 would have sufficient income for a $117,500 home and a family with a $50,000 income would qualify for a $146,900 home.

DOC.HEAD: Troubles Of Space Shuttle Still Puzzles Engineers
DOC.TEXT: NASA engineers said today they must find and quickly fix a hydrogen leak that has grounded the space shuttle fleet or the agency will have to postpone still more shuttle missions. Space shuttle chief William Lenoir said it was still not known what caused a hydrogen leak in two of the nation's three space shuttles, but he said the problem must be fixed within a few weeks to keep NASA anywhere near its ambitious flight schedule. Columbia was to have been launched in May on an astronomy mission. The schedule called for other launches by Atlantis in July, Columbia again in August and then Discovery in October. A leak in Columbia's hydrogen system in May and the discovery last week of a similar leak on Atlantis scrambled that NASA launch schedule and Lenoir said it is unclear now if the agency can recover in time to fly all the missions this year. Discovery's flight cannot be changed because its cargo is the Ulysses science probe that is to study the sun. The craft must be launched during a planetary alignment that occurs only once in every two years. ``We're right on the edge of the point where two flights no longer fit in the schedule before the launch of Ulysses,'' said Lenoir. Fixing the leak, he said, will have to be quick and simple to avoid more changes in the NASA launch schedule. Parts of Columbia are being tested in a laboratory and Lenoir said that Atlantis may again be tested on the launch pad at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The engineers, he said, should have more answers by Thursday. Meanwhile, an investigation should start formally later this week on why the Hubble Space Telescope was launched with a flawed focusing system. Engineers testing the orbiting space telescope found last week that either the primary or the secondary mirrors on the $1.5 billion telescope were flawed so badly that starlight could not be focused as precisely as had been planned. The poor focus seriously affects how well the telescope can study the universe. NASA chief scientist Lennard Fisk said that scientists are working to determine how the unfocused light can be manipulated by computer to give clear pictures of the distant stars. ``There are two characteristics of the people who work for NASA: We're stubborn and we're clever,'' said Fisk. ``We're going to make this thing work.'' Fisk said that the agency will complete the appointment of an investigation committee this week. He said the investigation would review the entire history of Hubble and should find answers for why the mirrors are flawed.

DOC.HEAD: Californians Brace For More Of The Same After Devastating Fires
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with efforts to put out hot spots; estimates on when fire would be declared out; 50 people cited for allegedly sightseeing at emergency scene; fixes typo in `Information' in 2nd graf pvs, ```It's a ...' picks up 3rd graf, pvs, `The worst ...'. SUBS 7th graf, `Elsewhere, large...', and last graf to UPDATE size of Colorado fire.
DOC.TEXT: Homeowners trimmed trees and cleared brush to deny fuel for future fires as officials warned relief from blazes that scorched tens of thousands of acres may be short-lived in the drought-plagued region. At the scene of the worst devastation, Santa Barbara County fire Capt. Charlie Johnson said firefighters would be putting out hot spots all day, using a helicopter with infrared cameras to spot danger areas. Gusts to 35 mph had flared up without warning from forecasters, he said. ``It caused some edginess because those crews didn't expect it to come up,'' Johnson said. The blaze was expected to be declared controlled by Tuesday morning. But because of the possibility of flare ups, some personnel might stand by for a week or 10 days, Johnson said. At least 50 people were cited on charges of sightseeing at an emergency scene, a misdemeanor that can be punished with a $500 fine and six months in jail, sheriff's spokesman Tim Gracey said. He said there was no evidence that anything had been stolen: ``To be honest with you, there's not a heck of a lot left to steal.'' However, the gapers were going around roadblocks and interfering with utility crews and residents, he said. ``There's nothing anyone could find in there, but it's irritating to think someone was trying,'' said John Warkentin, who said someone combing the ruins of his house had moved a filing cabinet and opened its drawers. The improved fire picture did not mean the state's problems were over, officials said. ``It's a reprieve, not the end,'' Arnold Hartigan, spokesman for the National Fire Information Center in Boise, Idaho, said Sunday. ``We've got a long summer to go yet.'' The worst of the fires, the 4,900-acre blaze that leveled an estimated 430 houses and 28 apartment buildings on the fringe of Santa Barbara, was contained Saturday evening. Ten businesses and four public buildings also were burned. The Glendale fire, which destroyed dozens of homes in Los Angeles County, was out. Major fires that burned thousands of acres in San Diego, Riverside and San Bernardino County also were either controlled or contained, meaning fire lines had been cut around them. The widely scattered fires _ ranging from Santa Barbara 200 miles south to San Diego County, killed two people, destroyed or damaged 520 homes and burned 22,000 acres, officials said. Early estimates of the financial loss topped $250 million. At least five of the fires were believed set, officials said. Elsewhere, large blazes were brought under control in Arizona and Texas, and firefighters hoped to have a 3,875-acre blaze in Colorado under control by Tuesday. Hartigan said there was a special danger of new fires in the region left tinder dry by four years of drought during this week's Fourth of July holiday if people do not curb traditional fireworks celebrations, he said. ``The idea we're trying to get across, especially now, is that brush, woods and fireworks do not mix,'' Hartigan said. ``It's not a good idea to take fireworks, legal or not, out into the woods or brushy canyons to set them off.'' With a presidential disaster declaration for Los Angeles and Santa Barbara counties made Saturday, Federal Emergency Management Agency Offices were expected to be opened by Tuesday. Structural losses in Santa Barbara County were put at $238 million, but county Supervisor Bill Wallace said the value might top $500 million. The Santa Barbara fire, which killed a woman, was set about 6 p.m. Wednesday by an arsonist. No arrests have been made. Scores of sightseers on Sunday parked along San Marcos Pass Road to gaze at the charred brush and firefighters at work. ``I think the whole thing is incredible _ that an arsonist could do so much damage,'' said Irv Bromberg, a tourist from Coral Springs, Fla. Another fatality occurred in Riverside County, where an inmate firefighter died of burns suffered in a blaze near Hemet. In Arizona, meanwhile, the worst wildfire in the state's history was contained Sunday after burning 28,480 acres in the Tonto National Forest, killing six firefighters and destroying the historic Zane Grey cabin here. At at Guadalupe Mountains National Park in Texas, firefighters used helicopters and tanker planes to contain a stubborn, 6,014-acre blaze. Firefighters in Colorado said they hoped to have the 3,875-acre Horesfly Creek fire near Norwood in the southwestern part of the state under control by Tuesday. Earlier reports indicated the fire was spread over 4,100 acres, but infrared film gave a more accurate picture, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: They'll Parade Into Wedded Bliss
DOC.TEXT: When Lisa Fowler and Jeff Clark say ``I do,'' a speed boat will be their altar and a Fourth of July parade their cathedral. The couple agreed to be married in the most public of ceremonies for a promotion by Lexington radio station WKQQ. ``We're always out to do something just a little bit off the wall, especially for the Fourth of July parade,'' Linda Faircloth, the station's promotions and marketing director, said Monday. Clark and Miss Fowler, both 23 and from Frankfort, will exchange vows while standing in a 16-foot speed boat the station is giving away in a separate promotion. A magistrate dressed like a ship's captain will preside. The station offered a seven-day honeymoon cruise to the Bahamas to the selected couple. Forty couples applied.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending Down 2nd Straight Month
DOC.TEXT: The construction industry remained in a slump in May as spending dropped 0.4 percent for its second straight monthly decline, the government said Monday. ``Private spending has been weak and probably will remain weak for the next few months,'' said David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association. Government spending also will slow, ``given the large budget deficits at all levels.'' Added David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders: ``The second quarter certainly is shaping up to be a negative.'' The Commerce Department reported that residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $445.6 billion after falling 2.2 percent in April. The April decline was even worse than the 0.7 percent drop first reported last month. March spending, on the other hand, was revised upward from a 0.7 percent decrease to a 0.4 percent increase. Residential construction fell 2.2 percent to an annual rate of $199.7 billion after a 1.4 percent decline in April. Single-family building dropped 3.9 percent to $115.8 billion on top of a 3.8 percent decline a month earlier. Berson attributed the falloff in residential building to high interest rates and declining demand after 7{ years of a growing economy. Builders also have complained of tighter restrictions on lending following the savings and loan debacle. Nevertheless, apartment building posted a second straight monthly increase. Spending was up 1.0 percent to an annual rate of $20.6 billion after gaining 2.0 percent in April. Non-residential spending, however, fell 1.7 percent to an annual rate of $101.6 billion after sliding 1.4 percent in each of the previous two months. Part of the problem in this sector, Berson said, is high vacancy rates, particularly in office buildings, in many parts of the country. The volatile government spending area nearly recovered its 4.9 percent loss in April, rebounding 4.4 percent to an annual rate of $109.1 billion. The total construction figure was up 2.5 percent from the level of a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Ordered To Apologize in Ads to Man Falsely Accused of Rape
DOC.TEXT: A woman who falsely accused a man of raping her was ordered to run radio and newspaper advertisements apologizing to him. But the man says the sentence will not undo the damage. ``You can't change a wrong to a right,'' said Gary Nitsch. ``I lost a job. I had to get a lawyer. The kids at school were saying to my kids, `Your dad's a rapist.''' And the ads may never be printed or aired. Elizabeth Irene Richardson, 24, is considering appealing the sentence, which the Nebraska Civil Liberties Union says may be cruel and unusual punishment. Ms. Richardson accused Nitsch, 44, of Overton, of raping her in September 1988. He was arrested and charged with sexual assault. Ms. Richardson testified that Nitsch raped her, but the case was dropped for lack of strong physical evidence. Word later reached authorities that Ms. Richardson told friends the rape was a hoax. She was convicted of perjury last February. County Attorney John Marsh said the woman's motives centered on trying to get the attention of her husband, a truck driver who was often away from home. A judge ordered Ms. Richardson to apologize to Nitsch in a half-page advertisement in every newspaper and a spot on each radio station in Dawson County, a county of about 22,000 in central Nebraska. The media campaign was expected to cost about $1,000, her attorneys say. She also was sentenced to 180 days in jail and was placed on two years' probation. A panel of state civil liberties union attorneys who reviewed the case said the sentence may violate Ms. Richardson's rights under the Eighth and 14th amendments. The Eighth Amendment protects against cruel and unusual punishment and the 14th ensures due process. The organization is ``concerned about the scarlet letter approach in sentencing,'' said Bill Schatz, NCLU executive director. ``Suppose someone is arrested for shoplifting. Are we going to make him wear a sign saying he's a convicted shoplifter? Is there such a thing as punishment fitting crime?'' If the case is appealed, the organization will offer research services and may file a friend-of-the-court brief, Schatz said. Nitsch said he was still puzzled how his name came up. He said he met Ms. Richardson once in the spring or summer of 1988 when he went to her house inquiring about a painting job she had advertised. ``I would just like to have someone tell me how I was named,'' he said. He says his ordeal has taken a toll on his family. He said his wife, Naomi, ``doesn't like to come to town and face people.'' His 18-year-old daughter quit high school in March because of the way she was treated, Nitsch said. ``We've lived in a trailer house since 1973,'' he said. ``We're saving for a home, but when you have attorneys' fees, it's hard.'' Nitsch said he was fired from his job as a driver after being questioned at work by authorities and jailed three days. He's now a part-time construction worker. He said he wants a full-time job but ``people want clean help. They don't want somebody that's been in trouble with the law.'' ``I used to go into town and drink coffee and joke with people, but everything just kind of turned sour,'' Nitsch said. ``The first year, I was so depressed I didn't even want people to see me,'' he said. ``If I went into town I had to have somebody drive me so I could scoot down in the seat so nobody would see me.'' Nitsch said he is also bitter about the way authorities handled his case. His attorneys are suing four sheriff's deputies for $100,000, alleging he was arrested and his home was searched without cause. ``Mr. Nitsch is apparently the victim of some lies. But that is not the fault of the sheriff's department,'' said Randy Goyette, an attorney representing the Dawson County Sheriff's Office. Jim O'Rourke, now a district court judge, was Dawson County attorney at the time. ``I believe that the case was very professionally and accurately handled,'' O'Rourke said. ``We went with what we had and we did the best we could.'' O'Rourke said Ms. Richardson decided not to pursue the case after he told her the trial would be difficult for her without corroborating physical evidence. O'Rourke said he never doubted her story, but added, ``I think it's been established that he's been a victim.''

DOC.HEAD: New Chancellor Takes Over at UC-Berkeley
DOC.TEXT: Chang-Lin Tien, a native of China, took over Monday as chancellor of the University of California, Berkeley. He said he would work to fight racism on campus. ``I will do everything possible to enhance and promote diversity and freedom and justice,'' Tien said recently. ``But I also realize it will take some time.'' Tien, who replaces Ira Michael Heyman as chancellor, said he supports the university's ``fighting words'' policy, under which students who verbally harass or abuse other students are subject to punishment such as dismissal. ``I want to improve the campus environment so everyone feels comfortable,'' he said. Heyman is returning to teaching and research at UC's Boalt Hall School of Law. Tien, 54, is a scientist and engineer who's taught at Berkeley for 29 years. He was born in Wuhan, China, but his family was uprooted to Japan during World War II. In 1949, during the Communist revolution in China, the family moved to Taiwan. At National Taiwan University, Tien pursued studies in mechanical engineering and took up a serious interest in basketball. When he arrived in the United States in the 1950s, the 5-foot, 6-inch Tien had his hopes for a professional basketball career dashed. He earned a master's degree in mechanical engineering at the University of Louisville and at Princeton University. At Berkeley, he became the youngest professor to earn the Distinguished Teaching Award at age 25 for pioneering research in heat transfer.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman of Stamp Advisory Committee Retires
DOC.TEXT: Belmont Faries is retiring as chairman of the committee that recommends subjects for new postage stamps, the U.S. Postal Service announced Monday. Faries, of Livingston, Mont., has headed the Citizen's Stamp Advisory Committee for 15 years and will remain a committee member. Jack Rosenthal, president of Clear Channel Radio Inc., in Casper, Wyo. was selected as the new committee chairman by Postmaster General Anthony Frank. The committee recommends stamp subjects to Frank, and participates in the selection, design and reproduction decisions. In addition to Faries and Rosenthal, committee members are Richard Coyne, Palo Alto, Calif.; John E. Foxworth Jr., West Bloomfield, Mich.; Ann DeWitt Harvey, Sudbury, Mass.; C. Douglas Lewis, Washington; Virginia Noelke, San Angelo, Texas; Also Mary Ann Owens, Brooklyn, N.Y.; Richard ``Digger'' Phelps, Notre Dame, Ind.; Jerry Pinkney, Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., Beatrice Sanchez, Kansas City; John Sawyer III, Kingwood, Texas and George Stevens Jr., Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Argues Evidence is Strong Enough to Convict Buckey
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor urged jurors today to convict Raymond Buckey of child molestation, but said the decision must be based on more than the testimony of three children. ``I would not ask you to convict the defendant in this case based solely on the testimony of the children,'' said Deputy District Attorney Pam Ferrero in her closing argument. ``The children's testimony is corroborated by the circumstantial evidence in this case,'' she added. She told jurors they should look at videotapes made during the children's interviews at a child therapy center and read the expressions on the children's faces rather than listening to their words to determine whether they were molested. She said the children had sometimes denied being molested because of threats from Buckey that the youngsters' parents would be killed if they told what had happened to them at the McMartin Pre-School in Manhattan Beach. ``This particular case boils down to credibility,'' the prosecutor said. ``Who do you believe? If you believe the children, then the people have proved their case beyond a reasonable doubt.'' However, she conceded that the children's testimony was not clear on all points and required corroboration. She also warned jurors that the three girls who testified during the trial had been through so many different interviews and witness-stand appearances during the past seven years that their testimony might be contradictory. Buckey is being tried for the second time on eight counts of child molestation. The first trial ended Jan. 18 with Buckey's mother acquitted of all charges and Buckey acquitted of 40 counts of molestation. Jurors deadlocked on 13 other charges against Buckey, however, and prosecutors refiled eight of those counts. ``What would you be able to relate to after this number of testimonies and interviews?,'' Ms. Ferrero asked. She said some of the children were ``telling the story for the umpteenth millionth time.'' As Ms. Ferrero spoke, the 32-year-old Buckey, wearing a dark suit and tie, sat at the counsel table with his lawyers and looked directly at jurors. He has testified that he never molested any children while he was a teacher at his family's now-defunct preschool.

DOC.HEAD: West German Labor, Management Duel on East German Frontier
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's biggest union gave a glimpse of its power to mobilize East Germany's anxious work force Monday by orchestrating a series of strikes by thousands of factory workers. A West German employer group also is advising East Germany's newly private enterprises on how to deal with their increasingly militant workers. One day after East Germany merged its economy with the West and opened its borders to the free market, the West Germans were taking their labor-management struggle to the new economic frontier of the East. About 3,000 workers staged a one-hour warning strike at the giant Locomotive Electronics Works in Hennigsdorf, a city of brown brick factories and 25,000 people about 12 miles northwest of Berlin. They were among 30,000 workers in 10 factories around Berlin who staged brief strikes or protests Monday as a prelude to wage talks between management and the powerful IG Metall labor union. The union, which has 2.7 million West German members, has added 1.7 million East German metalworkers to its new East German affiliate since last autumn's revolt against communism. The union is demanding wage increases and guaranteed jobs as East Germany begins its transition to a market economy, a process expected to result in widespread factory closings and joblessness. ``If Kohl wants to go into the annals of history, he'll have to pay for it,'' said local union leader Karl-Heinz Graffenberger, referring to West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's swift push for German unification. Graffenberger and other union leaders spoke to thousands of workers who put down their tools at 1 p.m. and marched out of the sprawling factory complex, which produces locomotives, welding equipment and other metal products. The crowd gathered at the factory's clubhouse to hear speakers demand better wages to keep pace with the higher-priced Western goods now filling East German stores. The rally concluded minutes before IG Metall leaders from both German states began talks with representatives for 151 factories around Berlin, representing about 200,000 workers. IG Metall has been financing and advising the East German labor movement, and handed out 90,000 fliers alone on Monday to workers around the region. ``We tell our colleagues how things like this work,'' said Wolfgang Berger, a union organizer from IG Metall headquarters in Frankfurt, West Germany, who was at Monday's strike rally. But the employer group, the Association of Metal and Electronics Industries, is also being advised by its Western counterpart, with which it will merge on Sept. 25, said a spokesman. Christoph Borchelt, a West German who is spokesman for the East German employer association, said East German factories are too vulnerable now to withstand serious labor unrest. ``These companies have absolutely no money,'' he said. He called the demands by the union ``very massive.'' Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere warned workers last week that strikes only would worsen the threat of mass unemployment as the country's aging, overstaffed enterprises are forced to compete with Western businesses. The giant locomotive factory, however, is one of the stronger East German enterprises and exports goods to Greece, Brazil and several East bloc countries, said Wilhelm Kuenzel, head of the supply division. But he said some operations of the company are unprofitable and only are being continued to avoid layoffs. He said 500 jobs on Friday were eliminated, all by early retirements. Under the currency union, East Germans had their wages converted from nearly worthless East German marks to West German marks at an artificially high 1-1 exchange. But workers who walked off their jobs Monday said they need Western-style wages to keep pace with the prices of Western products now filling East German stores. Workers at the locomotive factory make about 1,000 marks, or $600, and the union is demanding a 400-mark _ $240 _ increase. The average East German now earns about 1,200 West German marks _ $720 a month _ less than half the average West German salary. However, East German rents and other basic items will be kept low for a while to help compensate. But Kerstin Arendt, 21, an inventory worker, who makes 640 marks per month after deductions, or $390, said housing, heating and food costs already are skyrocketing. ``With 600 marks you don't get very far,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: West German Currency Stays Powerful After Introduction Into East Germany
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The West German mark remained strong Monday in closely watched trading sessions that followed the powerful currency's introduction into East Germany. Currency dealers said the mark also was strengthened by the possibility of U.S. tax increases to combat an American deficit. The mark was fixed at 1.6538 to the dollar in Frankfurt, up from 1.6715 marks on Friday. In London, the mark was pegged at 1.6535 to the dollar, up from 1.6635 marks on Friday. The stock market in Frankfurt on Monday also reacted favorably to the first business day of economic union and the German Stock Index climbed to 1,912.58 from 1,879,90 on Friday. Dealers remained optimistic that the West German stock market could be set for a continued rising trend if the economic union progesses smoothly to keep the inflation rate down. Although markets were steady to improved, one dealer cautioned that warning strikes at some East German factories on Monday could be troubling to money and stock markets. According to the powerful IG Metall metalworkers union, which is heading negotiations for new labor contracts in East Germany, thousands of people took part in brief warning strikes at more than 20 plants to press demands for more pay and better working conditions. During the past several days, West German central bank officials have repeatedly emphasized that the dangers of inflation from economic union previously anticipated by some experts had waned. The West German government said it was very satisified with how smoothly the currency union was going. The people in East Germany ``have with the D-mark won their freedom as consumers. They will make intelligent use of that,'' deputy government spokesman Dieter Vogel said at a news conference in Bonn. West Germany sent 25 billion marks ($15.1 billion) from its national bank's cash reserves of new bills to cover initial phase of economic unification. No new money had to be printed to cover the project. Finance Minister Theo Waigel said in a Sunday news conference that only one fourth ($3.79 billion) of the new West German marks were withdrawn in cash by the East Germans. They were able to exchange a limited mumber of East German marks for West German marks at a 1-1 rate, but kept most of it in their their bank and savings ccounts. Moderate withdrawals from accounts by the East Germans averaged only about 800 marks ($485), far below the limit of 2,000 marks ($1,200) set under the rules. Dealers said that kept the amount of new money in circulation far below the expected high, resulting in a strong and steady mark on world markets. Stores throughout East Germany reported that most customers were closely checking new prices and not rushing to make purchases.

DOC.HEAD: Injured Alaska Sled Dog Retraces 250-Mile Trek in Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to CLARIFY that husky was flown back to Alaska after retracing Soviet trek. Picks up 5th graf, ``I saw ...''
DOC.TEXT: A lost and injured Alaska sled dog retraced the route of a 250-mile sled dog trip it took with its owner along the Soviet coast. The white husky named Vixen was found at the starting point of the sled dog trip, and was flown to Alaska where it was reunited Sunday with its owner, Sue Steinacher of Nome. Steinacher, an artist and teacher, thought she had seen the last of Vixen on April 13 after completing a sled trip from the Soviet city of Provideniya to the Soviet village of Uelen. A biplane carrying her, two Soviet mushers and about 30 dogs crashed after takeoff from Uelen on the Bering Strait, which separates the Soviet Union and Alaska. A Soviet musher died in the crash, along with two of Steinacher's dogs. Vixen and another dog were missing. ``I saw her running around outside the plane. She was in bad shape,'' said Steinacher, who suffered four broken ribs and bruises in the crash. ``The people in Uelen tried to catch these dogs. A friend of mine there would take walks in the evening and try to find them. One of the hunters was leaving food at the crash site,'' she said. But Vixen eluded villagers. ``She was a very shy dog.'' Steinacher disputed one report that Vixen was seen in another village between Uelen and Provideniya. Then there was another account that Vixen had been shot by Siberian Eskimos defending wild reindeer herds from wolves. But it was her other missing dog that was shot and killed. Then Asanassi Makovnev, the leader of an earlier sled dog expedition, flew to Provideniya to check out another white-dog report. It was Vixen, who had taken up residence in a half-buried pipe. Makovnev coaxed the frightened animal from her lair, and Vixen finally arrived home Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: US Drops Deeper In Debt
With AM-US Debt Table
DOC.TEXT: The United States tightened its grip on the title of world's largest debtor nation in 1989, ending the year with a net debt of $663.7 billion, up a sharp 25 percent from the previous year. The latest figures, based on data collected by the Commerce Department, are certain to heighten the emotional debate over whether the United States is losing control of its financial destiny to foreigners. The Commerce Department report showed that U.S. holdings of overseas assets rose by $146.9 billion last year to $1.412 trillion, a gain of 11.6 percent. But foreign holdings in the United States climbed at an even faster pace of 15.6 percent, rising by $279.6 billion to $2.076 trillion. The $663.7 billion imbalance between what Americans own overseas and what foreigners own in the United States is the country's net debtor position. Many private economists believe it will top $1 trillion within a few years. As recently as 1983, the United States was still the world's largest creditor nation, a position now held by Japan. The 1983 surplus of $89 billion fell to $3.3 billion in 1984 and disappeared altogether in 1985, the year the country became a net debtor for the first time in 71 years. The surplus was eroded by America's huge merchandise trade deficits as Americans transferred billions of dollars into foreign hands to pay for imported cars and television sets. Those dollars have been reinvested in everything from U.S. Treasury bills to prime real estate in many American cities, raising cries that foreigners are buying America. The Commerce Department reported that 54 percent of the increase in foreign holdings in 1989 came from direct investment, defined as at least 10 percent ownership of a company. Britain retained its position as the country with the largest amount of direct investment in the United States at $119.14 billion, a 17 percent increase over the 1988 level. Japan was No. 2 with $69.70 billion in direct investment, up 31 percent from 1988. The largest Japanese transaction last year was Sony Corp.'s $3.4 billion purchase of Columbia Pictures. While supporters defend the foreign buying surge as proof of America's attractive investment opportunities, critics contend that the development shows that the United States has become overly dependent on foreign capital to finance its huge budget and trade deficits. ``The United States is going ever more in debt. That keeps interest rates higher in this country because of the need to attract foreign capital and it hurts our ability to compete internationally in a number of ways,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. The Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis took the unusual position of deleting the debtor position from Monday's report although it supplied enough detail that it was a simple matter to arrive at the bottom-line figure. BEA Director Allan Young denied that there had been any pressure from the Bush administration to obscure a politically embarrassing figure. He said he ordered the net debtor figure omitted because of a belief that it had become statistically invalid, a problem the BEA is working to correct. The problem involves the value given to the assets. At the present time, direct investment is valued at its historical purchase price, thus tending to understate older U.S. investments in relation to newer foreign purchases in this country. But private economists said that even when all the assets are reported at current value, the United States is still likely to be a net debtor by a considerable margin. They said the debate over valuation of the assets neglects the more important question over America's ever-growing foreign borrowings. ``We are competing for money on international capital markets with countries such as emerging democracies in Eastern Europe who desperately need investment funding,'' said David Wyss, chief financial economist of DRI-McGraw Hill. ``In our case, we are borrowing just because we are too undisciplined to pay our bills.'' C. Fred Bergsten, head of the Institute for International Economics, said that while U.S. assets were undervalued, there was also a serious problem in overlooking some foreign assets in the United States because of faulty data-gathering. He said the two errors probably cancelled each other out, leaving the net debtor number at about the right level. ``In our reading, the United States is still the biggest debtor country, but the government doesn't like publishing a report which makes that point,'' said Bergsten, who is writing a book on America's debtor position.

DOC.HEAD: Navas Names to No. 2 National Guard Post
DOC.TEXT: Brig. Gen. William A. Navas Jr., a former Puerto Rico National Guard officer, was named vice chief of the National Guard Bureau on Monday by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney. Navas, 48, deputy director of the Army National Guard since 1987, succeeds Lt. Gen. John B. Conaway, who was elevated to chief of the bureau. Before coming to Washington, Navas was director of plans, operations, training and military support of the Puerto Rico Army Guard State Area Command. He is a veteran of the Vietnam War.

DOC.HEAD: Stealth Bomber Problems Weren't Relayed to Pentagon
DOC.TEXT: The chief of the Tactical Air Command intensified training for stealth fighter-bomber crews after learning that they had missed their targets in Panama, but did not pass the information on to the Pentagon, a spokesman said Monday. Col. Ron Sconyers, a spokesman for Gen. Robert D. Russ, commented after The New York Times reported that a classified Air Force report concluded Russ, the command's chief, knew of the failures by the radar-evading aircraft but did not tell his superiors. ``General Russ eventually knew that the aircraft had missed its targets, but not early on,'' Sconyers said. He said it was at least 10 to 15 days after the operation when the general found out. Russ ``made training decisions based on that information,'' he said. But he said the general did not think it was up to him to make a report to the Pentagon because he was ``basically just a supplier of aircraft; he is not part of the operational chain of command.'' The Tactical Air Command is responsible for tactics and training for the F-117A, called stealth for its ability to avoid radar detection. ``Because he wasn't part of the operational chain of command and doesn't receive or generate operational reports, he made the assumption that that would be done through the operational chain of command,'' Sconyers said. ``There was never any intent on Gen. Russ's part to withhold information,'' the spokesman said. He added, ``In hindsight, he would have done it a little differently.'' Russ, in a statement given to the Times in response to two questions, said, ``There is always some confusion in the reporting of any military operation, and I didn't want to add to it. When look back at what has transpired, it is evident that more detail should have been forwarded.'' The Times said a lack of information had initially led Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to brag about how accurate the bombing had been when bombs actually missed by as much as 160 yards. Cheney demanded an explanation following reports that a bomb from one of the two planes had hit a hillside some distance from the intended target. After receiving the report, Cheney's spokesman, Pete Williams, said May 31 that Cheney was satisfied that Air Force officials didn't try to mislead him.

DOC.HEAD: AP-CWA Contract Vote Count Awaited
DOC.TEXT: Ballots will be counted Tuesday in a vote by Associated Press technical workers on a proposed two-year-contract. Negotiators for Local 1314 of the Communications Workers of America, which represents more than 300 technicians at the news agency, and the AP agreed tentatively on a contract four weeks ago. But the union described the contract as inadequate, particularly in its health and pension benefits, and urged members to reject it. AP management said the package was fair and urged employees to approve it. Jim Peecook, president of CWA Local 1314, said Friday that ballots were being mailed to a union post office box in Boston, where they would be counted. The contract calls for a ``managed care'' approach to control the cost of the medical plan by reducing unnecessary use of doctors and hospitals. It also proposes weekly pay increases of $23.50 for top-scale technicians in the first year and $24 in the second, bringing weekly top-scale technician salaries to $612 in 1991. Similar percentage increases were proposed for all other job classifications. Terms of the present CWA-AP contract were extended until 11:59 p.m. Monday pending the ratification vote.

DOC.HEAD: Government Spokesman Says Ban On Imelda May Affect Future Trials
With AM-Marcos Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A government spokesman said Tuesday that Imelda Marcos was still banned from returning home despite her acquittal on racketeering and fraud charges in the United States. Presidential Press Secretary Tomas Gomez also said Mrs. Marcos' acquittal Monday may hamper efforts to recover money she and her late husband, former President Ferdinand Marcos, allegedly stole during his 20-year administration. A federal jury in New York cleared Mrs. Marcos of charges of looting the Philippine treasury of $222 million to buy real estate, jewelry and art. The second defendant, Adnan Khashoggi, was acquitted of charges he helped Mrs. Marcos hide ownership of the property. ``I am disappointed,'' Gomez said. ``In my mind, she's guilty as hell.'' Gomez said the government was still drafting an official statement on the decision. The verdict was announced about 2 a.m. Manila time, and Gomez did not know whether Mrs. Aquino had been informed. On Monday, Mrs. Aquino said she would not allow Imelda to return to the Philippines regardless of the verdict. ``She will have her day in court,'' Gomez said of Mrs. Marcos. ``But not unless she is ... allowed to return. The position yesterday was that she was not allowed to return for security reasons. That stands as of now.'' The Philippine Constitution bans trials in absentia. The Aquino government claims Marcos and his associates stole $10 billion before he was ousted in the 1986 uprising that propelled Mrs. Aquino to power. But the government has never filed criminal charges against any member of the Marcos family for fear they would demand their right to return and face accusers. Marcos died last September in Hawaii, and Mrs. Aquino forbade his burial here. Asked whether the verdict would undermine efforts to recover the alleged ``hidden wealth,'' Gomez said: ``I suppose it will have. This will be an obstacle.'' Much of the money is believed to have been deposited in Swiss banks. Swiss authorities have been reluctant to lift banking secrecy laws and transfer funds without criminal charges. Gomez said many Filipinos, including Mrs. Aquino, harbored bitter memories of the Marcos presidency. ``Imelda Marcos is responsible for the assasination of Ninoy Aquino, and we should never forget that,'' Gomez said. He was referring to Mrs. Aquino's husband, a former senator who was assassinated in 1983 moments after returning from exile in the United States to challenge Marcos. Forty people, mostly soldiers, are on trial for the Aquino assasination. The trial began in April 1987 and is still dragging on. DZMM radio urged listeners to telephone their reactions to Mrs. Marcos' verdict. Most expressed shock and disbelief. A few were convinced the jurors were bribed. ``Until now, I still can't believe that she's been acquitted,'' said radio commentator Bert Berbon. The acquittal is bound to convince many Filipinos that the United States set Mrs. Marcos free to pressure the government into extending the lease on the six U.S. military bases after their expiration in 1991. But public support for banning Mrs. Marcos and her three children appeared to be slipping after the late President Ferdinand Marcos died last September in Hawaii. Even if the government sticks by the ban, political commentators believe Mrs. Marcos will wield considerable influence in national elections set for 1992, either by endorsing a candidate or running herself. Although prospects for a ``President Imelda'' seem remote, Philippine politics is in such disarray that anything is possible. Recent public opinion surveys show that Mrs. Aquino's popularity has been steadily declining because of high prices, deteriorating infrastructure and perceived inefficiency in her administration. Also, the recent withdrawal of all Peace Corps members from the country and reports that one of them has been kidnapped by Communist rebels heightened concern about a deterioration of law and order. Mrs. Aquino has said she will not seek re-election, and no clear front-runner has emerged. But some commentators believe Mrs. Aquino would change her mind if she believed Imelda or an Imelda-backed candidate stood a good chance of winning. ``If so, it will be a war between widows _ one who is in power and another who has lost it but still possesses enough resources to challenge a government,'' wrote columnist Emil Jurado in The Manila Standard.

DOC.HEAD: Groups Ask to Inspect Government's Meat Inspection Plan
DOC.TEXT: A coalition of consumer groups is asking that a scientific review of the Agriculture Department's new beef inspection plan be held up until the government discloses new information about the plan. One of the group, the Government Accountability Project, plans to file a lawsuit in U.S. District Court asking that the USDA's information be released under the Freedom of Information Act. The controversy is over the department's long-pending plan for a ``streamlined inspection system'' for beef which has been undergoing pilot tests in preparation for final review by the National Academy of Sciences. The NAS was contracted by USDA for $170,000 to review the proposal. The plan, called SIS-Beef, would require participating meat plants to take greater responsibility for some of the chores traditionally done by federal inspectors. Agency officials contend the inspectors would then concentrate more on checking for disease and other defects that can affect meat in the consumer pipeline. Each participating plant would have to submit a quality control plan in advance for USDA approval. Critics claim that means fewer inspectors would monitor plants and that beef would be turned out under speeded-up, slipshod, dirty conditions. Tom Devine of the Government Accountability Project said the NAS review should be delayed until the department releases more information. GAP is a non-profit public interest group that provides legal support for government whistleblowers. ``It's our contention that serious public health decisions shouldn't be made on the basis of secret reports,'' Devine said in a telephone interview. ``The reason these things aren't being released is they couldn't withstand scrutiny.'' But the USDA's Food Safety and Inspection Service, which oversees the program, said results at the pilot plants show the SIS system ``compares favorably with the traditional system'' of federal inspection. Spokesman Jim Greene said the agency denied the request by Devine and others for more information on grounds that ``some of it is proprietary'' and not allowed to be made public. ``Some of it has a direct bearing on the on-going agency contract with NAS, and release of that information to a third party would interfere with the scientific process and possibly compromise the results of that contract (with NAS), he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Scientists to Help Soviets Computerize Plant Data
DOC.TEXT: A team of scientists will go to the Soviet Union this fall to help set up a computer bank for Russian plants, the Agriculture Department said Monday. Information about seeds and other plant reproductive material _ germplasm _ will be stored in a Soviet database modeled after a Germplasm Resources Information Network, called GRIN, developed by the department's Agricultural Research Service. James H. Elgin Jr., the agency's national program leader for forage and pasture crops, said GRIN stores more than 1.5 million entries on about 8,100 different plant species worldwide. He will lead the USDA team to Leningrad in September. Elgin said the goal is to have the Soviet database compatible with the GRIN system, allowing both countries to have access to each other's information.

DOC.HEAD: Poland To Participate in Talks on German Border
DOC.TEXT: Polish Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszeski will participate in talks in Paris on July 17 on Germany's borders and military future, the State Department said Monday. The Polish government is looking for assurances that Germany will not try to recover territory it lost at the end of World War II. The Soviet Union, which is sending Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to the talks, is also interested in containing Germany to the current boundaries of East and West Germany, plus Berlin, after merger. Secretary of State James A. Baker III will represent the United States. He also is likely to meet with Shevardnadze on the side to discuss proposals for elections in Afghanistan. The pro-Soviet government in Kabul is fighting U.S.-armed rebels. Prospects for a settlement may depend on how the two superpowers decide to deal with President Najibullah. The Soviets want to to keep him in power while the United States are trying to arrange his ouster. Other participants in the Paris talks will be Foreign Ministers Roland Dumas of France, Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany, Markus Meckel of East Germany and Douglas Hurd, the British foreign secretary. Baker will leave Washington on July 16 and return on July 18, the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Congress: KGB Chief in the Balcony, Dan Rather in the Lobby
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: KGB Chief Vladimir A. Kryuchkov discovered democracy in the second balcony Monday. He and other members of the Communist Party's ruling Politburo shattered tradition by sitting among the 4,657 delegates at the party congress, rather than in splendid isolation at the front of the hall. Instead of slipping out through a private door, most of the leaders were exposed to ambush by party members on the first day of a congress that opened with an attack on Mikhail S. Gorbachev's continued leadership. Despite the stormy opening, most radical reformers and hard-liners interviewed by reporters in the marble lobby of the Kremlin Palace of Congresses avoided confrontation. Caught by a correspondent as he left his seat for a break, Kryuchkov stoutly affirmed his loyalty to Gorbachev, who faces a conservative challenge to his position as party general secretary. ``I will remain with the Communist Party, in the center,'' Kryuchkov said. ``I am for Gorbachev.'' He added that he could not be quite so definitive about the inclinations of other KGB officers in these days of political pluralism. Not all the officials were so amiable. Kryuchkov's fellow Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev, a hard-line critic of Gorbachev, brushed off a query on whether he will run against his boss for the Communist leadership. ``That will be decided by the congress,'' he said, and dashed off to the closed area backstage. In the lobby, American anchorman Dan Rather of CBS-TV rushed into a crowd of 50 people surrounding parliamentary chairman Anatoly Lukyanov to ask a question. It was a striking contrast to past party secrecy, which banned journalists from national policy-making meetings and left Sovietologists scrutinizing the holiday line-up of Politburo members on top of Lenin's tomb for any change that might signify a rising star. This time, only three of the 25 full and candidate members of the Politburo sat on the dais as part of the group leadership of the congress. They were the top three officials in the Soviet government: Gorbachev, Lukyanov and Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. ``We must unite all the forces that support socialism,'' said Alexander Buzgalin, a member of the conservative Marxist platform. He left reporters shaking their heads in confusion with claims that his group could find common ground with the reformist Democratic Platform, which calls for abandoning the ``70-year experiment'' with Communism and opting for West European style social democracy. One member of the Democratic Platform, Grigory Omelchenko of Kiev, wearing a red-and-white ``DP'' button on his lapel, said he did not want reformers to split from the party for the time being. He said he wanted to prevent a coalition of centrist and hard-line forces. But arguing is only natural, protested Ivan Polozkov, an extreme conservative. ``We are on our way to political pluralism,'' said Polozkov, whose election as head of the Russian branch of the party last momth strengthened predictions of a party split. Just nine minutes into the meeting, a coal miner stood to call for the resignation of the top 250 leaders in the party, including Gorbachev, for failure to improve the country's standard of living. But Gorbachev swept it off the floor with the promise of a discussion later in the 10-day meeting. During Gorbachev's 2 hour, 20-minute speech, applause was rare and very light. But delegates clapped long and hard for Alexander Yakovlev, a leading reformer disliked by the hard-liners. Yakovlev followed party ideologue Vadim A. Medvedev to the podium. Medvedev had been jeered. ``I'm also in for a tough few minutes,'' Yakovlev deadpanned, drawing laugher from the conservative crowd. Yakovlev won the attention, and apparently the respect, of the delegates with his blunt, uncompromising support for Gorbachev's reforms and condemnation of the party's history. In contrast to the Soviet parliament, where some delegates wear flowered headscarves, flowing clerical robes and the square embroidered caps of Central Asia, the party congress was nearly colorless, a sea of gray-suited managers and bureaucrats. Women were rare, as were the workers and peasants the Communist Party claims to represent. After party ``apparatchiks'' engineered their own election to nearly half the seats at the congress, officials discovered that fewer than 7 percent of the delegates were factory workers and farmers _ so they invited 300 as guests.

DOC.HEAD: Imelda: In Her Room
With AM-Marcos Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos's supporters staged a noisy celebration in her East Side apartment on Monday afternoon, but the former Philippines first lady retreated to her bedroom rather than join the party. ``Everybody here is very, very happy, as you can hear,'' a man who identified himself as Monsignor Domingo Nabraes, ``personal priest,'' said in a brief telephone interview. ``I can barely hear you.'' ``Mom is in her room,'' he said of Mrs. Marcos. ``She won't bee. ... (It) was a very draining experience.'' Nabraes said dozens of supporters had filled the apartment where Mrs. Marcos out for a whil stayed during her racketeering trial. ``We are not surprised,'' he said. ``We said all along, `The truth makes us free.''' The apartment, near the United Nations, was lent Mrs. Marcos by Doris Duke, the tobacco heiress. Immediately after her acquittal Monday, Mrs. Marcos and an entourage were driven from the federal courthouse in lower Manhattan to St. Patrick's Cathedral in midtown. There, she walked on her knees down the aisle to the altar, and bowed her head to the floor.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says His Proposals to Revamp Top Party Jobs in Trouble
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Monday that most Communists have rejected his plan to break the party chief's job he holds into two and radically restructure other party organs to make them more democratic. Although Gorbachev may eventually get his way _ the proposals have not yet come to a final vote _ his admission that the tide is turning against him underscored how much he has lost control over party policy. At the same time, it reflected his skill at sensing the mood of the meeting, the 28th Soviet Communist Congress, where he is trying to balance the demands of radical reformers and hard-liners. Party rules to be voted on at the congress, which began Monday, would revamp what have traditionally been the Soviet Union's most powerful political institutions, including Gorbachev's post as party general secretary. Whatever is decided will not affect Gorbachev's other job _ Soviet president. Changes that Gorbachev has proposed would replace the general secretary _ his present party title _ with a party chairman and first secretary. The chairman, assisted by a deputy chairman, would set overall party direction while the secretary would manage the party's daily affairs. In addition, the party's top body, the Politburo, would be renamed and expanded, thus diluting the power of each present Politburo member. The Politburo, now made up of 12 voting and seven non-voting members, would be renamed the Presidium, with about 30 members. In his keynote speech, Gorbachev said he had learned in discussions with delegates that ``a majority of Communists are for the (creation) not of a party chairman and his deputies and the Presidium, but for preservation of the post of general secretary, his deputy as a No. 2 party figure, and the Politburo.'' Applause that followed his remark indicated wide support for sticking to the current party structure. The only change Gorbachev indicated most Communists would support would be designation of the No. 2 party official as deputy general secretary. Such a post has existed only informally in the past. Gorbachev said the issue would be discussed further at the congress, scheduled to last until July 12. It was not clear where the critics referred to by Gorbachev fit in the political spectrum. If they are conservatives, that would correspond to their earlier demands that Gorbachev leave the top party job altogether, in favor of someone who could devote full time to the post. Gorbachev's only explanation for the criticism was that some Communists believed the proposed Presidium would not be ``energetic.'' He did not elaborate. Gorbachev has been pushing for the new structure, as well as other changes, to make the party more democratic and responsive to the membership and the people at large. At a meeting of the party's policy-making Central Committee in March, he said the Presidium would be a ``broader executive body'' made up of workers, peasants, intellectuals, servicemen, party veterans and heads of the 15 republics' Communist parties. The Politburo now has 12 full and seven non-voting members. Gorbachev has already eased some conservatives off the body, and has shifted some of its decision-making functions to popularly elected government bodies.

DOC.HEAD: New Medicare Coverage for Pap Smears Takes Effect
DOC.TEXT: Pap smears performed to screen for early detection of cervical cancer have been added to the list of Medicare-reimbursed medical expenses, officials said Monday. The new coverage began Sunday, allowing Medicare to help pay the cost of Pap smear screenings once every three years or more often if the patient is at high risk for developing cervical cancer. Previously, Medicare would paid for Pap smears only if the patient were being treated for an existing gynecological cancer or disorder or showed signs of some abnormality. Congress added the expanded benefit in legislation passed last year. The expanded benefit is expected to cost the program about $15 million for the rest of this fiscal year and about $30 million in fiscal 1991, according to the Department of Health and Human Services. For those enrolled in the Part B Medical Insurance Program, Medicare pays 80 percent of the approved charge, after the beneficiary has met an annual deductible. Medicare's current average allowed charge is estimated to be about $11.30 for a Pap smear, which does not include the physician's charge for an office visit, according to the congressional Office of Technology Assessment. A February report by the office said 25 percent of new cases of invasive cervical cancer occur in women 65 and older. It also said that only about half of the women in this age group have had a Pap smear within the past three years. About 13,500 new cases of invasive cervical cancer are expected to be diagnosed this year, and the disease is expected to cause about 6,000 deaths. Of these, 3,700 cases and 2,500 deaths will be among elderly women, the American Cancer Society estimates.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Liberia, 1st Ld-Writethru, a0627, a0628, a0632, a0634,0930
DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Rebels Attack Capital, Cut All Land Routes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines urgent series, reorganizes slightly. The following is a pool report filed by journalists in Monrovia, including Associated Press reporter Michelle Faul.
DOC.TEXT: Rebels attacked Monrovia Monday in a two-prong offensive, cutting all major land routes out of the Liberian capital. Heavy automatic gunfire and artillery fire erupted in the eastern and western suburbs. People streamed from the city center to escape the fighting and headed for areas believed already controlled by the rebels. State-run ELWA Radio, a Christian missionary station, said in its 7 p.m. broadcast (3 p.m. EDT) that the government was imposing a curfew from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. throughout the country. The radio also said diplomats were advised to stay in their missions or residences. The radio was monitored in Abidjan, Ivory Coast. In response to the rebel onslaught, President Samuel Doe re-broadcast his June 25 proposal to include the rebels in a broad-based interim administration to govern the country until early elections next January. In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Monday the United States is willing to help Doe depart the country if he asks for such assistance. As for the possibility of evacuating the remaining Americans in Liberia, she said the United States ``is considering all options.'' The U.S. Navy has had a task force off the Liberian coast to help with an evacuation if it is considered necessary. Ms. Tutwiler said there are slightly fewer than 800 Americans serving in Liberia, including about 70 working for the U.S. government. Doe's proposed national unity government would include the rebel National Patriotic Front and all political parties. Rebel leader Charles Taylor earlier rejected similar proposals. Taylor has repeatedly demanded that Doe resign before he and the rebels will stop their advance. The insurgents refused to attend a second round of church-mediated peace talks last week in Freetown, Sierra Leone. All international telephone and telex lines were cut around 7 a.m. (3:00 a.m. EDT), and flights from the city's small Spriggs Payne airfield were canceled because crews could not reach it. Soldiers, some drunk, commandeered cars and extorted money from people. More than 100 rebels marched down the main road from Mount Barclay village past the Coca Cola factory into the eastern suburb of Paynesville, 10 miles by road from the city center, witnesses said. Automatic rifle and rocket fire echoed through the heavily populated suburb for much of Sunday night and Monday morning. Smoke poured from the army base there. Rebels were reported within a few hundred yards of the main state radio transmitter, which still was broadcasting music interspersed with repeated broadcasts of the government offer to the rebels. State radio went off the air intermittently, but said the shutdowns were due to shortages of fuel for a generator being used since Monrovia's power supply was cut off Friday evening. Water supplies were cut last Wednesday. Five soldiers near the Swiss, German and Moroccan embassies just five miles from the town center prevented a foreign reporter from going farther later Monday, saying rebels were in the area. Other approaches to Monrovia also were guarded by only a few soldiers. The main resistance was expected at Scheiffelin army base 12 miles east of Monrovia, but rebels appeared to have bypassed the camp or taken it in the advance on Paynesville. ``There are no defenses on the outskirts of the city and once they (rebels) get to the executive mansion they will find a bit of resistance, then it will all be over,'' a Western diplomat said. The diplomat declined to be further identified. In a 1985 rebel attempt to overthrow Doe the insurgents took most of the capital before being over-powered by Doe's soldiers. However, the president's forces this time have had little luck stopping the six-month advance of Taylor's men. Doe was believed holed up in his fortified Israeli-built mansion facing the Atlantic Ocean with 500 troops of his elite presidential guard. Another 500 or so troops are believed to be in the capital. Vice President Harry Moniba and three other senior legislators held consultations with officials at the U.S. Embassy. Thousands of ordinary Liberians trudged through the tropical rain back to homes, which by then were presumed to lay in rebel-held territory. Rebels also moved in from the northwest of the city of 500,000 people, cutting the road west to Sierra Leone at the Saint Paul River bridge, residents contacted by telephone said. They captured the nearby town of Caldwell, just two miles from Monrovia port early Monday morning, and soldiers fled back to the city center in pickups. ``It's terrible, terrible, there are so many (rebels). They are so armed and coming with vengeance written on their faces,'' said one Caldwell resident by telephone. Some Monrovians, fearing their own army more than the guerrillas, tried to move toward the rebels' ill-defined lines. Others tried without success to board an aircraft out of the country. They included Commerce Minister John Wesseh Mcclain, Doe's speechwriter and a nephew of President William R. Tolbert. Tolbert was killed when Doe seized power in a 1980 coup. Most of Doe's Cabinet and other senior administration officials have fled. Liberian and diplomatic sources said army chief of staff Lt. Gen. Henry Dubar resigned during the weekend. Defense Minister Boimah Barclay took the last plane out on Sunday to Guinea, aviation sources said.

DOC.HEAD: $19 Million Payback in Store for Victims of Insider Scam?
DOC.TEXT: Investors defrauded in a massive 1988 insider trading scheme may be entitled to compensation from $19 million in alleged illegal profits surrendered by one of the defendants, officials said Monday. The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a proposed plan in a New York court for distributing the money obtained in what was at the time allegedly the second-largest insider trading case in U.S. history. In 1988, the SEC accused Fred C. Lee, a Taiwanese national living in Hong Kong, and Stephen K. Wang, a junior analyst in the mergers department at Morgan Stanley & Co., of engaging in an insider trading scheme that allegedly netted Lee $19 million.
