According to the SEC, Lee traded _ for himself and at least 33 people who were not identified _ with information he had obtained from Wang. Wang pleaded guilty in September 1988 to one count each of securities, wire and mail fraud for taking about $200,000 to funnel confidential information to Lee about at least 25 takeover deals that were being handled by Morgan. There was no allegation of wrongdoing by Morgan, which suspended and later fired Wang, who was sentenced to eight months in prison. Lee, although agreeing to settle civil charges with the SEC without admitting or denying wrongdoing, has not answered a criminal indictment stemming from the SEC investigation. As part of his settlement last August, Lee agreed to pay $19 million into a fund to reimburse investors defrauded by the scheme. He also agreed to pay the government $1.5 million in fines and $4.5 million in back taxes with interest. As of April 16, the receivership fund, plus accrued interest, totaled $20.3 million, according to the SEC. In papers filed in federal court in Manhattan, the SEC proposed reimbursing investors who sold securities in 18 companies on the same day the defendants bought those securities. The trades in question took place between July 1987 and April 1988. Securities of the following companies were involved: Utah Power & Light Co., Manpower Inc., Savannah Electric & Power, IC Industries Inc., E.F. Hutton Group, Outboard Marine Corp., Chi-Chi's, Richmond Hill Savings Bank, Catalyst Energy Corp., E-II Holdings Inc., Stanadyne Inc., American Standard, Federated Department Stores, Stop & Shop Companies Inc., Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., Sabine Corporation and Staley Continental Inc. Those wishing to comment or object to the plan should write the court-appointed receiver, Margaret A. Bancroft at the Manhattan law firm of Dechert Price & Rhoads, or the SEC's chief litigation counsel, Thomas C. Newkirk, at 450 Fifth Street, N.W. Stop 4-2, Washington, D.C. 20549.

DOC.HEAD: Exerpts From Gorbachev Speech at 28th Party Congress
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Excerpts from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech to the 28th Communist Party congress as translated by The Associated Press and the official Tass news agency:

PERESTROIKA AND PARTY FAILURES: The Soviet citizen of today no longer accepts what he meekly tolerated in the past. He reacts with understandable alarm and anger to the negative phenomena that, like foam on the surface, accompany the turbulent and basically healthy process of perestroika. A clear and well-founded answer to the question why this has happened is important for formulating conclusions as to what and how should be done next. It is also essential in order to fortify people's faith in perestroika. After all, voices can now be heard _ even more _ this is now something like an attitude _ claiming that perestroika is to blame for all our present troubles. In speaking of all this, comrades, I certainly do not want to mitigate assessments or conclusions concerning the activities of the Central Committee, the Political Bureau (Politburo) or the Communists working in party, government and economic bodies in the republics or locally. We have inherited a heavy legacy. The deplorable state of our lands and economy and the disastrous state of the energy sector ... are not the result of recent years. There are many things we could have foreseen and there are negative processes, above all, in the economic and social spheres, in inter-ethnic relations, in the sphere of culture and ideology, whose development we could have prevented. The Political Bureau does not deny its responsibility for these errors. We must analyze the situation, and we must see what revolutionary transformations will be made because the U.S.S.R. is rapidly becoming a second-rate power.

ECONOMY: Improvement of the Soviet economy depends to no small extent on how it integrates in the system of the international division of labor. ... But the main thing is to work for the convertability of the ruble. ... This matter should not be put off. We must have powerful export stimuli, and barriers for ineffective import and growth of the foreign debt. There must be mutually beneficial conditions for attracting foreign capital. ... At present, the government is drawing up proposals for the entire set of problems related to economic activity abroad. This applies to expanding ties with capitalist countries, and going over to world prices and settlements in hard currency within the framework of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance. This also concerns revision and introduction of certain correctives in our cooperation with Third World countries.

AGRICULTURE: A few words here about a question that is the focus not simply of discussion, but of real speculation. I am referring to the collective and state farms. People go to the length of saying that the new agrarian policy puts in doubt their very existence. But its purpose is to give equal opportunities to all forms of farming. Let each of them prove its viability and effectiveness. That is our position of principle. And we certainly reject the demand for ``blanket decollectivization.'' I am convinced that the collective and state farms which go about their business skillfully, which advance on the social plane and provide peasants with worthy living conditions, deserve every support. They will naturally remain an organic part of the renovated Soviet countryside. Those collective and state farms, however, that have not put their hearts into their work for decades, that are in the red and live off subsidies, and whose management is obstructing the reform of property relations and the introduction of new forms of farming _ those must undergo cardinal transformation. And one more topical issue _ that of land reform. Let's be frank: the land act has not been working so far. And not only due to the prevailing administrative structure, the posture of the managerial apparatus, but also to the old psychology, the petrified stereotypes which resulted from the peasant's depersonalization, the working man's detachment from the land and the means of production, in a setting of guaranteed remuneration regardless of the end results. ... All hindrances should be put out of the way for those who wish to apply themselves to free farming.

BUREAUCRACY: We are being directly opposed by the bureaucratic sector of the population. If we do not overcome the resistance of such workers, and there are many in management structures, the situation will worsen.

CHRONIC SHORTAGES: I would subscribe here to everything that is said on this subject and express solidarity with the most scathing criticism. But just fanning emotions won't increase the amount of goods. Yet at the same time, the situation on the consumer market, far from becoming less strained, has in many cases grown more acute and become intolerable. In any case _ and this should be admitted _ the consequences could have been less painful if the government had approached the economic reform comprehensively, and had managed to stand up to the pressure of various industries and the old managerial structures that sought to keep their position and maintain the command methods of administration.

ETHNIC STRIFE: At present, as we embark on a succession of deep-going changes in our multinational state, we need tranquility, peace and cooperation in the interests of all nations. I hope that this appeal of our congress will be heard in all parts of the country. What we lived through and reflected upon in recent times, has caused us to realize that the updating of the union cannot be confined to mere, even though highly considerable, extension oof the rights of the republics and autonomies. What we need is a real union of sovereign states.

HUMAN RIGHTS: For all this, human rights will retain priority over the interests of national sovereignty and autonomy. This must be entrenched in the constitutional fabric of the union and each of the republics. Nor must we depart even an inch from this principle, which guides us on the international plane as well.

EASTERN EUROPE: Big changes are under way in Eastern Europe. And when it is said, ``It is the failure of socialism,'' we ask in reply: ``What kind of socialism?'' The kind that was in fact a Stalinist version. Well, we are getting rid of that ourselves.

STALIN'S CRIMES: The revision of the cases of all the victims of the lawlessness of the times of Stalin's repression has proved to be the most essential element in giving the people the truth of history. The deliberations of the relevant commission of the Politburo of the CPSU Central Committee have resulted in posthumously rehabilitating the party and civic honor of thousands upon thousands of Communists, big-caliber party and government leaders, workers, peasants and intellectuals. ... But I consider that we have not yet finished the job. It must be carried on.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Signs Bill on Rolling `Boom Boxes'
DOC.TEXT: Playing loud music on a car stereo could bring a $32 fine under a bill Gov. Bob Martinez signed into law Monday. Drivers can be ticketed for playing a car stereo ``plainly audible'' from at least 100 feet away. ``Plainly audible'' will be defined by the Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles, which also will establish regulations on how police measure the sound. Motorists also could get ticketed if their stereos are ``louder than necessary for the convenient hearing by persons inside the vehicle'' when near a hospital, school or church. The bill exempts law enforcement and business vehicles and those blaring political messages via loudspeaker. Martinez also signed into law a bill that lets judges require drunken-driving offenders to install a device that keeps a car from starting if the driver has a blood-alcohol level above 0.05 percent. A level of 0.10 is considered intoxication. The bill's sponsor, Rep. John Renke, said five other states have similar measures. The laws take effect Oct. 1.

DOC.HEAD: After 48 Days, Winner Declared in Nebraska Gubernatorial Primary
DOC.TEXT: Forty-eight days after the election, an Omaha lawyer was certified Monday as the winner of Nebraska's Democratic gubernatorial primary. It was the closest margin for a governor's race in modern U.S. history _ 42 votes. ``The wheels are ready to start spinning,'' Ben Nelson said after his long wait had ended. ``We're ready to start. The Fourth of July is a truly great time to get a campaign going.'' The state Board of Canvassers certified Nelson as the winner of the May 15 primary, with 44,721 votes to 44,679 for fellow Democrat Bill Hoppner. Hoppner, former aide to U.S. Sen. Bob Kerrey, appeared before the board and said he believed Nelson had won the nomination and asked that they certify his victory. Nelson will face incumbent Republican Gov. Kay Orr in November's election. ``This has gone on long enough; it's time for the Democratic party to get on with the election,'' Hoppner said. Mrs. Orr ordinarily chairs the Board of Canvassers, but she declared a conflict of interest before the board's June 20 meeting and did not attend Monday's session. The certification was delayed by an initial recount that was mandated by state law because the election was so close and a second recount of so-called undervotes in 21 counties. Undervotes are ballots, read by machine, that initially showed no vote for the governor's race. A Washington-based consulting firm, Election Data Services, said the election was the closest primary or general election contest for governor in modern American politics. Mrs. Orr, informed of the decision while attending meetings in Omaha, said: ``I'm pleased that it is over and behind us so that we can get on with the campaign. Mr. Nelson now will have to talk about his plans for Nebraska's future. He'll have to give us more than the general political rhetoric he did in the primary.'' Asked how she would approach the campaign against Nelson, Mrs. Orr said she would emphasize ``the good news of Nebraska's economy'' during her four years as governor. Nelson said he'd never be able to match Mrs. Orr's advantage in fund-raising, but said that wouldn't hurt him. ``The issues will drive the campaign. It's not going to be a matter of how much money one has. It'll really be a matter of who better expresses their position and is more in tune with the people of Nebraska on issues such as taxes,'' Nelson said. He commended Hoppner for being ``graceful and gracious'' about the process and noted that the healing process in the party has already begun.

DOC.HEAD: Innovative Jazz Organization Honored
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Wilson, Ahmad Jamal and other jazz musicians saluted New York's own Jazzmobile on the closing night of the JVC Jazz Festival. Shortly before the concert ended, another celebrity dropped by. Mayor David N. Dinkins presented jazz composer and pianist Billy Taylor an official proclamation declaring Saturday Jazzmobile Day in New York. Taylor is the longtime chairman of the Jazzmobile board. The Avery Fisher Hall audience was celebrating the 25th anniversary of an innovative organization that likes to call jazz America's classical music. Jazzmobile was the first performing arts group to bring artists to people in their neighborhoods; this year, its 26th summer, it will present about 70 concerts by jazz artists in neighborhoods throughout the city. Its Wednesday night concerts at Grant's Tomb overlooking the Hudson River are well known to city jazz lovers. The Terence Blanchard Quintet, with Blanchard on trumpet, opened the concert, but played too solemnly for the occasion. The party brightened considerably, though, when Ahmad Jamal strode to the piano and unleashed his restless energy. He was ably backed by Dave Boller on drums and James Comack on bass. The highlight of the trio's performance was a duel between Jamal and Boller, with Comack playing the role of mediator. Miss Wilson, who played the second half of the concert, enjoyed a strong rapport with her audience. She sang her standards with verve, but at times her delivery was strained. The only regret the audience could have had was that Taylor, who co-founded Jazzmobile with the late Daphne Arnstein, didn't play some tunes himself. Tayor announced that he is resigning as the group's chairman because the revival of jazz, which the arts organization has done much to help, has resulted in increased opportunities for him.

DOC.HEAD: Black Workers in South Africa Protest Factional Battles
DOC.TEXT: Black workers nationwide stayed home Monday in a strike to protest black factional fighting that has killed thousands. Labor groups said up to 3 million blacks took part. Black absenteeism in the major cities of Johannesburg, Pretoria, Durban and Port Elizabeth ranged from 50 percent to more than 90 percent, according to estimates by police, labor and management. Trade unionists reported one death in a township outside Durban and several injuries in scattered clashes around the country. Also, police said an 8-year-old boy was fatally shot and three people injured when an officer fired at a mob stoning his vehicle. It was not immediately clear if the attack, in a township southeast of Johannesburg, was related to the strike. In most places, however, the strike was peaceful. No precise figures were available on the number of participants, but labor groups claimed up to 3 million took part. The Congress of South African Trade Unions, which joined the African National Congress in organizing the one-day strike, estimated that up to 3 million workers stayed home. ``The response from our people demonstrates unequivocally the extent of mass support for the programs and policies of our organizations,'' the labor group said in a statement. The ANC is the country's leading group fighting the white government's system of racial discrimination. The group, whose deputy president is Nelson Mandela, has denounced the deadly feuds between black factions, saying they detract from the struggle against apartheid. The South African Chamber of Business estimated Monday's work stoppage cost the country almost $300 million in lost productivity. The ANC called the walkout to protest black factional fighting in the eastern province of Natal. The fighting has claimed about 4,000 lives since 1986. The ANC has demanded the white-led government end a state of emergency in Natal and disband local Zulu police. Several black groups opposed Monday's strike. The opponents included the Inkatha movement, the conservative Zulu organization that has been fighting ANC supporters for supremacy in Natal. Black groups have become increasingly hostile to one another in recent months as they compete for supporters and influence. Hundreds of blacks have died in factional fighting since President F.W. de Klerk legalized dozens of anti-apartheid organizations in February. In Natal, at least two-thirds of the black workforce took part in the strike, according to Congress of Trade Unions. Police put the participation figure at 60 percent in Natal and said many people were intimidated into staying home. ``People wanting to go to work have been prevented from doing so,'' said Mangosuthu Buthelezi, the leader of Inkatha and the Zulu homeland. He accused the protest organizers of ``political thuggery.'' Police reported Monday that three blacks had been killed in the latest factional fights in Natal during the weekend. Authorities made efforts to break the strike Monday. Police in some black townships offered transport to bring workers to their jobs after most black bus drivers went on strike. Police trucks transported black hospital staff to work in Durban. In Pretoria, a helicopter dropped police leaflets urging blacks to ``ignore intimidation and go to work.''

DOC.HEAD: Plane's Backers Say Pentagon Report Proves Their View
DOC.TEXT: Congressional backers of the V-22 Osprey are touting an internal Pentagon report on the tilt-rotor aircraft as conclusive evidence against Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's plans to scrap the plane. ``The Pentagon's arguments about the high cost of the Osprey are no longer credible,'' Rep. Curt Weldon, R-Pa., said Monday in response to the draft report delivered to lawmakers Friday. The congressman's comments came one day after Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., released excerpts of the 1,200-page report by the Pentagon's own think tank, the Institute for Defense Analysis. ``The cat is out of the bag now,'' Specter said, ``and there can be no more stalling or equivocating by the Defense Department about the merits and cost-effectiveness of the Osprey.'' Citing budget constraints, Cheney last year proposed canceling the program to buy the Osprey, an aircraft that takes off like a helicopter but flies like a plane. Lobbying by lawmakers from Texas and Pennsylvania _ the Osprey is built by Boeing Helicopter of Lester, Pa., and Bell Helicopter Textron of Fort Worth, Texas _ was fierce with Weldon and Specter two of the most vocal supporters. Congress eventually put off a final decision and earmarked $255 million for research and development of the aircraft in the defense budget for 1990. Cheney again called for terminating the program in 1991, arguing that a mix of CH-46, CH-53 and UH-60 helicopters would be a cheaper alternative. The proposal touched off another round of persistent lobbying that is not expected to end until Congress approves the defense budgets later this year. The draft report, which Congress called for last July, said the original plan to buy and operate 502 of the aircraft for the Marine Corps would cost $33 billion in fiscal 1988 dollars. The alternative of a mix of CH-53 and CH-60 helicopters would cost about $24 billion. By limiting the Osprey program to $24 billion, or 356 aircraft, the report said the V-22's ``speed, range and survivability advantages could enable even the fleet to be more effective _ sometimes significantly more and other times slightly more _ than all of the proposed helicopter alternatives in each of the four Marine missions examined.'' That assessment is certain to be used by backers of the aircraft in their long-running battle with the Defense Department over funds for the Osprey. But Cheney's spokesman indicated in May that the V-22-is-cheaper argument will not sway the defense secretary. ``If indeed the report makes the same argument, that's not a new one and that would not be grounds for us to change our minds ... I'm unaware now of any plans for us to reconsider that decision,'' said Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams.

DOC.HEAD: Wilderness Society Calls Alaska Lands Act a Failure
DOC.TEXT: A national conservation group declared the decade-old Alaska Lands Act a failure on Monday and called on Congress to begin monitoring the protection of the state's national parks and wildlife refuges. ``Opponents of this law have done everything they could to turn a resource protection act into a resource development act,'' said George Frampton Jr., president of The Wilderness Society. ``It's time Americans had a look at what's being done to the 39 percent of the federal lands that lie within Alaska. It's not a pretty picture.'' During the past six months, The Wilderness Society has studied the effectiveness of the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act signed in 1980 by President Jimmy Carter to preserve the state's wildlife areas. The act was hailed by conservationists as one of the most ambitious preservation initiatives ever enacted. It set aside 104.3 million acres of national parks, wildlife refuges and other protected areas in Alaska. In its study, the society found that ``many of the lands that supposedly were being protected are facing serious threats.'' ``We hope this report and the work that underlies it will serve as a basis for congressional oversight,'' Frampton said at a news conference called to release the 61-page report. The most serious threat to public lands in Alaska is oil and gas development in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, according to the report. ``There is less than one-in-five chance that a commercially viable oil field lies beneath the refuge's fabled coastal plain,'' it says. ``If there is such a field, the most likely annual yield would satisfy less than two percent of U.S. oil demand.'' The Arctic refuge is located in the northeastern corner of Alaska. The refuge's center of wildlife activity is a 1.6-million-acre coastal plain, a roughly 25-mile-wide area framed by the ocean and the Brooks Range. A provision in the Alaska Lands Act directed the U.S. Park Service and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to review all lands within Alaska's national parks and wildlife refuges to see if they qualify for wilderness protection. Congress can designate public land as wilderness if it hasn't been developed. That designation means the land can never be developed. Under the act, the Interior Department was to complete that review in 1985 and the president was to recommend to Congress which areas ought to receive protection. The Interior Department still hasn't conducted the wilderness review. Society officials said the Bush administration isn't seriously following the act's mandate to protect wildlife, but is trying to preserve development options whenever possible. ``In Alaska, there has been no significant change from the policy of the Reagan administration,'' said Frampton. ``We're stuck in the crack of a broken record.'' Excessive logging in the 16.9-million-acre Tongass National Forest is another serious threat, society officials said. The act set a minimum harvest of 4.5 billion board feet from Tongass in one decade. Congress gave the Forest Service $400 million to build logging roads and administer the harvest program and the Forest Service sold the trees to private industry. However, the price the Forest Service got was so low, it lost 73 cents for every taxpayer dollar paid, said Bennett Beach, a spokesman for the society. The Wilderness Society wants Congress to pass the Tongass Timber Reform Act in a form close to the bill passed by the House last July. Society officials said the version approved June 13 by the Senate needs to be strengthened, which is expected to go to conference after the August recess.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts on Kremlin Aide's Speech at Party Congress
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Excerpts from a speech by Politburo member Alexander N. Yakovlev, a close adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to the 28th Communist Party Congress on Monday, as translated by The Associated Press and the official Tass news agency:

It's high time to talk at Communists' congresses ... about nobility, charity, morality and conscience ... it's high time to end the civil war we have not been able to end so far. ... I am convinced of the historical correctness of the choice made in 1985 and its profound moral value. What has happened to us? ... The party of the revolutionary idea has turned into the party of power. ... A monopoly on truth is fatal. ... In these conditions, only a renewed, more left-leaning and rejuvenated party will be capable of leading the country onward along the path of drastic transformation. This movement is inexorable. It will continue _ with or without the party. ... Conservative sentiments and trends that have recently made themselves felt are evidence to the fact that the party is still a captive of the system of social stagnation generated by the regime of personal power. ... Certainly, this is the last congress for me. And, forgive me for being sentimental, I consider myself a happy man, as I have been a contemporary and an active participant of a great renewal in a great country, of its historic march to the world of freedom. Nowadays, a lot depends on the measure of courage and of conscience, but also from a capability to nobly go through torments of reconsidering our existence, of our life. Let us remember that not only empty store shelves forced perestroika, but empty souls as well.

DOC.HEAD: AM-US-Patriarch,440
Greek Orthodox Patriarch Arrives, First to Visit US
DOC.TEXT: Dimitrios I, the first Greek Orthodox patriarch to visit the United States, arrived Monday and warned that civilization is threatened by a turn away from morality and spirituality. ``The world today, precisely because of technological achievements and its material well-being, has immense problems of a moral and spiritual nature,'' said the leader of the Orthodox Church. ``These threaten to shatter the very structure of our civilization and even the planet itself. This nation must lead a moral and spiritual rebirth for the good of mankind,'' he said. He addressed greetings to all Orthodox, and then greeted ``all our brother Christians with whom, unhappily, we are not yet in full communion of faith and sacrament.'' ``The effort toward reconciliation, theological dialogue and full unity among divided Christians is at the very center of our concerns and of our daily prayers.'' In l964 his predecessor, Athenagoras, visited Pope Paul VI. The following year the mutual excommunications between the Greek and Roman churches were lifted after more than 900 years. The patriarch came with an entourage of 14 on the ``Olympic Flame,'' a plane put at his disposal for the trip by the Greek national airline. Dressed in the flowing black robes and high headdress of his church, the patriarch spoke in Greek. He is the spiritual leader of 250 million Orthodox faithful, most of them in the Soviet Union and eastern Europe. One of the objects of his trip is to promote a meeting in Geneva, Switzerland, in September of Orthodox leaders from everywhere, including the Soviet Union and the Western hemisphere. A Turkish citizen, Dimitrios lives in Istanbul where tradition holds that Orthodox Christianity was founded by St. Andrew the Apostle nearly 2,000 years ago. He will spend most of this month in the United States, including 10 days in Washington. He will meet President Bush and leaders of Congress. He was greeted at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington, D.C., by Edward J. Derwinski, secretary of Veterans' Affairs, and Sen. Paul Sarbanes, who is of Greek ancestry. ``He is a leader of the free world as we enter what we hope will be a more peaceful period,'' Derwinski said. The patriarch, who is 75 years old, walked along a fence after the official ceremony, shaking hands and blessing children among about 300 people who came to greet him. On July 9, he will attend the official opening of the 30th biennial Clergy-Laity Congress of his church. George D. Carcazes, a Chicago attorney, is planning to challenge the procedures of the congress, asking greater authority for the laity.

DOC.HEAD: East German Workers Strike, Shop, Celebrate Economic Union of Germanys
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout, UPDATING with new strike figures, details, quotes. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LEI1,BER3
DOC.TEXT: East Germans plunged into capitalism Monday with West German money in their pockets, strikes by thousands of worried workers and happy housewives buying bananas, chocolate and fresh meat. It was the first day of business after East Germany merged its economy and social welfare system with West Germany's on Sunday, officially ending East Germany's 40-year experiment with a Communist system. Gerhard Pannier, a worried coal dealer, said, ``We're rolling into a dark tunnel without even knowing there'll be an engine to pull us out.'' Full political unification is expected in December. With widespread layoffs expected in East Germany, there was immediate labor unrest. A spokesman for the powerful IG Metall union claimed during a rally that up to 30,000 workers briefly downed tools in warning strikes in about 10 factories around East Berlin. Karl-Heinz Graffenberger, a union leader, said 3,000 workers struck a locomotive factory in Hennigsdorf, where the rally was held. One worker, Kerstin Arendt, 21, said she makes 640 marks (about $390) a month take-home pay. ``With 600 marks you don't get very far,'' she said. Other strikes were reported at the Ludwigsfelde car parts plant south of Berlin and a steel factory in Brandenburg. Workers demanded higher pay and improved working conditions, East Germany's ADN news agency reported. Graffenberger said they also wanted job security. East Berlin coal dealers used their trucks to blockade loading points at four locations to protest the end of state subsidies on brown coal, the nation's most important source of energy. Economists have predicted up to one third of East Germany's 8,000 businesses may fail when the full force of West German competition decends on their inefficient production methods. The number of unemployed East Germans rose to 150,000 from 100,000 a month earlier, East German Labor Minister Regine Hildebrandt said in a radio interview Monday. Experts have predicted up to 4 million people could end up out of work in this nation of 16.6 million. ADN said the Robotron computer company was offering courses in office automation and business management to jobless East Germans. Employees of Robotron, which used to be East Germany's high-technology showcase, are taking part of the course themselves to become familiar with Western management techniques, ADN said. Heiko Lehmann, 26, a research physicist working for a lamp factory, grumbled, ``First of all, I'll lose my job. Then I'll live on 700 marks a month, and I don't know how I'll get by on that.'' But he said he was optimistic about ultimately landing a new job. His $424 benefit is 75 percent of his last-earned wage. West Germany sent 25 billion marks ($15.1 billion) from its national bank's cash reserves to cover the initial phase of economic unification. East Germans could change some of their worthless East German marks for West German marks at a 1-1 rate as the country swung over to a capitalist system. On international markets, the West German mark remained strong and even made slight gains against the U.S. dollar. To East Berlin shoppers, unification meant that Chiquita bananas, Tuborg beer and Milka chocolate were available at the corner grocery. Buying those items used to involve what one housewife called ``exhausting'' trips to West Berlin. Before the Berlin Wall came down in November, there was no way she'd have gotten them at all. Housewives praised the lean and more appetizing meat now on sale. ``Some things are cheaper, some are more expensive, but on average ... it should be OK,'' said Dietmar Bauer as he emerged from a grocery store. Frustrated by a gargantuan checkout line, he bought nothing. Salaries in East Germany are less than half the average in West Germany. But East German rents and other basic items will be kept low for a while to help compensate. On the whole, prices of most foodstuffs and consumer goods were about equal to those in West Germany. But because East Germany has ended all government subsidies on food, the price of a roll tripled from eight to 24 pfennigs (5-15 cents). The price of milk more than doubled, ADN said. Trade Minister Sybille Reider toured shops belonging to the Konsum chain on East Berlin's outskirts, and accused the formerly state-owned enterprise of ``shamefully abusing'' its monopoly in the countryside, ADN reported. Ms. Reider found a Konsum store in Beelitz, southwest of Berlin, charging 2.29 marks ($1.38) for a half-pound of butter, as opposed to 1.79 marks ($1.08) in areas where competition exists. She complained of ``half-empty shelves'' and said, ``Whatever East German produce was for sale was miserably wrapped and of very poor quality.'' Also Monday, the elevated railway system known as the S-Bahn resumed services between East and West Berlin for the first time since the Berlin Wall went up in 1961. S-Bahn authorities plan to reopen six more cross-border lines, but major repairs to stations and tracks are needed before they become operational.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Criticize Prosecution, Cite Lack of Evidence
With AM-Marcos Jurors, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jurors who acquitted Imelda Marcos of racketeering and fraud on Monday said the U.S. government did a ``terrible job'' in prosecuting the former Philippine first lady. The jury forewoman also said the panel felt Mrs. Marcos should not be held responsible for the acts of her late husband, Ferdinand E. Marcos. ``Just because she was married to him doesn't make her guilty,'' said Catherine Balton, a retired office manager. After a three-month trial, the jury cleared Mrs. Marcos and her co-defendant, Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, of all charges. ``We thought the government did a terrible, terrible job,'' said Thomas O'Rourke, a mason with the Transit Authority. ``They had half-truths and not the right witnesses. It was a terrible case.'' O'Rourke said that on the first day of deliberations Thursday the panel had voted 10-2 for acquittal. ``There was heavy discussion. There was yelling and certain people thought different ways,'' O'Rourke said. ``But everybody walked away happy. ``It was a totally silly case,'' he added. Ms. Balton, reached at home, said the jurors felt there was not enough evidence to convict Mrs. Marcos and Khashoggi. ``It was a poorly prepared case,'' Ms. Balton said. ``There was nothing to convince any of them that there was a case.'' In a terse statement, the office of U.S. Attorney Otto Obermaier praised the work of the trial prosecutors and said: ``The jury has rendered its verdict. Our system of justice has spoken.'' O'Rourke said the government should have dropped the case when Marcos died last September. ``For three years they have made this poor woman's life miserable,'' he said. ``It may have been a conspiracy but not a conspiracy by Marcos.'' O'Rourke said the jurors took photographs of each other after the verdict, and planned a reunion in about a month.

DOC.HEAD: Developments in German Unification
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the major developments Monday in East and West Germany:

LABOR UNREST: About 30,000 workers in 10 factories around Berlin staged brief warning strikes or protests, union officials said, East Germany's 8,000 companies conducted their first full day of business in a free-market economy. Strikers included about 3,000 people at the giant Locomotive Electronics Works in Hennigsdorf. Other strikes were reported at the Ludwigsfelde automobile parts plant and at a steel works in Brandenburg. Strikers demanded higher pay and better working conditions, East Germany's ADN news agency said. East Berlin's 66 coal dealers used their trucks to block loading points in four locations around the city. They were protesting abandonment of state subsidies _ halted as part of the economic merger of the two Germanys, which took effect Sunday.

CURRENCY: The West German mark fared strongly on international markets despite increases in the amount of money in circulation, due to the exchange of West German marks for East German marks. The mark's strength was attributed to the smooth start of the economic merger and the possibility of U.S. tax increases. Dealers also said moderate withdrawals of West German marks by East Germans indicated a consumer's buying spree would not occur, keeping inflation in check.

STORES OPEN: Long lines formed outside most grocery stores in East Germany Monday morning. Virtually all had been closed over the weekend as workers changed prices and restocked shelves with higher-priced Western goods. Prices on some staples, such as milk, also were higher. East Germans were spending some of their new money on long-desired goods in West Berlin and West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Government Strongly Warns Against Use of Aspirin By Pregnant Women
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 2 and 4 pvs to CORRECT that problems affect the unborn child, sted newborn
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration on Monday announced stronger warnings against use of over-the-counter aspirin products by women in the last three months of pregnancy unless directed by a physician. The agency said the stronger warning on labels is being required because aspirin can affect fetal circulation and uterine contraction. Manufacturers have one year to add the stronger warning to all oral and rectal over-the-counter products containing aspirin, the FDA said. The warning must read: ``It is especially important not to use aspirin during the last three months of pregnancy unless specifically directed to do so by a doctor because it may cause problems in the unborn child or complications during delivery.'' Aspirin products now carry a general warning that says: ``As with any drug, if you are pregnant or nursing a baby, seek the advice of a health professional before using this product.'' An advisory panel of medical experts had recommended the stronger warning. A similar, third-trimester pregnancy warning is already required on nonprescription products containing the pain-reliever ibuprofen. The regulation is to be published in the Federal Register on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Names Three to Hubble Board
With AM-NASA, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NASA on Monday named two University of Arizona astronomers and a retired vice president of Eastman Kodak Company to a board investigating the problems of the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. Named to the panel were Bob Shannon of the university's Optical Sciences Center and Roger Angel of Steward Observatory, and Charles R. Spoehlhof, formerly of Kodak. The board of investigation is led by Lew Allen, director of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif. Other members are George A. Rodney, NASA associate administrator for Safety and Mission Quality and John D. Mangus, head of the Optics Branch at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland. Problems with the spacecraft have impaired much of its touted ability to provide quality photographs from outer space.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Cities In Tightening Budget Crunch
DOC.TEXT: More than half of the nation's cities and towns expect spending to exceed revenues in their current budget year and two-thirds of the municipalities say budget crunches are worse than a year ago, according to a survey released Monday. The National League of Cities survey of 576 communities said the budget pressures are greatest in the Northeast _ where the regional economy is slumping. Five of six cities and towns surveyed in that region reported that their financial problems were worse than a year ago. A majority of communities in the South, the Midwest and the West also reported that budget strains were greater this year. Leaders of the organization, whose membership is open to cities and towns with populations of at least 10,000, said a major factor in the growing municipal budget problems is the lack of help from Washington. ``We see this as a crucial time for national leadership,'' said Donald Borut, the league's executive director. As President Bush and congressional leaders seek an agreement on a deficit-reduction plan likely to include some form of higher taxes, the survey showed many cities also were looking for additional revenues. Forty-one percent of those surveyed have raised local property taxes; 76 percent have increased fees and other charges, the League of Cities said. Just over half _ 51 percent _ reduced the rate of spending growth in their budgets and 39 percent contracted out certain services in an attempt to cut costs, the survey found. Borut called the results ``a warning signal about stresses on our local revenue systems, about our ability to maintain important services and about the consequences of unfunded mandates and the continuing withdrawal of federal and state participation in providing vital services.'' The league's board of directors plans to meet with House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., next week before the organization makes its suggestions on deficit-reduction priorities. Rostenkowski last month told another municipal organization, the U.S. Conference of Mayors, that cities are unlikely to get any additional help from Washington in the foreseeable future.

DOC.BYLINE: Council Recommends Truck Weight Policy To Save $4.3 Billion. ^By DAVID BRISCOE
DOC.TEXT: A federal research group recommended on Monday a more liberal policy on truck weights that it said could save $4.3 billion a year in transport costs and cost railroads $750 million in lost revenue. The National Research Council committee said all states should be given the option of exempting some trucks from a federal limit of 80,000 pounds on the nation's interstate highways. It also recommended changes in the rules for bridge use that would allow heavier concrete mixers, dump trucks and other trucks with shorter wheelbases. The weight exemptions would be on the condition that they include fees to cover pavement and bridge wear, said the committee, which is made up of transportation experts from universities, the industry and government. The research council is linked to the National Academy of Sciences and the National Academy of Engineering. The committee report recommends that heavy trucks still be restricted to designated routes, comply with all other federal weight restrictions and comply with strict safety standards. The exemptions would still be up to individual states, but the report said it was not fair to prevent about half the states from allowing exemptions while the others who had exemptions before the current law can keep theirs. If all states adopted the exemptions, annual transportation savings for truckers could total $1.9 billion because of the use of more productive vehicles, the report said. This would lower costs by 1.6 percent, attracting $750 million in rail business, it said. Savings in trucking costs from a new bridge formula could total $2.4 billion, the committee said. The report, requested by Congress, brought praise from the trucking industry, which estimates its services at $240 billion annually. ``We feel the suggestions would have a great value to the economy as a whole and will make significant differences in the competitive situation of the United States as compared to the rest of the world,'' said John Reith, policy director for the American Trucking Associations. He said the report is the result of two years of research. A rail industry spokesman said he had not seen the report but was concerned that any nationwide increase in truck sizes and weights could have a serious impact on railroads. Dan Lang, vice president of the Association of American Railroads, said trucks pay only about half their share of highway maintenance costs and fail to pay other highway expenses, including the social cost of pollution and added traffic. ``If you're going to go out and upset the status quo this way, you should really take another look at all the costs associated,'' Lang said. The committee report did not call for substantially heavier trucks over 80,000 pounds and did not address truck lengths, said its chairman, Lester A. Hoel of the University of Virginia. ``We simply recommended a level playing field for fairness, to give all states the option of imlementing a permit program,'' said Hoel. Federal law currently restricts gross vehicle weight to 80,000 pounds, with a limit of 20,000 pounds per axle and 34,000 pounds for tandem axles. Bridge-crossing requirements are based on a formula which includes weight, the number of axles and their distance apart. The report recommends that axle weight limits be maintained, which means the heavier trucks would not cause significant changes in pavement wear, it said. The committee concluded that it was ``arbitrary and inequitable'' to allow some states to give exemptions but said it would cost about $8 billion to remove all exempted vehicles from the highway. This would result in more accidents, pollution and traffic because it would take more, smaller trucks to replace them, the study said. It said the current formula for bridge use ``is an overly cautious limit on weights for shorter trucks.''

DOC.HEAD: Moore Says Barry Suspected Something on Night of Arrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 21st graf with additional Moore testimony; ADDS one graf with order in Farrakhan suit.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry smoked crack cocaine the night he was arrested in an FBI sting operation although he suspected ``something was going on,'' Rasheeda Moore testified Monday in Barry's cocaine and perjury trial. If Barry had been so hesitant, ``why did he go on and (use) the pipe?'' defense attorney R.Kenneth Mundy asked. ``Because he had a desire to,'' Moore said. Under heavy cross-examination, Moore also testified that she continually brought up the subject of cocaine when Barry repeatedly declined interest in using it. In her second full day of questioning by Barry's attorney, Moore insisted that although Barry seemed suspicious throughout the evening, he still acted on his own in purchasing cocaine from an undercover agent and then smoking it just before agents stormed into the room and arrested him. Mundy also replayed the videotape of the mayor's hotel room session with the former model. ``I felt from the beginning, being in the room with him, he was suspicious,'' Moore said. ``I believe he felt intuitively something was going on.'' The videotape showed Barry continually berating himself after his arrest, saying he should have ``trusted my instincts'' and not visited Moore's room. But Mundy hammered away at the methods used to produce the mayor's arrest, asserting that Moore provided ``the pipe .. the light ... the know-how ... the liquor, the room ... the encouragement.'' Barry's attorney is arguing that the mayor's Jan. 18 arrest in an undercover FBI sting operation should not lead to a conviction because he was lured to Moore's hotel room to smoke the crack cocaine. Moore has testified that she and Barry used drugs together ``over 100 times'' during a two-year intimate relationship that ended six months before the Jan. 18 sting operation. Mundy buttressed his argument by pointing to seven instances in which Barry either declined to use drugs or expressed no interest in the subject when Moore began talking about it. But in portions of the transcript Mundy did not go over, Barry tells Moore, ``I'm going up to the Hilton. I may get ... a tab.'' Moore testified earlier that Barry was referring to cocaine when he used the phrase ``tab.'' At one point, after saying he did not want to use crack cocaine, Barry changed his mind and urged Moore to have the undercover agent return with the crack cocaine that Moore had just given back. On the videotape that was released last week, Barry said that he no longer ``smoked'' cocaine and said he did not know how to use the pipe that Moore provided. Mundy also concentrated on Barry's unfamiliarity with the crack pipe he used the night of the sting, saying that if the mayor were an experienced drug user, Moore would not have needed to show him how to use it. ``It was unusual,'' Moore said of the directions she gave Barry. ``I don't understand why he was asking me to show him how to use the pipe.'' Moore had initially testified that Barry was unfamiliar only with the type of pipe being used and needed instruction on it. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony counts of lying to a federal grand jury about his alleged drug use. One of the possession charges stems from his arrest in the sting operation. Moore also testified that she would have cooperated with the sting even if she had known of Barry's alleged heart condition. Emergency medical technicians were on hand after Barry's arrest to make sure that his ingestion of crack cocaine did not produce heart trouble. However, medical records Barry released last year show no record of heart illness. While Mundy and prosecutors battled in the courtroom, two black leaders filed suit to gain admittance to the proceedings. The local chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union filed papers with the federal appeals court asking that body to overturn Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's refusal to allow Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan and a dissident black Catholic priest from entering the proceedings. Jackson said that the presence of Farrakhan and George Augustus Stallings in the courtroom would be disruptive. ``The burden is on the judge to say why it would be disruptive,'' said Arthur Spitzer, legal director for the local ACLU. ``There has to be real evidence to base that decision on.'' Spitzer said Jackson's decision violates constitutional guarantees of the mayor's right to a public trial and the public's right to witness the proceedings. A dozen pro-Farrakhan demonstrators also gathered outside the courthouse to protest Jackson's decision. A federal appeals ourt panel ordered U.S. Attorny Jay B. Stephens to file by Tuesday any opinion he has regarding the ACLU suit. The ACLU was ordered to enter any follow-up papers by Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Gunning for Justice Lawyer Notches Another Win With Marcos Verdict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for story slugged AM-Marcos-Spence Profile on AM-News Digest
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Marcos Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Cowboy attorney Gerry Spence can cut another notch onto his six-shooter _ he won an acquittal for Imelda Marcos on racketeering and fraud charges Monday, adding to his long list of courtroom triumphs. Many of the successes of the lanky, silver-haired attorney have been played out before juries in courtrooms of the High Plains and the mountains of his native Wyoming. Although a nationally known attorney, this was Spence's first trial in New York, and it was a rough one. He often wrangled with U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan during the three-month trial. The judge complained about Spence's manner and cross-examination of witnesses. After one acrimonious blowup with Keenan, Spence told him he ``never felt so unwelcome in any courtroom. The jury adores you, judge, and they hate me.'' But after the jury acquitted the former Philippines first lady of looting her homeland's treasury to buy real estate, jewelry and art, Spence said he had always known the jury would be on his side. Spence, who wore a Stetson cowboy hat and boots to court and came to New York with a reputation of being virtually unbeatable, had trouble as soon as the trial began. He stumbled during his what he later conceded were the worst opening arguments of his career. His colleagues said he blundered in cross-examing several government witnesses, ignored or misread earlier testimony and elicited answers that were unexpected and damaging. Uncharacteristic behavior for a lawyer who Time magazine once called ``The Fastest Gun in the West.'' The magazine said a key to Spence's success was his exhaustive preparation. The lawyer, who has offices in a log cabin in Jackson, Wyo., has had a long string of successes, many of them described in his book, ``Gunning for Justice.'' In a lawsuit against Penthouse, held in a courtroom in Cheyenne, Spence referred to the magazine's publisher, Bob Guccione, as an arrogant New Yorker. He pointed out the New York publisher to the jurors as ``the gentleman sitting over there in the velvet pants,'' a type of attire rarely seen in the Cowboy State. In a 1979 lawsuit against Kerr-McGee Corp., an energy conglomerate, he repeatedly referred to the corporation's lawyers as ``the men in grey.'' Spence made his national reputation by winning that lawsuit on behalf of the family of Karen Silkwood, a nuclear plant worker who had become contaminated with plutonium. But Spence found that the shoe, or the cowboy boot, was on the other foot in the Manhattan courtroom. Court officials and other lawyers scoffed at his cowboy attire. Spence said felt ``great irony'' at the ridicule. Other lawyers on Mrs. Marcos' four-lawyer team, of which Spence was the leader, said his rambling opening statement and shambling courtroom manner had got him off to a bad start and that things had steadily deteriorated. At one point, the other Marcos attorneys pressured Mrs. Marcos to drop Spence, who was hired for a $5 million fee not long before the trial opened April 3. During the dispute Mr. Spence attributed the problem to a difference in styles. ``In high-profile cases, there's a lot of conflicting interests,'' he told The New York Times at the time. ``I'm here because she wants me here.'' In the end, Spence said prosecutors just didn't have the evidence to compel the jury to convicted Mrs. Marcos.

DOC.HEAD: Sullivan Defends Bush Veto of Family Leave Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, ``But this, with two grafs to CLARIFY that reported comments came after comments at commission session
DOC.TEXT: Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan on Monday defended the president's veto of parental leave legislation, saying the measure would have put an unfair burden on businesses. Sullivan said the family medical leave had a ``laudable goal ... this is, indeed, an ideal we would like to have.'' ``But this is not the best way to achieve this because the unintended consequences in terms of our economic competitiveness, viability of our businesses would really in the larger sense work counterproductive to that,'' he said. Sullivan commented after defending the administration on the issue at a roundtable discussion by National Commission on Children. The bill would have required companies to give as much as three months unpaid leave to workers with new babies or family illness. Bush vetoed it last Friday. But Gary David Goldberg, president of UBU Productions and creator of the television series ``Family Ties,'' said Bush's action is contrary to White House talk of strengthening the family. He called the veto ``much more of an offensive act than anything 2 Live Crew'' could ever dream of,'' referring to the rap music group that has been attacked for sexually explicit lyrics. Goldberg said Bush's message was clear: ``that business counts more than family.'' ``You can have Mr. Rogers, you can have Michael Jordan and Bill Cosby on television 24 hours a day, but if there's no one here in Washington willing to acknowledge and confront the changing face of the American family, the impact will be whistling in the wind,'' Goldberg said. Sullivan and Goldberg spoke at a roundtable discussion of the commission, a 36-member panel created by Congress and the president to assess the health and well-being of children. Monday's session focused how children develop values. The secretary said an erosion of basic values stemming from collapse of the family and community is the main reason behind some of children's must urgent problems, including teen pregnancy, infant mortality and drug abuse. He repeated his call for ``a new culture of character,'' in which individuals ``celebrate self-discipline and family commitment, rather than self-indulgence and short-term gratification.'' Phyllis Schlafly, president of the conservative Eagle Forum, said schools have failed to reinforce strong family values among children because ``they are not being taught what is wrong and harmful.'' Children today are too often given the facts about such things as drugs and sex and are then told to make their own choice. ``Why can't we teach that sex for unmarried minors is wrong and harmful. It is wrong and harmful,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Florio Gains National Kudos, But Faces Unrest At Home
LaserPhoto TN2
DOC.TEXT: In just six months, Gov. Jim Florio has made his mark as an aggressive, decisive and unconventional governor. He has enacted major auto insurance reforms, signed a ban on assault-style rifles and turned the state's school funding system upside-down. He also has said yes _ emphatically _ to new taxes. Those actions have drawn the attention of the national media and prompted New York Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a perennial non-candidate for president, to suggest Florio may be presidential material. But while the national spotlight has cast a warm glow on the Democratic rookie governor, Florio has made enemies at home. More than 5,000 angry residents spent a sunny afternoon at the statehouse Sunday to protest the tax increases and castigate Florio. Leaders of the rally, which also targeted President Bush, promise to launch a ``tax revolt'' in New Jersey. Florio's stance on assault weapons enraged the gun lobby. The New Jersey Education Association, the state's powerful teachers' union, has promised political revenge for the school funding bill, which took money from rich districts to improve education in poor districts. The teachers' group complained that the measure requires richer school districts to pay for teacher pensions, a tab traditionally picked up by the state. With the Democratic majority in both the Assembly and Senate facing a Republican challenge next year, Florio has fences to mend. He admits pitching the tax increases to a wary public will be difficult. But Florio believes he will overcome the opposition at home. He says he has taken on vexing problems in an era when fear of voter wrath has paralyzed politicians. ``As Joe Louis used to say, you can run but you can't hide,'' said Florio, a former Navy boxer. ``I was elected to lead, and I'm leading. You can't run from these problems, or they'll come back and bite you in a way that is very painful.'' Republicans, however, blast his tax increases and charge the governor with railroading his programs through the state Legislature. Florio steamrolled Republican opponent James Courter in the race for governor last year with a campaign that was praised as effective and criticized as nasty. Barely a week after his inauguration, the governor unveiled his auto insurance reforms, and traded harsh words over the plan with Allstate Insurance Co. officials. The Legislature swiftly passed the reforms. The auto insurance plan, which promises to cut rates by 20 percent next March, is being challenged in court by several insurers because it forces the insurance industry to pay half of a $3 billion debt facing a state pool for high-risk drivers. Florio's biggest battle was over the budget. He said he was being forced to break a campaign promise not to raise taxes because the state was facing a huge budget deficit left by former Republican Thomas H. Kean. Kean has defended his administration, but steadfastly refuses to comment on Florio. Democratic legislators delivered an increase in the sales tax from 6 percent to 7 percent. The tax now includes items such as disposable paper, soap, telephone bills, cigarettes and alcoholic beverages. A new tax on oil and a higher cigarette tax also passed. They all went into effect Sunday. Florio also got a higher income tax for about 17 percent of the state's residents to pay for the dramatic change in school funding. Florio pushed through a plan that would send more state dollars to poor districts and less to wealthy ones. His school funding revision was later backed by a state Supreme Court ruling that the school system discriminates against poor urban areas. However, Republicans have derided the Florio plan as one that would hurt middle-class residents who live in richer areas. Florio was the clear target at Sunday's anti-tax rally, organized by six private citizens with the help of a Trenton talk-radio station that publicized the event. It drew the year's largest crowd of protesters to the statehouse. ``There is growing voter frustration and anger over tax increases,'' said Assembly Minority Leader Chuck Haytaian, a Republican. Florio says he is not worried about a tax revolt. He says many residents will benefit from the property tax relief components of his plan, and that his actions avoided a costly downgrading of New Jersey's bond rating. ``Nobody likes taxes,'' Florio said. ``Hopefully, people will understand that we are being responsible.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Says Keep Sanctions In Place
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-6, `Mandela's remarks' with seven grafs to UPDATE with British reaction to Mandela's remarks on IRA, Mandela response and arrival in London. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `Mandela, the ...'
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said Monday that promises of change in South Africa should not bring an end to economic sanctions, because ``the reality is that the apartheid system continues.'' ``All the fundamental features of the South African racist system remain unchanged. In other words, no profound changes have taken place leading to the final abolition of the apartheid system,'' the deputy president of the African National Congress told a joint session of the Irish parliament. He also urged Britain to follow the example of President F.W. de Klerk's South African government and not require a cease-fire before talking to an armed foe, in this case the Irish Republican Army. Mandela's remarks met swift criticism in London, the next stop on his foreign tour. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who herself once narrowly survived an IRA bomb, is firmly against any compromise with the militants. Mrs. Thatcher has also lifted some of Britain's sanctions against South Africa despite Mandela's pleas for continued pressure. Members of the governing Conservative Party and the opposition Labor and Liberal Democrat parties said Mandela was mistaken in drawing a parallel between South Africa, where the black majority cannot vote, and Northern Ireland, which has universal suffrage. As he took leave from his Irish hosts, Mandela said he was saddened to be ``dragged into a controversy that is not of our making and which we never intended.'' ``We do not prescribe to anyone'' how peace should be achieved, he said. On arriving in London Monday night, Mandela deflected questions and said he would hold a news conference at the end of his British visit on Wednesday. Mandela arrived in Ireland on Sunday following an eight-city U.S. tour. Mandela, the first non-head of government ever to address a joint meeting of Ireland's 166-member Dail and 60-member Senate, delivered a 25-minute speech laced with allusions to Ireland's own struggle against ``unrelenting tyranny'' to achieve independence from Britain in the 1920s. Though he apologized for coughing due to a heavy cold, the 71-year-old black leader looked well as he took a walking tour of Leinster House, the seat of Parliament, before entering the packed chamber. His wife Winnie sat in the gallery. Earlier, at a news conference, he was questioned repeatedly about his attitude toward the IRA, which is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland. ``The only way of resolving this conflict and of stopping this mutual slaughter ... is to sit down and talk,'' said Mandela, who noted that the British joined in negotiations in Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe, while an armed struggle continued. The British and Irish governments both maintain that talks can only be held with the constitutional parties of Northern Ireland _ those that uphold the law and eschew violence. They say the IRA, outlawed on both sides of the border, represents only a small minority. Mandela said the South African government had long insisted the ANC lay down its arms before negotiations, but eventually joined in talks without extracting such a concession. Regarding sanctions against South Africa, Mandela said he expected to international community to follow the lead of the ANC. Mandela said de Klerk had asked to meet him as soon as he returned from his tour of Europe and the United States, ``and the reason for that is because sanctions are biting.'' He said: ``We are even more concerned than the government about sanctions because they are destroying our economy. We don't want it because we are the people who suffer. It is blacks who are thrown out of jobs... ``This is the price which we are prepared to pay in order to dismantle apartheid and to have the principle of one person, one vote introduced in our country.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 15th graf: ``Lenoir said,'' Atlantis testing continued on pad
DOC.HEAD: NASA Study Whether Misaligned Fuel Tanks Caused Shuttle Leak
DOC.TEXT: NASA engineers are focusing on a small misalignment of fuel tanks and spacecraft on two space shuttles as they search for the elusive hydrogen leaks that have grounded the shuttle fleet. The continuing mystery of the leaks is throwing the shuttle schedule into disarray and threatens to postpone at least two missions this summer, officials said Monday. Most of the 35 orbiter-tank combinations flown so far have had some misalignments, but the two found in the shuttles with the leaks are the largest to date, space flight director William B. Lenoir said. ``One of the areas we are looking at is the angle of connection between the external tank and the orbiter,'' Lenoir said. ``Ideally you think of them to be really aligned (but) it's never perfect, it's always some small degree of misalignment.'' Lenoir said the leak problem _ which shows up while the tank is being filled with supercold liquid hydrogen a few hours before flight _ must be fixed within a few weeks to keep NASA anywhere near its ambitious flight schedule. The schedule called for a Columbia launch in May on an astronomy mission, Atlantis in July, Columbia again in August and then Discovery in October. The hydrogen leak on Columbia in May and the discovery last week of a similar leak on Atlantis scrambled that schedule and Lenoir said it is unclear now if the agency can recover in time to fly all the missions this year. Discovery must go in October to take advantage of a planetary alignment that occurs only once every two years. The shuttle's cargo is the Ulysses science probe that is to study the sun. ``We're right on the edge of the point where two flights no longer fit in the schedule before the launch of Ulysses,'' said Lenoir. Fixing the leak, he said, will have to be quick and simple to avoid more changes in the NASA launch schedule. The shuttle orbiter _ the airplane-like vehicle in which astronauts fly _ is attached to the 154-foot-long fuel tank at three points, two on the lower end and one on the upper. Fuel flows from the tank to the orbiter's three engines through a 17-inch pipe that disconnects when the tank is empty and begins its fall back to Earth. One of the lower attachment points on Columbia's tank is .160 of an inch higher than the other and the one on Atlantis is off by .150 of an inch, said shuttle boss Robert L. Crippen. That small misalignment is well within the tolerance built into the shuttle system, he said. But whether that is enough of a deviance to put strain on the fuel line, also near the bottom of the tank, is being studied by one of the four teams NASA has set up to look into the problem. Lenoir said he hoped to get some answers by Thursday. Parts of Columbia are being tested in a laboratory. Atlantis was undergoing tests _ with helium substituting for the volatile liquid hydrogen _ while still on the launch pad Monday, despite severe thunderstorms and high winds that raked the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. ``We've been unable to say, `Hey, that's a problem area,''' Lenoir said. ``On the other hand, because of their coincidence we are not stopping there.'' NASA's science chief, Lennard Fisk, sought to put a brighter view on NASA's other headache, the faulty mirror on the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope that prevents the accurate focusing that scientists sought. ``There are two characteristics of the people who work for NASA,'' he said. ``We're stubborn and we're clever. We're going to make this thing work.'' NASA is consulting with experts in image processing _ using technology to enhance pictures received from the telescope. ``There is growing optimism that we will be successful,'' Fisk said. ``Six months from now, a year from now, I expect you all to ooh and ahh over the picture that Hubble is going to produce and of course, compliment the current management of NASA for their success in pulling it off.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Eases S&L Lending Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: Savings and loan regulators on Monday temporarily eased restrictions imposed by last year's bailout bill on thrift institution lending. As expected, the Office of Thrift Supervision said it would give healthy thrift institutions until the end of 1991 to meet stricter limits on the amount of money S&Ls may lend to one borrower. The exemption applies only to loans for residential projects, not commercial development. Also, only the roughly 1,100 thrifts _ of 2,500 _ that meet strict new capital requirements effective in 1995 are eligible. Aiming at high-flying S&Ls that risked all of their capital on one loan, last year's law said thrifts could lend no more than 15 percent of their capital to a single borrower. However, homebuilders used to borrowing from one thrift complained to Congress and the Bush administration that they were having trouble getting loans for sound projects. The National Association of Home Builders and other trade groups launched a lobbying campaign to get the standard temporarily eased. The transition rule will permit healthy thrifts to lend 60 percent of their capital to one borrower until the end of this year, when the limit drops to 30 percent. Beginning in 1992, the limit returns to the 15 percent required by the law. A month ago, an agenc official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the thrift office had submitted a draft of its new lending rule to the Treasury Department. Thrift Office Director Timothy Ryan, in a statement, said he supports the intent of the original restriction _ to prevent institutions from risking everything on one or two projects. But he said he ``believes the transition rule will give the best-capitalized thrifts time to adjust to the new requirement in a carefully prescribed and prudent manner.'' The loan-to-one-borrower rule is one element of a reported credit crunch affecting borrowers, particularly for real estate acquisition, development and construction. Commercial banks, who have operated under a 15-percent-of-capital limit all along, had opposed easing the rule. However, Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America, said his group was softening its stance in recognition that last year's thrift reforms, taken all together, may be too onerous. ``I think (thrift regulators) are trying to keep the healthy healthy and I think they're also reacting in part to the real estate lending crunch that is sweeping across this country and has people very, very worried,'' he said. Separately Monday, the Commerce Department said construction spending slumped 0.4 percent in May, the second consecutive decline.

DOC.HEAD: Mostly Dry Over 48 States
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms fell Monday along the central Gulf Coast and over Florida, but dry weather predominated across most of the country. The Florida thunderstorms produced 2.29 inches of rain in Gainesville during the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT. Showers were scattered over New Jersey, northern Minnesota and the Pacific Northwest. Strong, gusty southerlies blew over the southern High Plains. Temperatures were generally above 90 degrees from the Southeast to the High Plains, with readings above 100 degrees in Oklahoma, Kansas, Nebraska and South Dakota. It was 104 degrees in Salina, Kans., at 2 p.m. EDT. On Sunday, two dozen cities from the High Plains to the southern Atlantic Coast reported record high temperatures for the date. The mercury inched into the lower 80s in the Great Lakes region Monday, and was mostly in the 70s in the Northeast. Temperatures were only in the 50s and 60s along the northern and central Pacific Coast at midday, but were soaring above 100 degrees in the Southwestern deserts. The low for the Lower 48 states was 41 degrees at Gunnison, Colo. On Sunday, thunderstorms spawned five tornadoes in North Carolina and one in Virginia. There were more than 100 reports of large hail and damaging winds, with severe weather reports most numerous in North Carolina. There also were reports of severe weather in Florida, Utah and Montana. Preliminary data received by the National Severe Storms Forecast Center showed 412 tornadoes reported over the United States in June, considerably higher than the preliminary figure for any other month in the past 40 years. States with the highest preliminary June totals were Indiana with 65 tornadoes reported, Illinois and Kansas with 40 each, and Nebraska and Colorado with 35 each. The South Plains got nearly three weeks of 100-plus degree heat in the region's hottest _ and driest _ June in history, leaving cotton farmers fearing devastating losses.

DOC.HEAD: Prisoner Accuses Officials of Stifling His Marijuana Accusation
DOC.TEXT: Federal prison officials were accused in a lawsuit Monday of trying to silence an inmate who claimed during the 1988 presidential campaign that he had once sold marijuana to Dan Quayle. Inmate Brett C. Kimberlin accused federal prison authorities of canceling a press conference he had scheduled just four days before the election and in retaliation placing him in solitary confinement for a day. The Bureau of Prisons acknowledged in a letter to Kimberlin's attorneys that it placed him in solitary again on Nov. 7 when he tried to arrange a telephone conference call with reporters, according to court papers filed with the lawsuit in U.S. District Court. The lawsuit charged that Kimberlin was kept from meeting with reporters to repeat his allegation _ denied by Quayle _ before the Nov. 8 election, when the Indiana Republican won the vice presidency. J. Michael Quinlan, head of the Bureau of Prisons, and Loye W. Miller Jr., then the Justice Department's chief spokesman, were accused of concocting a false story that Kimberlin's Nov. 4 placement on solitary confinement was to protect him from other inmates. There was no answer late Monday afternoon at the public affairs office at the Bureau of Prisons and at the home of Miller. The suit charged that the two officials ``intentionally caused and facilitated Kimberlin to be placed repeatedly into detention for the purpose of stifling his attempts to communicate with the press about a matter of public interest and for the purpose of retaliating against Kimberlin for such attempts.'' The complaint charged that Quinlan cancelled the Nov. 4 meeting Kimberlin was to have with reporters even though it had been set up by officials at the federal prison in El Reno, Okla, where Kimberlin was being held at the time. Kimberlin is serving a 50-year sentence for marijuana smuggling and participating in a series of 1978 bombings in Speedway, Ind. Kimberlin, who has served 12 years of the prison term, was recently told at a parole hearing he could expect to be released in 1994. Kimberlin, who had claimed to several reporters in telephone conversations that he had sold marijuana to Quayle nearly 20 years ago, had granted an interview to NBC News on Nov. 4. After being deluged with requests from reporters to interview Kimberlin, prison officials scheduled a 7 p.m. press conference, which was canceled by Quinlan, the complaint said. Quinlan canceled the press conference even though Frank Keating, the associate attorney general, had previously advised ``that reporters should have the same access to Kimberlin as with any other prisoner,'' the lawsuit said. The Bureau of Prisons said in a recent letter to Kimberlin's lawyers that the press conference was cancelled because it was in violation of federal prison regulations.

DOC.HEAD: Four Militia Members Killed in Attack by Gunman, Battle
DOC.TEXT: Two members of the leftist militia that controls this southern port city were killed Monday in an attack by gunmen, police and militia reports said. Two other members of the Popular Nasserite Organizatio were killed later Monday in a battle with the Israeli-backed Southern Lebanese Army. In another attack, assailants tried to kill an official of the Palestine Liberation Organization in the Rashidiyeh refugee camp outside the southern port city of Tyre, police said. The PLO official was reported unharmed. In a statement, police said gunmen in a speeding car raked a checkpoint of the leftist Nasserite militia with AK-47 automatic rifle fire, killing two militiamen and wounding two. The gunmen were not identified. The report gave no further details about the shooting, which occurred on the first day of the Moslem holiday of Al-Adha, or the feast of sacrifice. The holiday marks the yearly pilgrimage to Mecca's Grand Mosque in Saudi Arabia, the holiest Moslem shrine. The fighters of the Nasserite militia later traded artillery fire around the hilltop town of Kfar Falous, six miles east of Sidon, with the South Lebanon Army. That group is an Israel-backed militia with Christian Lebanese officers. A Nasserite statement said the South Lebanon Army started the shooting. The leftist militia said two of its own fighters were killed in the bombardment. There was no comment from the South Lebanon Army. The 3,000-member militia polices Israel's self-declared security zone in south Lebanon. Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut, has a predominantly Sunni moslem population of 250,000. The 2,000-member Nasserite militia has ruled the city since the 1975 outbreak of Lebanon's Moslem-Christian civil war. The organization is headed by Sunni Moslem Mustafa Saad, whose militia is allied to Syria and bankrolled by Libya. He also maintains close ties with Yasser Arafat's PLO, whose 6,000 hard-core guerrillas constitute the strongest military force in south Lebanon. The police also reported a dynamite-throwing attack Monday on the house of Lt. Col. Abu Hamid, commander of the PLO garrison in Rashidiyeh, 50 miles south of Beirut. Hamid escaped unharmed, authorities said. The assault came two weeks after Arafat's guerrillas routed followers of terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal at the refugee camp.
