Five guerrillas of Abu Nidal's Fatah-Revolutionary Council faction were killed, 16 wounded and 40 taken prisoner in the fighting on June 17 and 18. Arafat and Abu Nidal, whose real name is Sabri al-Banna, have been at odds since Nidal broke away from Arafat's mainstream Fatah faction of the PLO in 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Major Airlines Cancel Flights Prior to Paris Air Controllers' Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Air strike due to start 6:30 a.m. Tuesday Paris time, 12:30 a.m. EDT)
DOC.TEXT: Major airlines canceled dozens of flights in and out of Paris in anticipation of a three-day strike by air traffic controllers due to begin Tuesday at France's largest flight control center. The strike would come at the start of the busy summer vacation season. KLM, the Dutch airline, announced Monday it canceled all 16 of its daily flights to and from Paris for the duration of the walkout. Air France and Air Inter, a French domestic carrier, earlier announced plans to reduce short- and medium-range flights by 60 percent. Air France said its long-distance flights would not be affected. The controllers seek higher pay and the hiring of additional staff to ease the workload at the Athis-Mons control center south of Paris. The center is responsible for all air traffic in far-northern France and two-thirds of aircraft departing from or arriving at the three Paris airports _ Roissy-Charles de Gaulle, Orly and Bourget. The strikers are demanding wage increases of from $540 to $900 a month. They now earn about $2,900 a month. Over the weekend, ferry crews ended a blockade of the harbor at Calais, but remained on strike to protest a proposed change in working hours. The action had caused major disruptions for travelers crossing the English Channel, forcing ferries to use the Belgian port of Zeebrugge instead of Calais.

DOC.HEAD: Weary Bensonhurst Jurors Tell Judge They're Stymied
DOC.TEXT: Jurors considering charges against a defendent in the Bensonhurst racial slaying case said Monday they couldn't agree on a verdict, but the judge asked them to try once more before he declares a mistrial. The development came on the eighth day of deliberations in the trial of John Vento, 21, the third man to stand trial in the slaying last summer of a black teen-ager in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. The weary-looking jurors filed back into state court shortly before 1 p.m., and sent Judge Thaddeus Owens a note that said in part, ``Each and every juror understands the arguments. However, we do not agree on what we understand.'' Vento is charged with murder, riot, unlawful imprisonment and other charges. If convicted of murder, he faces up to 25 years to life in prison. Owens asked the jurors if they were deadlocked, and nearly all of them nodded, `Yes.' It was unclear if the jurors were deadlocked on all or only some of the counts. ``You should attempt to resolve your differences,'' Owens told the jurors, but he added, ``If you come back tomorrow, if you are in the same position you are in now, I will take the necessary steps to discharge you.'' After the jury filed out of court, Owens told the lawyers for both sides that he would declare a mistrial if the jur could not reach a verdict by Tuesday. Owens dismissed the jurors around 6 p.m., but told them to return to court Tuesday morning. The events followed a frustrating weekend of deliberations in which the judge chided the jurors Saturday when they asked for a definition of the riot charge for a ninth time. On Sunday, the panel appeared to be concentrating on the charge of murder by depraved indifference and asked for further explanation on that count. ``Obviously, no one is happy about a situation where it looks like we're not going to get a decision,'' Vento's attorney, Gerald DiChiara, said outside the courtroom. ``It's just tough to go through all of this and not to get a decision.'' Prosecutors would not comment. DiChiara said he thought the judge handled the situation with ``great diplomacy and tact'' and said he believes the jury is deadlocked on all the counts. Yusuf Hawkins, 16, was shot to death Aug. 23 when he and three friends who'd gone to Bensonhurst to look at a used car were surrounded by a crowd of bat-wielding whites. Joseph Fama, 19, the alleged triggerman, was sentenced to 32 and two-thirds years to life in prison after he was convicted of murder. Reputed ringleader Keith Mondello, also 19, was acquitted of murder but was convicted of lesser crimes and sentenced to five and one-third years to 16 years. Vento at first planned to testify against the others, but changed his mind and fled to Ohio. He returned voluntarily after several weeks, but still refused to testify. He was then charged with murder.

DOC.HEAD: Bordeaux Mayor Bans National Front Meeting
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of Bordeaux on Monday refused to allow the extreme right National Front to hold its annual summer meeting in his city, saying it would be a risk to public order. Jacques Chaban-Delmas, who is also a ranking conservative parliamentary deputy, told a news conference he was breaking off negotiations with the National Front, which had sought to rent out meeting grounds belonging to the city. Bordeaux was the latest in a series of French cities which have refused municipal space for meetings of the far-right anti-immigrant party. The refusals started after the May 10 desecration of a Jewish cemetery in Carpentras, in southern France, which Interior Minister Pierre Joxe indirectly blamed on National Front leader Jean-Marie Le Pen. ``Protests have been numerous following the announcement of this meeting,'' Chaban-Delmas said. ``According to the information I have received, it is clear that public order would be threatened by serious disturbances'' if the National Front meeting were held in Bordeaux. Chaban-Delmas, of the Rally for the Republic party, said his decision did not amount to discrimination against the National Front. The National Front political bureau immediately issued a statement charging that Chaban-Delmas' decision was made ``under pressure from Rabbi (Joseph) Sitruk,'' the grand rabbi of France, ``supposedly acting in the name of the Jewish community.'' The statement said the Front would use ``all lawful means against the decision ... and against all calumnious commentaries which motivated it.'' Le Pen was recently charged with racial defamation for making a reference in an interview last year to what he called the ``Jewish international.'' He has been fined in the past for anti-Semitic statements. Following the Carpentras desecration, Joxe said Le Pen had contributed to a climate of hatred that could lead to such acts. Le Pen's National Front has been refused municipal space in more than a half dozen cities since then. His home town in Brittany, Trinite-sur-Mer, would not welcome him, and a big Paris meeting planned for a music hall nearly two weeks ago had to be held outside the capital in Le Bourget. The National Front, which became a political force in France in 1984, has the support of about 15 percent of the electorate, according to polls.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Employees Strike Draws Little Support
DOC.TEXT: About 1,500 students forced their way into a government ministry and occupied its courtyards for two hours Monday to back an announced strike by government employees. But most government ministries functioned normally Monday despite the strike, which was called by a Sandinista-dominated trade union to protest politically motivated firings. The National Employees Union had called for a walkout by the 100,000 government workers to protest what it called ``massive firings'' in violation of agreements reached with the government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro to end a strike in May. An estimated 1,000 workers in the mayor's office and Foreign Ministry took part in the strike. Most government workers are holdovers from the leftist Sandinista administration and fear cutbacks and political firings by the U.S.-backed government of Mrs. Chamorro, who took office April 25 after winning elections. Work at the Construction and Transportation Ministry was briefly disrupted after about 1,500 students forced their way into the building to protest a government decision forcing them to pay to ride public transportation. Police did not intervene as the students pushed through the building's doors and occupied the interior courtyards. Police threatened to use force to remove the students. But the protesters left peacefully two hours later after the minister, Jaime Icabalceta, promised to allow high school and university students to continue riding public transportation free of charge. The ministry had announced last week that it was removing the government transportation subsidy and ending free transportation for students. ``We are trying to restore one of the achievements of the revolution,'' said Mario Chamorro, vice president of the Secondary Students' Federation, referring to the 1979 Sandinista revolution that overthrew dictator Anastasio Somoza. Chamorro is not believed to be related to the president. Workers at some ministries said that although they had not walked out, they were ready to support the strike. Gloria Hernandez, secretary-general of the union at the Agriculture and Livestock Ministry, said ``the strike will be in stages.'' ``Here we're not on strike yet but we are ready to start it,'' she said. The government said in a communique that workers can strike ``as long as they fulfill the requirements of the law.'' The May strike drew the support of 65,000 government employees who were protesting the suspension of a civil service law that protected their jobs and benefits. After paralyzing the country for a week, the strike ended when the government promised to grant workers a 100 percent pay increase and not to retaliate against strikers. But Jose Angel Bermudez, the secretary-general of the National Employees' Union, said more than 800 government employees, most of them Sandinistas, have been fired out of ``pure revenge.'' The Chamorro government, in turn, has accused the Sandinistas of attempting to destabilize the new administration through strikes. Reducing the size of the government is part of Mrs. Chamorro's plan to slow the inflationary spiral and restore the country's battered economy.

DOC.HEAD: President Prepares for Changes, No ``Bombshell,'' in NATO Alliance
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Updates with later Bush comments, additional detail in top 11 grafs, picks up 10th graf pvs: ``The White,'' DELETES last two grafs as outdated
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met with top foreign policy strategists Monday to prepare for a NATO summit he says will bring changes but no ``bombshell'' in the Western alliance's military strategy. Bush, who used last year's NATO summit to unveil a proposal for major troop reductions in Europe, said, ``there will be some very interesting developments'' at the session Thursday and Friday in London. ``Some will call it dramatic policy changes and others won't,'' he told reporters. ``There will be some changes, but I don't happen to believe that it's bombshell dimension.'' Vice President Dan Quayle, Secretary of State James Baker III, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Colin Powell and other senior officials flew from Washington for the morning strategy session at Bush's vacation home overlooking the Atlantic. They met amid reports that Bush had already sent the NATO allies a blueprint for radically altering the alliance's ``flexible response'' strategy on when and how the West would use nuclear weapons to stem a Warsaw Pact invasion. Later Bush told reporters as he teed off for a round of golf with Quayle and others, ``We covered a lot of ground. We're ready, ready for NATO.'' National security adviser Brent Scowcroft, also in the golf party, said, ``We made a number of suggestions and proposals to our allies and a number of others have made suggestions.'' He said Bush wants to discuss the proposals first with his colleagues before going public with them. But U.S. officials said privately Bush will urge the NATO allies to overhaul their strategy for repelling a Soviet invasion by making the use of nuclear weapons a highly unlikely last resort. This would be a major change from the current strategy that explicitly maintains the option of early use of nuclear weapons to counter a massive Warsaw Pact invasion of Western Europe, a scenario of almost vanishing possibility when the Soviets are withdrawing troops from Eastern Europe and some Warsaw Pact members wish publicly they could be in NATO too. Bush also is ready to consider scrapping the 1,470 U.S. nuclear-tipped artillery shells now based mostly in West Germany and reducing or eliminating an arsenal of 1,560 U.S. nuclear bombs deployed in seven NATO countries, sources who insisted on anonymity told The Associated Press. The Washington Post and The New York Times first reported Monday that Bush would propose making nuclear arms weapons of last resort in Europe. The White House did not deny any of the news reports of the possible changes in NATO strategy that Bush was readying. Bush, fielding questions on the lawn outside his Walker's Point home, said, ``we're trying to get our act totally together. We're in good shape for the meeting. I think our side is generally agreed on the big questions.'' Bush said he expects the NATO summit to produce ``a document that is unanimously agreed to that will set the course for the future. And as conditions have changed, NATO will change.'' He said the United States already has had ``close contacts'' with allies on the proposals, and Baker was headed for Brussels on Tuesday to ``iron out some of the differences before we get there.'' Baker and other NATO foreign ministers were attending a 24-nation conference in the Belgium capital on aid to Poland and Hungary before the NATO summit. Alixe Glen, a deputy White House press secretary, said Bush was encouraged by the early feedback he has already gotten from the allies. On a separate issue, the White House distanced itself from Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole's remark Sunday that Bush was unlikely to accept higher tax rates as part of the current budget negotiations with Congress. ``That's Senator Dole's personal prediction,'' said Ms. Glen. ``The president has said a thousand times, 'No preconditions. Everything's on the table.''' Quayle's wife, Marilyn, accompanied him to Maine, and the couple were staying at Walker's Point as overnight guests of the Bushes. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady was also staying overnight. Brady was also on hand for a second strategy meeting planned to prepare for the economic summit in Houston that starts Monday with the leaders of the world's seven major industrialized nations. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and a team of economic experts were flying up Tuesday for that session.

DOC.HEAD: Ships Collide, Fuel Oil Leaks in Chesapeake Bay, River
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with oil washing ashore but dissipating in bay, still leaking but contained, danger apparently passed for fisheries; prediction of environmental damage as minimal; ships' owners and destinations, one owner taking responsibility for cleanup costs. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NK2
DOC.TEXT: Crews worked Monday to clean about 30,000 gallons of fuel spilled from the collision of two cargo ships in the Chesapeake Bay. It was one of the largest oil discharges into the estuary in more than a decade, authorities said. The spill was concentrated along the Elizabeth River section of the inner Norfolk harbor, and in the bay, where it had largely dissipated, officials said. Some fuel oil washed ashore along two miles of bayside city beaches in the Oceanview area of Norfolk. Oil was still leaking during the afternoon, but was being contained by booms and recovered by vacuum, said Capt. Eugene K. Johnson, commander of the Coast Guard Marine Safety Office in Norfolk. In addition to beaches, the spill raised concerns about the area's prime crab nursery. The crab harvest for the bay last year was 43.1 million pounds. ``If oil sinks to the bottom, it would kill or cover the crab larvae or eggs that are hatching,'' said Joe Maroon, president of Virginia's chapter of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation. But later in the day, Coast Guard officials and National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration scientists said the danger appeared to have passed for the bay fisheries. ``We're seeing minimal oil sheens out in the bay. The area of the (Elizabeth) River contaminated does not include any shellfish beds,'' said Ann Hayward Walker, NOAA's scientific coordinator with the Coast Guard. The cargo ships collided during a thunderstorm Sunday night four miles north of Norfolk, outside the Hampton Roads Bridge-Tunnel. The outbound Columbus America and the inbound Neptune Jade suffered extensive damage, said Johnson. The Columbus America, a hole below its water line, leaked about 30,000 gallons of No. 4 heavy fuel oil as it returned to a shipyard on the Elizabeth River. The oil was from the ship's fuel tanks, not from cargo. ``We consider this a major marine casualty because of the damage done and the amount of oil spilled,'' said Coast Guard Cmdr. George Naccara. Larry McBride, Tidewater regional director of the State Water Control Board, said the spill was one of the largest in the bay since the early 1970s. Johnson ordered the main shipping channel into Norfolk closed Monday morning as crews from the Coast Guard, Navy, water board and a private contractor worked to clean it. The channel reopened after about four hours. An aerial survey of the bay in the afternoon showed oil in the surf along a two-mile section of beachfront. By mid-afternoon, work crews had collected about 50 bags of oily debris, Johnson said. ``I think the environmental damage will be minimal,'' he said. But in the river, things did not look so good. ``We're covered in oil right now,'' said Gordon Shelton of the Tidewater Yacht Services marina on the Elizabeth River. ``I want to know who the hell is supposed to clean it up.'' Shelton said the oil contaminated the 200 boats in the marina, fouled his shoreline and covered the 20 or so ducks that live in the marina. The Coast Guard is investigating the accident; a board of investigation was scheduled to hear testimony Tuesday. Johnson said both vessels were carrying containers of hazardous material, including petroleum distillates, paint and laquer products, but none of the containers leaked. The region's main resort area, Virginia Beach on the Atlantic Ocean, will probably be spared, Johnson said. About 40 workers were on the Oceanview beaches since dawn, said Stanley Stein, acting director of the city's Department of Parks and Recreation. The Neptune Jade, owned by Neptune Orient Lines of Singapore, was headed for Halifax, Nova Scotia. Its last port of call was Panama City. The Columbus America, owned by Columbus America Inc. of Hamburg, West Germany, was bound for Melbourne, Australia. Johnson said Columbus America Inc. had taken responsibility for the cleanup costs, and that West Germany and Singapore were cooperating in the investigation. The bridge crews of both ships were tested for drugs and alcohol, a normal procedure after accidents, Johnson said. The Chesapeake Bay Foundation, a non-profit environmental group, called for more regulation of traffic on the bay. ``Given the fragility of the bay, the large quantities of oil transported on it, and the apparent inability of the current regulations to stop oil spills and clean them up, the states and the federal government must do more to prevent such potential catastrophes,'' said group Vice President Ann Powers.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapped American Described As Brilliant But Shy
With AM-Philippines-US
DOC.TEXT: A Peace Corps volunteer kidnapped by rebels in the Philippines was described as a brilliant but shy young man by acquaintances in his hometown. Timothy Swanson, 26, was abducted June 13 by members of the New People's Army from the island of Negros, where he was working as a volunteer for the Peace Corps. Swanson grew up and attended public school in Cheyenne. ``Tim was a very bright student,'' said Walt Miner, an English teacher at Cheyenne East High School, where Swanson graduated in 1982. ``He was very precise and he was quite a good student.'' ``He's a brilliant young man, kind of shy but intelligent,'' said the Rev. Eugene Todd of St. Mark's Episcopal Church, where Swanson served as an altar boy. ``To go (to the Philippines) and do what he was doing seemed perfectly natural.'' Swanson, a National Merit scholar, did not take part in sports in school, but focused instead on academics, said his father, Leonard Swanson. Swanson did not participate much in group activities, Miner said, although he added that he never considered Swanson a loner. After graduating from Cheyenne East, Swanson attended the University of Chicago, where he studied geography. Leonard Swanson said Tim became interested in joining the Peace Corps in 1987. ``He decided to go into the Peace Corps for basically humanitarian reasons,'' he said. ``He felt a need to try to help some folks who he thought might be in need.'' Swanson went to the Philippines in February 1988. He recently completed his two-year assignment, but obtained a 13-month extension. He was married to a Filipino teacher on May 29. Swanson enjoyed his work in the Philippines, which involved a reforestation project, his father said. He added that he believes his son has the qualities needed to weather the abduction. ``I think he has the personality and the patience, the perception to handle this in a satisfactory manner,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Fear Fireworks Could Ignite More Fires in Parched West
DOC.TEXT: Infrared cameras zeroed in on the last hot spots at the Santa Barbara fire Monday, and officials warned that July 4 fireworks could touch off a new plague of wildfires in the parched West. Officials lowered their acres-burned estimate for the Santa Barbara fire from 4,900 to 4,200, but doubled the damages to $500 million. Arsonists were blamed for that fire and others in Southern California's Los Angeles, Orange, San Bernardino, Riverside and San Diego counties that consumed more than 500 dwellings. Anyone near locations where the blazes broke out was urged to contact authorities no matter how sketchy their information. ``No matter how insignificant they think it is, when they add it to what we've got it may break the case open,'' Santa Barbara sheriff's Sgt. Tim Gracey said. Southern California, southern Colorado, southern Utah, Arizona and New Mexico are severely affected by a four-year drought, with big ``flash fuel'' crops of dry grasses ready to ignite, said national Fire Information Center spokesman Sheldon Wimmer. There have been fires in all those places in the past week. In Arizona, U.S. Forest Service officials estimated that a lightning fire in the Tonto Forest did $5.7 million damage and cost nearly that much in firefighting expenses and wages. It was the worst forest fire in Arizona history. Fire officials warn that northern California, northern Nevada and Idaho are expected to reach the same level of dryness later this summer. Those helped renew calls by many fire officials to ban all fireworks, even the so-called ``safe and sane'' variety. ``I hate that term `safe and sane fireworks' because it's a misnomer,'' said Fountain Valley Fire Chief Richard Jorgensen. Jorgensen and other Orange County fire chiefs boycotted a fireworks safety news conference two years ago when they learned that manufacturers of legal fireworks were also scheduled to appear. ``First of all, they burn at a temperature over a thousand degrees,'' Jorgensen said. ``We teach kids all year long not to play with fire, then we turn around on the Fourth of July and put them in their hands and tell them it's fun.'' Independence Day revelers often show lapses in judgment, like some young Fountain Valley adults caught lobbing fireworks back and forth at each other as they stood on a wood roof, he said. Near Santa Barbara, where 430 houses and 28 apartment buildings were destroyed, an overnight scare reminded edgy firefighters that they had only won a reprieve in what promises to be a months-long battle, fire Capt. Charlie Johnson said. At 4 a.m. Monday, gusts suddenly reached 35 mph near where the firestorm began Wednesday. The humidity dropped into the teens. The temperature rose to 79. Sparks were churned up into the air. ``It wasn't in the weather forecast,'' Johnson said. ``Just suddenly, the winds were blowing, similar to when the fires started. ``Because of that, it actually helped us some. The embers blew back into the burned area, and some places that flared up had natural burnouts instead of us having to go in with shovels and picks.'' Because of the flareups, however, officials decided to delay declaring they had the fire controlled. Control is now expected at 6 a.m. Tuesday. In addition to three water-dropping helicopters, one chopper carried an infrared camera to make sure firefighters got to the remaining hot spots, Johnson said. He said the winds had convinced officials to keep firefighting equipment and personnel on the scene much longer than earlier planned. ``It now appears we're going to have people assigned to this fire for eight or 10 days as a precaution,'' Johnson said.

DOC.HEAD: Mentally Retarded Death Row Inmate Goes On Trial For Second Time
DOC.TEXT: A mentally retarded man went on trial for a second time Monday in the 1979 stabbing death of a 22-year-old woman, a crime for which he was nearly executed four years ago. Prosecutors told jurors that Death Row inmate Johnny Paul Penry had nearly ``stomped'' the victim to death before calmly stabbing her with a pair of scissors. Defense attorneys said Penry's retardation was at the root of the case. Penry, now 34, has been on death row since 1980, when a jury convicted him of capital murder in the death of Pamela Moseley Carpenter. Mrs. Carpenter was the sister of former Washington Redskins kicker Mark Moseley. In 1986, he came within hours of execution by lethal injection before receiving a stay from the U.S. Supreme Court. The court vacated his death sentence two years ago, saying jurors should have been told about Penry's retardation. Prosecutors are re-trying the entire case because, under Texas law in a capital murder case, the penalty phase alone cannot be retried. In opening arguments Monday, District Attorney Joe Price described how Penry allegedly forced his way into Mrs. Carpenter's home the morning of Oct. 25, 1979, and how she was attacked. ``He dragged her, knocked her down, into the bedroom,'' Price said. ``He nearly stomped the life out of her, stomped her into submission. Then he calmly and deliberately walked across the room, picked up a pair of orange-handled scissors, sat on her stomach, looked her in the eye and stabbed her in the chest. ``You will never, for the rest of your lives, forget these orange-handled scissors,'' Price told the jurors. ``She reached up and pulled the scissors out of her chest.'' She died within hours of the assault. Penry confessed in a signed statement after he was arrested. ``In an ordinary case, perhaps a signed statement would convince you,'' Penry's attorney, John Wright, said of his client's confession to police. ``This is no ordinary case. Johnny Paul is mentally retarded. All the horror story you've just been recounted had its start right there.'' Penry has said he was abused by his parents, particularly by his mother, and never attended regular school beyond a few days in the first grade because of his retardation. He has an IQ estimated at between 50 and 60 and the reasoning capacity of a 7-year-old. In testimony Monday, Mrs. Carpenter's husband, Bruce, identified bloody clothing as belonging to his wife. He also described his wife of three years as ``young and beautiful'' and then identified her battered body in a picture taken after her death. Penry, who replied ``not guilty'' when asked Monday for a plea, sat attentively during the arguments and initial testimony. At times, he exchanged words with one of his attorneys. Penry has denied killing Mrs. Carpenter. ``I told them I did it, but I didn't do it,'' he has said. ``I don't know who did it. All I know is I didn't''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Defends Policies in Eastern Europe
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Monday defended policies that led to the ouster of hard-line Communist rulers across Eastern Europe, saying the region is ridding itself of Stalinism. ``Big changes are under way in Eastern Europe,'' Gorbachev said in his keynote speech to the 28th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party in the Kremlin. ``And when it is said, `It is the failure of socialism,' we ask in reply: `What kind of socialism?' The kind that was in fact a Stalinist version. Well, we are are getting rid of that ourselves,'' he said. ``The Stalinist model of socialism is being replaced by a civil society of free men and women,'' Gorbachev declared. Many hard-line Soviet Communists have questioned the wisdom of Gorbachev's relaxation of controls over its allies in the Warsaw Pact military alliance. Gorbachev told his fellow party members Monday that his policies had allowed change to occur peacefully in Eastern Europe. Except for Romania's violent revolution in December, little blood was shed as Communists rulers were overthrown elsewhere. Every East bloc Communist leader in power during the last Soviet Communist Party congress in 1986 was ousted by this spring. In Hungary and Poland, the changes came at the ballot box. Peaceful revolutions swept away the old orders in East Germany and Czechoslovakia. The Communists in Bulgaria ousted longtime rulers under the pressure of popular protests. The upheaval was produced in part by Gorbachev's social and economic reforms in the Soviet Union. Eastern European Communist reformers and opposition activists quickly sensed the significance of the policies of glasnost and perestroika that Gorbachev put into effect shortly after he took power in 1985. In addition, Gorbachev's tacit renunciation of the Brezhnev doctrine accelerated reform in Eastern Europe. That policy, outlined in 1968, limited the sovereignty of Moscow's Warsaw Pact allies and sanctioned the use of force to preserve socialism.

DOC.HEAD: Centennial Wagon Train Ends Its Journey
DOC.TEXT: Thirty dusty days on the Jim Bridger Trail ended in rain Monday as the Wyoming Centennial Wagon Train rolled into Cody with modern-day pioneers who relived the past to celebrate the state's 100th birthday. Approximately 200 wagons and 1,600 riders on horseback were greeted with a great whooping and hollering from several thousand well-wishers who jammed streets and roof tops to watch the four-mile-long procession. ``I wouldn't have bet there were this many horses in this whole United States,'' lifelong Cody resident Frank McJunkin, 70, said as he watched the parade of covered wagons, horses and exhausted but delighted riders ramble by. The cavalry led the wagon train to the end of its 260-mile trek along the Jim Bridger Trail, one of the main pioneer routes northwest through Wyoming. Riders recreating the Pony Express followed with state centennial flags. U.S. Sen. Alan Simpson, in a red Western shirt and beaded vest, rode the last few miles with the wagon train and predicted that years from now everyone will claim they rode along. ``There'll be as many people saying they rode the Wyoming Centennial Wagon Train as said they saw Babe Ruth's last game at Yankee Stadium _ about 7 million,'' said Simpson, who grew up in this frontier town founded by showman Buffalo Bill Cody. Kayne Pyatt, the trail boss who oversaw the journey organized by a group of enthusiasts, said, ``It's sort of like I've lived a great childhood adventure, a fantasy. ... If I died tomorrow, I'd be satisfied.'' The riders started the day about 16 miles east of Cody and followed alongside U.S. 14A, encountering a torrential downpour about a mile out. Simpson and his wife, Ann, were joined on the final leg by Wyoming Gov. Mike Sullivan and his wife, Jane, and Wyoming Rep. Craig Thomas and his wife, Susan, all on horseback. Montana Gov. Stan Stephens rode in a red surry. The sun broke through as they reached the edge of town, but distant thunder and lightning added a dramatic backdrop. Horses reared and bucked, riders waved and hollered and a few wagon passengers played their fiddles to the Cody crowd. ``Cody loves you,'' some spectators yelled. ``Happy birthday Wyoming!'' Some of the trail riders welcomed the return to modern conveniences, while others regretted reaching the end of the line. ``In a way, it's sad and in a way I'm glad to roll into Cody,'' said Ken Hagen, 71, of Roseau, Minn. ``The dust was the worst. Some days, there was so much dust you couldn't see the team ahead of you. And for six days, we never saw a tree.'' The final miles brought together past and present, as modern-day vehicles on the highway buzzed by the rumbling replica wagons. ``This is a chance for a person like me to be a part of history, maybe not a significant part, but a part,'' said Mike Wozniak, of Casper, who spent two days on the trail. ``This wagon train is not going to happen again _ maybe not for another 100 years.'' The train left Fort Caspar June 2. Besides the dust, it was accompanied by fears the organizers wouldn't be able to pay their bills. Arriving here, the organizers estimated they were about $100,000 shy of the approximately $500,000 they figured they'd need to pay for things like hay, water and portable toilets. Participating costs ranged from $40 a day to just ride along in your own rig, to $198 a day to ride on one provided. The organizers also raised money through contests and auctions along the trail, and plan to raffle off an elk permit donated by Gov. Mike Sullivan.

DOC.HEAD: Where's a 2-Ton Crouton When You Need One?
DOC.TEXT: Talk about your garden-variety oil spills. Firefighters and street sweepers mopped up 2,000 gallons of corn oil _ the kind used to make salad dressing _ that spilled from a holding tank over the weekend. Vandals broke into the Van Law Food Products Co. in Orange County south of Los Angeles on Sunday afternoon and tapped the oil tank, said plant manager Murray Mickelson. They also spilled fruit-punch concentrate and splattered paint on the machinery. Mickelson said the vandalism caused an estimated $100,000 in damage and cleanup costs. The company makes California Classic Salad Dressing with the corn oil.

DOC.HEAD: Tragedy and the Pilgrimage to Mecca Are No Strangers
With AM-Mecca Deaths
DOC.TEXT: Tragedy and the hajj _ the pilgrimage to Mecca that every Moslem is expected to make at least once _ are no strangers, and Monday's disaster was the second in three years in which a great number of pilgrims lost their lives. In 1987, clashes with Saudi security forces in Mecca killed 402 people during the hajj, 275 of them Iranians. Hundreds were injured. The year before, the Saudis had confiscated large quantities of explosives from members of the Iranian contingent to Mecca. In 1979, religious extremists seized the Grand Mosque in Mecca and held it for two weeks before Saudi forces stormed it. More than 250 people were killed and Saudi authorities later beheaded 63 more. Saudi Arabia restricted the number of pilgrims and later broke off diplomatic ties with Iran after the 1987 carnage, the most serious of a series of incidents during pilgrimages since Iran's Islamic revolution in 1979. The incidents were fired by Iranian efforts to politicize the hajj and encourage other Moslem nations to seize shrines at Mecca and Medina from the control of the kingdom's Saud royal family. Last month, the Saudi government said Iranians were welcome to take part in this year's Islamic pilgrimage to Mecca, but would not be allowed to demonstrate. It was an anti-American demonstration that led to the 1987 slaughter. Iran denied in September 1989 that it was involved in two bomb blasts in Mecca two months earlier, and Tehran-supported terrorists vowed to avenge Saudi Arabia's execution of 16 Shiite Moslems convicted of setting the explosions. The bombs exploded as thousands of people took part in the annual pilgrimage to Islam's most sacred city, killing one person and injuring 16. The explosions erupted as hundreds of thousands of pilgrims were praying and walking around the Kaaba, Islam's holiest shrine, inside the Grand Mosque. The attacks were believed connected to the centuries-old feud between Sunni and Shiite Moslems. Every Moslem, Sunni or Shiite, has a duty to make the pilgrimage to Mecca, the birthplace of the 7th century prophet Mohammed, and to Medina, where Mohammed is buried. Sunnis and Shiites disagree about who should have succeeded Mohammed, who founded Islam. Iran, which has an overwhelming majority of Shiites among its nearly 50 million people, had been urging Moslems to seize Mecca and Medina. Last year, an estimated 1.8 million Moslems from more than 80 nations went on the annual pilgrimage. An estimated 2 million people attended this year.

DOC.HEAD: Former Cincinnati Post Editor Dick Thornburg Dead at 86
DOC.TEXT: Dick Thornburg, editor of The Cincinnati Post during much of the Fifties and Sixties, has died at age 86. Thornburg died Saturday in Prescott, Ariz., where he had lived. The cause of death was not given. ``He was the consummate newspaperman,'' said William R. Burleigh, senior vice president of Scripps Howard and a former editor of the Post. ``He loved newspapers and he understood what the role of a newspaper was in the community.'' Thornburg began his journalism career in 1929 as a $17.50-a-week copy boy with the old Columbus (Ohio) Citizen. He was managing editor of the Scripps Howard Newspaper Alliance in Washington, D.C., before being named editor of the Post in 1953. He retired from that job in 1969. Former Ohio Gov. James A. Rhodes recalled that Thornburg was a leading advocate of building Cincinnati's Riverfront Stadium downtown along the banks of the Ohio River, rather than in the suburbs. The downtown advocates won and the ballpark _ now home of baseball's Cincinnati Reds and football's Cincinnati Bengals _ opened in June 1970. He is survived by his sister, Virginia Dungan of Silver Springs, Md. There were no ceremonies planned, the Post said Monday.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: RETRANSMITS a0654 to CORRECT spelling of name in headline
DOC.HEAD: Moseley Sworn in as Assistant Agriculture Secretary
DOC.TEXT: James Mosely, a veteran of the Environmental Protection Agency, was sworn in Monday as assistant secretary of agriculture for natural resources and environment, the Agriculture Department said. Mosely, 42, was confirmed for the job by the Senate on Friday. He was sworn in by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, who called him ``an outstanding professional.'' As assistant secretary, Mosely will oversee operations of the Forest Service and the Soil Conservation Service. Mosely, an Indiana native, had served the past year as agricultural adviser to EPA Administrator William Reilly.

DOC.HEAD: Sharpton Acquitted of Fraud and Larceny
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Al Sharpton, a flamboyant black activist, was acquitted Monday of charges he stole money from a civil rights group he started as a teen-ager, then spent it on himself. The state jury deliberated for less than six hours before finding Sharpton innocent on all counts of fraud and larceny, said Ed Barbini, a spokesman for the office of state Attorney General Robert Abrams. The trial lasted almost two months. The state called more than 80 witnesses; the defense called none. Sharpton was charged with stealing about $250,000 from the now-defunct non-profit National Youth Movement, a civil rights organization he started as a 16-year-old high school student, and spending it on himself. If convicted, he would have faced up to seven years in prison. ``We accept the verdict of the jury. We could not ignore the body of evidence that pointed to improprieties at the National Youth Movement, and we felt it was our obligation to take these allegations before a jury,'' Barbini said. Assistant Attorney General Victor Genecin charged in his summation that Sharpton ``sold ideals,'' then cheated the people he was supposed to be helping. Sharpton's lawyer, Alton Maddox, said he was pleased with Judge Joan Carey's handling of the case. Maddox said the charges brought against his client were baseless and accused Abrams of acting out of vindictiveness because Sharpton had advised Tawana Brawley, the black teen-ager found by a grand jury to have concocted a tale of abduction and sexual assault at the hands of a gang of white men. Maddox, 44, also represented Brawley. In May he was suspended from practicing law for refusing to appear before a grievance committee investigating his conduct in the widely publicized Brawley case. The judicial panel let him finish the Sharpton case. ``I'm not worried about anything,'' Sharpton said after the jury retired, ``except maybe on which side of the bars I'm going to do my work. I'm not tied to any geographical location.''

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Higher in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold rose 58 cents an ounce Tuesday, opening at $358.53. It closed at $357.95 Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Upholds Anti-Sleeping Ordinance
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge says a town may arrest people who sleep on the beach or in their cars in beachside neighborhoods, rejecting a challenge to an ordinance's constitutionality. The law for the town of Westerly doesn't involve ``a fundamental right,'' U.S. District Judge Francis J. Boyle said in a ruling handed down Friday and released Monday. The state American Civil Liberties Union challenged the law on behalf of two Connecticut men arrested in July 1988. The case was expanded to a class action covering 268 people arrested during the past three years. The ACLU said enforcement was unfair because Rhode Island residents were given summonses and released, while out-of-staters were jailed unless they appeared before a justice of the peace, pleaded no contest and paid a $20 fine. Boyle ruled that Westerly had a legitimate interest in treating out-of-state residents differently because if they fled after release there was no way to bring them back to court on the misdemeanor charge. The ACLU also argued that the law discriminated against those who could not find lodging here during the busy tourist season and made them drive out of the area when dangerously tired. Westerly Police Chief Mark S. Champlin contended the nearly 30-year-old ordinance was needed to reduce a rash of crimes in beachside neighborhoods. ``By preventing persons from camping on Westerly's beaches and parking lots, without proper amenities and sanitary facilities, the town protects important governmental interests,'' Boyle said. He rejected what he called the plaintiffs' contention that ``the Constitution of the United States provides them with an assurance of an evening's lodging in Westerly.'' Westerly is about 50 miles southeast of Providence.

DOC.HEAD: Haitian Political Activist Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs with background on council attack, aborted 1987 elections.
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A gunman identified as a soldier jumped from a truck and killed a political activist outside a house where the victim was attending a friend's wake, privately owned Radio Haiti-Inter reported Monday. It was the latest in a series of attacks blamed on terrorists seeking to derail presidential elections scheduled for Nov. 4. Mariano Delaunay, a lay teacher at a Roman Catholic school and founder of a night school for urban poor, was shot Sunday night while standing on a sidewalk in the Port-au-Prince slum of St. Martin, the radio station said. It said the killer drove up in a red truck, got out and shot Delaunay in the head and chest. The report did not say whether the assailant wore a uniform, but witnesses said they recognized him as an army sergeant. Haiti has experienced an upsurge in violence since the installation of an independent Electoral Council on May 2 to organize presidential elections. The army leadership has pledged to cooperate with the civilian caretaker government of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot in providing security for the coming elections. But loyalists of the former Duvalierist dictatorship, both in and out of the army, are violently opposed to a transition to democracy. On June 28, four gunmen, including two in army uniforms, attacked a meeting of the 19-member Council of State and killed council member Serge Villard and union activist Jean-Marie Montes. Haiti's last attempt to hold free and fair elections, on Nov. 29, 1987, failed when thugs supported by the army shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters at polling stations.

DOC.HEAD: New Effort To Get Peace Talks Resumed
DOC.TEXT: U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar met with Iran's foreign minister late Monday in an effort to rekindle the stalled Iran-Iraq peace talks. The Iranian official, Ali Akbar Velayati, indicated after the meeting that new direct talks with his Iraqi counterpart, Tariq Aziz, might be in sight. ``It's possible, but it depends on the assessment of the Secretary General after his meeting with the Foreign Minister of Iraq,'' he told reporters after the three-hour meeting. Perez de Cuellar is scheduled to meet the Iraqi official, Tariq Aziz, on Tuesday. The peace talks started Aug. 25, 1988, five days after a U.N.-sponsored cease-fire tentatively ended the eight-year Gulf war. The negotiations have bogged down over the first point in the cease-fire resolution, which called for a withdrawal to internationally recognized boundaries. The main sticking points include the continued presence of Iraqi troops on Iranian territory and the longstanding dispute over the Shatt-al-Arab, the confluence of the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers which forms the southern boundary between the two countries. The stalemate has left an estimated 100,000 soldiers in prisoner-of-war camps maintained by both sides.

DOC.HEAD: Plane With Six Aboard Crashes on Mount Rainier
DOC.NOTE: Eds: EDITS throughout to ADD times plane vanished and was found, minor editing elsewhere; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A small airplane with six people aboard crashed Monday on a glacier high up Mount Rainier, officials said. There was no immediate word on the fate of the pilot or passengers, said Mount Rainier National Park spokesman Cy Hentges. The Cessna 210 was en route from Portland, Ore., to Penticon, British Columbia, when it vanished from radar screens shortly after 1 p.m., according to Bill Hamilton, state aeronautics director. The plane was about two miles southwest of the 14,410-foot Cascade Mountain peak. An emergency beacon was picked up a short time later. Around 5:30 p.m., an Air Force search plane from Portland found the wreckage of the plane on a glacier on the west side of the mountain at the 12,500-foot level, below an area known as the Sunset Amphitheater, Henges said. The pilot of the search plane was running low on fuel, and could not determine the status of those aboard the plane, he said. National Park Service rescue workers called for a high-altitude helicopter from the Fort Lewis Army base to ferry them to the site, Hentges said. The Army agreed to send a CH47 helicopter from Fort Lewis, said base spokesman Sam Cagle. The pilot of the Cessna was identified as H.R. Card, believed to be from Pendleton, Ore., Hamilton said. The names of the others on board were not immediately available. Mount Rainier is about 100 miles north-northeast of Portland.

Moseley, 42, was confirmed for the job by the Senate on Friday. He was sworn in by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, who called him ``an outstanding professional.''
