Moseley, an Indiana native, had served the past year as agricultural adviser to EPA Administrator William Reilly.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Hears Final Arguments In Buckey Case
DOC.TEXT: A defense lawyer Monday urged a jury to end the 7-year-old McMartin Pre-School case ``once and for all'' by acquitting Raymond Buckey of child molestation. ``The truth never had a chance,'' attorney Danny Davis said as he showed jurors an enlarged copy of a letter police sent McMartin parents in 1983 suggesting Buckey might have molested children. ``End this case once and for all,'' Davis said in his final argument in the second trial in which Buckey is accused of molesting students at his family's now-defunct Manhattan Beach pre-school. But a prosecutor said Buckey is guilty. Deputy District Attorney Pam Ferrero urged the jurors to discount the testimony of former McMartin teachers called by the defense who had been accused of molesting students and cleared. ``I think it's quite possible that people in this case were falsely accused,'' Ferrero said in her closing argument. ``I'm not here to apologize for anyone that came before me. Nor am I going to say the investigation in this case was perfect. But I think it's clear that anyone who's been accused in this case has an ax to grind. They in their own minds feel they have been wronged by the system.'' Ms. Ferrero and Deputy District Attorney Joe Martinez took over the case after two other prosecutors bowed out. Buckey, 32, is on trial for a second time on eight counts of child molestation in what has become the longest and costliest criminal proceeding in U.S. history. In the first trial, he and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, were accused of molestation and conspiracy. It lasted 2{ years and ended Jan. 18 with Mrs. Buckey acquitted of all charges and Buckey acquitted of 40 counts of molestation and conspiracy. Jurors deadlocked on 13 other charges against Buckey, and prosecutors refiled eight of those counts. Five other McMartin teachers originally were accused of molesting students but charges against them were dropped for lack of evidence after a preliminary hearing. Mrs. Buckey, 63, was called as a prosecution witness in her son's second trial, which has lasted three months. Buckey has testified that he never molested any children. Ms. Ferrero ridiculed Buckey as ``a young man who worked for his mommy, a woman who was quite dogmatic.'' She repeatedly cited the testimony of three young girls who claim Buckey molested them up to 11 years ago. Conceding that the girls gave sometimes contradictory testimony, she cited the time elapsed and the ordeal they've experienced, and said their testimony should be believed. ``The children's testimony is corroborated by the circumstantial evidence in this case,'' Ms. Ferrero said. At another point she said, ``This particular case boils down to credibility. Who do you believe? If you believe the children, then the people have proved their case beyond a reasonable doubt.'' Davis said a number of parents ``bought into'' a story of molestations which did not take place. He noted that at least two of the three girls who testified in the second trial had accused other McMartin teachers of molestation, only to see them acquitted. He stressed that the children's and parents' stories have changed over the years, noting that the three girls who testified were 12 and 13 years old but talking about experiences as toddlers.

DOC.HEAD: Ninth Victim Dies a Month After Storms
DOC.TEXT: A 65-year-old woman has died from injuries suffered in tornadoes that tore across Indiana a month ago, bringing the death toll to nine. Evaline Hilgeman of Petersburg died Sunday at St. Mary's Medical Center in Evansville. Two-thirds of this southern Indiana city was destroyed in the tornadoes that touched down June 2 in about 50 locations, injuring more than 150. Mrs. Hilgeman, Pike County auditor from 1974 to 1982, and her son, Lawarell, were trying to reach a neighbor's basement when the tornado struck. The neighbor, Mayor Jack Kinman, said he and his son found Mrs. Hilgeman about 15 feet from their door. ``It was eerie,'' said Kinman, whose home was destroyed. ``There wasn't anything on top of her. She was just lying there.'' ``She had to take oxygen all the time and she had her tank with her. ... I think she had it on a cart and that slowed her down.'' Kinman said Mrs. Hilegeman suffered a broken leg, arm and collar bone. Her son was not seriously injured.

DOC.HEAD: Hazelwood Lawyers File Appeal
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for the captain of the Exxon Valdez have appealed his misdemeanor conviction, arguing the judge should not have allowed prosecutors to use the skipper's blood-alcohol test. Joseph Hazelwood is appealing his conviction by a state Superior Court jury on one count of negligent discharge of oil. He was acquitted March 22 of more serious charges that he had been drunk and reckless when the tanker ran around. He was ordered to pay $50,000 in restitution to the state of Alaska and to spend 1,000 hours scrubbing still-oiled beaches on Prince William Sound. The sentence was postponed pending the appeal before the Alaska Court of Appeals. Attorneys raised 20 arguments in the appeal. They contended that trial Judge Karl Johnstone erred in allowing evidence of Hazelwood's blood-alcohol test into the record. The test was taken 10 hours after the tanker grounded. They also argued the judge should have allowed the defense to introduce tests showing traces of alcohol and marijuana in the blood of Coast Guard employees on radar watch the night the tanker struck the reef. The Exxon Valdez ran aground March 24, 1989, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Hajj Is World's Largest Religious Gathering
With AM-Mecca-Deaths, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The hajj, an annual pilgrimage to Islam's holiest shrines in Saudi Arabia, is the world's largest religious gathering. It brings together Arabian princes, merchants from Indonesia, peasants from Soviet Uzbekistan, and paupers from Bangladesh. The hajj must be made at least once in a lifetime by all Moslems who can afford it. Performing the hajj is one of the five ``pillars'' of the Islamic faith. The others are professing that there is only one god and Mohammed is his prophet, saying the five daily prayers, giving alms to the poor, and observing the dawn-to-dusk fast during the lunar month of Ramadan. A Moslem who performs the pilgrimage is called a hajji. Each year, hundreds of thousands of Moslems from around the world travel to the holy city of Mecca by land, sea or even on foot for the pilgrimage. The pilgrims join in chanting ``God is so great and to him we pay high tribute.'' Waves of veiled women and men in white seamless robes, signifying equality before Allah, take part in the prayers. During the hajj, pilgrims must abstain from sex and may not quarrel, cut their hair, or even kill a fly. The hajj is performed during the Islamic lunar months of Shawwal, Zul- Quideh and Zul-Hijjeh. Similar rituals performed out of the season are called ``Umrah,'' or lesser hajj. The hajj proper is limited to six days. A pilgrim may commence the rituals at any time during the three months. Hajjis start the pilgrimage by praying at the Grand Mosque in Mecca. They then circle seven times around the Kaaba, a granite cube draped with gold-embroidered black brocade. Moslems honor the Kaaba as the house of Allah, where the Prophet Abraham offered his first prayers to God. As they circle the cube, pilgrims bend to kiss the sacred black stone set in silver on the east corner of the granite structure. Moslems believe the stone is a meteorite which came from heaven. The legend says the stone was originally white, but became black over the centuries as hajjis washed away their sins on it. Hajjis are then required to run back and forth seven times between two rocks about half-a-mile apart, called al-Safa and al-Marwa. This ceremony is meant to relive the agony of Hagar, Abraham's second wife, when she was looking for water for her son Ishmael, considered the ancestor of the Arabs. The main center of the pilgrimage then moves to Mina, a meeting place for the hajjis to gather before they climb Mount Arafat for the climax of the observances. Moslems believe Arafat is where Abraham showed his devotion to God by offering to sacrifice his son. At Mount Arafat, each pilgrim throws seven stones at each of the three ``devil pillars,'' a spot where Moslems believe the devil tried to tempt Abraham to disobey Allah and refuse to sacrifice his son. At twilight, pilgrims offer the Eid Al-Adha, or Feast of Sacrifice, prayers before slaughtering hundreds of thousands of sheep, cows and camels. The meat traditionally goes to poor Saudis. But since the discovery of oil virtually eliminated poverty in the kingdom, most is flown to poor Moslems in 26 countries. Hundreds of thousands of pilgrims then stream down Mount Arafat to the Mina plain and on to Mecca for the farewell prayer before dispersing _ creating what may be the world's biggest traffic jam. Arafat is about eight miles from Mecca. It is at this stage that most accidents occur. The Saudi government has spent $15 billion in recent years on a development plan to move pilgrims in a more orderly fashion for the hajj, building networks of roads, tunnels, dormitories and medical clinics. The tunnel where Monday's tragedy occurred is one of several equipped with giant ventilators and air conditioning.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Dodges Demand for Resignation, Calls for Unity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with color, Bush comment. Picks up 4th graf, `It was ...'
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev parried a demand on Monday that he resign and urged unity among bickering factions of the Communist Party in what he said was a race to keep the country from becoming a second-rate power. Despite a lack of enthusiasm for his 2-hour, 20-minute speech opening the Communist Party's crucial 28th Congress, the Soviet leader appeared to have papered over differences between reformers and traditionalists with equal doses of confrontation, conciliation and confession. Applause was rare and very light during his speech. Delegates displayed little strong emotion despite declarations by the party leader that the congress would decide the Communist Party's fate. They came to life with a vengeance, however, with derisive whistles and a contemptuous waving of their red party cards, when party ideology chief Vadim Medvedev tried to deliver a speech on the current political situation. President Bush was asked in Kennebunkport, Maine, about the criticism Gorbachev was getting from hard-liners. ``I know the feeling,'' Bush quipped. It was unclear whether Gorbachev could continue to hold back the explosive disputes among the 4,657 delegates threatening his leadership and the unity the party has maintained since the 1920s. Gorbachev defended his reforms and insisted radical reform is vital because the Soviet Union ``is rapidly becoming a second-rate power.'' Only nine minutes into the congress, the Soviet party chief and president faced a demand for his resignation. Coal miner Vladimir Bludov from the Far East said the leadership had bungled a program to improve food supplies and implement other reforms. Another reformer, Yuri Boldyrev of Leningrad, called for the nationalization of the party's property. Attacks on Gorbachev's leadership are increasingly frequent as reformers and traditionalists find fault with a failing economy, republics bent on secession, and rampant crime. ``I think we can return to this proposal,'' the Soviet leader said evenly in response to Bludov, and the congress overwhelmingly supported him. At the end of the day, Politburo member Alexander N. Yakovlev, considered by many the brains behind Gorbachev's reforms, won an ovation for a fiery speech calling for delegates to rally around Gorbachev. ``Tomorrow the party will not be alone in this violent political sea,'' he said, referring to new parties the communists have permitted. ``Criticism will be mounting. This is when both unity and confidence will be especially necessary, and we should learn it today.'' When the 10-day congress is over, it will have elected a party leader and Central Committee, and will have approved new party rules and platform. Yakovlev, a frequent target of conservatives, stepped out of Gorbachev's shadow to warn that ``only a renewed, younger and more leftist party will be able to lead the country forward to more serious reforms.'' ``Let us remember that not only empty store shelves forced perestroika, but empty souls as well,'' he said. ``It's impossible to stop the movement, it will continue with or without the party.'' Gorbachev sharply attacked the party bureaucracy for impeding reform, but did not yield to reformers' demands that the party get out of the army, KGB, police, and workplaces. He received some of his strongest applause when he said party cells will remain. He defended policies that led to the replacement of hard-line Communist leaders in Eastern Europe. Gorbachev said those countries were freeing themselves from Stalinism, as the Soviet Union itself is doing. In a counterattack on traditionalists who seized control of a reconstituted Communist Party in the huge Russian republic, Gorbachev chastised ``leading cadres who prefer the old and are ... quite incapable of integrating in the reform processes, and who, moreover, refuse to accept them either politically or psychologically.'' He said street crime and the Soviet Union's fragile unity have worsened. His most visible rival on the ruling Politburo, Yegor K. Ligachev, said at a mid-June meeting that Gorbachev could not hold down both the party leadership and the Soviet presidency. On Monday, Ligachev would not say whether he expected a formal challenge to Gorbachev. Gorbachev acknowledged the Politburo and other party leaders had been late or mistaken in making key decisions. But he laid much of the blame for the nation's economic, political and ecological crisis on a ``heavy legacy'' of abuse and stagnation under Stalin and other leaders. Reform-minded delegates said they were unimpressed with Gorbachev's report. ``I expected it to be more constructive, more radical with greater understanding of the fact that the fate of the party depends on this congress,'' said reform-minded Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak. The radical Democratic Platform said previously that its 100 delegates would walk out of the session and announce a formal break. However, Grigory Omelchenko, a member from Kiev, said they decided to stay. ``The most important thing is that there must not be a consolidation of forces from the center and the right wing,'' he said. Another reformer, Sergei Stankevich, said the group would lobby legislatures after the party congress to divide up its property. Despite its small representation at the congress, members believe they have the backing of up to 40 percent of the party's 18 million members. There also were conciliatory words from traditionalists. Alexander Buzgalin, a member of the hard-line Marxist Platform, told reporters that leaders like Stankevich and Ligachev must stay in the party. ``It's difficult for such people to stay in the same party, but it will be reality for now,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Files Criminal Charges Against Noriega
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT one graf after 7th graf, ``It should ...' to UPDATE with U.S. reaction. Picks up 8th graf, `Attorney General ...'
DOC.TEXT: Panama has filed 16 criminal charges against toppled dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega, including charges of murder, torture, human rights violations and drug trafficking, authorities said Monday. They said Panama is also suing Gen. Noriega for alleged offenses while he ran the military. News reports said the suits amount to more than $5 million. Gretta Marchosky, an assistant to Panama's attorney general, said the criminal charges were filed by government prosecutors and private citizens. Noriega was ousted as chief of the Defense Forces by the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion and now awaits trial in Miami on drug trafficking charges. He surrendered to American forces Jan. 3 after holing up in the Vatican Embassy. In Miami, Noriega attorney Frank Rubino said he wasn't aware of the Panamanian charges. ``Really, I'm shocked. I have no idea (why the Panamanian government brought the charges). ``It should not affect his trial here in any way,'' Rubino said, but added: ``It's possible the Panamanian government could petition this government for extradition.'' It then would be up to the U.S. Justice Department to decide whether to send Noriega back to Panama. ``We cannot speculate on what the government of Panama will do,'' Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen, said late Monday in Miami. ``We have no further comment at this time.'' Attorney General Rogelio Cruz declined to say how Panama plans to pursue the charges and civil suits in Noriega's absence. Panama is working through the law firm of Williams and Connally, which has its headquarters in Washington. A summary of charges prepared by Cruz accuses Noriega of murdering 10 military officers who led a botched coup attempt in October and of murdering Hugo Spadafora, an opposition leader whose decapitated body was found in Costa Rica near the Panamanian border in 1985. Cruz said about $500,000 worth of Noriega's bank accounts in Panama have been frozen so far. Three luxury homes, one worth $10 million, remain in the custody of the Panamanian government. Other property has been found in the name of Noriega's wife, Felicidad, and their children, who live now in Cuba and the Dominican Republic. Ms. Marchosky told The Associated Press that from the time Noriega entered the armed forces as a lieutenant in 1962 until he was toppled his salary and other compensation totaled $648,583. American diplomatic sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, estimate his fortune at $280 million to $300 million. Noriega's lawyers say at least $11 million of that was from the CIA, for which he once worked. Panamanian officials say the United States' retention of thousands of boxes of documents is hindering attempts to trace Noriega property illegally obtained with public funds. Cruz told a news conference his office received 14,276 accusations since January, most of them against Noriega and his associates.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Clears Marcos and Khashoggi of All Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-8, `Khashoggi, 54 ...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Mrs. Marcos emerging from apartment, quote; picks up 9th graf, `As was ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY43,45,50,51; LaserColor NY58; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: A jury Monday cleared Imelda Marcos of charges that she looted $222 million from the Philippines and hid the money by buying art and real estate with the help of Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi. The U.S. District Court verdict _ on Mrs. Marcos' 61st birthday _ reduced the former Philippines first lady to tears and sent her supporters into jubilant celebration. The jury also acquitted Khashoggi, the jet-setter once known as the world's richest man, of charges that he helped Mrs. Marcos and her late husband conceal ownership of four New York buildings. ``This is the best birthday present I ever had,'' said a beaming Mrs. Marcos as she left the courtroom. ``I am in great awe and respect for the jury system that symbolizes the soul of the American people,'' she said. Mrs. Marcos went directly to St. Patrick's Cathedral, where she walked on her knees down the aisle to the altar, then bowed her head to the floor and prayed. From St. Patrick's she went to the Manhattan apartment she has been staying during the trial, where friends and supporters celebrated with her into the evening. She emerged from the apartment shortly before 10 p.m. Asked about her plans for the future, she said, ``Home.'' Mrs. Marcos then got into a van with several friends. They were reportedly headed to a party at a Manhattan restaurant, with Khashoggi as host. Khashoggi, 54, also praised the American jury system. ``I feel very happy for myself and my family and for the United States,'' he said earlier. A Moslem, he said he planned to leave New York to make a pilgrimage to Mecca, Islam's holiest city. As was his habit during the trial, Khashoggi returned to his posh midtown apartment via subway, posing with strangers and signing autographs. Once above ground, he and his wife used a cellular phone to call friends in France, England and California with the news. If convicted on all charges, Mrs. Marcos could have been sentenced to 50 years in prison and fined $1 million. Khashoggi could have drawn a sentence of 10 years and a $500,000 fine. The jury announced its verdict in the fifth day of deliberations after a three-month trial. Prosecutors called 95 witnesses. The defense, led by Marcos attorney Gerry Spence, called none. ``It was a poorly prepared case,'' forewoman Katherine Balton said later in a telephone interview. ``There was nothing to convince any of them that there was a case.'' When Balton read the first innocent verdict in court, Marcos supporters cried out, ignoring Judge John F. Keenan's warning against outbursts. Mrs. Marcos was in tears. She smiled and hugged her lawyers. The prosecutors sat facing the judge, eyes downcast. In a terse statement, the office of U.S. Attorney Otto Obermaier praised the work of the trial prosecutors and said: ``The jury has rendered its verdict. Our system of justice has spoken.'' The jury acquitted both defendants of all charges _ racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice against Mrs. Marcos, and mail fraud and obstruction of justice against Khashoggi. Carmen Pedrosa, a spokesman for the Philippines government, said in a hastily written statement issued here that even though Mrs. Marcos was acquitted, the trial showed that Marcos' regime was rife with ``unbridled corruption and total abuse of power.'' A government spokesman in Manila said Mrs. Marcos was still banned from returning home. Estimates on how much the case cost the U.S. government were not available, Obermaier's office said. Mrs. Marcos had been accused of conspiring with her husband to buy art, jewelry and four Manhattan commercial buildings with $222 million stolen from their country. Ferdinand Marcos was indicted with his wife in October 1988, 2{ years after the president and first lady fled the Philippines. He died in Hawaii last September. During the trial, the judge had called the case ``an unprecedented prosecution'' because it involved world figures, including a former head of state who was a major U.S. ally. Authorities charged that much of the tens of millions of dollars used for investments in the United States came in kickbacks Marcos collected from government contractors while he was Philippines president. Witnesses said the money was funneled to the United States through numbered bank accounts in Switzerland, Hong Kong, Manila and Los Angeles and was used to secretly buy the buildings for the Marcoses through associates and offshore corporations. The central issue the jury had to decide was how much Mrs. Marcos knew about her husband's alleged corrupt practices. Spence, of Jackson, Wyo., said during closing arguments that Mrs. Marcos was a ``world class shopper.'' But he said she did not know the source of her husband's wealth. The defense attorney said she was guilty only of loving and supporting her husband. The prosecution argued that even though its evidence was heavily circumstantial, it proved that Mrs. Marcos, as a cabinet minister and mayor of Manila, knew the millions of dollars they invested was accumulated illegally. The alleged offenses took place in the latter part of Marcos' two decades as Philippines president. Marcos was deposed in February 1986 by a ``people's revolution'' led by Corazon Aquino, widow of a murdered Marcos opponent. She became Philippine president as the Marcoses fled to exile in Hawaii. The testimony was highlighted by witnesses' accounts of Mrs. Marcos' shopping habits, including spending sprees at Bloomingdale's and numerous New York jewelry stores. Witnesses also said she used close friends and a secretary to handle purchases and deliveries of large amounts of cash for her expenses. The basic allegation of the racketeering charges was that Mrs. Marcos violated U.S. laws against wire fraud and the transfer of stolen money into the United States. The racketeering charges also included underlying allegations that she defrauded American banks of millions of dollars in financing the New York properties, and obstructed justice in a civil lawsuit brought by the Aquino government to recover the buildings. The mail fraud and obstruction of justice charges against Mrs. Marcos and Khashoggi stemmed from his alleged efforts to help the Marcoses conceal their ownership of the New York buildings and some paintings after a court order in the Philippine lawsuit froze the Marcoses' assets. Khashoggi is a financier and arms dealer who divides his time between homes in New York, France, Saudi Arabia and other locales. He played a middleman role in the Iran-Contra affair, in which U.S. arms were secretly sold to Iran by officials of the Reagan administration and the profits diverted to the U.S.-backed Contra rebels in Nicaragua. The properties at the heart of the case were three office buildings _ the Crown Building on Fifth Avenue, 40 Wall St. and 200 Madison Ave., and a vertical shopping center called Herald Center. The Aquino government's claim on the real estate has not yet been decided because the civil lawsuit is pending. The trial was clearly an ordeal for Mrs. Marcos, who wore black dresses to court every day in observance of mourning for her husband. The trial was interrupted three times because Mrs. Marcos fell ill with stress-related ailments. She was hospitalized for four days after collapsing in the courtroom with a stomach problem and was treated for high blood pressure.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Infected Man Faces 300 Years For Sexual Assault
DOC.TEXT: A man infected with the AIDS virus was convicted Monday of sexually abusing young boys and deliberately exposing them to the disease. A Superior Court jury convicted Feaster on 26 counts of enticing a minor, indecent acts with a minor and sodomy of a minor, leaving him liable to sentences totaling 300 years in prison. Because Feaster was infected with the HIV virus, he originally was charged also with assault with a deadly weapon, namely himself, his bodily fluids and the virus. However, that charge was later dropped because there was not enough evidence to convince a jury he had transmitted the virus to the boys. None of the children tested positive for the AIDS virus. Prosecutors alleged that Feaster kept a house for young boys from 1987 to 1989 and engaged in sexual activity with six boys ranging in age from 9 to 15 years. Feaster gained the confidence of vulnerable women who were often crack addicts and had them sign over their sons to him, U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens said in a statement. Feaster promised that he would feed and clothe the children, raise them in a good home and send them to school. Sentencing was set for Sept. 12.

DOC.HEAD: Bags Become Focus of Investigation into Slaying-Dismemberment of Activist
DOC.TEXT: The hunt for the killer of an environmental activist is focusing on the bags in which his dismembered body was found, authorities said Monday. James Michael Madden, 24, of Whitefish Bay, was last seen Wednesday going door to door to enlist support for Citizens for a Better Environment. His remains, minus the head and arms, were found Friday in two plastic bags. They were identified through a tattoo Sunday. Authorities said Monday they had no motive. The plastic bags were of a type environmentalists often oppose. But investigators don't believe Madden's killer was using them to make a political statement, said Deputy Sheriff Jim Ivanoski. ``I don't put a connection to that,'' Ivanoski said. ``He was in the wrong place at the wrong time and he ran into a psycho. That's what I think.'' Still, Ivanoski said, the search for the killer was focusing on the two yellow, industrially durable bags _ described as expensive and not readily available on the retail market. Officers were investigating who manufactures and distributes the bags, as well as who buys and uses them, Ivanoski said. ``The bags are one of the keys to our investigation,'' he said. Madden's dismembered body was found in a field about three miles from the rural town of Norway, where he was last seen alive. Police were interviewing Norway residents, and said they received hundreds of calls offering information. ``We're still checking all of the area where the victim was last seen and we haven't gotten any additional leads out of that,'' Ivanoski said. Racine County Coroner John Esayian conducted tests Monday but said he remained unsure of the cause of death. Ivanoski said Madden's remains may not be available for burial for at least two weeks. ``There's a possibility we may not return the body until the crime is solved,'' he said. Authorities refused to comment on how the body was dismembered. Madden, who worked for Citizens for a Better Environment for two months, was soliciting donations alone when he disappeared, said RoseMary Oliveira, the group's administrative director. He was reported missing when he failed to return to work. ``This is a serious tragedy for all of us. But on the other hand, we're continuing our work for the environment. We'll carry him in our hearts,'' Ms. Oliveira said. Ms. Oliveira, who said the organization won't return to Racine until the killing is solved, said environmentalists oppose the type of bag in which Madden's body was found. Residents in the affluent Milwaukee suburb where Madden lived with his parents and brothers described him as civic-minded and helpful.

DOC.HEAD: Art Gallery Director Dies in Fall
DOC.TEXT: A struggling sculptor who was the director of a Manhattan art gallery died when she apparently fell from the fire escape of her apartment building, police said Monday. Linda Bailey, 29, a native of Great Britain who moved to New York about six years ago, was found Sunday morning in the courtyard of her building in SoHo, long a neighborhood of struggling and established artists. For the last three years she was director of the Terry Dintenfass Gallery, a respected midtown gallery specializing in contemporary American artists and American modernists. Neighbors said Bailey was dressed in shorts and sandals and had been waiting for her boyfriend to pick her up for a day at the beach. Her body was discovered in the rear of the building, directly below her fifth-floor apartment, around 11:30 a.m., said police Sgt. Thomas Kenny. She moved into the building last fall. Kenny said her death was ruled an accident ``by process of elimination.'' He said there was no sign of forced entry, no evidence anyone else had been inside her apartment and no suicide note found at the scene. A piece of her artwork was found on the ground next to her body, leading detectives to surmise she was sculpting when she fell. ``She was a real sweet person,'' said Robert Trombetta, who worked with Baiely as co-director of the Dintenfass Gallery for about 18 months. Terry Dintenfass, who owns the gallery, was vacationing in England. Bailey sculpted in steel and created abstract bird-like forms, said Trombetta, also an artist. He said Bailey went to work for Dintenfass to support herself but that sculpting was her real love. She had several shows, most recently last fall at the gallery where she worked. ``Every time I ran into her I'd ask, `Are you working,' meaning sculpting and she'd say, `No, not really,''' Trombetta said. ``It's hard being a gallery director and at the same time trying to pursue an art career.'' But, he added, ``She certainly was not any more upset than any other artist at the way their career is going.'' Trombetta said that four days ago he ran into Bailey, who had just returned from vacationing in Kenya with her sister and ``was quite animated about it.'' Bailey left her home in Essex, England, as a teen-ager to go to college in Tampa, Fla., Trombetta said. She moved to New York in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Iran's Leader Thanks World for Quake Aid, But Not U.S.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th pvs, `Despite the...' to CORRECT that $760,000 only from U.S. government, private American groups made additional contributions. Pickup 5th pvs, `The money...'
DOC.TEXT: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran sent messages Monday to 98 world leaders thanking them for helping the victims of last month's earthquake, but he left out the United States. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Cyprus, said Rafsanjani thanked the leaders for their sympathy, financial contributions and material aid. It listed 98 countries, Soviet republics, Arab emirates or U.N. agencies. But the United States, which Iran once called the ``Great Satan,'' was missing from the list. Despite the history of ill will between the two nations, the U.S. government provided $760,000 in aid for the earthquake survivors, according to the State Department. The State Department said private American groups have sent an additional $4 million in aid. The money was accepted, although some Iranians argued fiercely that it should be rejected. Rafsanjani, who has been seeking to improve relations with the West, is at odds with hard-liners in his government who shun any contacts with the United States. The June 21 temblor, which registered between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter scale, killed at least 40,000 people and injured about 60,000 by Iranian estimates. About half a million were left homeless. Also missing from today's list was Saudi Arabia. That moderate Arab country provided tents, medicines and food during relief efforts. Iran and Saudi Arabia are embroiled in a dispute over the annual Moslem pilgrimage to Mecca. The Saudis accuse Iran of having instigated terrorism there. Also left off today's list was Iraq, Iran's enemy during the 8-year Persian Gulf war that ended two years ago. Iraq also sent relief supplies.

DOC.HEAD: Body of Australian Man Put in Cold Storage Until Cure Found
DOC.TEXT: The body of an Australian man who died after brain surgery was frozen and flown to the United States on Monday in hopes he might one day be revived and cured, a spokesman for a cryonic suspension society said. The body of Rocco Schiavello, 30, of Melbourne arrived at the Riverside facilities of the Alcor Life Extension Foundation, said Mike Darwin, Alcor's director of research. ``He will be placed in long-term liquid nitrogen storage,'' said Darwin, a member of the group that contends people can be frozen and later restored to life. Schiavello, who died June 22 after surgery for a brain tumor, had asked his family to have his body stored in cryonic suspension. It took several days for Alcor to make the necessary arrangements to transport the body, said Darwin. Alcor has attracted national attention with a couple of cases. Most scientists dismiss the foundation's efforts as unrealistic. Preservation of a body costs approximately $100,000. One of those is that of a mathematician who wants to have his head frozen while still alive and then removed for frozen storage. In another case, the Riverside County coroner investigated the freezing of an 82-year-old woman's body because the woman had died without a doctor being present. The coroner had ruled the death was a homicide brought on by barbiturates, but Alcor said the drug was administered after death to preserve the head. No charges have been filed.

DOC.HEAD: Closing Arguments Heard In Manslaughter Trial of Christian Science Parents
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Monday began deliberating the case of a Christian Science couple accused of involuntary manslaughter for using prayer instead of medicine to try to treat their sick 2-year-old son. The jury in the Suffolk County Superior Court trial of David and Ginger Twitchell, both 34, began deliberations after closing arguments by defense attorney Rikki Klieman and Special Prosecutor John Kiernan. Klieman said the case against his clients was one of ``speculation, exaggeration and distortion.'' Kiernan said the Twitchells must be held accountable for not seeking medical help for their son, Robyn, who died in April 1986 after a five-day illness. An autopsy showed he suffered from a bowel obstruction. ``I don't suggest for a moment these parents intended to kill their child,'' Kiernan told jurors. ``But they intentionally did things that caused his death.'' Klieman conceded that the Twitchells made a mistake, but said they didn't deserve to be convicted. The jury, hearing the case in the city that is home to the Christian Science Church's headquarters, began deliberations late in the afternoon after instructions from Judge Sandra Hamlin. During closing arguments, the defense and the prosecution returned to themes presented in two months of testimony by medical experts, emergency personnel, Christian Science practitioners and the Twitchells' former neighbors. Key issues have been the severity of Robyn's symptoms, his time of death, his parents' actions in calling in Christian Science practitioners and whether their church allows medical treatment when prayer fails. Klieman made an emotional appeal to the jury to reject the notion that the Twitchells were uncaring parents who callously treated Robyn's dead body ``like garbage.'' She reiterated that witnesses who saw Robyn from April 3 to April 7 said the boy was clearly sick, but that his life did not appear to be threatened. Klieman disputed the prosecution claim that Robyn's bowel obstruction, which was due to a birth defect, could have been easily diagnosed and treated. Rather, the bowel can twist and untwist, making diagnosis difficult, she said. ``If it can fool a doctor, it can fool any parent and it certainly can fool parents who rely on spiritual healing because it gets worse, it gets better, it gets worse, it gets better,'' Klieman said. Kiernan said parents have a millennium-old obligation to protect their children. What he termed the Twitchell's ``unabashed, unbridled arrogance'' made the obviously suffering little boy a martyr to their belief that prayer alone could heal. ``This little boy was sacrificed for his own parents' intellectual purity,'' he said. Describing Robyn as moaning in pain, Kiernan gestured at the Twitchells, saying, ``How could they sit there and not do anything? How could they not call for a doctor?'' As they have through much of the trial, the Twitchells sat still and held hands. David Twitchell had testified earlier; his wife did not take the stand. The Twitchells now live in New York with their two other children.

Editors
