DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of June 25-July 2:
DOC.HEAD: News Interest Hits New Lows Among the Young, Study Finds
DOC.TEXT: Americans under age 30 know less about what's going on in the country and the world than any other generation in the past 50 years, a new study shows. Twenty-five years ago, 67 percent of people under age 35 said ``yes'' when asked if they had ``read a newspaper yesterday.'' Now only 24 percent say ``yes.'' Television news-watching has dropped, too. Young people who said they watched the TV news ``yesterday'' fell from 52 percent in 1965 to 41 percent this year. The study said that from 1941 to 1975, young Americans were on a par with their elders in public knowledge and in following most major news events closely. But since 1975, young people have been less attentive and the trend is accelerating, it said. ``The Information Age has spawned ... an uninformed and uninvolved population,'' the study said. It was conducted by the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press, which is sponsored by the company that publishes the Los Angeles Times and other newspapers. The center's own polls and those of four other polling organizations taken over the years were analyzed. Even though the average 30-year-old is more likely to use a computer, to have attended college and even more likely to be reading a book than someone 20 years senior, the younger generation knows less about the world, the study said. In the latest measurement, 12,000 random sample interviews conducted between May 1989 and last March were analyzed. The number of young people who could correctly answer questions about current news was at its lowest level since pollsters started asking questions about familiarity with the news in the early 1940s. The polls had a margin or error of plus or minus 2 percentage points. The exceptions: sports and the abortion issue. There, the young match their elders in news interest. In 1989, 25 percent of each group kept up with the World Series; 41 percent of the young and 33 percent of people over 50 knew about the Supreme Court's most recent major abortion ruling. But, the survey reported, younger Americans are 20 percent less likely than those over 30 to know who won the recent election in Nicaragua, what happened to Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu or what the Soviet Union's role has been in the political upheavals of Eastern Europe. The study said that in the 1940s a majority of people _ both those under and those over 30 _ could identify Norman Thomas, the American socialist. And in the 1960s two-thirds of young people and 59 percent over those over 50 could identify Earl Warren, the chief justice of the United States from 1953 to 1969. By contrast, in a March 1990 survey, less than a quarter of people under 30 and less than half of those over 50 could identify Jim Wright, who resigned a year ago as speaker of the House of Representatives, or Helmut Kohl, chancellor of West Germany. A newspaper editor, William B. Ketter of The Patriot Ledger of Quincy, Mass., called the findings distressing. ``I think it is symptomatic of our fast-food, fast-paced society where they want everything instantly and don't want to concentrate on newspapers, and apparently that even extends now to television,'' said Ketter. He is chairman of the Readership Committee of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, which is seeking ways to make newspapers more attractive to readers. ``I call it a dangerous camel under the tent because I think if our society becomes less informed about the events that go on in the world and at home it becomes less vigilant for the protections of the Constitution, and that could spell problems,'' Ketter said.
DOC.HEAD: Joint Chiefs' Chairman Orders Greater Attention to News Pools
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff has ordered senior commanders to give ``personal attention'' to arranging pooled news coverage of military operations, conceding that the arrangements were faulty during the U.S. invasion of Panama. ``Although the media was deployed, it was unable to cover military action until the second day and, consequently, did not perform as planned'' during the December invasion, said Gen. Colin L. Powell. Powell's message was sent to service chiefs and commanders-in-chief of military commands. ``He needed no convincing to sign the message,'' Pete Williams, assistant secretary of defense for public affairs, said in a letter to Larry Kramer, chairman of the Press, Bar and Public Affairs Committee of the American Society of Newspaper Editors. Kramer, editor of the San Francisco Examiner, wrote to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on May 2, asking for a meeting to discuss possible revisions in the pool operation. A Pentagon-commissioned report issued in March said Cheney's ``excessive concern with secrecy,'' along with a lack of planning, prevented reporters from covering the opening battles of the invasion. The report recommended that plans for military action include assurances that a pool will travel with the U.S. forces. Williams, replying to Kramer on Cheney's behalf, said the Pentagon is considering the recommendations and making decisions on them as it completes the analysis of each.
DOC.HEAD: AP-CWA Contract Vote Count Awaited
DOC.TEXT: Ballots mailed by Associated Press technical workers voting on a proposed two-year contract will be counted on July 3. Negotiators for Local 1314 of the Communications Workers of America, which represents more than 300 technicians at the news agency, and the AP agreed tentatively on a contract four weeks ago. But the union described the contract as inadequate, particularly in its health and pension benefits, and urged members to reject it. AP management said the package was fair and urged employees to approve it. Jim Peacook, president of CWA Local 1314, said June 29 that ballots were being mailed to a union post office box in Boston, where they would be counted. The contract calls for a ``managed care'' approach to control the cost of the medical plan by reducing unnecessary use of doctors and hospitals. It also proposes weekly pay increases of $23.50 for top-scale technicians in the first year and $24 in the second, bringing weekly top-scale technician salaries to $612 in 1991. Similar percentage increases were proposed for all other job classifications. Terms of the present CWA-AP contract were extended until 11:59 p.m. July 2 pending the ratification vote.

DOC.HEAD: Suffolk County Introduces Strict Recycling Law
DOC.TEXT: A new law requires large-circulation newspapers printed or sold in Suffolk County to start using recycled paper at the end of next year. The law requires a complete switch to recycled paper for newspapers with weekly circulations of 20,000 or more by the end of 1996. County Executive Patrick Halpin, who signed the measure on June 29, said it would help solve Long Island's garbage crisis by creating a market for recycled newspapers. ``I hope this law spurs the state and federal government to adopt similar legislation, because communities are drowning in their garbage,'' he said. All the large daily newspapers sold in the county will be affected, including Newsday, The New York Times, the New York Post, the Daily News and USA Today. The law will take effect Dec. 31, 1991, under a timetable that will allow the papers to gradually shift to recycling by the end of 1996.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Building Blaze Forces Evacuation; Delays Edition
DOC.TEXT: An explosion and fire in the basement of the Dallas Times Herald forced an evacuation of the building and moved the printing of the June 28 edition to another newspaper's presses. One worker was injured and a woman was treated for smoke inhalation. About 200 people were forced to leave the building because of dense smoke. The fire, caused the night before by an electrical short, was out less than an hour after it was reported. A delayed morning edition of the Times Herald was printed 35 miles away at the Fort Worth Star-Telegram. Jerry Zinnick, director of production at the Star-Telegram, said the newspaper had sufficient press capacity to allow the Times Herald to use two of its presses. About 200,000 copies were printed by 6 a.m.
DOC.HEAD: Media Drive Launched To Reach Those Uncounted in Census
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers across New York state used their Sunday editions to distribute more than 5 million census forms on July 1, in a government drive to make sure that New York gets its share of federal funds and congressional representation. Mayor David Dinkins and state Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, who organized the drive, said an undercount would mean less federal money to the state and could leave the state with fewer members of Congress. ``In 1980, the Census Bureau failed to count at least 450,000 New Yorkers,'' Dinkins said. ``It was as though ... the Census Bureau had wiped the entire metropolitan region of Kansas City, Mo., off the face of the Earth.'' Some newspapers printed the forms instead of carrying them as inserts. Radio and television stations told listeners and viewers where to get forms, and New York City set up 77 ``Were You Counted?'' centers.
DOC.HEAD: The National Planning New Print Sites
DOC.TEXT: The National plans to have 16 printing sites in 13 markets by the end of March 1991, Publisher Peter Price said. The daily sports newspaper has been publishing separate editions in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles since its launch Jan. 31 and started a San Diego edition on June 25. It plans to add editions in six more markets by the end of the year and three more in the first quarter of next year. Price said June 26 that the owners of the newspaper, headed by Mexican media baron Emilio Azcarraga, have decided to commit more than $50 million to equip the printing sites to handle production of the heavy-grade, four-color newspaper. That is in addition to the $25 million spent on the launch in the first three cities. Executives of the paper have said the Azcarraga group is prepared to spend at least $100 million over five years to make The National profitable. The newspaper's circulation has been a topic of some conjecture. Price said it is selling about 200,000 copies daily on average, and expects circulation to approach 400,000 by the end of the year. Audited figures have not yet been made available to ad agencies. ``We will feel better when they supply us with some good circulation information,'' said one agency executive, Richard Weigand, senior vice president and media director for Saatchi & Saatchi DFS-Pacific in Torrance, Calif.
DOC.HEAD: Woman Sues Newspaper Over Rape Story
DOC.TEXT: A rape victim filed a lawsuit against the Fort Worth Star-Telegram on June 25 for publishing a story that she says contained identifying details even though it did not give her name. The woman alleges the story violated her right to privacy as a victim of sexual assault. She is seeking at least $8,000 in damages for alleged emotional and physical distress. The Star-Telegram did not publish the woman's name or address in reports about the Sept. 24 rape. The lawsuit contends the story included information about the rape and about her, including her age, occupation and the make of her car, that made her identity ``readily apparent'' to people in her community. As a result of the story, the woman has suffered ``extreme and severe embarrassment, humiliation and acute depression,'' the lawsuit alleges. The lawsuit seeks $3,000 in damages to pay for psychological treatment and $5,000 in past and future lost wages. Texas law does not prohibit publishing rape victims' names, nor does it prohibit law enforcement agencies from releasing the names, said Star-Telegram Associate Executive Editor Phil Record. ``We were just surprised at this kind of suit because we don't see that it has a great deal of merit in it,'' Record said. The lawsuit names as defendants the newspaper, President and Publisher Richard Connor, Executive Editor and Vice President Michael Blackman and former reporter Betsy C.M. Tong.
DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles Times Reporter Handcuffed While Covering Supervisors
DOC.TEXT: A reporter for the Los Angeles Times was briefly handcuffed by a sheriff's deputy on June 26 after he tried to shout a question to county supervisors as they emerged from a closed meeting. Richard Simon was placed in the cuffs by a deputy who had told him not to open a door and question supervisors as they emerged from the session to discuss their federal court redistricting case. The deputy said he was acting under orders, and was later supported by a statement from the sheriff's office, which said the restricted area for the closed meeting included a hallway outside the meeting room. The Times said the deputy ``overreacted,'' and the Los Angeles chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists called the action an abuse of power that required an explanation.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter Refuses To Hand Over Notes, Surrenders to Jail Officials
DOC.TEXT: A television news reporter began serving a six-month jail term June 27 for refusing to turn over the name of a confidential source to prosecutors and defense lawyers in a murder case. ``I sure don't want to do six months in jail,'' KMOL-TV reporter Brian Karem said before entering the Bexar County Jail. ``But I'm going to keep my promise.'' Karem has defied three court orders to turn over his notes from a telephone interview last year with one of the two suspects jailed in the murder case. Both the prosecution and the defense contend they need to know who arranged the interview to prepare their cases. Karem has said the source fears for his life if his identity is revealed. On June 26, the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals refused to issue a stay that would have allowed Karem to remain free while he appeals the contempt citations. The U.S. Supreme Court refused to intervene on June 27. KMOL news director Ron Harig said the jailing was unnecessary. ``The information contained in those notes could have been easily obtained by those attorneys and the agencies they represent,'' he said. ``We shouldn't be an investigating arm of law enforcement.'' The jailing stems from an interview Karem conducted last year with capital murder defendant Henry David Hernandez, accused with his brother Julian in the 1989 shooting death of police officer Gary Williams. Henry Hernandez said during the interview that he shot the officer in self-defense. Prosecution and defense attorneys say they have to know who arranged the interview so that they can determine whether it can be used in the trial under rules of evidence. Henry Hernandez' attorney does not want the interview admitted in the trial. Julian Hernandez' attorney does. Prosecutors want to know whether any law enforcement official was involved, or whether any promises were made or extracted for arranging the conversation. Karem has been held in contempt by two state district judges, most recently by State District Judge Pat Priest in February. He has been jailed three times in the case, each time for a few hours before being released on bond. After Priest's ruling, Karem and KMOL took the case to federal court. In mid-June, U.S. District Judge H.F. Garcia ruled Karem must surrender the notes. The judge also said he would not extend the stay that has kept Karem out of jail.
DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Reporter To Reveal Source
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge said June 25 he will order a reporter to spend six months in prison for refusing to reveal her source in a story detailing a policeman's domestic problems. U.S. District Judge Edward Cahn said he would impose the order on Terry Mutchler, a former reporter of The Morning Call and now a writer for The Associated Press in Harrisburg, within 10 days. Cahn said he would suspend the sentence, however, while Mutchler and the newspaper appeal to the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The name of Mutchler's source was sought by Allentown officer Kenneth Scheetz Jr. and his wife, Rosann, who have sued the newspaper, Mutchler and her source. The Scheetzes say a May 1989 story by Ms. Mutchler and a follow-up article about a marital fracas put the couple in a false light and caused them emotional and mental distress. Without disputing the accuracy of the stories, they contend she based her writing on a stolen police report _ apparently given to her by someone in the Police Department. The Scheetzes claim the article was designed to embarrass Kenneth Scheetz, who had been named the 1988 ``Officer of the Year.'' After the session, Ms. Mutchler said, ``I gave my word that I would grant confidentiality to my source.'' ``My reporting can only be as good as my word, and I'm going to stand by it ... or, in this case, sit in the jail cell, if that's what it takes.'' The newspaper contends the story was written to illustrate the department's failure to thoroughly investigate domestic squabbles involving officers. In this instance, Rosann Scheetz twice sought sanctuary in police headquarters after being assaulted by her husband in their home, according to the report.
DOC.HEAD: Subpoenas Amount to Fishing Expedition, Magazine Editor Says
DOC.TEXT: Editors at High Times magazine say they are bracing for a challenge to their First Amendment rights: a federal investigation into whether the publication is part of a drug conspiracy. Editor Steve Hager said June 25 that he and two other employees were subpoenaed to appear before a grand jury in New Orleans. USA Today reported that federal prosecutors are investigating the drug conspiracy theory. High Times, which distributes 250,000 issues monthly, plans to challenge the subpoena, and Hager said he did not plan to go or to provide the business records and other information that was requested. ``If I do go down, it will be to take the Fifth Amendment. The Bill of Rights is being systematically dismantled in the name of the war on drugs,'' he said. ``I'm not exactly clear what it is they're trying to do. It's basically just a big fishing expedition to try to put us out of business,'' Hager added. John Volz, the U.S. attorney in New Orleans, was in court and could not be immediately reached for comment. Hager said the magazine is outspoken in its support of a movement to legalize marijuana, but advises people to stay away from hard drugs, as well as tobacco and alcohol. USA Today said the Drug Enforcement Administration in October searched businesses that advertised garden equipment in High Times and arrested about 400 people for marijuana possession and other offenses. High Times subsequently lost two-thirds of its advertising, said Hager. ``This magazine would be bigger than Playboy if it weren't for government intervention,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Southern Baptist Fundamentalists Crack Down on Press Service
DOC.TEXT: Ruling Southern Baptist fundamentalists have ordered top editors of the Baptist Press, the denomination's news service, to resign quietly or be ``dealt with harshly,'' the editors said June 26. The ultimatum came after two years of rising fundamentalist power and pressures on the service, long considered the most open and objective denominational news operation in the country. Al Shackleford, the service's director and target of the ouster order, called it an ``attempt to control the right and responsibility of Baptist church members to know what is happening in this denomination.'' ``This is a violation of treasured Baptist principles,'' he said in a telephone interview from denominational headquarters in Nashville, Tenn. Executive committee officers who are said to have ordered the ouster did not immediately return telephone calls seeking comment. Reporters were tipped that both Shackleford and news editor Dan Martin were told on June 19 that they were out. After word of the ouster leaked, Martin issued a story confirming it. The story said they would be given six months' salary beyond Sept. 1 on condition that they kept silent. ``There's no way we would try to put the cork in the volcano and attempt to stifle the news,'' Martin said. ``It was fully engaged in the denominational rumor mill and when reporters called about it, we responded.'' What the action meant for the future of the nearly half-century-old Baptist Press remained unclear, since Shackleford and Martin are the only two remaining staffers at its Nashville base. Another Nashville editor, Marv Knox, aware of a potential crackdown, had resigned June 1. The service has five bureaus around the country and serves 400 outlets, including 38 state Baptist weeklies. The service's daily news report about religious affairs was widely recognized by journalism specialists as the most thorough and objective denominational news operation in the country. However, it has come under increasing fire from a fundamentalist wing that has achieved control of the 14.9-million-member denomination, the nation's largest Protestant body.
DOC.HEAD: Media Seeks To Publish 11 Photos
DOC.TEXT: The judge in the Central Park jogger case reserved decision June 28 on whether the media can use 11 photographs that have been entered into evidence. The pictures are mostly of injuries suffered by one of the victims who has since testified at the trial. They also include photographs of the crime scene. The application was made by Anthony Bongiorno, a lawyer for CBS. His motions to publish these photographs was opposed by the prosecution and the defense attorneys. Bongiorno said the main reason for the opposition was the privacy of the witnesses and the inflammatory nature of the photos. At the start of the trial, both sides in the case also opposed allowing cameras in the courtroom and Galligan ruled in their favor.
DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Lifts Gag Order in Mail Bombs Investigation
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court panel lifted a 4-month-old gag order June 28 in the case of Water Leroy Moody Jr., who is being investigated in a series of mail bombs that killed an appeals court judge and a Savannah lawyer. The panel dissolved a February order by U.S. District Judge Richard C. Freeman sealing all proceedings in the investigation of Moody until an indictment or further court order. An attorney for the media appealing the gag order, Terry Adamson, said he regretted that it took so long to lift it, but hoped the ruling would stop judges from issuing future orders in such cases. No one has been indicted in the investigation of the pre-Christmas mail bombs that killed 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert S. Vance at his home in Alabama and Savannah City Alderman Robert Robinson at his law office.
DOC.HEAD: High Court Rejects Attempt To Reinstate Death Sentence
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court has refused to reinstate the death penalty for the man convicted in the 1976 car-bomb slaying of Phoenix newspaper reporter Don Bolles. Arizona Attorney General Bob Corbin said the June 28 ruling means that John Harvey Adamson still faces about 10 years in prison. Corbin said he was surprised by the decision, which came one day after the court upheld the state death penalty law under which Adamson had been sentenced. ``The Supreme Court upheld the death penalty statute in Arizona on Wednesday so we figured that since Adamson is coming up on the same issues, they'd do the same thing,'' Corbin said. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1988 threw out Adamson's death sentence after striking down a provision in Arizona law that lets judges, instead of juries, choose between life and death for convicted murderers. The appeals court's ruling called into doubt the validity of death penalty laws in Idaho and Montana, which also allow for sentencing by judges. But the Arizona provision was declared constitutional by the Supreme Court in another state case. Prosecutors said Adamson was paid $100,000 to attach a bomb to the car of Bolles, who had investigated organized crime for The Arizona Republic in Phoenix. Bolles died June 11, 1976, nine days after his car exploded.

DOC.HEAD: Ban on Prisoner Reporting, Bylines Upheld
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ruled in favor of prison administrators who put an inmate writer in solitary confinement after he criticized the warden in print. ``Articles about matters within a prison can create a danger of violence, or at least threats of violence,'' and can weaken the staff's control of the prison, said U.S. District Judge Charles Legge. In the ruling June 26, Legge said the U.S. Bureau of Prisons' security concerns justified regulations that prohibited inmates from acting as reporters, from being paid for newspaper articles or from writing bylined articles for outside newspapers. Outside newspaper reporting by prisoners can cause rifts within a prison, improperly focus attention on individual inmates, create divided loyalties, and turn the writer into a ``big wheel'' with ``disproportionate notoriety and influence,'' Legge said. The ruling is not binding on other courts. U.S. Attorney William McGivern, whose office defended the regulations, said the 52-page decision should be persuasive in future cases. Legge lifted his March 1989 order that prohibited enforcement of the regulations against Dannie Martin, a convicted bank robber who has written more than 40 bylined essays on prison life and conditions for the San Francisco Chronicle since 1986. Martin's articles from the federal prison in Lompoc had been praised by the parole board and had not prompted any disciplinary action until June 1988, when he wrote a Chronicle column describing tensions and warning of a possible riot because of restrictions imposed by new warden A.H. Rison. Martin was charged with violating the regulations, placed in solitary confinement for two days, and then transferred twice, ending up at a federal prison in Phoenix. Legge said those actions were taken for Martin's own protection and for legitimate security concerns, and were not attempts to punish him for criticizing Rison.
DOC.HEAD: Three Kenyan Editors Charged With Incitement, Released on Bail
DOC.TEXT: A court has released on bail three executives of the Standard newspaper who pleaded innocent to charges of publishing information likely to cause ``fear, alarm and despondency.'' Magistrate Omondi Tunya set bond on June 29 at $2,100 and ordered acting editor in chief Mitch Odero, Sunday editor Francis M. M'Thaiya, and deputy managing director Githui Muhindi to return for a hearing July 13. The charges stemmed from stories suggesting a city commission employee died during a violent eviction operation in a Nairobi slum and was clandestinely buried. The prosecution said the reports were ``untrue and likely to cause fear, alarm and despondency to the public.'' The Standard is the oldest newspaper in Kenya and is owned by the London-based multinational Lonrho.
DOC.HEAD: Controversy Over Photo of Prince, Princess
DOC.TEXT: A semi-official photographer may be banned from the Imperial Palace for snapping a candid picture of the newly married Princess Kiko smoothing her husband's hair. The Imperial Household Agency, caretakers of the royal family, were horrified at the photograph, which appeared in all of the country's major newspapers July 2. Prince Aya, the youngest son of Emperor Akihito, married graduate student Kiko Kawashima in an elaborate ceremony on June 29. At an official picture-taking session after the wedding, the prince's hair was a little ruffled, and the princess smoothed it. Photographer Toshiaki Nakayama snapped a picture of the fleeting gesture before taking the official portrait. Palace officials called it a betrayal of trust and said it was ``uncalled-for to release a picture that was taken by mistake.'' Nakayama defended the photo, saying no one objected at the time. He was barred from covering official post-wedding events July 2, and the agency said the ban may be permanant. Although Nakayama works for the Kyodo news service, the Imperial Household Agency says it considers photographers authorized to take pictures of the royal family as ``semi-employees'' of the palace.

DOC.HEAD: Minority Broadcasters Cheered by Supreme Court Ruling
DOC.TEXT: Minority broadcasters said a June 27 Supreme Court decision upholding the Federal Communications Commission's affirmative action rules will spur efforts to increase minority ownership of radio and TV stations. James L. Winston, executive director of the National Association of Black-Owned Broadcasters, said the decision ``means the FCC's ability to help promote minority ownership can now go forward without fear of constitutional challenge. ``While this still ... is not at the level we would like to see, we are pleased that the ability of the FCC to utilize policies to increase ownership will be allowed to continue and expand.'' Before the FCC established the rules in 1978, blacks owned about 30 radio stations and one television station, according to the association. Now, blacks own 182 radio stations and 17 television stations, the group said Wednesday. That represents an increase from 1 percent to about 3.5 percent of the nation's radio and TV stations, the FCC said. Those numbers are likely to grow now that the legal uncertainties have been lifted from the rules, broadcasters said. Eddie Fritts, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, said the decision ``affirms the FCC's ability to improve the under-representation of minorities in broadcast ownership.'' The rules that were upheld award preference to minorities seeking broadcast licenses. The FCC ``comparative'' licensing process also gives preference to competing applicants based on other factors, such as whether prospective owners plan to operate the station. Female applicants also receive extra points, but the court said it was not ruling on gender preference.
DOC.HEAD: House Subcommittee Approves Re-Regulation Measure
DOC.TEXT: A House subcommittee approved a bill June 27 designed to control prices for basic cable TV services and ensure competition. The voice vote by the House Energy and Commerce telecommunications subcommittee paralleled a Senate committee's near-unanimous approval earlier in June of legislation that also would restore some of the oversight on the cable industry that Congress lifted in 1984. The House version, however, would make it easier to prove that existing cable rates are too high, and could lead to price cuts in some instances, said Gene Kimmelman, legislative director of the Consumer Federation of America. ``This is a very significant consumer victory,'' Kimmelman said of the House bill. If enacted, ``it will finally bring cable rates down to reasonable levels and promote competition ... most usefully in rural America.'' The cable TV industry opposed the House bill immediately. ``We are very troubled by this bill,'' said James Mooney, president of the National Cable Television Association. He said many important issues remain to be resolved when the bill goes to the full Commerce Committee.
DOC.HEAD: CBS Gets PGA Championship
DOC.TEXT: CBS added another major event to its sports collection June 27, taking the PGA Championship away from ABC. CBS will begin televising the tournament in 1991. The network already televises the Masters and 16 other PGA Tour events. ABC has televised the PGA Championship since 1965. Prior to that, CBS broadcast the tournament from 1958-1964. Terms of the contract were not announced. One day earlier, CBS acquired the rights to Big Ten basketball games beginning in the 1991-92 season.
DOC.HEAD: Tisch Denies Rumors on Studio Merger or Sale of CBS
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. chief Laurence A. Tisch says he's in the television business for the long run despite persistent rumors he may sell the network or merge it with the Walt Disney Co. or another studio. ``One (additional) ratings point in prime time can do more than any acquisition that we could make in the next five years,'' Tisch told reporters on June 27, the first day of CBS' annual convention of affiliated television stations. He said the company's billions in cash earns interest every day, and he feels ``no need to move quickly'' to acquire other companies even though he's always looking for opportunities. ``I don't think it would make any difference to combine a network with a studio _ I don't think it strengthens our position,'' Tisch said.
DOC.HEAD: Lunden Hired To Host TV Program Designed for Waiting Rooms
DOC.TEXT: Joan Lunden, co-host of ABC's ``Good Morning America'' show, has been signed to host a new television program that Whittle Communications plans to put in medical waiting rooms this fall. Lunden has signed a three-year contract to host Special Reports Television, a commercially sponsored TV show that premieres in October. Whittle Communications, based in Knoxville, Tenn., expects the one-hour program will be airing continuously in 20,000 doctors' reception areas by January, reaching an annual audience of almost 50 million viewers, mainly young mothers. The company is now approaching advertisers about buying commercial time on the programs and is recruiting doctors who will let it put its television set in their waiting rooms and will play the program through the working day.

DOC.HEAD: DeWitt Named Marketing Director
DOC.TEXT: Blake DeWitt, publisher of The Prescott Courier, has been named marketing director for Western Newspapers, Inc., at its headquarters in Yuma. The June 28 announcement said DeWitt would be replaced by Robert D. Gilliland, who was general manager of the South Division Newspaper Group of South Coast Newspapers, Inc., of Oceanside, Calif.
DOC.HEAD: Judy Gelestor Named Publisher at Weirton
DOC.TEXT: Judy Gelestor, advertising manager of the Weirton Daily Times, was named publisher-general manager on June 26. Ms. Gelestor, 34, succeeds Ed Looman, who moves to publisher-general manager of the Astabula, Ohio, Star-Beacon. Both are Thomson newspapers. She joined the newspaper in June 1979 as an advertising account executive. She was named advertising manager in 1987. Ms. Gelestor began her career as an advertising saleswoman at the Burgettstown (Pa.) Enterprise, a weekly newspaper.
DOC.HEAD: Warren Becomes Publisher at Bluefield
DOC.TEXT: Stanley Warren, publisher of the Dalton (Ga.) Daily-Citizen News, was named publisher of the Bluefield Daily Telegraph on June 25. Warren succeeds Terry L. Horne, who was named publisher of the Charleston Daily Mail. Warren previously worked in advertising sales in Georgia at the Valdosta Daily Times and the Cordele Dispatch, and The Laurel Leader-Call in Mississippi.
DOC.HEAD: Sands Named Night Managing Editor at World-Herald
DOC.TEXT: The Omaha World-Herald has appointed Deanna Sands as managing editor-nights, succeeding Carl Keith, who is retiring after 30 years with the newspaper. Miss Sands is a former state president of the Society of Professional Journalists. Before joining the World-Herald, she worked for the Nebraska City News-Press. At the World-Herald, she has been a copy editor, wire editor, Sunday editor and assistant night news editor. Keith, a former president of the Nebraska Associated Press Association, began his career at the Beatrice Daily Sun. Before coming to the World-Herald in 1960, he worked at the Hastings Tribune and Scottsbluff Star-Herald in Nebraska and the Lead Daily Call and Deadwood Pioneer Times in South Dakota.
DOC.HEAD: Knight Foundation Awards Nearly $1 Million in Free Press Grants
DOC.TEXT: The Knight Foundation announced $850,000 in grants June 25 to promote the development of a free press in Eastern Europe. ``The sudden collapse of communism gives us an exceptional opportunity to help shape a free press in Eastern Europe for the first time since the Soviet bloc took over in that part of the world after World War II,'' said Lee Hills, vice chairman of the foundation's board of trustees. The largest grant, $525,000, was awarded to the World Press Freedom Committee, of Washington, to expand its educational services to free press organizations in Eastern Europe. The Center for Foreign Journalists Inc., of Reston, Va., received $300,000 to develop training programs. The foundation also announced four grants to promote discussions between professional journalists and members of the general public on ``their joint ownership'' of the First Amendment. The foundation gave $50,000 to the Institute for Journalism Education, Berkeley, Calif.; $25,000 to the University of Missouri School of Journalism's New Directions for News program; $15,000 to the First Amendment Congress, Denver; and $5,000 to the Washington Journalism Center, Washington.

Some Washington radio and television stations struggled on June 28 with the decision of whether to air rough language heard on the videotape of Mayor Marion Barry's January arrest. WUSA decided to air the entire, unedited hour-long tape at 11:30 p.m. Said News Director Dave Pearce: ``I feel people have a right to see it if they want to. They've paid for this thing, so to speak.'' Tyler Cox of WWRC used an edited version: ``There are certain words that we're just not going to air on our station ... regardless of the speaker or the context in which they are used.'' ... George Bush sent best wishes and a bottle of champagne to his sometime jogging companion, Associated Press reporter Rita Beamish, when she was married July 1. Ms. Beamish, who covered the Bush campaign in 1988 and has covered the White House since, married public relations executive Paul Costello in Kennebunkport, Maine, where the president was vacationing.
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: Confidence in President Bush's war on cocaine is waning and concerns are on the rise about drug abuse in the nation's neighborhoods, a national survey has found. Nearly half the respondents in the Media General-Associated Press poll said drugs are a serious problem where they live. That was up from 40 percent 10 months ago, when Bush announced his anti-drug campaign. Many Americans _ more than four in 10 of those under 45 years old _ continued to say they know a cocaine user. While most believed the government can reduce drug abuse, 55 percent expected the problem to worsen. In September, just after Bush declared war on drugs, 74 percent of Americans believed the administration was making a serious effort to combat illegal drug use. That confidence fell to 59 percent in the new survey.

Democrats say they see renewed signs of hope of winning the White House in 1992, largely because of the potential political travails facing the man who beat them so soundly in 1988. Moreover, they now say the numbers of that crushing defeat are not really as bad as they appeared at first blush. The party leaders wound up their weekend meeting in Portland, Ore., professing to be on a roll and eager to adopt a more aggressive stance against a Republican president and party they maintain is being torn by festering internal strife _ a malady more often associated with Democrats. Their next order of business is to select the site for their 1992 convention. Party officials say it will be New York City, barring a last-minute snag.

Republicans are out to an early lead in the Ohio governor's race as the GOP nominee tries to blame his Democratic rival for the ills of a state government he likens to a ``dirty sock.'' ``It stinks,'' says George Voinovich, who in January ended his 10-year tenure as mayor of Cleveland. The Democratic nominee, state Attorney General Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr., is keeping his distance from outgoing Democratic Gov. Richard Celeste and hoping to gain votes with his newfound support for legalized abortion. With Celeste having to step aside after two terms, both parties want to control the governor's mansion when legislative and congressional districts are redrawn next year based on the results of the 1990 census. Nationally, the GOP sees the Ohio race as one of its best opportunities to pick up a state now in Democratic hands.

Both liberals and conservatives can find decisions to cheer in the Supreme Court's 1989-90 term, but there is little doubt the court's conservative majority is in control. ``The past year has been a mixed one,'' said Steven Shapiro of the American Civil Liberties Union. ``There were important victories, most notably in the flag burning case and the two affirmative action decisions.'' The court struck down a federal law that banned flag burning and upheld government policies helping blacks and other minorities seeking radio and television station licenses. ``On the other hand,'' Shapiro said, ``the court's decisions on abortion, religion, search and seizure ... have done serious damage to longstanding civil liberties principles.''
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Ken Johnson, who charted unknown territory in 1964, had to admit that Andy Hawkins went him one better. ``Four-nothing. Boy, that's rough. I only lost 1-0,'' said Johnson, who until Sunday was the only pitcher in major-league history to throw a no-hitter and lose. Johnson, a right-hander with the Houston Colt .45s, was beaten in 1964 by the Cincinnati Reds, who converted two errors into the only run of the game. Hawkins' New York Yankees lost 4-0 to the Chicago White Sox, who made the most of two walks, an infield error and two dropped fly balls.

DOC.HEAD: Lots of Facts, But What's the Truth?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Substitutes for the regular column by Walter R. Mears, vacationing.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: This is a town that is drowning in words, swimming in information but parched for facts. When decisions have to be made, the decision-makers, in Congress, in the White House, in the agencies of government, afloat in data and analysis, still yearn for the decisive fact that will tell them what to do. Would reducing the tax on capital gains give the economy a booster shot, as President Bush claims, or merely deepen the deficit gap, as his Democratic opponents say? If the House Ways and Means Committee were to announce hearings on that question today, the corridors would be crowded tomorrow with experts carrying briefcases loaded with facts to prove indisputably both sides of the argument. Predictive facts _ what would happen if _ are not the only kind that are hard to come by. So are contemporary facts. Homelessness is a gnawing social problem, high in the public consciousness, the subject of strenuous government effort, yet no one knows how many homeless people are out there, or who they are, or how long they have been homeless. Back in 1971, President Richard Nixon, concerned by inflation, took the unprecedented step of imposing peacetime wage and price controls on the economy. Overnight, it became illegal to raise the price of a Buick or a bagel. It was a radical move for a Republican president, intended to stem inflation that he saw as threatening to the economy and his re-election prospects. And yet, says Herbert J. Stein, who was one of Nixon's economic advisers, ``there was a lot of uncertainty about what the rate of inflation actually was.'' Inflation was, and is, measured in dozens of ways and no one can say which measurement most accurately reflects the rise in the price of goods and services. That's not all, says Stein: ``We still don't know what caused the depression in 1929. There's still disagreement over whether some international thing was moving the whole world or whether it was the way the monetary system was being managed. ``It's hard to get information on a lot of subjects,'' he says. ``Take all the talk on the S&L business. It is hard to find where all the estimates of losses (which seem to change monthly) come from. We have very little information about what happened in the first place.'' When President Franklin D. Roosevelt died in 1945 and Vice President Harry S. Truman suddenly became president, he learned about the secret work on the atomic bomb and one of the first decisions he had to make was whether to use it against Japan. Fleet Adm. William D. Leahy, chief of staff to Roosevelt, came to him, Truman recalls in his memoirs, and in absolute certainty advised him not to use the bomb. ```That is the biggest fool thing we have ever done,' he observed in his sturdy, salty manner,'' Truman writes. ```The bomb will never go off, and I speak as an expert in explosives.''' That's the trouble with experts, of which this town is also full. Their opinions always parade as facts. Says Charles Schultze, who played the same role for President Jimmy Carter that Stein played for Nixon: ``There are zillions of facts. ... The question is, having all those facts, what do you conclude? ``If you ask me what a reduction in capital gains taxation would do to federal revenues, I can get you two highly quantitative reports, full of numbers, one saying it will go up and one saying it will go down. Sometimes the `facts' come from people who want them to be true.'' As long ago as 1931, Charles Evans Hughes, then chief justice, reflected in a speech on the potency of facts. Said Hughes: ``An unscrupulous administrator might be tempted to say, `Let me find the facts for the people of my country, and I care little who lays down the general principles.''' Says Jim Jaffe, a savvy aide on Capitol Hill since 1976: ``Look at what's happening behind what we used to call the Iron Curtain. You can say one of two things. You can say the Reagan plan of spending like a madman, figure they'd run out of money before we would, has been wildly successful. Or you can say the communist world was deteriorating anyhow and look at all the domestic concerns we ignored while we were wasting all this money on missiles we had no need for. ... It's an intellectual game, it's not a factual game.'' There are lots of facts in Washington, but judgment is always scarce. That's a fact.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Mike Feinsilber has been reporting in Washington since 1968.
DOC.HEAD: Above Advance for release TUE PMs July 3
Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Saturday, July 14, the 195th day of 1990. There are 170 days left in the year. Today's highlight in history: On July 14, 1789, the French Revolution was in full swing as citizens of Paris stormed the Bastille prison and released the seven prisoners inside. On this date: In 1798, Congress passed the Sedition Act, making it a federal crime to publish false, scandalous or malicious writing about the United States government. In 1853, Commodore Matthew Perry relayed to Japanese officials a letter from former President Fillmore, requesting trade relations. In 1881, outlaw William H. Bonney Jr., alias Billy the Kid, was shot and killed by Sheriff Pat Garrett in Fort Sumner, N.M. In 1921, Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti were convicted in Dedham, Mass., in the killing of a shoe company paymaster and his guard. Sacco and Vanzetti were executed six years later. In 1958, the army of Iraq overthrew the monarchy. In 1966, eight student nurses were murdered by Richard Speck in a Chicago dormitory. In 1976, Jimmy Carter won the Democratic presidential nomination by an overwhelming margin at the party's convention in New York. In 1978, Soviet dissident Anatoly Shcharansky was convicted of treasonous espionage and anti-Soviet agitation, and sentenced to 13 years at hard labor. Shcharansky was released in 1986. In 1983, two members of Congress, Illinois Republican Daniel Crane and Massachusetts Democrat Gerry Studds, admitted having sexual relations with congressional pages, and were later censured by the full House. Ten years ago: The Republican national convention opened in Detroit, where nominee-apparent Ronald Reagan told a welcoming rally he and his supporters were determined to ``make America great again.'' Five years ago: Doctors at Bethesda Naval Hospital said President Reagan was making a spectacular recovery from major abdominal surgery to remove an intestinal growth that proved to be cancerous. One year ago: Leaders of the seven richest nations opened a summit in Paris, which was also celebrating the bicentennial of the French Revolution with pomp and pageantry. Today's birthdays: Author Isaac Bashevis Singer is 86. Former President Ford is 77. Former CBS newscaster Douglas Edwards is 73. Movie director Ingmar Bergman is 72. NBC News commentator John Chancellor is 63. Football player-turned-actor Rosey Grier is 58. Thought for today: ``It takes people a long time to learn the difference between talent and genius, especially ambitious young men and women.'' _ Louisa May Alcott, American author (1832-1888).

DOC.HEAD: CBS Affiliates Keep an Eye on Business
DOC.TEXT: There is something slightly strange about sitting in a darkened ballroom for three days watching television with about 1,000 CBS representatives. For one thing, the hype is overwhelming. The sound level is loud. The speeches are a curious mixture of cheerleading and defensiveness. Welcome to the annual convention for the eye network's affiliated stations, held last week at the Century Plaza, the favorite hotel of former President Ronald Reagan. Like many conventions, the CBS gathering was long on glad-handing and short on substance. ABC had its convention in the same spot two weeks before. NBC held its convention infore going off to the mission. McClane does use his resourcefulness _ and it seems neverending. Just as the guy comes up for air, he goes under again and comes back even stronger. But where McClane found himself in a crazed situation by accident in ``Die Hard,'' he's superhero by choice in ``Die Hard 2.'' This, somehow, makes it very different and lessens the sympathy or empathy we might have for him. There are loads of laughs _ even when unintended by the filmmakers, lots of raw, macho action and a few surprises in this Gordon Company-Silver Pictures Production. And a lot of people probably won't want to fly again once they learn about ``the outer perimeter'' and that great parking lot in the sky. Produced by Lawrence Gordon, Joel Silver and Charles Gordon, ``Die Hard 2'' is rated R for violence, including an icicle impalement and language.

DOC.HEAD: High Volume Retailers Force Competitor to Boost Efficiency
DOC.TEXT: The Miller brothers, Jack, Harvey and Arnold, thought they ran their office supplies company with unusual efficiency until they came up against the biggest challenge of their lives. In just a few years, the multibillion dollar industry's historical arrangement of wholesalers and retailers was upset by the development of big-volume, low-price retail superstores. Quill Corporation, which the Millers had developed in 34 years to sales of $275 million, making it perhaps the biggest business-to-business supplier of office supplies, had to cut prices while improving service and efficiency. It was an enormous and unexpected challenge to an industry accustomed to traditional ways of doing things. ``We discovered unbelievable efficiencies,'' said Jack, the president, from his office in Lincolnshire, Ill. ``We thought we were rough and tough, but we were just pussycats.'' Miller believes his is a message for independently owned businesses everywhere. Yes, he says, you too can raise sales and improve efficiency and service without resorting to large-scale layoffs. Maybe even raise morale too. The first step was to lower prices 18 percent, and that ``forced us to say we had to be sharper than in the past,'' he said. ``It was a kick in the pants to profit margins. We had to find savings from the smallest to largest.'' Here are a few of the smaller ones: _Negotiating a new, long-term contract with the primary long-distance telephone carrier, a savings of about $32,400 annually. (Quill is a direct mail supplier; most of its business is done by mail, fax and phone.) _Recycling scrap cardboard at an annual savings of about $7,200. _Conserving energy by replacing two 15-watt incandescent bulbs in emergency signs with one 12-watt fluorescent bulb. Savings: $1,800 in the first year, $3,000 for the second year. _Microfiching documents closer together. Annual savings $12,000. _Saving on benefits without reducing them. Since many medical-care providers issue duplicate copies of bills, Quill's benefits department stopped making copies for employees. Savings: $10,000 a year in materials and labor. Encouraged by messages in the company newsletter, in a special weekly bulletin and on a display outside the lunchroom _ to say nothing of their stake in the profit-sharing plan _ employees cooperated. The philosophy of efficiency spread. Workers asked themselves,``What is it I am doing?'' Nothing was too minor to recommend. Now that you think about it, you too can turn old file folders inside out and relabel them. ``You don't have to bribe workers,'' says Miller. ``People want to do a good job.'' Major strategic ideas were implemented. Everyday low pricing was instituted, sharply cutting the expense of frequent catalog changes. Whereas orders used to be shipped within eight to 32 hours, a goal of no more than 24 hours was established. While that immediately improved service on most orders, it had additional beneficial consequences. There was, for example, a quick dropoff in people calling to ask ``where's my order?,'' thus saving time and labor. Whereas orders had been spot-checked for accuracy before shipment, workers were added and the company went to 100 percent checking. The savings were immediate, in customer service, freight and returned merchandise. Such efficiencies never would have been discovered or implemented had not the industry been turned upside down by the super stores, or large-volume retail outlets that completely redefined pricing. With profit margins permanently cut, Quill now must continue its policy of everyday efficiencies. ``It's fantastic to see the kind of efficiencies competitive pressures can generate,'' says Jack Miller. In short, Miller declares Quill is a better business today for its management, employees and customers. ``No more work just to fill time,'' he says. While it is hardly pleasant to have competitors abruptly change old habits, the initial shock is waning. Miller was heard recently saying ``it's the best thing that ever happened to the industry.''

DOC.HEAD: Is Everything Kosher With Moshe Dragon's Duck
DOC.TEXT: Life at Lenny Ung's Moshe Dragon went from sweet to sour after the discovery of 18 suspicious ducks in the kosher Chinese restaurant. Did the ducks conform with the ancient Jewish dietary laws, or were they ``treyfe'' _ Hebrew for non-kosher abomination. The ensuing dispute, publicized in a series of investigative articles in the Washington Jewish Week, sent the Washington area's Orthodox Jewish community into a frenzy and pushed Ung toward financial ruin. Ung, 29, an ethnic Chinese, escaped from Vietnam and came to this country 14 years ago. Three years ago, he was lured from Philadelphia to Washington by an investor who wanted the 30,000 Orthodox Jews in the Washington area to have a full-service kosher restaurant. Moshe Dragon opened three years ago in the Washington suburb of Rockville, Md. The food was kosher, meaning it adhered to the ancient Jewish principles that forbid mixing dairy and meat products and only allow meat from cloven-hoofed animals who chew their cud. Pork is out, as are shellfish and scavenger fish. Ung obtained the required certification from the Rabbinical Council of Greater Washington, an eight-member monopoly that for some 80 years has been granting the kosher stamp of approval to area restaurants, stores and caterers. The rabbis hired Michael Mayer as Moshe Dragon's ``mashgiach'' _ Hebrew for supervisor. Things were going well. Mayer understood Ung, having served in Vietnam during the war, and he introduced him to the Jewish community. But last summer Mayer found 18 ducks which he deemed non-kosher, along with receipts from a non-kosher supplier. Non-kosher meat generally is less expensive than kosher meat. Mayer sealed the birds in the freezer as evidence, and went to tell the rabbis. Tempers flared, Ung accused Mayer of trying to destroy the restaurant, and Mayer was fired. ``They did the classic Roman thing _ they killed the messenger,'' said Mark Palmer, Mayer's lawyer. Concerned that Moshe Dragon might be harboring non-kosher food, the rabbis destroyed the ducks, just in case. Had they waited, a simple lab analysis could have determined the ducks' origins by their salt content: to make meat kosher, it must be soaked in salt water. When the rabbis questioned Ung, he said the receipts belonged to his cousin. But he later recanted, became distraught and was taken to the hospital. The rabbis said the questioning reminded him of interrogations in Vietnam. A private investigator was brought in, and the rabbis subsequently cleared Ung of all blame. But the PI, Susan Giller, was unhappy. ``The evidence I found was not consistent with the rabbis' conclusion,'' she said. ``I don't want to be associated with those conclusions.'' Rabbi Joel Tessler, a member of the Rabbinical Council, said the rabbis stand by their finding that the restaurant complies with the kosher dietary laws. Ung, he said, is an ``honorable man.'' Meanwhile, critics of the Rabbinical Council called for a law granting the state enforcement power over the implementation of kosher standards. And Mayer's lawyer asked the Maryland Attorney General to investigate whether Moshe Dragon violated the state's Consumer Protection Act. Business declined as customers began doubting the restaurant's standards after reading about the dispute in Washington Jewish Week. Matters weren't helped when Regardie's, a local business magazine, published a piece of its own about Moshe Dragon, complete with lab analyses of the Moo Shu pancakes. Regardie's reported that lab tests found traces of whey in the pancakes, a no-no when the pancakes are filled with meat. The rabbis responded with their own lab tests, saying those did not find any of the offending whey in two pancakes, and only minute traces in a third. Enter Mordechai Kohler, the Orthodox food supervisor who replaced Mayer. One day Kohler was incensed when a Chinese cook used a spoon reserved for meat to ladle spices onto a fish _ also a no-no. Kohler ended up quitting. In an interview with Jewish Week, Kohler said he was uneasy about the practices at Moshe Dragon, including the presence of a Buddha statue in the kitchen. He said workers, some of them devout Buddhists, dedicated food to the Buddha. Ung admits there was a Buddha figurine on top of a refrigerator, but he denied any sacrifices were made. The only sacrifice, he says, was his own. ``I tried to follow what the Council said,'' Ung lamented in broken English. ``I want to do the right thing for the community. My father teach me to do the right thing, not to cheat, not to steal.'' But Ung said he lost more than $30,000 and couldn't take the aggravation. He is selling Moshe Dragon and plans to become an acupuncturist. ``Maybe that is less pain,'' he said.

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ The dangerous legacy of 45 years of building atomic bombs is contaminated nuclear graveyards that will cost billions of dollars to clean up, if indeed scientists can figure out a way to clean them up. One researcher even says that trying to get rid of the radioactive wastes would cost more lives than leaving them alone.

Miles of 8-foot-high electric fences stretch through Bethel Valley, the once-secret cradle of the atomic age. They stand watch over burial grounds of deadly wastes that are the legacy of four decades of nuclear bomb production. Yellow and magenta signs proclaim, ``Radiation Hazard, Keep Out.'' The fences encircling some of the hundreds of acres of contaminated land on the federal Oak Ridge nuclear weapons compound are reminders that while the Cold War may be over, it took a serious toll. It cost about $250 billion for the roughly 65,000 nuclear weapons that the United States has manufactured since 1945, when the first was assembled. That bill is paid. Yet to be settled is the toll this secretive manufacturing process has taken on weapons workers and the environment. At Oak Ridge alone, the Energy Department has spent $1 billion since 1983 trying to control the environmental damage. It is expected to take at least 10 more years just to determine what poisons have seeped into the soil and ground water here, and 20 more years to stop it from spreading. The total bill for cleaning up Oak Ridge may top $12 billion. Costs at some of the 16 other active nuclear arms laboratories, manufacturing plants and proving grounds in 11 other states will be much higher. The full cost of environmental repairs alone may top $100 billion. Estimates vary greatly because the government itself doesn't know how badly some sites are contaminated. Nor has all the necessary technology been developed. In the meantime, Tennessee health authorities ban fishing and swimming in East Fork Poplar Creek, which winds through the 56,000-acre weapons plant as well as the adjacent city of Oak Ridge, and in a portion of the Clinch River, which borders the plant on three sides. The stream is poisoned by mercury, once used to separate lithium for nuclear weapons. Oak Ridge, originally called the Clinton Engineer Works, was the site of the first nuclear bomb production plants, code-named Y-12, X-10 and K-25. Today it remains a key link in the production chain, although some of its operations have been closed permanently. Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc., which runs Oak Ridge under a government contract, says 75 tons of toxic mercury and substantial amounts of the radioactive element cesium-137 have spread from the weapons plant and contaminated the sediment in Watts Bar Reservoir, which remains open to the public for swimming and boating. ``Not only did the atomic age start here, the problems did, too,'' says Bill Adams, the Energy Department's chief of waste and environmental management at Oak Ridge. Unfortunately, the problems don't end here. The radioactive and toxic contamination is so bad at several nuclear weapons plants _ in Colorado, Ohio, Tennessee, South Carolina, California, Missouri and Washington state _ that portions of these huge sites will become ``national sacrifice zones,'' scientists say, land deemed permanently unfit for human use. ``We have one hell of a legacy to clean up,'' says Leo Duffy, the top adviser to Energy Secretary James D. Watkins on long-term environmental issues. The question is how to get the money. Congress and the Bush administration are under pressure to cut the budget deficit even as defense spending slows in response to moves toward democracy in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. In the emerging national debate over the size of a ``peace dividend'' from expected military savings _ and how to spend it _ little has been said about the ``mortgage'' the atomic bomb builders took out to compete in the arms race. During the World War II development of the first atomic bombs in the Army's secret Manhattan Project, any thoughts of environmental or excessive health risks were subsumed by a feeling that the very survival of democracy depended on getting the bomb as quickly as possible. Later, through the Cold War period, military authorities used the shield of strict secrecy _ justified on national security grounds _ to continue borrowing against the environment and workers' health to speed up bomb production, according to interviews with current and former arms plant workers, government officials, scientists and congressional investigators. Now payment is coming due. Officials who have surveyed the dozens of existing and former nuclear weapons sites around the country say hundreds of billions of dollars are needed not only to control environmental damage, but also to reduce the health risks of nuclear plant workers and to make safety improvements long put off. Until the mid-1980s the government would not acknowledge these failures. ``Nobody wants to look under the rug, and a lot has been swept under the rug in the nuclear weapons industry,'' says Elizabeth Paul of the Snake River Alliance, based in Ketchum, Idaho. The citizens group opposes the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory, which recovers highly enriched uranium from naval reactors. Even an investment of $100 billion in environmental corrections won't completely reverse the damage. The chief problems are contamination of the soil and ground water _ on the federal sites and in surrounding areas _ with radioactive materials such as plutonium, tritium and strontium-90 and such toxics as mercury, arsenic and a variety of solvents. Plutonium is so potent that lethal lung doses are measured in the billionths of a gram. The ``burial grounds'' and some other parts of Oak Ridge, as well as large sections of the Hanford weapons plant near Richland, Wash., the Savannah River plant near Aiken, S.C., and portions of other sites from coast to coast won't be fit for human use for hundreds, perhaps thousands, of years. ``There'll be hot spots that will never have any other use except for disposal of hazardous and radioactive waste,'' says Vic Rezendes, director of energy issues at the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
OAK RIDGE, Tenn.: of Congress.
DOC.TEXT: The cost to human health is harder to assess. The government has never acknowledged any human health damage caused by emissions from its plants or by radiation releases from atomic bomb tests in the desert Southwest. But increasing numbers of Americans are going to court seeking compensation on grounds that chronic exposure to radiation caused illness and death, even at levels the government considers safe. Bruce H. DeBoskey, a Denver lawyer for some workers at the Rocky Flats plutonium processing plant, says relatives of workers who died of cancer feel cheated by the federal government. ``The widows of these workers who gave their lives to build these bombs are deeply embittered,'' DeBoskey says. ``There's a human tragedy here.'' Also at risk were thousands of uranium miners who dug out the bomb material in unventilated shafts in New Mexico, Arizona, Utah and Colorado from the late 1940s to the mid-1960s, when mining stopped because the government had stockpiled all it needed. Of the estimated 15,000 men who worked the mines, about 450 have died of lung cancer _ five times the number expected in a similar size group of American men, according to the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health. Congress is now trying to make some amends. In June the House passed a bill to establish a $100 million trust to compensate families of miners with radiation-induced illness, as well as certain cancer victims in Nevada, Utah and Arizona who were exposed to fallout from above-ground nuclear testing from 1951 to 1962. The Senate is expected to approve the bill. President Bush opposes it. Scientists have not yet determined conclusively whether accidental releases of radioactivity from nuclear weapons plants are a health threat. Nor are they yet sure of the risk posed by chronic exposure of workers to low levels of radiation. Until the mid-1980s these issues were secondary. Production was king, secrecy its serf. ``Things having to do with atomic weapons are born secret,'' says J. Carson Mark, who spent 27 years designing nuclear weapons at Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico and is now retired. Clyde Hopkins remembers the mind-set in the early 1950s when he was a production control worker at the Oak Ridge Y-12 plant, which used tons of mercury to separate lithium for use as a fuel source in thermonuclear warheads. ``The pressure was intense to come up with weapons components on a short-term basis,'' he says. ``People back in those days didn't even think about the environment. They thought about getting the doggone work out to support the country's nuclear stockpile. ``I can remember days when people were walking around with lots of mercury on the floor. You kept operating because you wanted that product to come out. So the emphasis then was on production. The thought that we had mercury leaking on the floor, obviously working its way down through the concrete into the ground, it wasn't thought about back then.'' Hopkins thinks about it a lot now. He is president of Martin Marietta Energy Systems, which is locked in negotiations with the Energy Department over its financial and legal liability for failing to meet state and federal environmental laws. Oak Ridge was not alone in its approach to meeting bomb production schedules. Cleve Anderson recalls fighting against a ``production-first'' mentality while he headed a committee studying long-range waste management at Hanford in the late 1950s. Hanford was the main producer of plutonium _ the most lethal element known _ for use in nuclear bombs, although today its nine reactors are shut down. ``At Hanford we had been indoctrinated thoroughly that the nation's survival depended on what we were doing, that nothing was more important to national security than getting ever more plutonium. Anything else that might interfere was secondary,'' he said. In a classified report written in December 1958 for General Electric Co., which was running Hanford under a government contract, Anderson urged that more money be spent to develop safer disposal methods for radioactive wastes. He wrote: ``The probability of the superiority of alternate methods of waste disposal has long been recognized but the pressing problems of (weapons production) precluded any but the most cursory examinations of these alternatives.'' He said his report was shelved. Years later, he had to file a request under the Freedom of Information Act to obtain a copy. Today Hanford is considered the most extensively contaminated piece of land in the United States, perhaps in the world. The government's own advisers were sounding the alarm on nuclear waste as early as 1955. In that year the National Academy of Sciences formed a committee to advise the Atomic Energy Commission on waste disposal. The committee concluded in late 1955 that dumping radioactive wastes directly into the ground ``probably involves unacceptable long-term risks'' to the environment. Yet such practices continued for more three decades. Hopkins, the Martin Marietta manager at Oak Ridge, says, ``I'd be surprised'' if officials there were told prior to the 1980s that dumping wastes directly into the ground carried the risk of serious environmental damage. ``If they had, I don't think we'd have done it,'' he said. Regardless of the reasons, the hazards posed by huge accumulations of nuclear wastes now represent a technological challenge for America unlike any it has faced since the dawn of the atomic age. ``We've scratched the surface,'' says Duffy, the Energy Department waste czar. ``We know the problems, we don't know the solutions.'' One of the least understood problems is how much of the nuclear graveyards can be excavated or treated without putting workers at unacceptable risk. Frank L. Parker, who headed Oak Ridge National Laboratory's radioactive waste management research in the late 1950s and early 1960s and now teaches environmental engineering at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Tenn., says the country will have to accept that some nuclear wastes are too dangerous to remove. ``The number of deaths you're going to incur to clean it up will dwarf the number who would be killed if you left it alone,'' he says.

With BC-APN--Bombmakers' Legacy
DOC.TEXT: OAK RIDGE, Tenn. (AP) _ For more than 30 years the National Academy of Sciences has been sounding warnings about the handling of radioactive materials at the nation's nuclear weapons facilities. A report to the government in 1958 cited the academy's ``continuing concern about the disposal of intermediate and low-level waste liquids in seepage pits at Oak Ridge National Laboratory because they contaminate the environment.'' For several years the academy urged the government to crack down on the waste management problems of the private companies that run all the weapons plants. In a 1966 report summarizing 11 years of recommendations on this issue, the National Academy said it had become commonplace for the plant operators to use the cheapest methods of waste disposal, even though these carried large environmental risks. ``Such methods represent a concept of easy disposal that has had and will continue to have great appeal to operators, but we fear that continuation of the practices eventually will create hazards that will be extremely difficult and expensive to eliminate,'' the report said. ``Any compromise with safety for the sake of economy could lead in the long run to mushrooming of waste disposal into the most costly item in the use of nuclear power.'' As with most weapons plant documentation from that period, the National Academy reports were not made public at the time they were submitted to the Atomic Energy Commission, a predecessor agency to the present-day Energy Department.

From AP Newsfeatures

DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON (AP) _ Here is a brief look at some of the other nuclear weapons plants and their problems.
DOC.HEAD: Feed Materials Production Center:@ Closed indefinitely in 1989,
DOC.TEXT: this plant near Fernald, Ohio, converts gaseous uranium into a metallic form for use at other weapons factories. At least 300,000 pounds of uranium dust were released into the air, and radioactive and toxic wastes have contaminated drinking water underground.
DOC.HEAD: Savannah River Site:@ Three active reactors that produce
DOC.TEXT: tritium, a gas used in nuclear warheads, are tentatively scheduled to resume production in 1991. They were shut down in 1988 for safety reasons. The site, near Aiken, S.C., has no way yet of safely disposing of its 35 million gallons of highly radioactive wastes.
DOC.HEAD: Hanford Reservation:@ Most of the plutonium used in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: nuclear weapons was made at this 600-square-mile plant along the Columbia River near Richland, Wash. It is considered the most severely polluted site in the weapons complex; technology to handle some of the hottest radioactive wastes does not exist.
DOC.HEAD: Rocky Flats:@ Located 16 miles from Denver, this plant
DOC.TEXT: fabricates plutonium into triggers for warheads. It has been closed for safety improvements since last fall. Its history is marked by numerous accidental releases of radiation as well as frequent injuries and contamination of workers with plutonium and other hazardous materials.
DOC.HEAD: Pantex Plant:@ A final assembly point for nuclear weapons near
DOC.TEXT: Austin, Texas, this is the most secretive site in the complex. Thousands of gallons of toxic chemicals dumped in unlined pits between 1954 and 1980 threaten the Ogallala aquifer, the main source of water for Texas' largest irrigated farming region. Officials say radiation protection for Pantex workers is inadequate.

The government also faces huge environmental tasks at dozens of inactive nuclear weapons production sites. Among the most difficult is the Weldon Spring uranium processing plant near St. Louis, which operated from 1956 to 1966. Radioactive contaminants from waste pits have leaked into the ground water. Estimates of the cleanup cost have leaped more than 100-fold in the past 11 years.

From AP Newsfeatures

DOC.TEXT: OAK RIDGE, Tenn. (AP) _ The full cost of 45 years of nuclear bomb production won't be known for decades. But already, in subtle ways, the social toll can be seen. Along quiet Bethel Valley Road, inside the boundaries of the Oak Ridge nuclear weapons compound, stands the one-room, wood-frame New Bethel Baptist Church. Behind the boarded-up building is a stone monument, nearly as tall as the church roof, with an engraving that reads, ``Erected in memory of new Bethel Baptist Church.'' ``Opened 1851 _ Closed 1942,'' it reads, adding for explanation that the sermons stopped when the government took over Bethel Valley and thousands of acres around it to build parts and materials for the atomic bombs used in World War II. The weapons plants are still here. So is the church, if only as a whitewashed reminder of times past, times when the tiny towns of Wheat, Robertsville, Elza and Scarboro had their own churches, their own stores, their own school, their own tobacco and corn farmers, their own histories, their own hopes for the future. Times before the bomb builders wiped them off the map. The New Bethel Baptist Church has been spared, but today it stands empty and alone except for piles of trash visible inside through its few unboarded windows, and several dozen gravestones in a grassy cemetery at the back of the church grounds. Two signs are nailed to a cedar tree beside the church. One, white and wooden, says simply ``New Bethel'' followed by the sign of the cross. Below it a red metal sign, of an obviously newer vintage, says, ``Area Closed to Hunters.''
