DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ The 40,000 Indians living on reservations in upstate New York are clinging to their traditional culture despite the encroachment of modern civilization. But conflict with the white man's world sometimes erupts in violence and gunfire, as evidenced by the recent shooting down of a National Guard helicopter.

Centuries after the legendary Hiawatha paddled the waters of Onondaga Lake with the Great Peacemaker to unite warring Indian tribes, the Six Nations of the Iroquois Confederacy endures. Onondaga Lake is now so polluted by industrial effluent that the fish are inedible and the shoreline is dominated by the modern skyline of the city of Syracuse. Yet, just a few miles away, Chief Leon Shenandoah presides over Confederacy meetings in the traditional Longhouse and performs religious ceremonies dating back to Hiawatha's time. The observances symbolize the dogged manner in which the tribes of the Iroquois have kept their culture alive despite the encroachment of modern civilization. ``We still have our own way of life, our own government,'' Shenandoah says. ``We didn't change much. I'm still doing my ceremonies.'' The confederacy is a nation within a nation, issuing its own passports, operating gambling casinos in a state where they are illegal, taking advantage of tax breaks to profit in the sale of such things as cigarettes and gasoline. Some Iroquois have withdrawn into armed enclaves to escape the white man's culture. Others have embraced it and still others have found a way to prosper while retaining their distinctive way of life. ``What is remarkable about the Iroquois is that they have survived as a coherent culture so long after coming into contact with us,'' says Jan Wojcik, humanities professor at Clarkson University in Potsdam, N.Y. ``Eighty-five percent of the Indian cultures are gone. There are very few left. The Iroquois are very strong, very healthy.'' Wojcik says, in fact, that the Mohawks on the St. Regis Indian Reservation in northern New York are ``very prosperous'' compared with Indians on most other reservations in the country. ``They have jobs. There are good houses. People drive cars,'' Wojcik says. ``They are almost indistinguishable from the middle-class mainstream.'' There are about 40,000 Indians living throughout upstate New York, about eight times as many as when Henry Hudson sailed the Half Moon up the Hudson River nearly 400 years ago. That journey signaled the start of centuries of uneasy relations between Indians and white men in upstate New York. The Iroquois Confederacy was founded between 500 and 1,000 years ago to prevent bloody conflicts among the Senecas, Mohawks, Cayugas, Onondagas and Oneidas. The Tuscaroras joined the Confederacy later when they were driven out of North Carolina. The influence of the Iroquois waned when the confederacy sided with the British in the Revolutionary War. Under a confused, and still disputed, patchwork of treaties in the late 1700s, the tribes of the Iroquois were relegated to reservations as waves of non-Indian immigrants settled across upstate New York. Legal title to those lands and whether the reservations embody sovereign nations are issues that continue to plague the Iroquois' relations with the state and federal governments. They're also the basis of bloody conflicts among tribal members themselves. On May 1, two Mohawks were killed when a dispute over casino gambling on the St. Regis Indian Reservation along the New York-Canadian border turned into a fierce gun battle between pro-and anti-gambling factions. New York and Canadian police are still manning armed roadblocks on the reservation to prevent further bloodshed. Earlier this year, a doctor was wounded when a Vermont National Guard helicopter was brought down by gunfire while flying over the Ganienkeh Indian Territory in northern New York. That prompted a tense standoff between heavily armed militant Mohawks and state troopers, with Indians vowing to die for their cause. The Iroquois insist on being treated as an independent nation, going so far as issuing passports that are recognized by such countries as the United States, Canada and Great Britain. Yet most police officials believe they have responsibility to maintain order on New York reservations and to investigate reports of felonies. At the same time, they know they risk a violent reaction by ordering officers onto Indian land. During the standoffs at the Ganienkeh Indian Territory, powerful automatic weapons were brandished by defiant Mohawks who said they were ready to take on troopers. No arrests have been made in the downing of the helicopter. County sheriff's deputies will not enter the Onondaga Indian Reservation without permission of the chiefs, even when they are pursuing a murder suspect. Sovereignty has its economic advantages. Indians are exempt from state and federal taxes and Indian entrepreneurs have made a booming business of selling cigarettes and gasoline to outsiders who come to the reservation to evade taxes. By making the trip to a reservation, a person can save approximately $3 on each carton of cigarettes and 14 cents on each gallon of gasoline.

DOC.TEXT: And, claiming sovereign exemption from outside laws against gambling, the Oneidas and Mohawks have established lucrative casinos and bingo parlors on their reservations, with tour bus service to transport customers in from neighboring cities. The St. Regis casinos were particularly popular with Canadian gamblers. New York officials insist that some of the gambling is illegal and they estimate that the state loses up to $20 million a year in taxes due to the Indian entrepreneurs. ``The word `tax' is not in our Seneca language,'' Dennis Lay, president of the Seneca Indian Nation, recently argued before state lawmakers in Albany. ``It is interpreted as being detrimental to our survival as a sovereign nation. Let the Seneca Nation govern ourselves without a taxing scheme created by your government.'' Lay's tribe won a major victory this spring when the city of Salamanca agreed to a new 80-year lease that calls for payments of at least $800,000 a year to the tribe. The agreement includes a one-time grant of $60 million to the Senecas to make up for past injustices against the tribe. One of the reasons the Iroquois have endured so well is by taking advantage of economic opportunities, says Clarkson University's Wojcik. The Iroquois, especially the Mohawks, have earned a reputation in the high-paying ``high steel'' work on New York City skyscrapers. The Indians, who display great balance, agility and an apparent fearlessness of heights, often share small apartments in New York City during the week and travel back to their upstate reservations on weekends. Iroquois life is full of other seeming contradictions between the traditional Indian culture and modern America. When the militant Mohawks at Ganienkeh were manning their barricades, they issued statements to the media via a fax machine. Harold Tarbell, a traditionalist chief at St. Regis, wears his hair in a traditional braid while sporting pleated pants and Pierre Cardin sunglasses. Despite outside pressures, Shenandoah, who has been the Iroquois chief of chiefs for two decades, insists the traditional Indian way of life is strong. Tom Porter, a Mohawk chief at St. Regis, says, ``I think practically every Mohawk to some degree follows the traditional way.'' Shenandoah is suspicious of white society and governments, staunchly refusing to accept governmental aid that was not part of a treaty. ``We accept nothing from the government,'' he says. ``No one from the state has any input here.'' The Longhouse continues to exert a strong influence over the Iroquois, says Shenandoah, gesturing toward the three churches on the Onondaga reservation. ``You can put all three churches together and we'll put more people in the Longhouse,'' Shenandoah says. ``We're not pagan. We don't idolize things in our way of life. The government is the one that idolizes money. The Creator did not create money. So we don't pray for money.'' The land the Iroquois control directly has been whittled away since the Revolution. The Onondagas, Mohawks, Senecas, Tuscaroras and Oneidas live on reservations scattered around upstate New York where their languages are taught to children in Indian schools. The Cayugas have no land and have gone to court to reclaim property they claim was illegally deeded to the state 180 years ago without the necessary approval of Congress. ``The reason we're fighting for land is so we can save our culture,'' says Cayuga Chief Frank Bonamie. ``We do not have a school so we miss out on teaching our children.'' The Oneidas are down to a 32-acre plot in the city of Oneida and have also gone to court seeking more land. The Mohawks also have land claims pending. To this day, the State of New York dutifully delivers 150 bushels of salt annually to the Onondagas to honor provisions of two treaties dating back to 1795 that turned Onondaga land into what is now Syracuse. Shenandoah does not recognize the salt payment. Chief Bonamie believes the Iroquois culture will endure. ``When you sit at the Grand Council and look around and think this has been going on for hundreds of years, there is a lot of power in that room,'' he says. ``It is an exciting time to be at a Grand Council meeting and feel the strength and power in that room.'' ``It might have its ups and downs, but I think it will endure forever.''

With BC-APN--Iroquois Confederacy
DOC.TEXT: Such American constitutional concepts as freedom of speech and representational government were derived from the Iroquois Confederacy's Great Law, some scholars say. The ancient Great Law of Peace that preceded the U.S. Constitution by centuries was based on strength through union. It enunciated such concepts as individual rights as well as checks and balances among the various branches of government. ``They copied our form of government,'' says Onondaga Chief Leon Shenandoah, who has been the chief of chiefs of the Six Nations of the Iroquois Confederacy for more than two decades. According to the oral history of the Indians, the Iroquois Confederacy was founded 500 to 1,000 years ago when the Great Peacemaker and the legendary Hiawatha persuaded the Senecas, Mohawks, Cayugas, Onondagas, and Oneidas to stop their warring and form a union. The Tuscaroras joined the Confederacy later when they were driven out of North Carolina. The Confederacy survives with the distinction of being the oldest league of nations in the world. Confederacy chiefs still gather at the Longhouse on the Onondaga Reservation near Syracuse, N.Y., to interpret the Great Law. One of the strongest proponents of the theory of the Iroquois influence on the U.S. Constitution is Donald Grinde, a professor of American Indian History at the University of California at Riverside. Benjamin Franklin, John Quincy Adams, Thomas Jefferson and James Madison were some of the Founding Fathers who were known to discuss the Iroquois system while they were formulating the U.S. Constitution, Grinde says. ``The founding fathers for a generation or more before the American Revolution looked at the Iroquois Confederacy as an alternative to the British model,'' says Grinde, who has written two books on the subject. ``They were definitely talking about it.'' Not all historians agree. ``The evidence is flimsy at best,'' says Jan Wojcik, humanities professor at Clarkson University in Potsdam, N.Y. Wojcik says the claim is based on hearsay. ``Supposedly, Benjamin Franklin listened to them give a description of their Confederacy before the Constitutional Convention, '' he says. ``In fact, he was contemptuous of the Iroquois and referred to them as savages. I don't really think there is any direct link that is traceable.'' To prove his point, Grinde cites a book John Quincy Adams wrote a month before the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia urging consideration of the Indian government. ``Their separation of powers is marked with a precision that excludes all controversy,'' Adams wrote at the time. In 1776, more than two dozen Iroquois chiefs participated in the debates over the Declaration of Independence at the invitation of the Continental Congress, the historian said. The framers referred to the Iroquois and the Confederacy in their debates to create the Articles of Confederation, which preceded the Constitution, Grinde says. ``It's all in the records of the Constitutional Congress and in the correspondence of the delegates,'' Grinde says. ``It's just been ignored, but Indians, especially the Iroquois, played a key role in the constitutional process.'' The Iroquois also provided the framers of the Constitution with a model for linking separate governments across a great geographical expanse, something the European governments did not do, Grinde says. For centuries, the Iroquois dominated much of what is now upstate New York. Ironically, most of the Iroquois sided with the British and the Confederacy lost much of its power after the Revolution.

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ For decades she labored in obscurity, writing the poems that no one would publish. Now at an age when most people are considering retiring, Amy Clampitt has begun to attract attention in the literary world.

In the early 1980s a New York bookstore sympathetic to struggling writers returned four of the five copies of Amy Clampitt's self-published poems she had asked the store to try to sell. The only one that was sold was bought by a friend of hers. But by the beginning of this year she had four collections published by a large publishing house, and her work was being likened in significance to Lowell, Stevens and Plath. One specialty publisher is now even producing a handmade volume of some of her work that will cost $700 per book. At age 70, Amy Clampitt is enjoying success rarely visited upon American poets. She first attracted attention with the 1983 publication of ``The Kingfisher,'' which unleashed, to use a phrase from one of her poems, ``a shower of bloom.'' The praise has largely continued through three more volumes, most recently, ``Westward.'' ``All I can tell you is that it wasn't any cinch,'' Clampitt says. For decades she wrote in the deep obscurity of a New York artist's life, even as the popular appeal of poetry seemed on a death spiral, especially the sometimes demanding verse _ critics call it allusive _ that she writes. Clampitt must have hardly seemed up to such hardscrabble work when she left the farm in New Providence, Iowa, a town of 200 people in the heart of the heartland. She was a nervous, elfin kid who had a Phi Beta Kappa key from Grinnell College, but had not been enough of a hand around the farm even to have milked a single cow. ``I wasn't very muscular or inclined to do strenuous things,'' she concedes. But she learned how to fetch a phrase. She learned mostly from her grandfather, a lover of reading and nature who once awakened one of his children and carried her into the night to point out the sound of a whippoorwill. Clampitt's poetry is alive with such pastoral sights and sounds: the ``cheekily anarchic dartings and flashings'' of birds, the ``vaporous fripperies'' of clouds, of ``bog laurel and lambkill'' the ``blurred flute note'' of a warbler. They all come out in ``torques, in curdlings, cadenzas by the earful.'' Even when the reader is wading through ``seaweed-clodded polyphloisboio thalasses'' or trying to see ``chiasmus through the looking-glass,'' her wordplay is resonant, musical. Over the years, as her splendid words went unnoticed, she sustained herself with a few attempts at traditional work, including a brief stint as an assistant librarian at the Audubon Society in New York. But she worked mainly as a free-lance editor. By the 1970s, she was reconciling herself to never being widely read. But she kept writing. Then, in 1978, The New Yorker _ one of the magazines which had ``been rejecting me for years'' _ took a long look and decided to publish some of her work. She had found a kindred spirit in poetry editor Howard Moss. ``He knew what a sundew is,'' she says, recalling with a fresh giggle one of their early conversations about her writing. After The New Yorker, many of the other important magazines followed. When ``The Kingfisher'' came out, the little world of American poetry was stunned by the thrill of, the achievement of, the thing. Clampitt, meanwhile, suffered the letdown that comes after publication of a first major work. She also suffered from all the attention. ``This kind of fame is limited to a little circle, but it is very different,'' says Clampitt, who was in Cambridge for a reading of her poems. ``I thought I was going to be a person who spent her life in obscurity, and then this came. It jolted me. I wasn't ready to have people know about me.'' Then, when the windfall of attention had subsided somewhat, the gainsayers who had been crouching in discontent emerged. And it hurt. The comeuppance came mainly by way of three poetry magazine contributors _ she calls them ``aspiring critics'' _ who took issue with her dense language and literary allusions. ``They were all women,'' she says. ``I guess some of them just don't allow for throwbacks like me.'' Some of the criticism was well-reasoned, for at times Clampitt can be excessive in her reference to other texts or in her language, i.e., her preference for classical traditions over the sparse style so much in vogue. But, oh, some of the things they said: ``Clampitt is not a poet of emotional depth.'' ``...it would be better for Amy Clampitt if, at least for a while, she tucked her notes from Poetry 101 away in a trunk.'' ``...all her prosodies tend to cacophony (sic).'' Clampitt can be vague, but her work is more likely to sparkle with the bright particulars she has enjoyed in her long romance with the language. She can be quick in her borrowings from other writers, but she is also a jewel thief who can pick the pockets of Hopkins or Wordsworth when they have just what she needs. She is stylistically somewhat outdated, but refreshingly so. Her poems already are finding their way into anthologies, and many critics are talking as if her work will ``last.'' Helen Vendler, Harvard professor and poetry critic of ``The New Yorker,'' says in her recent book on poetry, ``The Music of What Happens,'' that Clampitt's poetry will endure because of her rare voice and because it ``will take on as well the documentary value of what, in the 20th century, made up the stuff of culture.'' Because she was discovered so late in life, most of her close friends are much younger poets also just emerging. She is a little cowed in the company of the established writers of her generation. Clampitt has been a visiting writer and lecturer at several colleges, and is now working on more poems, occasional reviews, and on a play about Dorothy Wordsworth. Her latest volume, ``Westward,'' has not received as much attention as her earlier works, but it offers sensual delights and is accessible to even the most casual reader. Turn to ``The Prairie,'' a long poem in ``Westward'' for the spirit that imbued her. From this story of her family and the uncertainty and hard history of working the plains, she exacts a rugged, solemn beauty. ``Hard work.'' ``Hard work,'' it calls out. She answered the call, and still she wonders if her grandfather would approve of her journey eastward. ``I feel a halfway need to justify, to whisper. `Please don't disapprove, don't think me frivolous.''' He couldn't.

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ They were considered sacred, perhaps holding the secrets to the origin of life, but nobody knows exactly what they are. They are symbols of Egypt, along with the pyramids, but many have found their way to other countries. And wherever they stand today, obelisks are likely to be overshadowed.

Their sleek and sensual beauty captivated Roman emperors scouring their Egyptian domain for exotic trophies. Egypt gave one to France and got a clock in return. England shipped one to London to celebrate a victory over Napoleon. New Yorkers spirited one away to Central Park. But wherever it stands today, pity the poor obelisk. Its magic is shrinking. Once king of the horizon, it's fighting a losing battle in a world of high-rise skyscrapers. Even in Egypt, their home, the few remaining obelisks are overshadowed by almost every other kind of monument _ tombs, columns, pyramids, statues. In Cairo, a tower built in 1962 for a revolving restaurant that doesn't revolve gets more attention than the 3,250-year-old Gezira obelisk at its base. New York City's obelisk, the oldest skyscraper in a city of skyscrapers, is a midget by today's standards. Erected with much fanfare in Central Park on Feb. 22, 1881, it was the last obelisk to leave Egypt. But, ravaged by the city's corrosive fumes, it has suffered more from contact with the modern world than any of the others. In ancient times, obelisks were in such demand as trophies of triumph that Roman emperors hauled away at least 13 to grace public places in Rome, ``City of Obelisks.'' Fifteen hundred years ago, the Emperor Theodosius erected an obelisk in the new Byzantine capital Constantinople, today's Istanbul. Paris, London and New York went shopping for their obelisks only last century. Why obelisks? Nobody even knows what they are. In his definitive work, ``The Obelisks of Egypt,'' the late archaeologist Labib Habachi, Egypt's greatest authority, defined an obelisk as ``a four-sided single piece of stone, standing upright, gradually tapering as it rises and terminating in a small pyramid called a pyramidion.'' They were sacred, he wrote, carved from granite, basalt or quartzite and decorated with hieroglyphs. Habachi's American protege, Egyptologist Cynthia May Sheikholeslami, says obelisks are among the least-understood relics of ancient Egypt. ``They became one of the most characteristic and unique Egyptian symbols,'' Sheikholeslami says. ``But we don't know for certain what they were for. ``In ancient times obelisks _ at least their pyramidions _ may have been covered with gold or electrum (an alloy of gold and silver) reflecting the sun's rays. They would have been dazzling.'' Some people believe their stone shafts contain the origins of life, obelisk magic. Secret societies such as the Knights Templar of the Crusades and the Freemasons linked obelisks with mysticism. America chose the obelisk style as the monument to honor George Washington, a Freemason. Architect Robert Mills designed the Washington Monument with an elaborate and expensive circular colonnade serving as the obelisk's base. Government infighting over money continued for decades. Finally, only the obelisk was left. But building a real obelisk was ``an impossible dream'' as it had been for thousands of years, Sheikholeslami said. The problem was, ``Nobody on earth possessed the skills to build an obelisk. The technology had vanished.'' Ancient workers took months to create an obelisk, pounding the mother rock with diorite balls. The Washington Monument was fashioned of 36,000 marble-faced granite blocks. The 555-foot monument was dedicated on Feb. 21, 1885, an obelisk in shape only. Nobody knows when the first obelisks appeared. Pharaohs of the Fifth Dynasty, ardent sun worshipers whose period began almost 4,500 years ago, are thought to have been the first to decorate their temples with obelisks in pairs. Sheikholeslami said some may have been put up to celebrate pharaohs' anniversaries, others their victories. Small obelisks were erected at tombs. Despite their pagan origin, obelisks were blessed by popes and associated with early Christianity. They decorated French and English houses. A wealthy citizen of Philadelphia erected a large obelisk over his family's burial vault. Smaller versions served as grave markers. But they are best known outside Egypt as centerpieces in public squares and parks. Augustus Caesar, whose 44-year reign began in 30 B.C., began the trend by taking one obelisk for Rome's Circus Maximus, another for the Field of Mars. Cairo didn't get around to erecting an obelisk for show until 1958, a rose granite needle shipped upstream from the ancient Nile Delta city of Tanis to Gezira Island in the heart of the capital. True to form, the island now is famous not for its 47{-foot-tall obelisk but for Cairo Tower, soaring 594 feet just behind. ``When we brought it to Gezira, we had no idea that the Cairo Tower would be built behind it,'' Egyptologist Kamal el-Mallakh, a prime mover behind the project, said shortly before his death in 1987. ``If we had known, we wouldn't have done it. The obelisk is lost.'' Antiquities officials spent $1.2 million in 1984 to place an obelisk at Cairo International Airport. It's lost, too, because most flights land and leave Cairo in the dark. Scores of obelisks once guarded entry into Egypt's sacred temples. Only four still stand in their original slots. Twin obelisks were moved in antiquity from the temple of the sun god Ra, home of the phoenix in ancient Heliopolis, to the Mediterranean port of Alexandria. Misnamed ``Cleopatra's Needles,'' one now stands beside the River Thames in London, the second in Central Park. Other obelisks lie in ruins, toppled by earthquakes or desecrated by conquerors seeking to destroy a mysterious power said to lurk within. The oldest standing obelisk dates from the reign of Pharaoh Sesostris I, 4,000 years ago, at the site of the Ra temple. Now enveloped by apartment houses, it rises from a small park in a bustling, crowded Cairo suburb. The largest, 97 feet high and weighing 323 tons, was built 3,700 years ago by Queen Hatshepsut for the Karnak Temple complex in Luxor, 450 miles south of Cairo. A smaller, more damaged obelisk belonging to her father Tuthmosis I stands nearby. Both are ignored by thousands of tourists daily, who prefer to photograph immense decorated columns and monumental statues erected 150 years later by Pharaoh Ramses II. Egypt's most famous survivor is Ramses' own obelisk at the entrance to nearby Luxor Temple. Its twin stands in Paris' Place de la Concorde, a gift from Egypt. France reciprocated with a small clock, placed in a courtyard adjacent to Mohammed Ali Mosque in Cairo's Citadel. The timepiece doesn't work. And Ramses' once-great obelisk outside Luxor Temple is leaning.

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ The nation's growing appetite for fish has produced thriving catfish farms in the Deep South and trout farms in the Northwest. Now cashing in on the trend are farmers in Appalachia who are growing bass and salmon insted of corn and wheat.

METZ, W.Va. _ Joshua Brickenstein's home looks like the other rugged wooden dwellings in these tree-covered hills of Appalachia, deep in coal country. But inside he has signs, books and even a stain-glassed window that proclaim fish, not coal or cattle, is king here. Brickenstein is a farmer, a fish farmer. His cash crops are striped bass, coho salmon and tilapia. He is one of a growing number of landlocked farmers turning to fish as an alternative to such traditional crops as corn, wheat and hay. The U.S. Department of Agriculture says the market for farm-produced fish is growing. ``The 1990s should be an important decade for growth,'' the U.S.D.A. said recently. ``World population gains and limits on wild catch from the oceans should increase the demand for aquaculture products.'' The government says increased fish consumption in the United States will be met through more imports and more farmers like Brickenstein. David Harvey, a U.S.D.A. agricultural economist in Washington, D.C., specializing in aquaculture, said about one in every 10 fish eaten by Americans now comes from fish farms. Aquaculture thrives in states such as Mississippi, Louisiana and Arkansas, where the Mississippi River and its delta provides excellent conditions for catfish farming. It also is successful in Western states such as Idaho and Montana, where natural conditions make it profitable to raise trout. Joseph A. Marshall, associate biology professor at West Virginia University, said the practice is most popular in China, where one out of every four fish eaten comes from a farm. Asians first began growing their own fish about 4,000 years ago. Marshall said fish farming is growing because ocean fishermen are finding catches harder to come by. Fish are cheaper to feed than livestock, he says. It takes up to 9 pounds of feed for each pound of beef produced, compared with up to 1 pound of feed for each pound of fish produced, he says. In addition, he says many consumers are reluctant to buy fresh-caught fish for fear of pollution contamination. ``You don't know what you're getting when you eat ocean-caught fish,'' he says. ``You have no idea what the mercury levels are in many cases. There are no checks for many fish caught out of the country.'' Local restaurants also prefer a good nearby source of fresh fish, he says. ``When stores label fish `fresh,' that only means it hasn't been frozen,'' Marshall says. ``Big stores have week-old fish and they call it fresh. You can taste the difference.'' Brickenstein's 98-acre farm, about 80 miles southwest of Pittsburgh, includes two 2,000-gallon indoor tanks, which look like above-ground swimming pools and sound like giant aquariums. The tanks are used to keep young fish alive when winter weather sours. Later, maturing fish are transferred to outdoor farm ponds, where they are submerged in 4-by-4-foot cages that ensure their food stays in one place. Brickenstein, 62, took up fish farming six years ago after retiring as a self-employed plastics manufacturer in Tel Aviv, Israel, and Pittsburgh. He also grows raspberries on his farm, which he admits is more a hobby supplemented by money he accumulated as a businessman. He calculates a prudent fish farmer could net up to $30,000 a year with fish, although he has yet to turn a profit in five years as he experiments with different methods of aquaculture. Brickenstein builds his tanks by hand and uses a homemade filtering system to clean water pollution created by the fish. He raises the fish from fingerling stage, or when they're about the size of a tadpole. He stresses the importance of making sure fish get just the right amount of food; too much can leave them just as dead as too little. The fish are kept indoors in a building that's something of a cross between a henhouse, garage and a barn. The ponds, meanwhile, are located about a quarter mile from his house and the road, nestled in the hills and surrounded by rolling green meadows. Scientists say they still aren't sure if fish farming hurts the environment. Maryland officials are offering up to $15,000 in grant money to fish farmers who build waste-water treatment facilities. ``Essentially, if you take fish and feed them, the excess feed turns into a nitrogen product that may eventually turn into ammonia, which can hurt other fish,'' says Brad Powers, Maryland's aquaculture coordinator. ``What we're saying is we don't know whether aquaculture is a problem. What we're trying to do is head it off in advance.'' Still, Marshall believes the prospects for aquaculture are unlimited. ``What you make of it is really what you put into it,'' he says. ``You've seen farmers who raise scraggly cattle and you've seen farmers with sparkling cattle. How you manage will determine how well you do.'' Marshall also says aquaculture can be simple for someone who has an occasional yen for fresh fish. ``You just have to use a little ingenuity,'' he said. ``There's nothing saying that if you have an aquarium in your home you can't eat the fish.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ In creating the National Parks, Congress said they should be preserved as they were found. That meant no new critters could be introduced or tolerated on park land. But here are a bunch of stray horses that some people in Missouri would like to keep and the park service says must go.

The bands of stray horses that have roamed the rugged and beautiful Missouri Ozarks for more than 20 years are heading for the last roundup. Fugitives from farms in the mid-1960s, they have wandered through the wildflower-dotted fields of waist-high grass and drunk from the rivers and springs that flow through the lush forests and valleys. They've become as wild as mustangs. But now the U.S. Park Service contends the two dozen or so animals can't properly fend for themselves and should be captured and sold. The government announced in May that it plans to hire cowboys to round up the horses from the 60,000 acres of wilderness in the Ozark National Scenic Riverways in southern Missouri. ``It will be a sad day when there are no more wild horses around here,'' says Rolland Smotherman of Birch Tree, who trains and shoes horses for a living and often ventures out on horseback with friends to observe the strays. ``Where else can you go and see wild horses, except for out West?'' Smotherman and a number of residents of this sparsely populated region, located about 150 miles southwest of St. Louis, say the horses are thriving in the wild. Several new foals were seen this spring, he says. They believe the animals should be left alone to be enjoyed by the public, including the thousands of canoeists, campers and fishermen who flock to the Current and Jacks Fork rivers each year. ``Those horses wintered fat. I guarantee they are healthier than nine-tenths of the horses most people have around here,'' says Richard Wilkins of Mountain View, who owns a feed store and seven horses. Supporters have gathered about 1,000 signatures on petitions asking the Park Service to reconsider its plan to catch the animals, break them and then allow the public to ``adopt'' them for a fee. ``It's silly for the Park Service to think about removing them. No matter how many times you've seem them, it's always a thrill,'' says Gay Healzer of Eminence, a rodeo champion in barrel competition. The government claims the animals are not truly wild, like the mustangs roaming Western ranges, and therefore are not able to contend with harsh winters, disease, injury and food shortages. In addition, the horses create unwanted trails, trample rare and endangered plants and occasionally raid the hay fields of farmers who lease federal land, says Tom Graham, chief ranger of the Ozark National Scenic Riverways. ``We heard from an individual that three horses were shot recently and left to die,'' Graham says. ``There are occasional reports that humans are abusing them.'' Moreover, the agency is legally bound to remove the horses because non-native animals are not allowed to inhabit Park Service lands, he says. The government will choose this summer from bids submitted by individuals and businesses wishing to capture the horses. The Missouri Humane Society will be asked to monitor the roundup to ensure the animals' safety, Graham says. Smotherman calls the government's reasoning ``a bunch of baloney.'' It's unlikely the horses _ three separate bands of about eight animals each, led by a stallion _ would ever become overpopulated, he says. Deer cause more damage to farm fields than the horses, he adds. ``The Park Service has enough room down there to pasture 400 to 500 head,'' Smotherman says. The horses are mostly mixed breeds, including several appaloosas. Because they are inbred, most of the animals wouldn't bring more than $400 to $500 a head at market, Smotherman says. ``If somebody comes in here and catches them, I'll guarantee that 90 percent of them will be turned into dog food,'' Smotherman says. ``A lot of them are mares 15 to 20 years old. They're not going to be able to break them. Colts they'll be able to break. The older they get, the harder it is to break them.'' Tom Mooney of Eminence remembers seeing horses running wild when he was a child at his family's home on Blair's Creek, before Congress established the Ozark National Scenic Riverways in 1962 to preserve the natural beauty of the area. ``Those horses were there before the Park Service,'' Mooney says. ``They've never hurt anything. I love to see them here and I'd love to see them stay here.'' Jim Smith, whose family has operated wilderness trail rides at Eminence for 35 years, questions the government's contention that the stray horses aren't wild. He said he's seen the horses swim across a river or flee up a steep, rocky hillside at the mere sight of a human. ``You can't catch them,'' he says. ``I've chased 'em a little bit myself. Shoot, they outrun you. You can run a horse to death and you'll never get a rope on one. People have tried for years.'' Despite public sentiment, Graham says the government won't budge from its position that the horses must go. ``We have a legal obligation to do this,'' he says.

DOC.TEXT: Bob Newhart, who ended his sitcom with a surprise and a first-place finish, is now taking his act on the road. Newhart will make more than 30 comedy concert appearances this summer and will be host of a Showtime special, ``Just For Laughs: The Montreal International Comedy Festival.'' ``I've never stopped doing stand-up work,'' Newhart says. ``It's where I started. I wanted to keep my hand in. It's my first love.'' The 90-minute Showtime special will be televised live on Saturday, July 21, during the final weekend of the Montreal festival. ``This is live-live-live television,'' says Newhart, who can't remember the last time he did a live show. ``This will not be like an Improv show where you just introduce new young comics. The festival has comics from all over the world. I'll probably do an opening monologue, one of my old routines and maybe participate in a sketch.'' At least four other comedians will appear on the show, which will also present highlights of the two-week festival. Newhart took time out from working with contractors on a new house to talk about the special and his career. He virtually performs an act while telling about his woes building a new house. He recalls routines from the six ``Button-Down Mind'' comedy albums that launched his career. His first series on NBC in 1961-62 failed in the ratings, but won an Emmy and a Peabody Award. ``I wrote all my own material, and early on was torn between writing for a living or performing,'' he says. ``I offered some material to a well-known comedian and he turned me down. A few weeks later, he did my material on the old Steve Allen show. I figured the only way to protect myself was to perform my own material. ``People kept telling me when I did a comedy album I was giving my act away. I said it was the only way I had to attract attention. I had to keep writing new material all the time. I couldn't afford to hire a writer. People still want to hear those old routines, like Sir Walter Raleigh, the driving instructor, King Kong, the school for bus drivers, the submarine commander. What each one does is lays an attitude over a situation.'' Newhart is polishing his act while a new television series is being developed. He could return to the air as early as the fall of 1991. He ended the eighth year of CBS' ``Newhart'' with a funny and classy farewell that was also one of television's best-kept secrets. ``We had a red herring in the last script,'' he says. ``I get hit with a golf ball, go to heaven and have a scene with God. The crew had a pool going over whether we would get George Burns or George C. Scott to play God. That was so no one would know we had Susie for the last show.'' As virtually everyone knows by now, in the final scene Newhart woke up in bed with Suzanne Pleshette, his wife from ``The Bob Newhart Show'' that ran from 1972-78. Bob Hartley, his character on the earlier show, had dreamed the eight years of ``Newhart.'' The episode was first in the Nielsen ratings that week. ``We kept Susie hidden in a trailer and we sneaked her into the bed in the dark for the last scene,'' he says. ``People applauded as soon as they recognized the set. Nobody knew the ending. I think D-day was more public. I'm keeping a file of letters from people about it. ``It was my wife Ginny's idea. We were at a party the year before and she suggested it to Susie. Susie said, `If I'm in Bangkok I'll fly back for that.''' CBS had wanted to renew the show for another year, but MTM Enterprises said producing the show was too expensive. Newhart, who made both series with MTM, has parted company and will make his new show in partnership with Arthur Price, his manager and former president of MTM. ``We'll come back when we have a good concept,'' he says. ``If you don't have a good concept there's no reason to come back. I'm kind of glad we're off for a while. It's a good time to take a look at television and how it's changing. It's taking more risks now with shows like `Twin Peaks,' putting `The Simpsons' up against `The Cosby Show' and `In Living Color.' ``Sitcoms tend to be traditional, but within that format you can be innovative. I want to come back with a different show. That's where my head is. It must be a sitcom and it must be done with three cameras before an audience. I'm looking for an innovative way to combine all those elements _ with a twist.'' Newhart says he has one other requirement for his new show. ``It must be funny. That comes first.'' In the meantime, Newhart says he is developing several movies for television. He hasn't made a TV or feature movie in the last 10 years. He recalls the making of ``Catch 22'' in 1970 and does a comedy routine of director Mike Nichols directing actor Orson Welles, who was also trying to direct the movie. ``The funniest parts of the movie were behind the camera,'' he says.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.)
DOC.TEXT: American tourists can find two established British dramatists in top form this summer on the London stage. David Hare's ``Racing Demon'' and Alan Ayckbourn's ``Man of the Moment'' are standouts in a season otherwise marked by a lack of star names and an unusual number of short runs. ``Racing Demon'' beat ``Man of the Moment'' in April to win the Olivier Award, London's Tony, for the best new play. The drama also won the best-actor prize for Oliver Ford Davies as the doubt-ridden head rector of a quartet of London clergymen. The play, which has been selling out since February at the Royal National Theater's small Cottesloe auditorium, moves Aug. 2 to the larger Olivier stage to meet public demand. The cast includes Michael Bryant, winner of the Olivier Award for outstanding supporting performance, as a homosexual minister done in by a tabloid newspaper's smear campaign. Adam Kotz plays a zealous young curate and Stella Gonet is the girlfriend who finds she comes in a distant second to God in Kotz's affections. ``Racing Demon'' is Hare's first play since ``The Secret Rapture,'' which had a successful run at the National in 1988 but closed quickly on Broadway last fall. ``Man of the Moment,'' at the Globe Theater, is the 36th play from Alan Ayckbourn, the prolific author-director. Michael Gambon, television's ``Singing Detective,'' plays a suburban bank clerk brought face-to-face after 17 years with the one-time criminal, now a media celebrity, who shot and disfigured his future wife. With his black vision of human venality, Ayckbourn skewers television, tweed jackets, and even Spanish weather, while challenging his audience to think anew about the nature of good and evil. ``Racing Demon'' and ``Man of the Moment'' may prove too British to travel to Broadway, where Ayckbourn feels his work is ``at its most foreign.'' But William Nicholson's ``Shadowlands,'' at the Queen's through July 28, is due in New York in the fall, with Nigel Hawthorne repeating his acclaimed performance as writer C.S. Lewis. The play, concerning Lewis's tragic love affair with American poet Joy Davidman, played by Jane Lapotaire, began as a television drama with Joss Ackland and Claire Bloom. Also on Shaftesbury Avenue, the heart of West End theater, are ``Jeffrey Bernard Is Unwell,'' at the Apollo, with Tom Conti as a dissolute London columnist; and ``Vanilla,'' at the Lyric, American author Jane Stanton Hitchcock's spoof of New York social climbers. The director of ``Vanilla'' was British playwright Harold Pinter. ``Hidden Laughter,'' at the Vaudeville, is Simon Gray's first play since his off-Broadway hit, ``The Common Pursuit.'' Felicity Kendal stars in the work about a family as seen over 13 years at their weekend cottage. Also in the West End is Lanford Wilson's 1987 Broadway play ``Burn This.'' John Malkovich, reprising his volatile New York performance, stars opposite Juliet Stevenson. Fresh from his Tony nomination for staging ``The Merchant of Venice'' on Broadway, Sir Peter Hall has directed a revival of Henrik Ibsen's ``The Wild Duck,'' through August 1 at the Phoenix. David Threlfall takes top acting honors as the scheming ``idealist,'' Gregers Werle. Down the road at Wyndham's, Richard Harris stars as the madman in Luigi Pirandello's 1922 ``Henry IV.'' While first-rate new writing is as rare here as on Broadway, the classics continue to flourish _ a result, in part, of the state-subsidized theaters' ability to take financial risks. The classics provide the mainstay of the Royal Shakespeare Company and the Royal National Theater, Britain's two largest government-subsidized venues. Best of a lackluster RSC season is David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's rarely seen ``Pericles.'' The repertory also includes film and TV actor Charles Dance as Shakespeare's Coriolanus; Harriet Walter in John Webster's corpse-strewn 1614 tragedy ``The Duchess of Malfi''; and the ever-commanding Antony Sher in Peter Flannery's epic new play, ``Singer.'' The National honors Arthur Miller's 75th birthday with Howard Davies' revival of ``The Crucible,'' starring Tom Wilkinson and Zoe Wanamaker, and Michael Blakemore's London premiere of ``After the Fall'' with Josette Simon as Maggie. Eagerly awaited at the National are two Shakespeare productions that will go on to a world tour: ``Richard III'' and ``King Lear.'' Ian McKellen and Brian Cox, respectively, tackle the demanding title roles. Fans of the British musical will find slim pickings among the new entries. Both ``Buddy,'' at the Victoria Palace, and ``Return To the Forbidden Planet,'' at the Cambridge, are more like concerts than shows, and both encourage audiences to leap from their seats and dance in the aisles. A new production of ``The Rocky Horror Show'' at the Piccadilly finds Janet, Brad, Frank 'n' Furter, and the rest of the gang on hand seeking a new generation of cultists. A more sedate response is expected when the revival of ``Show Boat,'' the 1927 Oscar Hammerstein-Jerome Kern musical, opens at the Palladium on Aug. 1. American performers Bruce Hubbard and Karla Burns star, and Sally Burgess, an English actress, plays Julie. The long-running musicals continue, although ``Anything Goes'' must vacate the Prince Edward by late autumn to make way for the new John Caird-Stephen Schwartz musical ``Children of Eden.'' Andrew Lloyd Webber, who has three shows on Broadway, has five in London: ``Cats,'' ``Starlight Express,'' ``The Phantom of the Opera,'' ``Aspects of Love,'' and a special summer engagement of ``Song and Dance.'' The hottest musical ticket, ``Miss Saigon,'' heads for Broadway next March. Theatergoers hoping for tickets here can join the returns line at the Theater Royal, Drury Lane, which begins early every afternoon. Hit musicals and Agatha Christie's ``The Mousetrap'' aren't the only old reliables. At the Aldwych, ``Run For Your Wife,'' a fast Broadway flop last year, continues ``to run and run,'' as the British put it. Close behind it is ``The Woman In Black,'' at the Fortune, a two-character mystery.

DOC.HEAD: Lee Meriwether Greets Studio Visitors as Lily Munster
DOC.NOTE: Eds: retransmitting to CORRECT release date from July 6-8 to July 13-15
DOC.TEXT: Twice a week, clad in a filmy purple gown, wearing deathly white makeup and a heavy black wig, Lee Meriwether stands outside a sound stage and waves at the passing trams of the Universal Studios Tour. This is not a common occurrence on the tour _ few well-known actors deign to make an appearance. But Meriwether, star of the syndicated program ``The Munsters Today,'' enjoys the attention. ``It started when I was standing outside the stage one day when a tram came by. ... The tour guide told them who I was. I waved at them and they got a kick out of it,'' she said. ``One day, a tram load of Japanese tourists came by and nearly tilted over as everyone rushed to the side to take pictures,'' said Meriwether. ``I wish I'd had a camera to take a picture of that.'' Meriwether is now at work on the third season of ``The Munsters Today,'' a revival of the 1960s comedy series. The original was something of a copy itself, coming as it did on the heels of the popular show ``The Addams Family. It was then, and still is, a spoof of domestic family sitcoms. The Munsters live at 1313 Mockingbird Lane in a musty Gothic mansion. Each member of the family looks like a refugee from a horror flick. Herman, the father, is a gravedigger and dead ringer for Frankenstein's monster. Grandpa, who looks like Dracula, tinkers with inventions in the basement. The children are Eddie, a teen-ager who seems to be on his way to turning into a werewolf, and Marilyn, a pretty young woman. In the original show, the rest of the Munsters thought Marilyn was abnormal, and pitied her. Meriwether's Lily is a vampire. ``Lily is basically your everyday mother in a sitcom,'' said Meriwether, who was Miss America in 1955. ``She adores her children. She just looks different.'' The actress revels in the show's monsterisms. When she found a Transylvania cookbook, she bought dozens and gave them to friends. ``The show has been brought up to date,'' Meriwether said. ``The children have changed the most. Eddie no longer dresses in the Little Lord Fauntleroy clothes. He dresses as other teens do today. We no longer worry about Marilyn's looks. ... There was some talk that I would get a job.'' The series features John Schuck as Herman, Howard Morton as Grandpa, Jason Marsden as Eddie and Hillary Van Dyke as Marilyn. The original show, broadcast on CBS from 1964-66, starred Fred Gwynne as Herman, Yvonne DeCarlo as Lily, Al Lewis as Grandpa, Butch Patrick as Eddie and Beverly Owen and later Pat Priest as Marilyn. Meriwether did not give ``The Munsters Today'' much chance for survival. First, she said, ``I thought it would be just a pilot. I never thought it would become a series. Then I didn't think it would go beyond the first year.'' It is now seen on more than 100 stations. Meriwether is a television veteran; she had recurring roles on ``Mission: Impossible,'' ``Dr. Kildare,'' ``The FBI'' and ``12 O'Clock High,'' as well as ``The Time Tunnel,'' ``The New Andy Griffith Show'' and ``Barnaby Jones.'' In the last show, she played Betty Jones, the daughter-in-law of the eponymous character played by Buddy Ebsen. That show originally was an episode of ``Cannon,'' but before they had completed the filming it became a spinoff and a new series. It ran for eight seasons on CBS. After ``Barnaby Jones'' left the air in 1980, she did mostly stage work and spent five years as an aerialist with circuses in Switzerland, Sweden, Japan, Australia and South America. She worked as a substitute with the Flying Gaonas, and her daughter Lesley Aletter often worked with her. ``I wasn't a gymnast,'' said Meriwether. ``I did the simple tricks, but Lesley could do the unusual tricks.'' Lesley currently works as a film editor; another daughter, Kyle Aletter, is an actress. Meriwether is married to Marshall Borden, an actor, writer and director, and they frequently have worked together in regional theater.

In the Groove: Home Videos News and Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``sex, lies and videotape'' (RCA-Columbia Home Video. VHS-Beta, $89.95. Rated R)
``sex, lies and videotape,'' is a very intimate movie, styled with camera angles and sound reminiscent of home video. And it works very well on the small screen at home. In Steven Soderbergh's striking movie, winner at the Cannes Film Festival, the characters have trouble connecting _ to their own feelings as well as to the people around them _ in any meaningful way. Up-and-coming lawyer John Millaney (Peter Gallagher playing a nasty yuppie to the hilt) and his wife, Ann (Andie MacDowell), just go through the motions in their sterile Baton Rouge, La., home, without intimacy and with little affection. John has midday sex with Ann's sister, Cynthia (Laura San Giacomo). But their relationship, while red hot physically, has no depth. Ann and Cynthia don't even try to understand each other. But they go along. As Ann tells her therapist, ``Being happy isn't all that great.'' Into this rambles Graham (James Spader), John's old college pal who has spent nine years away perfecting a sense of control and distance. Ironically, it is Graham, with his videotapes of women discussing their sex lives, who upsets the balance and forces all the characters to pay some attention to their lives. This is a stunning film. The actors are wonderful, and the conversation is gripping.

``Old Gringo'' (RCA-Columbia Home Video. VHS-Beta, $89.95. Rated R)
Gregory Peck, Jane Fonda, a love triangle and the passion of the Mexican Revolution may have been too much _ too much to give ``Old Gringo'' the power that might have saved this melodrama based on Carlos Fuentes' novel. Fonda is Harriet, a repressed self-described spinster who leaves her mother and her life to work as a governess for a wealthy Mexican family. But by the time she arrives, the Mirandas have fled their hacienda. Meanwhile, 71-year-old writer Ambrose Bierce (Peck) also has escaped to Mexico to spend his final days searching for adventure and meaning to his life. Overhearing a conversation in which some revolutionaries detail plans to use Harriet as a ruse to get to the federal soldiers at the hacienda, he, too, ends up at the Miranda estate. And the third side of the triangle is Tomas Arroyo (Jimmy Smits), a general to Pancho Villa. Both men fall for Harriet, of course. But director Luis Puenzo's movie feels like a high-grade TV movie, with a Wild West-style shoot-'em-up that goes on and on, brave men facing death like men, and music that hits you over the head that this is a big, an epic movie. Fonda is fine, Peck is terrific, and there's a lovely scene when Arroyo leads the peasants into the Miranda mansion, where they then hold an exuberant party. There are some subtitles.

Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G _ General audiences. All ages admitted. PG _ Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 _ Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R _ Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Days of Open Hand'' (A&M) _ Suzanne Vega
Suzanne Vega's voice is a remarkable instrument. Though thin and delicate, it broke down barriers and opened a new market for female singers. Vega's popularity with a folk-pop sound paved the way for such women as Sinead O'Connor and Tracy Chapman, who made some of the best music of the late 1980s. While the genre has thrived, Vega has struggled. It's been three years since her last album and surprise hit, ``Luka.'' She complained of writer's block after her first two records used up a lifetime's accumulation of material. So with the release of ``Days of Open Hand,'' the question is: How good are the songs? And the answer is: just fair. The record doesn't have anything approaching the beauty of ``Luka'' (few albums do). And the pace flags toward the end of the 11-song set. Vega's lyrics are as fascinatingly opaque as ever. ``Men in a War'' (about abortion) and ``Fifty-Fifty Chance'' (about suicide) both deliver late-verse twists, and they're the most straightforward songs on the record. Words are at the heart of her art, which Vega acknowledges on ``Big Space'': ``Between the pen and the paperweight, I know there's passion in the language.'' The shimmering quality of Vega's best music is absent here most of the time, possibly because her acoustic guitar is less prominent than previously. That's unfortunate; the combination of Vega's voice and strummed guitar is one of the prettiest in pop. Her search for new sounds brings to the foreground synthesizers (``Big Space'') and strings (the Philip Glass-ish ``Fifty-Fifty Chance''). Vega's slower songs place more emphasis on texture and less on rhythmic punch than in the past. Clearly Vega wants her music to evolve, which is healthy and bound to produce interesting results. But ``Days of Open Hand'' is a dense record not anxious to win the affection of its listeners. That thin, delicate voice is most assertive. Suzanne Vega continues to make music on her own terms. By Steven Wine, Associated Press Writer.

``Reading, Writing and Arithmetic'' (David Geffen Co.) _ The Sundays
Britons Harriet Wheeler and David Gavurin make songs about moments and, like most moments, the songs on ``Reading, Writing and Arithmetic'' fade quickly from memory. She is the Sunday's multiple-octave singer; he is their guitarist. They are lovers, according to the press materials. There isn't much substance to the atmospheric songs on their debut album, songs which Gavurin refers to as ``largely impressionistic.'' A track titled ``You're Not the Only One I Know,'' seems to be about the sudden realization that one is talking to oneself; in ``I Won,'' Wheeler wonders why she can't get to sleep after winning a fight; in ``I Kicked a Boy,'' she remembers several impulsive acts of childhood cruelty and concludes, ``I could've been wrong but I don't think I was.'' The musical arrangements are spare and largely acoustic. Most of the songs rely on only two chords, creating a droning effect against which Wheeler sings in a detached, passionless way. The best of the collection is ``Here's Where the Story Ends,'' in which Wheeler recalls a broken romance while handling ``that little souvenir of a terrible year.'' At one point she sings, ``The only thing I ever really wanted to say was wrong.'' The line is piercing but it's not enough to recommend this record. _ By David Dishneau, Associated Press Writer.

Star Watch: A Spunkier Snow White
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Later this month, movie audiences will be able to see one of the few G-rated films of the violence-prone summer season, featuring a fresh, spunkier Snow White. The animated feature is called ``Happily Ever After'' (the Disney people objected to anything similar to ``Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs''). The fledgling 1st National Film Corp. is releasing the Filmation feature, with the voices of Phyllis Diller, Ed Asner, Dom DeLuise, Sally Kellerman, Carol Channing, Tracey Ullman, Malcolm McDowell and Zsa Zsa Gabor. The role of Snow White is voiced by Irenegh. Sometimes you have to be tough. I think there's a misconception that in order to be in control of your life you have to be tough and almost have a hard shell. I think you miss most of life if your shell gets too hard.'' After her last album, ``Touch,'' Branigan did her first world tour. ``I went all over South America. I love the Latin people. I think they love my music because it's emotional. They're not afraid to show emotion. You see people there striving less to be cool than people here.'' She expected undemonstrative audiences in Asia and was surprised. ``They were just wild, enthusiastic and screaming. It was great.'' In June, she'll start touring on the West coast, reaching New York about the end of August. As most performers discover, there's more to the music business than making music. Branigan loves recording and performing and audiences. ``The rest is a pain in the neck. You have to be on top of everything, always double-checking. You can't just sit back and relax and say, `I'll leave it to business managers,' or whoever. I've been taken for a lot of money because I didn't know what was going on. ``And you have to be sure they don't overbook you. You have to remember the voice is two pieces of flesh, not two steel strings. I find I have to say to my manager, `Stop. I need a vacation.' If you don't forcibly cut it, you keep going and going.'' She started the present album last June, and worked for eight months. ``I worked with three producers. Two had very definite personalities,'' she said. ``Musically, it was a wonderful experience. It really tested my skill; I had to juggle the personalities. I've always had one producer on an album before. Producers can be pretty intense. Richard Perry tries things 1,000 different ways. In the end he nails it, which is all that matters. Peter Wolf works on Synclavier, does everything himself and does it quickly. You couldn't find too more different people in the world if you tried. ``I feel it's the best album I've ever done. But it was a real test for me.'' She also co-produced some of the tracks with Steve Lindsey. Her marriage has survived during her career of making albums and touring, and Branigan takes to the road by herself. ``I've always felt I was a loner,'' she said. ``When I was growing up I was an introvert. I played the role of being gullible and dumb. I didn't want to put myself out on the line. That was safest so I just did it. You fall into what's safe sometimes.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
The Artists: The Rejuvenated Seattle Symphony
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Five years ago, the Seattle Symphony Orchestra was close to collapse from debt that accumulated over nearly a decade of internal discord and artistic doldrums. Today, the city's oldest performing arts group is on a financial crescendo and artistic fortissimo, recording more than any other orchestra in the world, expanding its audience and cutting debt by more than half. Music director Gerard Schwarz and managing director Edward R. Birdwell, who played trumpet and french horn respectively in the acclaimed American Brass Quintet in New York in the early 1970s, are now beating the drums for a new $54 million performance hall and talk of touring the East Coast and possibly Europe or Asia within five years. The orchestra's status is coming up rapidly, said Birdwell, former music program director of the National Endowment for the Arts. ``The next logical step and part of the natural recording process is to get us back East _ New York, Washington, Boston, Philadelphia _ because the reaction on 57th Street (where many music companies have offices in New York) is that if it didn't happen here, it didn't happen,'' he said. Schwarz said the symphony has been invited to play at Carnegie Hall, where Birdwell once served as deputy director. ``They're not ready to pay enough for us yet,'' Schwarz said. ``We will not make any tours that don't make sense economically, which means we don't travel a lot right now.'' The symphony did achieve a milestone this year with a West Coast summer tour that includes three concerts at the Hollywood Bowl in Los Angeles. Schwarz says his long-range goal is recognition as ``one of the greatest orchestras in the world,'' akin to the New York Philharmonic, Berlin Philharmonic or London Symphony. ``That's how far I think we can go,'' he said. ``We play better than them some of the time already, but that's not the point. The point is playing that way all the time.'' Principal percussionist Randolph L. Baunton, a 35-year orchestra veteran and president of the unaffiliated Seattle Symphony and Opera Players Association, the musicians' union, said that in terms of music, Schwarz had helped make the job much more satisfying. And there are the symphony's 12 recordings on the Los Angeles-based Delos label, ranging from Richard Wagner and Robert Schumann to the 20th-century American composers Walter Piston and Howard Hanson. No. 13, released last month, includes compositions by George Gershwin, Samuel Barber and Leonard Bernstein. A compact disc of Hanson's Symphonies No. 1 and 2 and ``Elegy in Memory of Serge Koussevitzky'' reached third on Billboard magazine's classical music sales chart, was named a Record of the Year for 1989 by Stereo Review and was nominated for three Grammy awards, including best classical album. The symphony has another nine recordings ready for release this year and eight are planned for 1991, mostly 20th-century U.S. composers, Schwarz said. In less than a year, the symphony had 28 recording sessions, each about 2{ hours, more than the New York Philharmonic, Boston Symphony, Philadelphia Orchestra, Cleveland Symphony and Chicago Symphony combined, said Rudy Simpson, Delos' marketing and media vice president. The heavy recording schedule has helped the orchestra's musical growth because they can play and then immediately hear it back, Baunton said. Schwarz, a native of Weehawken, N.J., lives about six months of the year in a condominium near the Pike Place Market with his wife, Jody, and their three children. ``We came here because of music, obviously,'' he said. ``Here, we all make a difference _ you, me, anyone. In New York, nobody can make much of a difference.'' Not even James Levine at the Metropolitan Opera or Zubin Mehta at the Philharmonic? ``Take Jimmy Levine. Is he a part of the fabric of life of New York City? No. Am I a part of the fabric of life of Seattle? I think I am,'' Schwarz said. Schwarz spends about five months a year in New York as music director of the New York Chamber Symphony, a post he has held since that orchestra was formed in 1977, and music director of the summer Mostly Mozart Festival. He also is principal conductor of the Waterloo Festival in New Jersey and was music director of the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra from 1978 to 1986. The Seattle Symphony's diminuendo began in the 1970s. Feathers were ruffled in 1976 when Rainer Miedel was hired as music director to replace Milton Katims, a violist and Arturo Toscanini protege who had held the post since 1954. By 1978, things were falling apart, Baunton said. Musicians struck for 10 weeks early the next year. ``It was bitter,'' Baunton said. ``It took us probably six or seven or eight years to get past that.'' A European tour in 1980 brought artistic recognition, but the $500,000 debt left some major contributors so upset they stopped donating. Schwarz became music advisor in 1983 after Miedel died from canger, and began orchestrating the turnaround. ``I went into it thinking that I would stay a couple of years, help them straighten out their financial problems and leave,'' he said. ``I felt that there were the makings of a great orchestra here. What I noticed here was that everyone was able to play, and everybody wanted to play. ``They had a wonderful spirit. What they didn't have was a strong personality,'' he said. ``The second year they started to make great strides artistically, and then I was hooked.'' Facing an accumulated debt of $1.5 million, Schwarz recruited key people to the board in 1987, the same year Birdwell arrived. Self-made multimillionaire and philanthropist Samuel P. Stroum became chairman, and Seattle-First National Bank president Richard Cooley became president. The annual budget, $4.3 million in 1983-84, is now $7.5 million, and the debt has been slashed to $747,000 as of mid-June. The number of annual subscribers has remained fairly stable at about 19,000, but the addition of music by Mozart, baroque, chamber and American composer series has boosted individual ticket sales from 30,495 in 1986-87 to a projected 58,200 for average attendance of about 90 percent this year. Meanwhile, a revolt in the ranks threw out the American Federation of Musicians as bargaining agent in favor of the newly formed independent association, which negotiated its first contract last fall. San Francisco Symphony musicians are considering a similar move, Baunton said. The pact boosts basic pay from $607 a week as of last year to $800 in the last six months of 1993 and medical benefits by 15 percent. Rather than extra pay for recording sessions, as required in the old union contract, recording work is included in the standard pay and those sessions are subject to the same restrictions as concerts, an arrangement being widely studied elsewhere, Schwarz and Baunton said. While Schwarz and Birdwell said they stayed on the sidelines in that dispute, both added that the union change proved instrumental in the recording boom. ``It should be replicated elsewhere,'' Schwarz said. ``We are the future.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, July 13-15
For Release Weekend Editions, July 13-15, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Books and Authors: Misreadings, Misunderstandings and Philip Roth
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Philip Roth held up a copy of ``Deception,'' his newest novel. ``What do people do with this?'' he asked. ``This thing falls into somebody's lap and they do something with it. They take it over. They can hit somebody over the head with it. They can be utterly indifferent to it.'' ``Every reading is a mystery. There's misreadings, misunderstandings.'' The author of ``Goodbye, Columbus,'' ``Portnoy's Complaint'' and ``The Counterlife'' was seated at the Manhattan offices of his publisher, Simon and Schuster, his intense stare softened by glasses and a blue tweed jacket. Roth reflected on his friends in Eastern Europe _ such Czech writers as Vaclav Havel, Milan Kundera and Ivan Klima. They endured censorship, imprisonment or exile for years and suddenly it all changed in the past few months. Now, Havel is the country's president, censorship has been lifted and 100,000 copies were made for the initial printing of Kilma's ``Love and Garbage,'' his first Czech publication in 20 years. ``I thought they were doomed,'' observed Roth, who has been promoting Czech writers and making annual visits to Prague since the early 1970s. ``Like anybody else, I thought Russia was this monolithic thing that's not going to change, that was only going to get to worse.'' Roth once commented that the difference between writing in Czechoslovakia and the United States was that ``There nothing goes and everything matters _ here everything goes and nothing matters.'' But his own history refutes that. He can never forget what happened in 1962, two years after ``Goodbye, Columbus'' won the National Book Award for Fiction, when the author was a panelist for a seminar at Yeshiva University on ``The Crisis of Conscience in Minority Writers of Fiction.'' In his 1988 autobiography, ``The Facts,'' Roth recalled being asked by the moderator if he would write the same stories if he were living in Nazi Germany. The author went on to describe the scene as he attempted to leave: ``I listened to the final verdict against me, as harsh a judgment as I ever hope to hear in this or any other world. I only began to shout, `Clear away, step back _ I'm getting out of here,' after somebody, shaking a fist in my face, began to holler, `You were brought up on anti-Semitic literature!' `Yes,' I hollered back, ``and what is that?'' _ curious really to know what he meant. `English literature!'' he cried. `English literature is anti-Semitic literature!''' For Roth, every reader offers a different interpretation, counter-readings, you might call them, reactions to the writer's reactions. And the author can't resist some counter-writing, selectively leaking information with the skill of a senior White House official. For instance, you can tell ``Deception'' is fiction because there's no table of contents in front, no bibliography in the back and no footnotes on the bottom. But why does Roth, a famous Jewish author married to English actress Claire Bloom, write about a famous Jewish author married to an English actress? And why is this famous Jewish author having an affair and arguing with his wife about writing a book about it? ``You say to me, `Well, did any of this happen?' And I say, `Well, everything happened.' Now ask me the next question,'' Roth said. ``Ask me what I did yesterday, I'll tell you what I did yesterday. I ate a tuna fish sandwich. I watched television. I watched a ballgame. That's what happened.'' ``Deception,'' virtually all dialogue, is a book about talking and listening, Roth says. The raving, cartooniish Jews of ``Goodbye, Columbus'' and ``Portnoy's Complaint,'' the kind of characters that so enraged his audience at Yeshiva University, are gone. The wild humor offered from the psychiatrist's couch in ``Portnoy's Complaint'' has been softened into whispered insights offered in bed and by coffee tables. Still, Roth takes a further step on the wrong side of the tracks. He's written several books about a Jewish author called Nathan Zuckerman, their lives linked so closely that Zuckerman ends up writing about Roth in the final pages of ``The Facts.'' But in ``Deception,'' Roth drops that thin line of protection. Zuckerman is mentioned only in passing; the famous Jewish writer in this novel is called ``Philip.'' ``It's like dropping dye into something,'' Roth said. ``It touches something and it changes the coloration. What happens if I put my name into it? It wasn't going to make life pleasant for me. ``I did think about using Nathan, but mischief led me to put my own name into it. You see what happens. If someone were to pull a pistol, it changes everything. If you drop your own name, then you change the ante on adultery.'' In ``The Facts,'' Roth recalls of his early years, ``I'd no intention as a writer of becoming `controversial,' and, in the beginning, had no idea that my stories would prove repugnant to ordinary Jews.'' He doesn't feel that way anymore. Roth predicts that he'll eventually be brought to court for something he's written, and includes a mock trial in ``Deception,'' in which the author is put on the stand by angry feminists. Again, he speaks of the surprises of books, how they're written and how they're read. The Yeshiva conference was ``the luckiest break I could have had,'' he wrote in ``The Facts.'' ``I was branded.'' For Roth, all books are eventually about talking and listening, conversations between readers and writers, dialogues always in danger of spinning out of control. ``Art has consequences, literature has consequences, sentences have consequences. We know from what's happened in Eastern Europe that it isn't just one little writer in America who discovered that sentences have consequences.'' ``You learn something,'' Roth said of the Yeshiva conference. ``In my case, it interested me. What is this? There's something going on here. What is the exchange between the writer and the reader, between the book and the writer?''
