For Release Weekend Editions, July 13-15, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Nashville Sound: C.W. McCall Tackles the Environment
DOC.TEXT: C.W. McCall, who gave up singing 12 years ago after selling 7 million copies of the catchy ``Convoy,'' is on record again. This time he warns about something more critical than an approaching state trooper: the environment. McCall, who quit performing in order to enjoy the mountain life in Colorado, has just released a collection of old songs and some new ones in the album ``The Real McCall: An American Storyteller.'' The music is hip, occasionally tongue-in-cheek, but also has clear messages about protecting the environment. The 61-year-old McCall, whose real name is Bill Fries, ended his music career in 1978 ``to live in the mountains and go fishing,'' he said recently in a telephone interview from his home in Ouray, Colo. But fans kept asking for his records, so he and ``Convoy'' collaborator Chip Davis got together to update old songs and work up new ones on Davis' independent label, American Gramaphone Records of Omaha, Neb. Cuts on the album include ``There Won't Be No Country Music,'' which is a warning about keeping the environment clean. ``Wilderness'' is about pure air. ``Glenwood Canyon'' questions the practice of clearing land for highways. Of course, ``Convoy'' also is included. A No. 1 pop and country music hit in early 1976, the song was about over-the-highway truck drivers and their encounters with law officers. In the tune, McCall was a beleaguered trucker with the citizens band radio handle of ``rubber duck.'' The song used CB jargon such as ``smokeys'' (state troopers) and ``the back door'' (the rear, where smokeys can sneak up). The tune showcasing McCall's bass voice also inspired a movie by the same name which starred Kris Kristofferson, Ali McGraw and Ernest Borgnine. ``It was timely,'' McCall said in analyzing the popularity of the song. ``Back in 1975-76, that craze was sweeping the country. The jargon was colorful, and the American public liked that, too. ``It was laced with humor, but it had a rebellious feeling about it and people responded to it. ``We took a slice out of this lifestyle and talk and put it into a number. It was just phenomenal. You turned on the radio and in two or three minutes, you heard `Convoy.' We just sat back and watched in amazement.'' McCall said he believes the most popular line in the song was, ``We're gonna roll this trucking convoy across the USA.'' ``It's very American,'' he said. ``The one-liners were memorable,'' McCall said. ``Especially, `11 friends of Jesus in a chartreuse microbus.' That meant it was for all kinds of folks.'' But performing was a new profession for McCall, who had spent his adult life as an advertising executive in Omaha. With ``Convoy,'' he suddenly was a public figure. As a college student years earlier, he said he had dreamed of playing clarinet in a symphony orchestra. But nothing like this. ``People came out to see me but didn't know what I looked like. They just knew my voice. So I had to learn to be a face. This meant a lot of rehearsing and learning the business of stage shows: how C.W. McCall was supposed to act and look. It was an identity crisis.'' After six albums, and another solo hit country record with ``Roses for Mama'' in 1977, McCall had had enough. He'd made enough money to relocate from Omaha to Colorado and take it easy. ``We had planned to do this, but `Convoy' put us 10 years ahead of schedule,'' he recalled. ``It was like winning a lottery.'' Since 1986, he has been mayor of Ouray, which he describes as ``a mining town with mountains all around and a population of 680 when we are all here.'' He doesn't plan to have a convoy touring the nation to plug the new album. ``I might do a few promotional things. But they had better come here to do the talk shows. I have an aversion to going to hot cities. ``I have a great love affair with this little town _ a town lost in time. We're not out to make a killing selling records. This was a project of joy and to satisfy the loyal fans. We did it as a creative outlet.'' McCall, a native of Audubon, Iowa, still has a CB radio in his four-wheel drive vehicle and continues to use the handle ``rubber duck.'' But the CB radio craze is not what it once was. ``We hardly ever use it,'' he said. ``It's gathering dust. We do use it in the mountains on the Jeep trails where you have to stick together.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, July 13-15, and Thereafter

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: A $10 million ABC-TV miniseries, ``Separate But Equal,'' starring Sidney Poitier will be filmed in South Carolina beginning in August. Directed by George Stevens Jr., the four-hour production will center on the landmark Clarendon County school desegregation case of the 1950s. Scenes will be filmed in Columbia, Saluda and Charleston. ``It is a dramatization of one of the really significant events of the 20th century,'' said Stevens, who has numerous television directing credits. Poitier will portray U.S. Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall, who was then the attorney for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People who argued the case for better schools brought by black residents of Summerton, S.C. Among the filming locations will be the Statehouse in Columbia and the ornate courtroom on the second floor of the federal courthouse in Charleston _ the same courtroom where the Summerton case was argued nearly 40 years ago. Filming is expected to take about two months and the production will likely air in April 1991.

``Screamplay,'' an anthology of staged horror, will open October 25 at the Astor Place Theater. Previews begin October 12. ``Screamplay'' will consist of 13 hypnotic pieces (from 90 seconds to 25 minutes in length) that will fuse horror, comedy and blood. The play will be directed by Del Close, who spent two seasons as resident comedy guru for the original ``Saturday Night Live.'' The stories, ranging from the morbid to the grotesque, from dark humor to disturbing satire, have been written by some of the leading writers of modern horror, including Michael Blumlein, Joe R. Lansdale, Pete Atkins and F. Paul Wilson.

Celebrating its 20th anniversary season, the free Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival will take place Aug. 1-28 at Lincoln Center's plazas and Damrosh Park. A gala opening night celebration beginning at 8:00 p.m. will honor the founders of the festival, including actress Geraldine Fitzgerald, followed by a performance by the American Ballroom Theater. Highlights of the 100 events include an evening of ``Jazz Explorations'' by the Dave Brubeck Quartet and TRIO!: Chico Hamilton, Buddy Collette and Cary DeNegris; Ko-thi's African and African-American dancing and drumming; and the North American debut of Concierto Ballet de Puerto Rico.

Germany set off on a bold adventure Sunday by forging a single economy and scrapping internal borders, and leaders in East and West said difficulties lie ahead. East Germans cheered, honked horns and set off fireworks to welcome their new West German money, which put fancy cars and vacations to Brazil within reach. Still, there was sobering talk from officials Sunday, especially in light of the possibility that East German businesses will start filing for bankruptcy as early as Monday.

East Germans tried to unload their Communist currency on enough food to get through a historic weekend, but stores shut down to wait for the fatter profits of the free market. ``Our local department store is completely empty,'' said East Berliner Johanna Suska, who was spending the last of her East German currency Friday on food for the first week of monetary union. ``There is just some bread and milk, sugar and flour,'' she said.

West Germany was the world's biggest exporter for the first three months of 1990, regaining its leadership over the United States, the International Monetary Fund reported Sunday. West Germany increased its exports to $99.8 billion, up more than 18 percent over the first quarter of last year. The U.S. increase of nearly 10 percent brought its total to $97.2 billion.

Senate Republican leader Bob Dole said Sunday he does not expect President Bush to propose increased income tax rates as part of a program of revenue enhancement. Rather, the Kansas lawmaker said he expects Bush to seek to raise oil import fees and taxes on alcohol and tobacco. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., said such an approach clearly would not boost federal income enough to reduce mountainous budget deficits.

President Bush vetoed a bill that would require companies to give as much as three months unpaid leave to workers with new babies or family illnesses. His action Friday set the stage for a new confrontation with Congress, where the bill has strong support from Republicans as well as Democrats. ``The president should be ashamed for vetoing this bill and making a mockery of the term `family values,' '' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo.

Campbell Soup Co. said it would sell its U.S. and Canadian fresh foods and fresh produce businesses, closing or selling a score of plants to focus on more profitable units. The moves announced Friday will result in after-tax charges of $247 million against net income for the fiscal year ending July 29. The company did not say whether it would post an overall profit for the year. The restructuring _ the third in the past year _ affects about 3,000 jobs and includes the sale of businesses with annual revenue of more than $300 million.

President Bush expressed confidence in his son Neil's integrity, but promised not to interfere with regulators who are investigating the son's role in the collapse of a Colorado savings and loan. Neil Bush, 34, served on the board of directors of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Assocition of Denver from 1985 to 1988. The failure of the thrift is expected to cost taxpayers $1 billion. ``I will stay out of anything to do with the investigation, but this is a fine young man,'' the president said Friday.

New home sales in May rose at an annual rate of 0.4 percent, but were still at virtually their lowest level since the economy emerged from its last recession 7{ years ago. The government said Friday that the increase _ from an annual sales rate of 530,000 homes in April to a rate of 532,000 homes in May _ was the first gain in six months.

Five importers of chlorofluorocarbons were accused in lawsuits of violating federal restrictions on the use of chemicals blamed for the depletion of the Earth's ozone layer. One of the five firms, a New York commodities importer, agreed to pay a civil penalty of $101,935 to settle one of the five lawsuits filed by the Justice Department, officials said. The five companies were accused Friday of violating the Clean Air Act and regulations promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency to protect the ozone layer.

The stock market inched ahead Friday, capping the first half of 1990 on a positive note. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 1.98 to 2,880.69. Bond prices rose in reaction to President Bush's remarks supporting a tax increase. The dollar fell in quiet trading. Gold posted its strongest one-day advance in three months on the threat of strikes at mines in South Africa and the Soviet Union. Silver futures advanced; soybeans surged while grain futures were mixed; livestock and meat futures were mostly lower; and energy futures slipped.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuits Against Ashland Cause Bitter Split in Small Town
LaserPhoto CN1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: In the shops and on the streets of West Virginia's westernmost town, the topic these days is more likely to center on oil refinery emissions, lawsuits and harassment than on high school football. More than $3 billion in lawsuits filed by more than 1,000 residents against Ashland Oil Inc. have caused a bitter split in Kenova. Neighbor is pitted against neighbor as the issue of jobs vs. pollution is played out in this town of 5,000. ``It's tearing our town apart,'' said Mayor Frank Heck. ``I look for it to start splitting churches and families apart here.'' The harsh words and hard feelings are found in places usually concerned with the chances of Ceredo-Kenova High School winning another state football championship. The residents who have filed suit contend that emissions from Ashland Oil's giant Catlettsburg, Ky., refinery just across the Big Sandy River have damaged their health and their property. The Kentucky Division for Air Quality, a state organization, found the emissions consisted of flakes of caustic lime dust a claylike substance used in a refinery product. The residents said they were alarmed by dying trees on their property and that they suffered from skin rashes and breathing problems. They also said the emissions have peeled the paint off their cars. A Kanawha County Circuit Court jury agreed in May, awarding $10 million in damages to the first four plaintiffs. Ashland Oil has appealed the verdict, and the company, one of the biggest employers in an economically troubled area, has plenty of supporters. Ashland Oil says it employs more than 2,700 people in West Virginia. Supporters have been flooding newspapers from Ashland to Charleston, 60 miles away, with letters to the editor challenging the verdict. One local insurance company is running a newspaper advertisement expressing its support for Ashland Oil, calling the company ``good neighbors, friends and a fine corporation.'' Some of the plaintiffs, however, say they've been harassed and had their property vandalized since the verdict was announced. Their lawyer, Rod Jackson, says the company is directly or indirectly encouraging the acts. Some people are reluctant to talk about the lawsuits. ``We've got people from both sides who come in here,'' said a pharmacist who would not give his name. ``It would be foolish to make a comment about it, for any business to.'' Resident Jan Moore firmly supports Ashland Oil but says her neighbor is one of the plaintiffs. She said they don't talk much about the legal case. One of the plaintiffs, Floyd Sowards, said his car was vandalized after his daughter-in-law, Cheryl Sowards, was among those in the $10 million verdict. Someone poured an oily substance over his 1985 car two weeks ago, ruining the paint, he said. Sowards said he has installed floodlights around his house and leaves his porch lights on at night following what he called the act of terrorism endorsed by Ashland Oil. ``People in the area have received death threats, had their (car) transmissions ripped out, received harassing phone calls at all hours of the night,'' Sowards said. ``No one _ and I think I speak for everyone _ no one wants to impose any grief on any Ashland Oil employee,'' Sowards said. ``I wish Ashland Oil to prosper. But they're not going to prosper at the expense of me and my family.'' Ashland Oil spokesman Roger Schrum denies endorsing any harassment and blames the plaintiffs' lawyer, Jackson, for intensifying the hard feelings with his allegations the company is behind the harassment. The dispute has prompted city councils in Kenova; Ashland, Ky.; and Ironton, Ohio, to pass resolutions supporting Ashland Oil. But a similar proposal before the Huntington City Council was defeated after members said they shouldn't get involved in a lawsuit. Dan VanderMeer, an official from the federal National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, says the emotional turmoil in Kenova threatens to derail efforts to determine whether the town really does have a serious health problem. Too many people are unwilling to discuss their health with strangers because of the hard feelings, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Decides It Won't Report All the Economic Bad News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report and on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government has come up with a novel approach for handling bad economic news: it has decided just to stop reporting it. The statistic in question is the annual assessment of America's global investment standing, which in the past few years has shown that the United States has gone from being the world's largest creditor nation to being the largest debtor nation. The government says the figure is no longer reliable. Critics say the Bush administration is playing politics by not releasing it. The report for 1989 _ the ``U.S. Net International Investment Position'' _ was scheduled to be released Monday. But last week, the government let it be known that because of concern over the data, the report would not be released this year. The Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis said a scaled-down version of the investment flows would be made public but without the key bottom-line figure. At the end of 1988, the U.S. debt burden stood at $532.5 billion, up 41 percent from the previous year, the BEA reported last year. That figure reflected the imbalance between what Americans owned overseas and what foreigners owned in this country. Based on information contained in other reports, private economists expected that America's net debtor position probably rose by around $110 billion in 1989, pushing America's net debt close to $650 billion. But the BEA release on Monday will not have a figure on America's net debtor position. There will be enough data provided on the component parts that make up the figure so that interested parties will be able to come up with their own unofficial estimate. But the number will not appear in the report. The BEA reasoning: the net debtor number as presently calculated has so many flaws that it is no longer reliable. BEA officials said they hoped to have a revamped report with more accurate figures ready for release in a year. Some critics aren't persuaded. ``The reason they are not publishing the number is that it shows the United States in an unfavorable light,'' said Jeff Faux, head of the Economic Policy Institute, a labor-backed think tank. The United States was the world's largest creditor country as recently as 1983, when it had an investment surplus of $89 billion. That surplus fell to $3.3 billion in 1984 and disappeared altogether in 1985, the year the country became a net debtor for the first time in 71 years. The plunge from largest creditor to largest debtor was caused by the huge merchandise trade deficits the United States piled up during the 1980s as Americans transferred billions of dollars into the hands of foreigners to pay for such things as imported cars and television sets. Foreigners now have reinvested those dollars in the United States in everything from corporate stock and U.S. Treasury bills to Hollywood movie studios and Iowa farmland. That has set off an alarm bells from city hall to Congress over the ``buying of America,'' with dire warnings that the United States was in danger of losing control of its economic destiny to foreigners. Allan Young, head of the BEA, denied that he was under any political pressure from the Bush administration to halt publication of the net debtor figure. ``I am an economic statistician and I decided the number is inappropriate because of the way it is put together,'' Young said. ``The problem has been increasingly recognized by us and by others.'' There have been complaints for a number of years that America's debtor position was being overstated because the report measured many of the assets at the historical purchase price. That undervalued the worth of U.S. assets in foreign countries, many of which were purchased decades ago, in comparison with foreign holdings in the United States, many purchased in the 1980s. The BEA is working to produce a report that will give an up-to-date current value on all assets, both foreign and U.S. holdings. While applauding this effort at statistical consistency, private economists said they believed the final result will still show the United States as a net debtor with the amount of debt growing at an alarming rate. Economist C. Fred Bergsten, who is completing a book on America's net debtor position, said that while the current report does understate the value of America's holdings overseas, it also understates foreign holdings in the United States because of errors in gathering data on foreign ownership. ``Our view is that both the asset and liability numbers are substantially understated and as a result the bottom-line figure is probably about right,'' said Bergsten, who is head of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington-based think tank. David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, said the debate over the exact valuation of the net debtor figure misses the more important point of America's growing dependence on foreign capital to run the U.S. economy. ``It was a scare number, but people ought to be scared,'' he said. ``It is a very serious problem and it is one that we aren't doing anything about.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Disappearing Debtor Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following are figures showing the net international investment position for the United States going back to 1973. A positive number means the United States was a net creditor, with its holdings of overseas assets higher than holdings by foreigners of U.S. assets. A negative number means the United States was a net debtor, with foreign holdings in the United States higher than American holdings overseas. Figures are in billions of dollars.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Little Changed at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Prices were little changed at midday Monday after a lackluster start on London's Stock Exchange. Traders said there was no domestic or overseas news to create any excitement or generate a direction in the market. At about noon in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 1.4 points, or 0.06 percent, at 2,373.2. Volume was 179.1 million shares at midday, compared with 324.1 million shares at the same time Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Joan Lunden Hired to Host TV Program Designed for Doctor's Waiting Rooms
DOC.TEXT: Joan Lunden, co-host of ABC's ``Good Morning America'' show, has been signed to serve a similar role for a new television program that Whittle Communications plans to put in medical waiting rooms this fall. Lunden has signed a three-year contract to host Special Reports Television, a commercially-sponsored TV show that premieres in October. Whittle Communications, based in Knoxville, Tenn., expects the one-hour program will be airing continuously in 20,000 doctor's reception areas by January, reaching an annual audience of nearly 50 million viewers, mainly young mothers. The company is now approaching advertisers about buying commercial time on the programs and is recruiting doctors who will let it put its television set in their waiting rooms and will play the program through the working day. The programs will be distributed on videodiscs and new programs will be made available every two weeks. Lunden was quoted as saying she views the service as ``a vehicle to deliver vital family information and news directly to parents.'' ``That makes it a very worthwhile project,'' she said. She joined ``Good Morning America'' in 1976 as a consumer reporter and became co-host in 1980. Last fall, she became the host of a nationally syndicated daytime talk show called ``Everyday.'' She has hosted videos and a TV special on parenting. She and her husband have three daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Ratners Launches Friendly Offer For U.S.-based Kay
DOC.TEXT: Ratners Group PLC, Britain's largest jewelry chain, today launched a friendly, $328.1 million, takeover bid for Kay Jewelers Inc., a U.S. company that operates nearly 500 stores in the United States. The deal will make Ratners the second largest jewelry retailer in the United States after Zales, which is owned by Canada's Peoples Jewellers Ltd. The addition of Kay's 494 stores will increase the number of Ratners' U.S. outlets to 967, Ratners said. The British company said its offer has been accepted by Kay's board members who control 34.6 percent of the American company's shares. Ratners said it was offering stock worth $17 a share for the 12.4 million shares outstanding of Kay's stock. The bid values the whole of the company, including the cost of assuming Kay's debt, at $328.1 million, Ratners said. Specifically, Ratners said it was offering one new Ratners U.S. convertible preference share for every Kay share. The Ratners preference shares will be convertible into three of its ordinary shares in the form of American Depository Receipts. Ratners effectively sealed the agreement against disruption by a counterbidder by gaining an option to purchase the 34.6 percent stake outright at $17 a share should another bid arise. Ratners said it also was given a conditional option to buy 2.49 million new Kay shares at $17 a share in the event of a higher counterbid. Ratners said it would pay for the takeover partly by selling $228 million of new Ratners shares to existing Ratners shareholders. The Kay's stores, which are located mostly on the East and West Coasts and in Texas, will fit in well with Sterling Inc., a U.S. jewelry retailer which Ratners acquired in 1987 for $202.8 million. Sterling's business is concentrated in the Midwest. Ratners said it plans to sell Kay's Marcus chain and its Black, Starr and Frost chain, which together have 48 outlets with sales last year of $70.2 million. Kay's, one of the largest jewelery chains in the United States, has seen its earnings suffer recently because of lower consumer spending on luxury goods and tighter U.S. credit policies. For all of 1989, Kay managed only a $196,000 profit on sales of $420.6 million. Regardless of the poor recent record, Ratners said the acquisition will fit in well with its plans to expand its U.S. market share. Ratners wants to operate 1,500 U.S. stores representing 10 percent of what it described as a traditionally fragmented U.S. market. The Kay's purchase, in doubling the number of Ratners' U.S. outlets, would increase its market share to 5.7 percent from 2.8 percent, the company said. Ratners, with 1,200 British stores, commands 50 percent of the British market. Ratners' after-tax profit rose to the equivalent of $139 million on sales of $1.6 billion in the year ended Feb. 3.

DOC.HEAD: Forstmann Little to Acquire General Instrument
DOC.TEXT: The leveraged buyout firm Forstmann Little & Co. today said it has agreed to acquire the diversified electronics company General Instrument Corp. in a deal valued at $1.6 billion. The company will pay $44.50 in cash for each of General Instrument's common shares outstanding, plus assume or refinance existing debt. In exchange, General Instrument agreed to amend its shareholders' rights plan, or ``poison pill,'' and to pay Forstmann Little $33 million should its board of directors accept a higher takeover bid. The deal is subject to, among other things, Forstmann Little acquiring, through its newly formed subsidiary FLGI Acquisition, a majority of the shares. It is set to expire on Aug. 13. The company said it already has received financing for the deal. General Instrument Chairman Frank G. Hickey said the offer ``provides an excellent value for our shareholders.'' Forstmann Little specializes in corporate buyouts. Earlier this year it was involved in the $825 million acquistion of Chrysler Corp.'s Gulfstream Aerospace Corp.

DOC.HEAD: National Rig Count Remains Almost Steady with Loss of 1 Rig for Week
DOC.TEXT: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States remains steady at 1,020 with a loss of only one rig this week, Baker Hughes Inc. announced Monday. Last week, the rig count jumped by 22 rigs to 1,021. A year ago this week, the count was 817. Baker Hughes' rig count reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. The Houston-based oil toolmaker company has kept track of the rig count _ the widely watched index of drilling activity _ since 1940. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Among major oil-producing states, California showed the biggest gain for the week, adding 11 rigs. Others showing gains included Kansas, which gained three and Pennsylvania, with two. Texas, which last week added 10 rigs, this week led major producing states in losses with 11 fewer rigs operating. Other losses were posted in Louisiana, which last week gained 16 rigs and this week lost five; Colorado and North Dakota, each down by three; and Michigan and Wyoming, which each lost one rig. Rig counts for New Mexico, Ohio and Oklahoma remained unchanged for the week.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturing Sector Grows For Third Month, Purchasing Group Says
DOC.TEXT: The manufacturing sector of the nation's economy grew for the third consecutive month in June, according to a survey of corporate purchasing executives released today. The Purchasing Managers Index, released monthly by the National Association of Purchasing Management, rose slightly to 51.1 percent from 50.7 in May, the group said from its Tempe, Ariz., headquarters. A reading above 50 indicates the economy generally is expanding; below 50, that it generally is contracting. June marked the third straight month the index was above 50. The 11 previous months the index declined. The Purchasing Managers Index, a composite figure of survey results on order levels, prices, employment and other areas, averaged 49.1 percent for the first half of the year. If the June index reading is repeated for the rest of the year, it would be consistent with real gross national product growth of about 1.9 percent, according to past experience, the group said. ``The manufacturing economy ended the second quarter with a moderate, but solid, increase in growth,'' said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the group's business survey committee. The group's production index rose for the fifth consecutive month, although at a lower rate than in May. Its new orders index also rose for the fifth straight month, at virtually the same rate as in May. The new export orders figure increased at a stronger rate than in May, while imports fell for the second consecutive month. Inventories declined for the 19th consecutive month, although the rate of decline was at the lowest since December 1989. Deliveries from suppliers were slower in June for the first time in 14 months, reflecting the increased demand and lower inventory levels, the group said. Prices rose in June for the second time in the last three months, and the group's price index stood at its highest level since May 1989. The purchasing managers group represents chief purchasing executives at more than 300 industrial companies.

DOC.HEAD: Asarco's Ray Unit Struck
DOC.TEXT: Asarco Inc.'s Ray unit was struck Sunday by unions representing about 700 copper workers. It was the first copper strike in Arizona since the turbulent Phelps Dodge strike seven years ago. The old contract expired at midnight Saturday and contract talks broke off here around 4 a.m. Sunday, union and company officials said. The union coalition had rejected the company's final offer. Robert Guadiana, the United Steelworkers official who heads the talks for the unions, said the 24-member union committee had ``significant concerns'' over Asarco proposals he said would damage pension, insurance and disability benefits. Guadiana also cited ``forced overtime'' rules as another problem. ``Obviously no one wanted a strike,'' he said. ``But it makes no sense for a company, with the profits they have and the expansion program that is under way, to try to force that kind of agreement down people's throats.'' Bruce Malone, general manager at Ray and the company's chief negotiators, said he was ``quite surprised'' that the union committee rejected the final offer, which would have provided an average $2.50-an-hour wage increase over three years. He said the company's offer proposed ``changes in the benefit plan _ all improvements'' that are ``very similar to what has been accepted at other properties.'' Malone said the company hoped to maintain about 60 percent of its normal production capacity using 165 salaried employees at its mine, concentrator and other facilities at Ray. Other Asarco properties, including the Hayden smelter and the Mission Complex south of Tucson, are not affected by the strike. The strike is the first in Arizona since 1983, when copper workers at Phelps Dodge Corp.'s Morenci operation went on strike. That violence-plagued strike lasted until 1986, when the union was decertified.

DOC.HEAD: Electronics Giant Forecasts Major Losses, Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: The Philips electronics multinational, Europe's largest consumer electronics company, Monday predicted more than $1 billion in losses this year and said it would have to cut its workforce by 10,000 jobs. New president of Philips Industries NV Jan D. Timmer announced the projected losses at a stockholders meeting, and said they would result from a major restructuring effort. The expected losses for the year exceed even Timmer's own previous pessimistic forecast June 14 that net income for the whole of 1990 would be very low. Timmer said Monday that the June 14 forecast had been made in the expectation that there would be normal restructuring costs of $212 million rather than the $1.4 billion that now has been slated. The Philips president said 1990 sales would total more than $29.7 billion. Although the restructuring will be aimed mostly at Philips money-losing information systems and components division, Timmer indicated that the group didn't intend to abandon these activities. Although Timmer conceded that the losses he expects Philips to absorb in 1990 are high, he said ``they are not such a high amount that panic is necessary.'' Howevever, he warned against any notion that the new Philips leadership can ``wave a magic wand'' to solve the electronics giant's problems. Timmer said that the company would begin the process of laying people off immediately. Most of the job losses will be in Europe, he said. Philips currently employs about 293,000 people worldwide. The restructuring effort is the latest of a series of drives over the past three years to improve Philips' performance. Under former president Cornelis van der Klugt, Philips spent $709 million over the past three years to improve its competitiveness. During that previous restructuring drive, Philips slashed its workforce by about 20,000 employees and closed about 75 factories worldwide, leaving it with 345 factories. The company announced Van der Klugt's resignation May 14 in the wake of unexpectedly poor first quarter results.

DOC.HEAD: Heat Forecasts Drive Up Corn, Soybean Futures
DOC.TEXT: Corn and soybean futures prices climbed rapidly early in today's session on the Chicago Board of Trade, supported by forecasts for extremely hot weather in the Midwest. Temperatures in the 90s or higher were expected today in the western and southern edges of the Corn Belt. Such hot weather wouldn't do much harm in the central Midwest, where conditions have been wetter than normal. But heat could stress the crops in southern Missouri and Arkansas, where the soil is drier, said John Frazier, director of agricultural commodities trading for Gerald Inc. The heat is not expected to last more than a day or two, which would limit its effect on crop yields, but the market is very sensitive to any signs of adverse crop weather. ``As long as somebody says it's there, they'll buy on it,'' he said. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent lower to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.27{ a bushel; corn was 1\ cents to 4{ cents higher with July at $2.99{ a bushel; oats were 2\ cents to 3 cents higher with September at $1.48 a bushel; soybeans were 13 cents to 15{ cents higher with July at $6.36{ a bushel. Hot weather forecasts also drove up hog and pork-belly futures in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Most cattle futures fell slightly. Live cattle were .40 cent lower to .05 cent higher with August at 72.67 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent lower to .45 cent higher with August at 83.72 cents a pound; live hogs were .70 cent to 1.27 cents higher with July at 61.37 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.93 cents to the permitted daily limit of 2 cents higher with July at 60.20 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Expects to Reach Price Pact Decision Shortly
DOC.TEXT: Brazil told other coffee-trading nations Monday that it hopes to decide within the next few weeks whether to back proposed negotiations on a new price-stabilization agreement. Lindenberg Sette, Brazil's chief delegate to an International Coffee Organization executive board meeting, proposed a special meeting of major exporters and importers in London on July 23, at which time Brazil would reveal its position. The board will decide Tuesday whether to accept Brazil's proposal, a coffee organization spokesman said. Sette told the board that the new Brazilian government's basic philosophy favored free trade, with regulation only for ``exceptional purposes.'' A new regulatory pact for coffee is strongly backed by Colombia, the world's second biggest producer, and by the United States, the largest consumer. Most African producers and the European Community have also backed a new pact. Efforts to open negotiations on an accord with the powers to regulate the market have so far been blocked by the uncertainty about the position of Brazil, the leading exporter. The present coffee agreement has no powers to regulate prices, because its export quota system, aimed at balancing supply with demand, was supended indefinitely last July. The suspension of the system triggered one of the sharpest falls ever in the price of coffee, to a 14-year low of 59 U.S. cents per pound last October. The coffee organization's latest indicator of the world market price was 66 cents, compared with the high for the year of 80 cents reached in February.

DOC.HEAD: German Mark Higher; Pound Soars; Gold Moves Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with European closing prices, quotes, plus midday New York rates.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against other major currencies in Europe today, pushed downward by active selling earlier in Asia. The German mark rose moderately in calm dealings on the first day of trading after German monetary union. The West German mark became East Germany's currency on Sunday. The pound surged nearly two cents on further speculation that Britain soon would link its currency with Europe's exchange rate mechanism. The mechanism limits exchange rate movements of nine of the Common Market's 12 currencies. Gold prices rose. Comments by U.S. Undersecretary of State for Economic and Agricultural Affairs Richard T. McCormack helped pare the dollar further against the Japanese yen, dealers said. McCormack is a member of the U.S. delegation to the upcoming Group of Seven summit in Houston. Speaking over the U.S. government's World Net system from Washington, he said the G-7 is concerned about the yen's depreciation in the past year, particularly since it will help boost Japanese exports. His comments in early afternoon dealings sent dollar buyers to the sidelines, European dealers said. Some dealers said the dollar's declines were slowed by reluctance among investors to take overnight positions, particularly since Singapore will be closed for a holiday Tuesday and U.S. markets are to be closed for the Independence Day holiday Wednesday. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.7635, up from $1.7450 late Friday. A pound fetched $1.76725 in early afternoon New York trading. DOC.HEAD: Sears Tower Mortgage Deal Closes
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck and Co. on Monday announced the closing of a previously announced mortgage on Sears Tower, the world's tallest building. The $850 million deal with AEW Partners, a limited partnership managed by Aldrich, Eastman & Waltch Inc. of Boston, includes options to buy the downtown Chicago landmark and related properties at the end of the 15-year financing period. Sears will receive net proceeds of $815 million after expenses and adjustments, the company said in a news release. Sears announced in November it had decided to refinance its 15-year-old headquarters building rather than sell the 110-story tower. The deal is part of a corporate restructuring to help combat sliding earnings in the company's retail division.

DOC.HEAD: US Sprint, Soviet Agency Agree on Data Services
DOC.TEXT: Sprint International has reached agreement with the Soviet government on a joint venture for a switching center in Moscow to provide high-speed data communications. The center, a joint effort of the US Sprint subsidiary and Central Telegraph of the Soviet Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, will connect with the SprintNet international data network and provide Soviet computer users with access to data bases throughout the world. The new venture, called Sprint Networks USSR, will provide Sprintmail electronic messaging service and link the domestic and international telex networks operated by Central Telegraph. ``The joint venture is a landmark in the development of the USSR's data communications capability, joining our telex systems with new technologies that will serve our country's needs, and those of foreign interests based here, well into the 21st century,'' Viacheslav Rubstov, general manager of Central Telegraph, said in a statement released by US Sprint. Sprint Networks USSR operations are expected to begin late this year following registration by the Soviet government and receipt of U.S. export licenses.

DOC.HEAD: New Store to Open in Rhode Island
DOC.TEXT: Retailer R.H. Macy & Co. on Monday announced plans to open a new department store in Providence, R.I., in the autumn of 1993. The new Macy's will be one of the main anchors of a shopping complex under development called Providence Place in the city's Capital Center District. The store is expected to employ about 500 people. It is one of nine new stores the retailer plans to open around the country over the next four years, the company said in a news release. Locations of the other stores weren't disclosed. ``We see a terrific opportunity in Rhode Island,'' said Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive officer of Macy's. ``It is a growing market _ and a new one for Macy's. We look forward to providing a unique and exciting shopping experience to the region.'' Macy's operates 149 department stores in the United States under the names Macy's, Bullock's and I. Magnin.

DOC.HEAD: Sells Control of U.S. Newspapers after Missing Junk-Bond Payment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs with Ingersoll comments; picks up 13th graf pvs, `Those bonds ...'
DOC.TEXT: Publisher Ralph Ingersoll II said today he agreed to swap the controlling stake in his U.S. newspaper chains for European publishing interests after failing to make an interest payment on high-risk junk bonds. Ingersoll is the latest entrepreneur to run into debt difficulties after building an empire in the 1980s with junk-bond financing. The announcement followed months of attempts by Ingersoll to buy back his companies' junk bonds at steep discounts to alleviate a heavy debt burden. Ingersoll's announcement also comes a little more than two months after he folded the St. Louis Sun, a new tabloid that Ingersoll claimed would revolutionize the slumping newspaper market by using new technology and marketing strategies. Under the agreement, Ingersoll is relinquishing his stake in three companies that publish dozens of daily and weekly newspapers to the New York investment firm E.M. Warburg, Pincus & Co. The two had been joint owners, although Ingersoll exercised voting control. Warburg, Pincus gains full control of Ingersoll Newspapers Inc., which publishes nine dailies and 53 weeklies; New Haven Acquisition Co., publisher of the New Haven Register; and Community Newspapers Inc., which has newspapers mostly in Ohio and on New York's Long Island. In return, Ingersoll will gain full control of a group of British and Irish newspapers that he had owned jointly with Warburg, Pincus. The newspapers have combined circulations exceeding 1 million and annual revenues of $178 million. In a telephone interview, Ingersoll said the deal matched his desire to get more involved in European publishing and the desire of Warburg, Pincus to expand its role in the U.S. market. The missed bond payment ``has zero to do with the trade we did today,'' Ingersoll said. The U.S. companies are profitable but no one could forsee the collapse of the junk bond market that torpedoed the bond issue, he said. Nevertheless, when asked if he would have preferred to retain his U.S. holdings while expanding into Europe, he responded, ``Would I like to have them both. Sure.'' Ingersoll's companies went on an expansion spree with proceeds from junk bonds issued by now-collapsed Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street investment bank that once dominated the market in junk-bond securities. But the collapse of the junk market in recent months sent the price of Community Newspapers' $125 million of 13 percent bonds plunging to as low as 40 cents on the dollar. That put Ingersoll in a bind because Community Newspapers was required to reset terms on the bonds to make them trade at $1.01. ``No one ever imagined that the reset would become unworkable,'' he said. Community Newspapers said it would not make the interest payment due July 1 on the 13 percent bonds. In addition, the company said it would not reset the interest rate on those bonds on July 7, as it was supposed to do. Those bonds were quoted at about 50 cents on the dollar after the announcement, down from about 59 cents previously. In a release announcing the agreement, Lionel Pincus, chairman and chief executive of Warburg, Pincus, said he hoped Community Newspapers would be able to work out its financial problems with bondholders. Those bondholders rejected Ingersoll's proposal earlier this year to buy back 80 percent of the bonds at 55 cents on the dollar. The affiliates of Warburg, Pincus that will own Ingersoll Newspapers and New Haven Acquisition have more than $3 billion in equity capital, Pincus said. ``We are pleased to have agreed upon this transaction with Mr. Ingersoll, as it will enable our affiliates to use their resources to improve and expand the operations of INI and New Haven,'' Pincus said.

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates Fall Again

DOC.HEAD: Coca-Cola Names New USA President, Makes Other Management Changes
DOC.TEXT: The Coca-Cola Co. announced key management changes Monday, including the appointment of M. Douglas Ivester as president of the soft drink maker's U.S. operations. The moves were seen by some industry watchers as a glimpse of who might be running Coke a few years down the road. ``We now know with some degree of definitiveness who are the key players for the future president and even chairman of the Coca-Cola Co.,'' said Jesse Meyers, publisher of the industry newsletter Beverage Digest. Ivester has been with Coke since 1979 and president of the company's European Community Group since June 1989. He succeeds Ira C. Herbert as president of Coca-Cola USA. Herbert will continue as executive vice president of Coke and will have corporate responsibility for Coca-Cola USA as well as the company's Canadian subsidiary. The company also announced that John Hunter, currently a senior vice president at Coke and president of the company's Pacific Group, will be given additional responsibilities as deputy to John W. Georgas, who heads the International Business Sector. Ralph H. Cooper, president of the Northwest European Division, will succeed Ivester as president of the European Community Group. The changes are effective Aug. 1. Meanwhile, Coke said Monday that Donald R. Keough, president and chief operating officer, will remain in his job until fall 1993, two years beyond the company's customary retirement age of 65. This decision had been announced to Coca-Cola management about two months ago and ``was widely known within the company,'' said spokesman Randy Donaldson. The management changes are part of the company's natural evolution, Donaldson said. Meyers said the 43-year-old Ivester was instrumental in improving Coke's European distribution system. The European Community Group, which accounts for nearly one-fourth of Coke's international gallon sales, recorded 11 percent gallon-sales growth last year. ``Any objective analysis will show you this man is on a heady track at the Coca-Cola Co.,'' Meyers said from his office in Greenwich, Conn. ``His financial background is excellent and now his operational skills are excellent.'' Hunter, 52, also has had success at Coca-Cola, Meyers said, running various division since joining the company in 1967. Meyers said he ``is clearly marked as one of the major international executives who in a relatively short time will be a key corporate executive.'' Hugh S. Zurkuhlen, an analyst who follows Coca-Cola for Salomon Bros. in New York, agreed that the three men involved in Monday's announcement are candidates for the future leadership of the company. ``I think that's the issue with Coke over the next five years _ who will rise to the upper echelon. Some of the very senior guys at Coke are getting older,'' Zurkuhlen said. Coke Chairman Roberto C. Goizueta is 58, while Keough is 63 and Herbert is 62. Meyers said the confirmation that Keough would be staying on was welcome news. ``At the moment, the Coca-Cola Co. without Donald Keough as chief operating officer is unimaginable,'' Meyers said. ``If you open up your window, you can hear 155 Coca-Cola bottlers breathing a collective sigh of relief. ... They idolize him.''

DOC.HEAD: Lenders Extend Credit Agreement with Control Data
DOC.TEXT: A group of banks led by Bank of America has extended its credit agreement with Control Data Corp. and offered expanded borrowing privileges to the computer company, officials announced Monday. The agreement, first signed in July 1988, would have expired June 30. The initial length of extension is 11 months, but it may be extended for up to two more years if Control Data achieves specified levels of operating earnings through March 1992, Control Data said. Control Data, which lost $1.5 billion in the past five years, continues to be subject to a variety of covenants in the amended agreement, including net worth and operating earnings tests. Letters of credit under the agreement total approximately $110 million. Availability under the amended agreement has been increased to $125 million, with the potential for further increases to $145 million if the company achieves certain levels of operating earnings at the end of the third and fourth quarters 293 deaths in 1988, she said. ``Since so many young people are killed and injured each year riding ATVs, it is essential that dealers follow the age recommendations. Our goal is the reduction of deaths and injuries associated with ATVs,'' said Jacqueline Jones-Smith, chairwoman of the CPSC. CPSC is continuing negotiations with two other major distributors of ATVs, Polaris Industries, L.P. and American Suzuki Motor Corp., in an effort to obtain a similar agreement, Birenbaum said.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturing Grows For Third Month, Purchasing Group Says
DOC.TEXT: The nation's manufacturing economy grew for the third consecutive month in June, according to an influential survey of corporate purchasing executives. ``It indicates that the manufacturing sector is not so weak as to suggest that a recession is drawing near,'' said John Lonski, chief economist for Moody's Investors Service Inc. Other economists were less optimistic, pointing out that manufacturing accounts for only about 20 percent of the economy. David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago, said the key to avoiding a recession is consumer spending, which comprises about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. If consumers continue to be cautious or cut their spending further, it could spell trouble, he said. The manufacturing survey is taken monthly by the National Association of Purchasing Management, which includes chief purchasing executives at more than 300 industrial companies. The group said its Purchasing Managers Index rose slightly in June to 51.1 percent from 50.7 in May. A reading above 50 indicates the economy generally is expanding; below 50, that it generally is contracting. June marked the third straight month the index was above 50. The 11 previous months the index declined. The index, a composite of survey results on order levels, prices, inventory and other areas, averaged 49.1 percent for the first half of the year. If the June index reading is repeated for the rest of the year, it would be consistent with real gross national product growth of about 1.9 percent, based on past experience, the group said from its Tempe, Ariz., headquarters. ``The manufacturing economy ended the second quarter with a moderate, but solid, increase in growth,'' said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of te group's business survey committee. Hale said the strength in the index is less significant than it appears because much, if not all, of it stemmed from rising car production. Automakers, which scaled back production in April, stepped up manufacturing in May and June, he said. Other economists disagreed. Ken Goldstein of the Conference Board, a New York-based business group, said manufacturing overall has been picking up strength. ``If anything, the purchasing managers report might be understating the momentum in the industrial sector of the economy,'' he said. Lonski said the commercial aircraft industry is the only other manufacturing sector aside from autos that was strong. But there were pockets of strength in other areas, such as computers and pharmaceuticals, he said. The June survey also included questions on credit conditions. Of the 18 percent of responding members whose companies had sought credit from a financial institution since April, few said they experienced tougher lending restrictions or felt the need to issue commercial paper as an alternative to bank loans. But a number of members said their smaller suppliers or customers had trouble obtaining credit. Among the components of the Purchasing Managers Index, production by the member companies rose for the fifth consecutive month, although at a lower rate than in May. New orders placed with the manufacturers also rose for the fifth straight month, at virtually the same rate as in May. New export orders increased at a stronger rate than in May. Imports by the manufacturers fell for the second consecutive month. Deliveries from suppliers were slower in June for the first time in 14 months, reflecting increased demand for raw materials and lower inventory levels maintained by these suppliers, the group said. Prices of raw materials bought by the manufacturers rose in June for the second time in the last three months and the group's price index stood at its highest level since May 1989. The level of inventories maintained by the manufacturers declined for the 19th consecutive month, although the rate of decline was the lowest since December 1989. Lonski said the inventory decline could be good news if the nation enters a recession. With little backlog, manufacturing would have to pick up quickly once the economy resumes strength. By contrast, in the 1982 recession, manufacturers _ particularly carmakers _ were caught with huge inventories that had to be sold before they could resume production.

DOC.HEAD: Railroad Lays Off 300; Further Cuts Planned
DOC.TEXT: Santa Fe Pacific Corp. handed layoff notices to 300 Santa Fe Railway Co. employees Mfied. Gehrt said the company expects to cut employment by another 1,200 jobs to 15,000 by the end of 1992. ``As time goes on, through attrition and other means, we expect to get down to that level,'' he said. The reduction is part of a corporate-wide downsizing that also includes spinning off two major subsidiaries, Santa Fe Energy Resources and Santa Fe Realty Co., to shareholders. Santa Fe Pacific announced those moves in April. ``We've told all our employees and told the world we're going to be a smaller company,'' Gehrt said.

DOC.HEAD: British Chain Makes Friendly Offer for U.S. Jewelry Retailer
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Britain's largest jewelry chain, Ratners Group PLC, on Monday announced a friendly $328 million offer for Kay Jewelers Inc. that would make it the second-largest jewelry retailer in the United States. Kay, a 494-store retail network based in Alexandria, Va., said its board of directors endorsed the offer and would recommend that shareholders accept it. The board controls about a third of Kay's shares. Ratners said it eventually wants to operate 1,500 U.S. stores, representing 10 percent of the fragmented American market. The addition of Kay's stores will increase the current number of Ratners' U.S. outlets to 967, Ratners said. The largest jewelry retailer in the United States today is Zales, with 1,938 stores owned by Canada's Peoples Jewellers Ltd. Kay's earnings have suffered recently because of lower consumer spending on luxury goods. Last year, Kay managed only a $196,000 after-tax profit on sales of $421 million. But Ratners said the acquisition would fit in well with plans to expand its U.S. market share. It said the Kay stores, mostly on the East and West Coasts and in Texas, would fit in well with Sterling Inc., a U.S. jewelry retailer that Ratners acquired in 1987 for $203 million. Sterling's business is concentrated in the Midwest. Ratners said it was offering stock worth $17 a share for Kay's 12.4 million shares. The bid places the company's value at $328 million, including the cost of assuming Kay debt, Ratners said. The British company effectively protected its offer against a rival bid by obtaining an option to purchase the Kay board of directors' 34.6 percent stake outright at the same price of $17 a share should another offer materialize. Last year, Ratners hesitated in an attempt to buy Gordon's, a 500-store U.S. chain, and Zales, its principal U.S. rival, succeeded with a lower bid. Ratners said it would pay for the takeover partly by selling $228 million worth of new Ratners shares to existing Ratners shareholders. After the takeover, Ratners said, it would sell Kay's Marcus chain and its Black, Starr and Frost stores, which together have 48 outlets with sales of $70 million last year. The Kay purchase, in doubling the number of Ratners' U.S. outlets, would increase Ratners' market share to 5.7 percent from 2.8 percent, the company said. In Britain, Ratners operates 1,200 British stores, commanding 25 percent of the market. It is aiming for 50 percent. Ratners' after-tax profit increased 46 percent to $139 million, while sales rose 41 percent to $1.6 billion in the year ended Feb. 3. Profits have soared, although other British retailers have been hurt by slower sales growth, partly because of Britain's 15 percent interest rates. The company's chairman and managing director, Gerald Ratner, is the ``most successful survivor of the entrepreneurial retailing boom in the 1980s,'' the Financial Times said. Ratner, 40, joined his family's company straight from high school.

DOC.HEAD: Former Rite Aid Owner Leaving Wall Street
DOC.TEXT: Former New York gubernatorial candidate Lewis E. Lehrman is taking his red suspenders from Wall Street to Washington. Lehrman, a wealthy Republican and former owner of the Rite Aid drug store chain, is leaving as managing director of Morgan Stanley and Co., one of New York's largest investment banking firms. He is joining Bell Mueller Cannon Inc., a two-year-old forecasting firm, as chairman. The firm was founded by supply-side economist John Mueller, who was a top aide to Housing Secretary Jack Kemp when Kemp was a congressman, and Jeffrey Bell, one-time Republican Senate candidate in New Jersey. Lehrman's shirtsleeves and red suspenders became a trademark during his 1982 campaign against Mario Cuomo. After the loss, he headed Citizens for America, President Reagan's lobbying organization. He has been at Morgan Stanley since 1987. Supply-side economists advocate tax cuts to spur economic growth and believe governments' role in the economy should be minimal. Bell Mueller is known for its advocacy of Mueller's world dollar base theory, which attempts to forecast economic growth and inflation by looking at the number of dollars circulating worldwide, not just in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: German Mark Higher While Dollar Falls; Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The German mark rose in foreign exchange Monday, the first day of trading after the monetary union in East and West Germany over the weekend, while demand for the British pound also remained strong. Support of the mark and pound put pressure on the dollar, which declined to levels not seen since 1988 against those currencies, according to traders. Gold prices rose on worldwide markets. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery traded at $358.80 a troy ounce, up 90 cents from late Friday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $357.85 an ounce, 35 cents higher. Timothy Burton, a trader for Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago, said dealers were buying marks and sterling at the expense of the dollar. He said a smooth distribution of marks to East Germans, starting on Sunday, was helping the mark, while sterling was supported by relatively high British interest rates and increased speculation that Britain would soon be joining the European Monetary System. The dollar traded at 1.6515 German marks in New York, down from 1.66065, and at 1.6580 marks in Europe, down from 1.6653. The last time it traded at those levels was in early 1988, according to Burton. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.7635, up from $1.7450 late Friday. A pound fetched $1.7715 in New York _ an 18-month high, Burton said _ up from $1.7490 Friday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.3965 Swiss francs, down from 1.4150; 5.5450 French francs, down from 5.5795; 1,212.75 Italian lire, down from 1,219.75; and 1.16175 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16335. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Friday: 1.4030 Swiss francs, down from 1.4155; 5.5635 French francs, down from 5.5945; 1.8650 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8737; 1,217.00 Italian lire, down from 1,222.50; and 1.1616 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1657. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 151.40 yen, down 1.45 yen from the finish last Friday, when the dollar fell 1.57 yen. It traded at 151.25 yen in London, and at 150.905 yen in New York, down from 152.10 yen Friday. Gold traded in London at $357.55 an ounce, up from $353.25 bid late Friday. In Zurich, gold traded at $357.80 an ounce, up from $352.00 bid late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold traded at $357.15 an ounce, up $5. Silver prices also strengthened. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery traded at $4.935 a troy ounce, up from $4.887 Friday. Silver rose in London to $4.95 an ounce from $4.84.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market opened the second half of 1990 with a moderate gain Monday, benefiting from buying that focused especially on blue chips. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 18.57 points to 2,899.26. Advancing issues slightly outnumbered declines in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 775 up, 744 down and 472 unchanged. The results of a monthly survey of corporate purchasing executives gave a slightly stronger picture than analysts had forecast of activity in the manufacturing sector of the economy. The National Association of Purchasing Management said its index increased to 51.1 percent in June from 50.7 percent the month before. Analysts said they weren't sure how or whether that bit of data might influence policy-makers at the Federal Reserve as they deliberated strategy on money and credit for the third quarter of the year. Another closely-watched indicator of business conditions is due out Friday with the issuance of Labor Department figures on employment in June. Trading set a slow pace throughout the session, suggesting that activity might be restrained for this whole holiday week. The markets will be closed on Wednesday for the observance of Independence Day. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 130.20 million shares, against 145.50 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 157.45 million shares. Nevertheless, brokers said investors' enthusiasm was piqued to some degree by news of a pair of takeover bids. General Instrument, target of a $44.50-a-share offer from Forstmann Little & Co., jumped 8~ to 45[ as the most active NYSE issue. Kay Jewelers rose 3] to 14\. Ratners Group of Britain launched an offer to acquire the company through an exchange of stock. Gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up | at 47[; General Electric, up 1\ at 70{; American Telephone & Telegraph, up ] at 38~; Eastman Kodak, up } at 41\, and International Business Machines, up 1 at 118{. Leading environmental stocks also were strong. Waste Management, up { at 41~, and Browning-Ferris, up } at 45[, both traded at record highs. Digital Sound Corp., traded in the over-the-counter market, plunged 4\ to 5. The company said it was likely to post a loss for the second quarter on lower revenues, citing slower-than-expected orders from some of its major customers. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $11.22 billion, or 0.33 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .74 to 196.22. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.98 to 422.49, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 1.52 at 359.54. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slipped .25 to 462.04. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 360.14, down 1.07.

DOC.HEAD: DataTimes, Dow Jones Information Services Reach Agreement
DOC.TEXT: DataTimes and Dow Jones Information Services have agreed to a joint marketing and service deal to combine their electronic libraries, the two companies anounced Monday. The arrangement will allow researchers to search electronically through the computerized files of 640 newspapers, magazines, news services and financial data sources. More than 450 sources will be available for simultaneous access. The agreement would allow a user to key in names or topics and search in nearly all the network sources at the same time. DataTimes is a subsidiary of the Oklahoma Publishing Company, with minority share owned by Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuela to Enter GATT in September
DOC.TEXT: Venezuela expects to enter the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in September, after an international working group approved its membership last week, Venezuela's chief negotiator announced Monday. Acceptance of Venezuela into the 96-nation trade group had been delayed by objections from the United States and the European Economic Community, which complained about high tariffs and subsidies granted to domestic business. But chief negotiator Miguel Rodriguez Mendoza said a compromise was struck. Venezuela agreed to limit tariffs, reduce a 5 percent value-added tax the government imposes on imports, and soften a law that encourages public companies to ``buy Venezuelan,'' Rodriguez Mendoza said. He said GATT members would vote on Venezuela's membership July 11. Two-thirds of GATT nations, or 64 countries, must approve, and Rodriguez Mendoza said approval was all but assured. Venezuela applied to enter the GATT last year, after tight finances forced the country to move from a state-controlled to a free market economy. Venezuela derives 90 percent of its export income from oil, but the government wants to diversify its manufacturing.

DOC.HEAD: Hot Weather Forecasts Boost Soybean, Pork Futures
DOC.TEXT: Forecasts for sizzling temperatures in the Midwest sparked sharp gains Monday in soybean and pork futures prices amid speculation that hot weather will scorch the bean crop and slow the movement of hogs to market. On other commodity markets, most grain futures advanced; cattle futures were mixed; oil futures mostly were lower; and precious metals rose modestly. On the Chicago Board of Trade, soybean futures settled 5 cents to 23 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July up 22{ cents at $6.46 a bushel; wheat futures finished } cent to 2 cents higher with July at $3.26{ a bushel; corn was 3\ cents lower to 2{ cents higher with July at $2.96\ a bushel; oats were 3{ cents to 3} cents higher with July at $1.39\ a bushel. In pork futures trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, hogs finished .87 cent to 1.4 cents higher with July at 61.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .95 cent to the permitted daily limit of 2 cents higher with July at 59.67 cents a pound; live cattle were .27 cent lower to .55 cent higher with August at 72.80 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent to .57 cent lower with August at 83.45 cents a pound. Analysts attributed the bullish tone in pork and beans largely to forecasts that 100-plus-degree temperatures would move into the nation's agricultural midsection from the Southwest. Temperatures above 100 degrees were reported in southeastern Nebraska Monday afternoon. The heat-bearing, high-pressure front was expected to continue moving east over the next few days. Hot, dry weather would be especially stressful to crops in the western and southern reaches of the Corn Belt, where conditions already are dry, analysts said. Hot weather also could slow marketings of hogs, which tend to lose weight more quickly as temperatures rise, said Thomas Morgan, president of Sterling Research Inc., an analytical service in Arlington Heights, Ill. ``Of course, this is only a temporary thing,'' he said. ``This heat is supposed to be gone by Wednesday or Thursday.'' But a number of influential weather forecasters on Monday issued longer-term predictions for warmer- and drier-than-normal weather in parts of the Midwest. Freese-Notis Weather Inc. of Des Moines, Iowa, was one of several private meteorological firms predicting above-normal temperatures and below-normal rainfall in July for areas including western Iowa, Nebraska, southern Illinois and the Mississippi Delta region. ``The pattern we're predicting resembles that of 1980, when southern Corn Belt and Delta crops were severely hurt,'' said Charles Notis, a partner in the private forecasting firm. The National Weather Service, which last week projected normal July temperatures and precipitation, issued a six-to-10-day outlook late Monday predicting above-normal temperatures and normal to below-normal rainfall in the Midwest for July 8-12. The Agriculture Department, meanwhile, released its weekly crop-progress report. It indicated soybean planting was 95 percent complete as of Sunday with 54 percent of the crop in good to excellent condition compared with 55 percent a week earlier. The USDA rated the corn crop 65 percent good to excellent compared with 64 percent a week earlier. The USDA also reported the winter wheat harvest was 50 percent complete as of Sunday and rated 77 percent of the spring wheat crop good to excellent, unchanged from a week earlier. Crude oil futures fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange on a combination of technical factors and expectations that striking oilworkers in Norway soon will return to work. Near-term gasoline rose, reflecting strong summer driving demand. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 18 cents to 35 cents lower with August at $16.72 a barrel; heating oil was .06 cent to .57 cent lower with August at 48.56 cents a gallon; and unleaded gas was .90 cent lower to .47 cent higher with August at 56.68 cents a gallon. Gold and silver futures extended the strong gains posted late last week on New York's Commodity Exchange. Gold futures ended 90 cents to $1 higher with July at $358.80 a troy ounce; silver was 4.7 cents to 5.8 cents higher with July at $4.935 a troy ounce.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with workers defying back to work order; EDITS thruout
DOC.HEAD: Oil Platform Strikers Ordered Back to Work
DOC.TEXT: An oil workers union on Monday accepted a government order to end a one-day strike on Norway's offshore platforms, but said its members refused to return to work. ``We have lost control of our members,'' said union official Oddleiv Tonnessen in a telephone interview. ``Production in the Norwegian North Sea is still completely at a standstill.'' At some offshore oil platforms, wildcat strikers barricaded helicopter landing pads to keep new crews from landing, he said. But helicopter pilots told reporters they had few problems while flying hundreds of workers back to their platforms. Norway's North Sea fields produced 1.63 million barrels of oil per day and 1.8 billion cubic meters of natural gas a month in April. News reports said lost production costs Norway up to 200 million kroner, or $31 million, a day. The legal strike began at midnight Saturday after last-minute bargaining failed to produce agreement. Union members walked out in a dispute with the Norwegian Confederation of Business and Industry over wages and job protection against automation. The union said the employers' offer of a 2.5-percent pay raise was less than half its demand. The employers' group said offshore oil workers already average 313,000 kroner, or $49,000, a year, 85 percent above the average onshore industrial wage. The government ordered 4,000 strikers back to work Monday, after the strike shut down the country's offshore oil platforms Sunday. Municipalities Minister Johan J. Jakobsen said compulsory arbitration was invoked to protect the national economy. He said one-quarter of Norway's national income comes from oil. The Norwegian Federation of Oil Workers union central committee accepted the government back-to-work order, and told its members to return to work. But Tonnessen said workers on many platforms defied the order by continuing the strike illegally. NTB quoted strikers as saying they will stay off the job until their demands are met. ``There have been some widespread problems,'' said Boerge Bekkeheien, of the Oil Industry Association, after meeting with the union.``We hope things will return to normal Tuesday.'' Norway's last major offshore strike lasted 20 days in 1986 and ended with a compulsory arbitration order.

DOC.HEAD: Standard & Poor's Downgrades MCI Credit Ratings
DOC.TEXT: Standard & Poor's Corp., a major credit-rating agency, on Monday downgraded its rating on some of MCI Communication Corp.'s debt. S&P said it lowered by one notch its ratings on MCI's senior unsecured debt and subordinated debt due to MCI's acquisition of Telecom USA Inc., another long-distance phone company. ``The acquisition, which will likely be financed with borrowings of up to $1.5 billion, should initially result in a sharp deterioration in the capital structure (of MCI) and correspondingly higher fixed charges,'' S&P said. ``However, the merger strengthens MCI's position in the rapidly growing and profitable small-business (phone) market,'' it said. S&P said MCI should pay off the acquisition-related debt by the end of 1993 due to its ``ability to generate robust cash flow.'' MCI, the nation's No. 2 long-distance carrier after American Telephone & Telegraph Co., announced the merger with Atlanta-based Telecom in April. Kathleen Keegan, a spokeswoman for MCI, said the company was disappointed by the ratings change but noted that the debt affected still was considered investment grade. She also said MCI expected to have paid down the debt incurred in its buyout of Telecom USA in two and a half to three years.

DOC.HEAD: Crude and Heating Oil Down, Gasoline Up, Natural Gas Unchanged
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil prices dropped in light trading Monday, weakened by word that Norway's government had moved to end a petroleum workers' strike, but wholesale gasoline prices rose slightly because of seasonal driving demand. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the August contract for key West Texas Intermediate crude fell 35 cents a barrel to $16.72. Subsequent contract months also fell. Brokers attributed the decline largely to developments in the day-old Norway oil workers walkout, which had halted the country's production of 1.63 million barrels of oil per day. The strike at first raised speculation of a supply shortage that would drive up world prices temporarily, and buyers jumped in to profit from that possibility. But when the government issued a back-to-work decree and a binding-arbitration order, the supply-shortage theory was discounted and oil-market speculators drove crude prices back down. The drop in crude spilled over into the home-heating oil market. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, wholesale home-heating oil for August delivery fell .06 cent per gallon to 48.56 cents. Later-month contracts also fell. Among other refined products traded on the exchange, unleaded gasoline for August delivery rose 0.47 cent a gallon to 56.68 cents, largely because of what brokers called higher demand for gasoline in the summer. Later contract months were lower. In natural gas trading, the August contract was unchanged at $1.519 per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.HEAD: Rhode Island Firm Bounced from Securities Group
DOC.TEXT: A Rhode Island securities firm was expelled and one of its principals fined $1.5 million by the National Association of Securities Dealers on Monday. The NASD, a self-regulating organization that oversees the over-the-counter securities market, said Brandon Securities & Investments, and Ernest E. Michaud, a registered principal of the North Providence firm, settled fraud accusations without admitting or denying wrongdoing. The NASD accused Brandon of engaging in a scheme to defraud 20 investors of $1.5 million over a four-year period by promoting and selling shares in an investment pool and then either misapplying or stealing the money outright. An investigation by the NASD's District 13 committee in Boston alleged that Brandon, 42, of Kingston, R.I., also supplied customers with fictitious statements that contained false representations about their investors. The investors were not identified. According to the NASD, the firm was expelled from membership in the association and, in addition to the fine he agreed to pay, Michaud is barred from association with any NASD in any business capacity. In other disciplinary actions announced Monday, the NASD: _Expelled a Tiburon, Calif. firm, Baldwin Capital Partners, from membership and fined a principal, George Horace Baldwin, also of Tiburon, $5,000 for failing to respond to NASD requests for information. _Fined a Rolling Meadows, Ill., firm, D'Martine Financial Services Inc., $50,000 for failing to maintain required minimum net capital and filing inaccurate reports.
